It sat beneath the table and stared at the peanut butter. Jonah offered a spoonful. The monster ate delicately, tongue rasping like a cat’s. When Mom returned, the creature had already curled up behind the water heater. She blamed the footprints on the dog next door.

By the third month the monster had doubled in size. Its spine had begun to arch like a question mark, and its fur—if fur is what it was—changed color with the weather. On cloudy days it was the gray-green of lichen; on sunny afternoons it was the gold of wheat fields. Jonah named it Alder after the saplings that grew along the creek. Alder learned to open the refrigerator with one hooked claw and developed a taste for cold spaghetti. Jonah’s parents assumed the disappearing leftovers were the result of a growth spurt. They bought more milk, more bread, more cheese. Alder grew again.

There were rules, of course, though no one wrote them down. Alder stayed out of sight when guests came over. Jonah told his parents he had an imaginary friend to explain the extra chair at dinner. Alder learned to fold its wings—because wings had appeared one Tuesday after a thunderstorm—tight against its body so they looked like an oversized hoodie. At night it slept on the floor beside Jonah’s bed, tail twitching in dreams that sometimes leaked into Jonah’s own: forests of glass trees, rivers of molten tin, a moon with a mouth.

The first winter was hard. The furnace coughed and died on Christmas Eve. Jonah’s father dragged out space heaters; his mother boiled water for tea. Alder, now the size of a Saint Bernard, padded through the house radiating heat like a living furnace. Jonah woke to find the creature wrapped around him, heartbeat slow as a drum. In the morning the windows were traced with frost except for one perfect circle of clear glass where Alder had breathed. They never did get the furnace fixed; Alder’s body was enough.

In spring Alder began to molt. Great sheets of translucent hide peeled away like birch bark. Jonah helped him gather the castoffs and buried them under the lilac bushes, where the soil grew rich and dark. Tulips came up that year the color of bruised plums. Mom said she’d never seen such a vivid garden. Alder, shy now that his new skin was tender and pinkish beneath the fur, hid beneath the porch for a week. Jonah read aloud to him through the lattice: Charlotte’s Web, The Hobbit, a battered copy of D’Aulaires’ Norse Gods. Alder’s favorite was Fenrir, the wolf who learned too late that love could be a chain.

School started. Jonah came home with stories: a girl who could whistle entire songs through her gap tooth, a boy who cried because he missed his guinea pig. Alder listened, head cocked, ears swiveling like radar dishes. He began to imitate the children’s voices—first the guinea-pig boy’s squeak, then the whistler’s birdlike trill. Jonah laughed until his stomach hurt. They practiced together: Alder could now say “hello” in fourteen distinct pitches. Mom thought Jonah had taken up ventriloquism. She signed him up for drama club.

Drama club was a revelation. Jonah discovered that words could be costumes; you slipped them on and became someone else. Alder watched from the wings, unseen, while Jonah played a tree in the fall play. Afterward the director—a woman with purple glasses—said Jonah had “an intuitive sense of stillness.” Alder tried stillness in the backyard, standing motionless for so long that a mourning dove nested between his antlers (because antlers had sprouted after the autumn equinox). The dove laid two eggs. Jonah’s father found them while raking leaves and spent an hour Googling whether monsters could legally be considered protected habitats.

Years passed like pages turning. Jonah grew tall; Alder grew stranger. His antlers became a thicket of branches that scraped the ceiling. His eyes multiplied—two more on the back of his skull so he could watch the past recede. He learned to fold himself small enough to ride in the backseat when the family visited Grandma, who lived by the sea. Grandma never noticed the extra passenger, though she once remarked that her knitting yarn kept disappearing. Alder unraveled it into long, shimmering strands that he wove into hammocks for the squirrels.

There were accidents. A tail knocked over Mom’s heirloom vase; a misplaced claw shredded the couch. Each time Jonah took the blame: “I was skateboarding indoors again.” His parents sighed, grounded him, then forgot a week later. Alder tried to help. He learned to vacuum with his tail, to load the dishwasher by extending a tentacle (tentacles had arrived the summer Jonah turned twelve). He left gifts on the porch: a perfect snail shell, a feather that glowed faintly, a stone shaped like a heart. Mom started calling the anonymous benefactor “the garden gnome.”

The first real problem came when Jonah was fifteen. A neighbor’s cat went missing. Rumors spread: coyotes, maybe a cougar. Jonah found the cat safe in Alder’s den under the porch, licking cream from a saucer. Alder’s eyes were wide with guilt. “It cried,” he said in his wind-scrape voice. “I only wanted to help.” Jonah returned the cat at dusk, claiming he’d found it stuck in a tree. The neighbor looked skeptical; the cat looked smug. Jonah installed a cat door so Alder could visit without abduction.

High school brought harder questions. Jonah’s friends talked about college, about leaving town. Alder listened from the closet, wings trembling. One night Jonah whispered, “What happens when I go?” Alder did not answer. Instead he began to shrink—not all at once, but incrementally, as though deflating. His antlers dried and fell; his extra eyes sealed shut. By graduation Alder was the size of the first shadow, small enough to fit in Jonah’s jacket pocket. On move-out day Jonah’s parents cried in the driveway. Jonah hugged them, then opened the car door. A faint weight settled against his heart: the monster, now no larger than a sparrow, tucked into the inner pocket where the fabric was thinnest. They drove away together, past the lilacs, past the creek, past the town limit sign already rusting at the edges.

In the dorm Alder learned to live inside a shoebox lined with dryer lint. He liked the hum of the mini-fridge, the glow of Jonah’s laptop. He became an expert at hiding during room checks, flattening into two dimensions behind posters. Jonah told his roommate Alder was a vintage shadow puppet. At night they whispered plans: maybe an apartment next year, maybe somewhere with a yard. Alder’s voice was small now, like paper tearing, but his dreams still leaked into Jonah’s—forests of glass, rivers of tin, a moon singing lullabies.

And so the monster adapted, not by ceasing to be monstrous but by becoming what love required: smaller, quieter, portable. He learned the shape of absence, the weight of waiting. And Jonah, in turn, learned the shape of presence: the way a shadow can warm you, the way a voice like wind can guide you home through darkened streets. They grew into each other’s silences, the way roots of different trees sometimes graft underground, indistinguishable after a time, feeding the same rising sap.

Years later, when Jonah had children of his own, he told them about a shadow who smelled of earth and mint, who taught him that monsters are not what we flee but what we fold into ourselves, warm and breathing, a second heart beating just beneath the first.

samples.prompt: Your daughter grew a pair of horns. You have no idea why or how.
samples.output:
I first noticed the horns on a Tuesday morning, the day the clocks in our apartment refused to agree on the hour. The one above the stove said 7:02; the one on the microwave, 7:11. I was late, as usual, and Mina was late, as usual, because she is eight and believes that time is a polite suggestion. She came shuffling into the kitchen with her hair in the same impossible tangle it has worn since kindergarten, her socks sliding down her ankles like exhausted caterpillars. In her hands she cradled the orange cat we do not officially own but who eats from our dishes when the landlord isn’t looking. She set the cat on the counter, yawned, and asked, “Do we have any strawberry jam?”

That was when I saw them: two pale ridges curving up from her temples, just above the hairline. They were the color of piano keys, smooth like river stones, tapering to blunt points that glowed faintly in the fluorescent light. For a moment I thought they were barrettes, one of those glittery plastic horns kids wear for dress-up. But they moved when she moved, rooted in bone. My heart made a small wrong turn inside my chest.

“Mina,” I said, and then stopped, because I had no next sentence.

She blinked at me, patient. “Jam?”

I opened the refrigerator and stared into it as though the answer to the entire situation might be wedged between the mustard and last week’s pickles. I closed it again. “Come here,” I said, kneeling. She stepped forward, the cat purring between us like a badly tuned motor. I touched the left horn. It was warm. Not fever-warm, but sun-on-metal warm. When my fingertip brushed it, Mina shivered and the horn pulsed, the way a snail’s eyestalk withdraws and extends.

“Does it hurt?” I asked.

She considered the question with the gravity of a Supreme Court justice. “Not really. They itch sometimes. Like when I think about lying.”

I laughed, a single cracked note. “You’ve been thinking about lying?”

“Not big lies,” she clarified. “Just the regular kind. Like telling Mrs. Alvarez I finished the reading log when actually I read half and pretended the rest.”

The horns looked ancient, as if they had been waiting inside her skull since before language. I thought of the ultrasound photo, the gray smudge of her profile at twenty weeks, the doctor announcing, “She’s perfect,” and how I had believed that adjective could be permanent.

I called work and told them a stomach bug had flattened both of us, which felt less like a lie and more like premonition. Then I called the pediatrician we have seen since Mina was a feverish bundle in footed pajamas. The receptionist asked, “Is this an emergency?” I almost said yes, but the word snagged on the image of Mina calmly spreading jam on toast while her new appendages gleamed. If I called it an emergency, some part of me would have to admit it was real.

Instead, I took her to the park. Sunlight is supposed to make everything easier to bear, like butter melting on warm bread. We sat on the edge of the sandbox and I watched other parents watch her. Some pretended not to notice. One toddler pointed and shrieked, “Unicorn girl!”—a small, delighted accusation. Mina smiled, the gap between her front teeth flashing like a private semaphore. I waited for shame to crawl across her face, but it never arrived.

“Mom,” she said, “I think they’re growing.”

I measured with my thumb and index finger. Yesterday, I would have sworn they were half an inch shorter. My stomach folded in on itself.

By afternoon, the horns had thickened, ridges spiraling like ivy on a column. Tiny nubs protruded near the base, the promise of additional branches. I googled “rapid horn growth in children” and found folklore, medieval woodcuts, and a Reddit thread titled My niece is sprouting antlers—AMA. None of it helped. I closed the laptop, opened it again, searched “pediatric dermatology anomaly near me,” found three offices, called the first, got voicemail, left a message that sounded like a prank.

Mina found me in the hallway. “Can we do the experiment tonight?”

She meant the backyard astronomy we’d planned: hot chocolate, blankets, a meteor shower that only happened after midnight. I had promised weeks ago, when horns were still imaginary. I wanted to say no. I wanted to build a pillow fort around her and keep the world outside. Instead I said, “We’ll nap first.”

We curled together on the couch like quotation marks around an unfinished sentence. When she slept, her horns cast thin shadows across my arm. I studied them the way I once studied her newborn ears, wondering how cells know where to stop dividing. I must have dozed, because I woke to the sound of her humming, a minor key lullaby she learned from her grandfather before he forgot our names.

At 11:30 we dragged blankets into the yard. The city had dimmed its streetlights for the event; the sky felt closer, a velvet ceiling lowered for maintenance. We lay on our backs, cocoa cooling in thermos caps between us. The first meteor scratched a bright line above the maple tree.

“Make a wish,” I whispered.

She squeezed her eyes shut. Horns or no horns, she was still eight, still believed wishes were contractual. I did not ask what she asked for. My own wish felt too large to fit in the small space between stars: Let her be ordinary again.

Another meteor, longer this time, like someone ripping open a seam. Mina’s horns caught the flash; for an instant they looked translucent, lit from within. She turned to me, eyes silvered by starlight. “I think they’re here for listening,” she said.

“Listening to what?”

“Everything that’s too quiet to hear otherwise. Like the moon pulling the ocean, or Grandma saying goodbye from the bedroom where she turned off all the lights.”

My throat filled with small sharp things. My mother had died three months ago, while Mina slept in a hospital waiting room chair, head on my lap. I had not thought she heard the final exhale, the soft click of the monitor. I had not heard it myself; the nurses told me later.

A third meteor flared, and the horns seemed to vibrate, like tuning forks. Mina reached up, touched the left one gently, as if adjusting an antenna. “She says you kept the sweater,” she told me, matter-of-fact. “The green one with the hole in the elbow.”

I had. It hung in my closet like a ghost made of wool. I had not worn it, could not throw it away. The air smelled suddenly of lavender and the particular soap my mother used, the bar that turned thin as paper before it disappeared.

I wanted to ask what else the horns heard, but the next meteor was brighter, closer, and Mina gasped. The light reflected in her eyes, on the curved bone, on the tears I pretended were from the wind.

We stayed until dawn bruised the horizon. The horns had grown again; now they arced backward like a lyre, ridged and pale. Mina leaned against me, weight heavier than yesterday. I carried her inside, asleep, horns brushing the doorframe.

I know I will take her to doctors. There will be measurements, scans, hushed voices. People will want to name what this is, build fences around it with syllables. But this morning, for the small eternity between one meteor and the next, I understood that the horns are not an affliction but an answer to a question I had forgotten I asked. They are the visible part of a conversation that began the day she was born and will continue long after I can no longer hear any voice but memory.

For now, I tuck her into bed. The horns rest against the pillow like parentheses enclosing a secret I am learning not to fear. I kiss the warm slope of the left one. It tastes faintly of starlight and strawberry jam.

samples.prompt: A person goes on with their daily routine oblivious to the fact that civilization has ended or is ending around them.
samples.output:
The kettle clicked off at 6:47, two minutes earlier than yesterday but still within the margin of error Leon had decided was acceptable. He noted it in the little spiral notebook he kept beside the stove—one more data point in the private science of morning. While the tea steeped, he wiped yesterday’s crumbs from the counter with the same blue-checked cloth, folding it back into a square when finished. He did not look out the window; the blinds stayed drawn so the sunlight would not fade the spice labels on the rack.

At 7:05 he carried the mug—white ceramic, hairline crack forming like a vein beneath the glaze—into the living room, set it on the coaster that still bore the faint ring from Tuesday, and opened his laptop. The machine took longer than usual to wake, fan whining like a distant insect. Leon attributed the sluggishness to an update he must have accidentally approved; he resolved to be more careful about clicking “later.” When the password prompt arrived, he typed with the confidence of a man who had never once forgotten the sequence of his own initials and the year of his first pet’s death.

The browser’s home page refused to load. That had happened yesterday, too, but he had been late for the bus and had simply closed the lid. Now he waited, watching the spinning circle, until the screen dimmed in protest. He tapped the track pad, waited, tapped again, then shut the laptop with a soft click. Perhaps the building’s Wi-Fi was down again; the landlord had promised to replace the router last spring. Leon made a mental note to send another e-mail—later, when the connection returned.

He drank the tea standing up, looking at the wall where the paint had bubbled slightly above the baseboard. He should sand and reprime before the problem worsened; moisture traveled upward like gossip. The thought anchored him in time, a small repair among the infinite possible repairs. It felt good to have a plan.

At 7:30 he opened the front door to collect the newspaper, an anachronism he maintained because the sound of its thud against the mat reminded him of childhood Sundays. The landing was empty. No paper, but also no welcome mat—just the scuffed tile and the faint smell of burnt electronics. He peered down the stairwell: no lights on the landings below, no murmur of radios. The silence felt deliberate, as though the building had been politely asked to wait. Leon stepped back inside and locked the door. Probably a holiday he had forgotten; the paper boy was allowed to sleep in on Presidents’ Day.

He decided to leave early for work. The walk would do him good—he had been skipping the gym since the treadmill began squeaking. In the bedroom he chose the navy slacks, the white shirt that needed cuff links shaped like tiny compasses. He had bought them because compasses were useful, though he had never tested them. Dressing took longer than usual; the shirt resisted the first two attempts at the top button, as if it had shrunk in the closet overnight. He blamed the new detergent and promised himself to measure the cap more scrupulously next time.

The hallway remained quiet. He pressed the elevator button, counted to twelve—his old habit—then pressed it again. Nothing. He took the stairs, noting that the motion sensors failed to illuminate his descent. Emergency lighting, he supposed; the building’s generator must be cycling. He felt a small pride at diagnosing the problem so quickly, and he rehearsed the sentence he would use when he reported it: “The battery array likely needs service.”

Outside, the sky was an even gray, neither overcast nor clear, a sky that had forgotten its own intentions. The air smelled metallic, like a subway tunnel. Leon turned left on Maple, the route he had walked every weekday for eleven years. Today there were no cars idling at the intersection, no dog walkers, no children arguing about who had touched whose scooter. A single sneaker lay on its side in the gutter, laces intact, as if its owner had simply evaporated mid-stride.

At the bus stop the timetable had been torn away, leaving only a rectangle of paler plastic. Leon checked his watch: 8:07. He could wait seven minutes, but the bench was missing. He decided to keep walking; the exercise would compensate for the missed gym session. Two blocks farther, he noticed the traffic lights were dark. No electricity, no hum of refrigeration units behind the bakery’s rear door. The city sounded like a recording paused mid-breath.

He passed the florist’s shop. The iron gate was rolled down, but through the slats he could see the buckets overturned, stems of gladioli scattered like dropped spears. Water had pooled and dried in brown rings on the concrete. A petal, mauve and delicate, trembled in the draft from a broken pane above. Leon paused. He had bought flowers here every March for his mother’s birthday—yellow tulips because she said they looked like morning. The absence felt personal, as though the shop had closed specifically to spite his calendar.

By the time he reached the office plaza, his shirt clung to his back. The revolving door was wedged open with a metal chair, its cushion slashed. Inside, the lobby echoed. The security desk sat unmanned; the logbook lay open to Thursday, the last entry illegible except for the time: 9:18. Leon signed his name anyway, out of habit, then walked to the elevators. They, too, were dark. He climbed ten flights, counting each landing aloud to keep rhythm. On seven he paused to catch his breath and noticed the framed photograph of last year’s holiday party had fallen, glass spider-webbed across smiling faces he could no longer name.

The office suite was unlocked. Fluorescent panels in the ceiling flickered like dying stars. His cubicle waited, unchanged: the same mug of pens, the same stack of invoices stamped “URGENT.” The monitor showed no signal. He pressed the power button on the tower; nothing. He sat for a moment, listening to the building creak, a sound like a ship far from land. On the desk lay a colleague’s half-eaten granola bar, wrapper folded back neatly. Leon considered finishing it—waste not—but decided against it; stealing was a line he would not cross, apocalypse or not.

He opened the top drawer for his backup flash drive. Instead he found a note in handwriting he recognized as his own: “Call Mom.” The letters looked urgent, but he could not remember writing them. He shrugged. She never answered before ten anyway.

Back in the corridor he noticed the conference room’s blinds were askew. Through the gap he saw the city’s skyline. A plume of smoke rose in the distance, not black but pale, as though something immense had sighed. The buildings themselves looked wrong—too sharp, edges outlined in rust. He squinted. The glass skin of the tower opposite had melted and resolidified, warped like candle wax. Yet the sight registered as merely another maintenance issue, something for another department. He straightened his tie.

Descending the stairs, he rehearsed the day’s small disappointments: no Wi-Fi, no elevator, no newspaper, no granola bar. Each absence fit neatly into the ledger of minor inconveniences he carried in his head. He would adapt, as always. Perhaps he would stop at the library on the way home—if it was open—and photocopy the crossword. The key was not to panic; panic solved nothing.

Outside again, the metallic smell had intensified. A newspaper page skittered past, caught on a wind that did not touch his clothes. Headlines flashed: “…EVACUATION…SAFE ZONES…” The words meant little; newspapers exaggerated. He had once read that the average person swallowed eight spiders a year in their sleep, and he had not believed that either.

The walk home felt shorter. He counted cracks in the sidewalk, a habit that predated any catastrophe. When he reached his building, the lobby door stood wide. Inside, the stairwell was dark, but he knew the count by heart: forty-three steps to the third floor. At his apartment he reached for his keys, then realized the door was already ajar. He pushed it open. The kettle sat on the stove, lid up, dry. The blue-checked cloth lay on the floor, a small scorch mark at its center. A faint glow came from the bedroom—his laptop screen, open now, displaying a single sentence in a dialogue box he had never seen: “Connection lost. Retry?”

Leon closed the lid. He picked up the cloth, folded it, placed it back by the sink. He filled the kettle, set it on the burner, and struck a match. The flame caught with a soft pop. He watched the water begin its slow climb toward boiling, the metal ticking like a clock that still believed in time.

Outside, something vast groaned, a sound like the earth turning over in its sleep. Leon adjusted the flame lower—no sense wasting gas—and opened the cupboard for a fresh teabag. There were only two left. He made a note: buy more.

samples.prompt: You're the villain. And for some ungodly reason, you're the one that was given a second chance, to go back in time, and fix your mistakes. You might as well take the chosen one under your wing and teach them a few tricks too.
samples.output:
I never asked for redemption.  
I asked for a sharper blade, a higher tower, a deeper grave for the world that screamed my name like a curse.  
Instead, the universe handed me a clock.

It is a small thing—no bigger than a sparrow’s heart—its crystal face cracked across the middle like a lightning bolt frozen mid-snarl. The first time I crushed it under my boot it sang, a sound like children burning, and the sky tore open and spat me back into my own past. Thirty-two years, four months, six days. The day I murdered my father and became the Black Star.

I stood in the courtyard of my childhood home, blood still freckling my seventeen-year-old knuckles, the old man’s corpse cooling at my feet. I remembered this moment; I had laughed then, laughed until the guards came, laughed all the way to the gallows they would never manage to hang me from. This time I did not laugh. I looked down at the clock’s shards glittering in the grass and understood that someone, somewhere, was mocking me. A second chance. As if the first had been an innocent mistake.

I did what any villain would do: I planned to break the game from the inside. I would still become the tyrant the bards would spit rhymes about—only faster, cleaner, mercifully. No clumsy sieges, no betrayals that took years to ferment. A single, perfect apocalypse before my twenty-fifth birthday. Then the clock would have nothing left to rewind.

But the universe, it seems, keeps its own score.

On the road out of the capital I met her. She sat cross-legged on a stump at the edge of the King’s Forest, whittling a stick into something sharp, her hair the color of late-autumn wheat, her eyes the exact green of the first poison I ever brewed. She looked up as my horse thundered past, and in that glance I felt the world tilt—the same tilt I had felt years later when she drove her father’s sword between my ribs and became the chosen one.

Elara. The girl who would one day unmake me.

I reined in so hard the mare screamed. She did not flinch. She simply studied me the way owls study mice, head cocked, curiosity bright and pitiless.

“You’re the one who kills the king,” she said, conversational, as though remarking on the weather.

My hand went to the dagger at my belt. Seventeen-year-old muscles remembered every feint, every parry I would learn across a decade of war, but she was thirteen, unarmed, still soft in the places my memory insisted should be hard. I could end the prophecy here, nip the bud with a single slash. Instead I heard myself say, “And you’re the one who kills me. Seems unfair I don’t get to return the favor.”

She shrugged. “Not if you teach me.”

The forest held its breath. I felt the clock’s phantom weight in my pocket, though it lay scattered back in the courtyard. Time, it appeared, was negotiating.

I laughed—an ugly sound, rusty from disuse. “You want the monster to train the hero?”

“I want to survive,” she answered. “And you’re the only one who looks honest about what the world costs.”

Honest. No one had ever accused me of that. I had lied to emperors, to lovers, to the face in my mirror. But the child saw something she liked, and I discovered, to my horror, that I was starved for an apprentice.

So I took her with me. I told myself it was containment: keep the blade sheathed at my own hip rather than let it wander the kingdom unsupervised. We traveled through the winter wars I once started, through plague towns I once decimated, and at every step I showed her the machinery behind catastrophe. How to collapse a bridge with three well-placed barrels of pitch, how to seed a rumor until it devours a city from the inside, how to flay a conscience so thin you can still feel the screams through it. I taught her the way a surgeon teaches disease, tracing veins so she could sever them later.

She learned fast. Too fast. One night I woke to find her sketching battle maps by moonlight, her tongue between her teeth, the lines eerily identical to the ones I would draw years ahead of schedule. My legacy, accelerating toward me like an arrow loosed by my own bow.

I tried to push her away. I left her in the ashes of a monastery I once burned, rode off convinced cruelty would cure her loyalty. Three days later she caught up, leading the survivors, their eyes full of her the way peasants pray to statues. She had fed them, blessed them, promised them justice. She was building the army I never managed to rally—an army that loved her instead of feared her. I felt the future rearrange its guts.

The second time I attempted to sabotage her, I saved her instead. We were ambushed by mercenaries I myself had hired in the original timeline to kidnap the young princess—another knot of history I meant to retie. I saw the crossbow bolt aimed at Elara’s heart and lunged without thinking. The quarrel punched through my shoulder, splintering bone. She dragged me into the reeds, pressed her small hands to the wound, whispering, “You’re not allowed to die before I do.”

I lost consciousness laughing. Somewhere in the black I heard my father’s voice: Every cruelty you commit plants a seed; water it with your own blood and see what blooms.

Recovery took weeks. She never left my side. She learned to brew the tinctures that would one day keep my soldiers marching three days without sleep, and she spooned them into me like communion. While I lay fevered, she read aloud from my own grimoire, mispronouncing the infernal glyphs, her voice steady, unafraid. I realized I was no longer the villain in her story; I was the crooked guardian, the wolf raising the hunter. And she was raising me back.

Spring arrived early, unnatural, as though time itself had grown impatient. We stood on a cliff above the capital, the city glowing below us like a bed of coals. I could see every domino lined up: the coronation I would crash, the crown I would weld to my skull, the rivers of blood that would carry me to the throne. All I had to do was give the word, and history would snap back into its familiar shape—tyrant and martyr, villain and chosen one, locked in their lethal waltz.

Elara slipped her hand into mine. Calluses rough from swordwork, palms still smelling faintly of the lavender she used to cleanse my wounds. “You told me the world costs everything,” she said. “But you never said who gets to set the price.”

I looked at her, this child who could already kill more cleanly than I could at twice her age, whose army camped in the valley singing songs about dawn, not darkness. I saw the future refracted in her eyes—and for the first time the reflection did not end with my corpse.

I knelt, the gravel biting through my trousers, and pressed the broken clock’s largest shard into her palm. “Then let’s rewrite the ledger,” I said. “You be the hero. I’ll be the shadow that teaches you where the light doesn’t reach. Together we’ll make a world that never needs either of us again.”

She smiled, fierce and tender, the way sunrise must feel to the condemned. “Deal. But you have to promise to stick around long enough to see it.”

I promised, knowing promises are only words, knowing I would break it the way I break everything. But the night air tasted different, like soil after lightning, like beginnings.

We walked down the cliff side by side. Behind us, the city waited, unsuspecting. Ahead, the road curved into country no map had yet drawn. I felt the years loosen their grip, the old story fraying where her fingers threaded mine. Perhaps redemption is nothing more than choosing a different mistake. Perhaps the universe, in its cruel, convoluted mercy, gave the villain the second chance because the chosen one still needed to be chosen—by love, by betrayal, by the monster who refused to stay monstrous at precisely the moment the hero learned to be human.

Either way, the clock was broken.  
And for the first time in both our lives, we had all the time in the world.

samples.prompt: : You are missing an eye, and hate being asked about the eyepatch. There's nothing you like less than having to explain the story of how a single acorn once saved your life.
samples.output:
The first thing anyone ever notices about me is the patch. Black leather, matte, no shiny buckles to catch the light—just a dull, deliberate blankness where my left eye should have been. People stare at it the way they stare at a clock that’s stopped: a mixture of pity and curiosity, as though the frozen hands might suddenly twitch forward and explain everything. They always ask. Sometimes they try to be clever, weaving the question into a compliment—“Nice patch; where’d you get it?”—as if I picked it up at a boutique between artisanal coffee and vintage vinyl. Sometimes they’re blunt, entitled, convinced that my body is public property because it deviates from the symmetrical ideal. Either way, the moment the words leave their mouths, I feel the old heat rise in my throat, the same heat I tasted when I woke up in the ravine with sap in my mouth and bark in my hands.

I hate the story. Not because it’s gruesome—though it is—but because it sounds like a fairy tale gone sour, the kind of thing you’d tell around a campfire to make children squirm and then laugh when they can’t sleep. Nobody ever believes the important parts. They latch onto the absurdity, the image of an acorn wedged into a bleeding socket like some grotesque seed pearl. They want to know if it still had its little cap on, if squirrels came sniffing, if I heard the voice of an ancient oak whispering secrets. They reduce the worst day of my life to a punch line, and I’m left standing there with one eye and zero patience.

The truth is smaller and uglier. No prophecy, no druids, no benevolent dryad. Just a hiking trail I’d taken a hundred times, a misstep on loose shale, and the long, graceless tumble that ended when my face met the jagged elbow of a fallen branch. The branch came from an oak that had died years earlier; its wood was iron-hard and riddled with the tiny tunnels of beetles. One of those tunnels, no wider than a drinking straw, had trapped an acorn from a neighboring tree, carried there by wind or bird or pure stubborn chance. When the branch speared through my orbit, the acorn—already scarred, already half-germinated—was driven in with it. The doctors told me the shell kept the splinters from slicing the optic nerve clean through; instead, they crushed it slowly, like a vice tightening over hours. That delay saved the rest of me: no brain bleed, no infection, just the slow, irrevocable death of sight. They said the acorn acted as a plug, staunching the flow, buying time. They said I was lucky.

Lucky. As though luck smells like moss and iron and your own blood fermenting in the sun. As though luck is waking up screaming because the morphine can’t dull the phantom ache where your eye used to be. As though luck is learning, six months later, that the oak you hated for maiming you was the only thing that kept you breathing long enough to be found. I tried to explain that once to a therapist—the guilt of hating the tree, the guilt of owing it everything. She leaned forward, eyes shining, and asked if I’d planted the acorn after surgery. I told her they incinerated it with the rest of the medical waste. Her disappointment was so naked I almost apologized for not growing a magic forgiveness tree.

People think the patch is a costume piece. They assume I must enjoy the mystique, the pirate swagger, the suggestion that I’ve seen things. What I enjoy is the way it hides the hollow, the sunken seam where flesh meets scar. What I enjoy is silence. But silence is a currency strangers refuse to spend. They want narrative, redemption arcs, lessons about resilience. They want me to wrap the whole mess in a bow and hand it to them like a souvenir. I’ve tried deflection—“Workplace accident”—but that invites follow-ups. I’ve tried lies—“Bar fight in Marrakesh”—which only makes them lean in, hungry for gory details. Once, drunk at a wedding, I told a table full of accountants that I’d traded the eye for the power to see the future. They believed me for half an hour, until I ruined it by laughing too hard and too long.

The patch has its own gravity. Children orbit it, staring openly, their parents mortified and fascinated in equal measure. I can chart the moment a kid decides the patch means I’m a villain; their eyes narrow, they grip their parent’s hand tighter, they wait for me to growl or limp or monologue about my tragic past. I disappoint them by smiling, by saying hello, by being boring. Adults are worse. They think they’re subtle. They think I can’t feel the weight of their gaze as they try to calculate the angle of impact, the force required to puncture bone. They think I can’t hear the hush that falls when I walk into a room, the way conversations pause and resume on topics chosen to exclude me: traffic, weather, anything that doesn’t involve depth perception jokes.

I used to carry a spare pair of sunglasses, the wraparound kind athletes wear, thinking I could hide the patch entirely. But sunglasses indoors make me look like a nightclub bouncer or a terminally hungover celebrity, and the questions only mutate. “Why so shy, Cyclops?” a coworker once asked, loud enough for the whole office to hear. I quit the next day. Not because of the insult—it was lazy, uninspired—but because I realized every job would be the same open-air zoo. The patch is always the headline; everything else—my code, my sourdough starters, the way I whistle whole Bach cantatas without realizing—is footnote material.

My mother tells me I should be grateful. She means well. She means I’m alive, I can still see sunsets, I can still read the tiny print on medicine bottles. She means the acorn was a guardian angel wearing a shell. I nod when she says it, because nodding is easier than explaining that gratitude feels like swallowing sand. The acorn didn’t save me; it prolonged me. It kept me here to endure the stares, the jokes, the endless origin-story interrogations. Some nights I dream it’s still lodged inside me, sprouting roots that curl around my optic nerve like ivy on a fence. In the dream, the roots grow upward, pushing through my brain, out my skull, until I am a walking tree with a single human eye blinking among the leaves. I wake up tasting tannin and dirt.

I’ve thought about gouging the other eye, just to balance the scales, to make the questions stop. But that would be giving the story more real estate than it deserves. Instead, I cultivate small mercies. I take the bus at odd hours when it’s mostly empty. I shop online. I order coffee from the same barista every morning—she never asks, just writes “One Eye” on the cup in block letters and calls it a day. I think she believes it’s a nickname I chose for myself. I let her believe it. Some days, that’s enough.

The thing I miss most isn’t the vision itself; it’s the absence of commentary. Two eyes make you invisible in a crowd. One eye makes you a prompt. I’ve started practicing a new response, one that doesn’t involve words. When someone asks, I simply stare with my remaining eye until they look away. It’s surprisingly effective. Silence, wielded like a blade. The patch helps—it turns the stare into a monolith, a period at the end of a sentence they’re suddenly not brave enough to finish. I like to imagine the acorn inside me approving, its shell still hard, still refusing to crack open and give them the story they want.

samples.prompt: With a quivering hand you finally utter "That's it, I'll kill everyone...."
samples.output:
With a quivering hand you finally utter “That’s it, I’ll kill everyone…,” but the words feel like they belong to someone else, someone wearing your face and speaking through your throat. The kitchen is too bright, the fluorescent bulb above the sink flickering like it’s trying to signal the end of the world in Morse code. You are holding the chipped blue coffeepot, the one your mother gave you when you moved into this apartment, the one that still smells faintly of the cinnamon-flavored beans she loved. Your fingers are white around the handle because you have been squeezing it so hard the plastic is groaning. The pot is empty; the last cup is already cooling in the mug beside the stove, untouched. You set the pot down carefully, as though it might explode, and the tiny click it makes against the burner is the only sound in the universe.

Outside, the city keeps breathing. Tires hiss on wet asphalt, a siren dopplers away, somebody laughs too loud in the corridor. Inside, your heartbeat is a trapped bird throwing itself against the bars of your ribs. You repeat the sentence once more, softer, just to see if it still fits in your mouth. “That’s it, I’ll kill everyone…” It tastes metallic, like the fillings in your back teeth are leaking mercury. You are not sure who everyone is. Right now it feels like everyone might be the whole world, every face you have ever seen, but also—more immediately—the four people upstairs who held another party last night, the one that started at two a.m. with reggaeton booming through the ceiling like a second heartbeat you never asked for. It might also be your boss who sent the 11:47 p.m. email marked “URGENT—WHERE ARE WE ON THE SLIDES?” It might be the landlord who promised for the sixth time to fix the shower pressure and instead left a passive-aggressive note about “proper use of fixtures.” It might be the man on the train this morning who leaned his entire body against your back for four stops even though the car was half empty. You are twenty-nine and you have been adding slights to an invisible ledger for so long the pages have started to tear.

You open the drawer to the left of the stove. You do not own a gun; you never felt the need. Instead there is a clutter of take-out chopsticks, rubber bands, and the eight-inch chef’s knife you bought the week you decided to teach yourself Julia Child recipes. You lift the knife out. The handle is smooth walnut, the blade recently honed because slicing tomatoes felt like therapy. You hold it the way you’ve seen people do in movies, fist close to the bolster, and you imagine walking upstairs and knocking. You can picture the door swinging open, the guy with the man-bun and the vape cloud, surprise blooming across his face like time-lapse footage of a flower opening in reverse. You imagine the first thrust, the resistance of skin, the wet sound of entry. Your stomach flips so hard you have to grip the counter with your free hand. The knife clatters into the sink. You think: I can’t even keep a houseplant alive; how did I think I could do this?

The faucet drips once, twice, onto the blade. You look at your reflection in the window over the sink and see a ghost haloed by the city behind you. Your eyes are red, but not wild; they are simply exhausted. You realize you do not want to murder strangers; you want to murder the feeling that has been living inside you like a parasitic twin, the one that whispers every night that you are falling irreparably behind, that you will never catch up on sleep or deadlines or friendship or love. You want to assassinate the version of yourself who apologizes for existing in grocery-store aisles, who rehearse conversations that will never happen, who keeps a mental spreadsheet of every mistake since eighth grade.

You leave the kitchen and walk the four steps to your living room, which is also your bedroom, which is also your office. The laptop on the folding table is open to a blank PowerPoint slide titled “Q2 Strategy.” The cursor blinks like it’s impatient. You close the lid. You sit on the futon and notice the envelope you never mailed: a rent check sealed last week but forgotten when you realized you were $120 short and would have to Venmo the landlord anyway, begging for three more days. You pick it up. The paper is soft, like fabric that has been handled too much. You tear it in half, then quarters, then eighths, until your fingers ache. The pieces drift to the floor like malformed snowflakes.

Your phone buzzes: a group chat, someone sharing a meme about “2020, part four.” You want to throw the phone against the wall, watch the glass spider-web into a constellation you could name: Clusterfuck Major. Instead you turn it face-down. The silence that follows is so sudden it feels deafening, and in that silence you hear your own breath, ragged and shallow, as if you’ve been sprinting while standing still. You press your palms against your eyes until you see fireworks. You think about the line between a thought and an action, how thin it is, how it can dissolve like sugar on the tongue. You imagine alternate universes branching off this moment: one where you are sobbing in an orange jumpsuit while a reporter describes “a senseless tragedy,” one where you are kneeling in the corridor trying to stanch strangers’ wounds with your own T-shirt, one where you simply go back to bed and wake up tomorrow with a headache instead of a headline.

You stand again, knees popping like bubble wrap. You return to the kitchen, pick up the knife, and this time you rinse it, dry it gently with the dish towel patterned with little red cherries, and slot it back into the block. You do it slowly, reverently, the way you imagine a samurai sheathing a blade after deciding not to draw blood. You open the freezer, retrieve the pint of salted-caramel ice cream you’ve been saving for “a day that deserves it,” and decide today qualifies. You eat it standing up, spooning large curls into your mouth until your teeth sing from the cold. Halfway through, you start to cry, quietly, the tears sliding into the corners of your smile, mixing salt with sugar. You are alive, inconveniently, gloriously alive.

When the pint is empty you peel the label off, roll it into a tiny scroll, and drop it into the trash. You look at the clock: 2:37 a.m. You feel hollowed out, but the hollowness is no longer vibrating with static; it is more like the hush after a cathedral bell stops ringing. You walk to the window and raise the blinds. The city is still there, indifferent and magnificent, a spine of red lights receding toward the river. Somewhere, a horn honks; somewhere, a couple argues; somewhere, a baby practices the solo art of screaming. You place your palm against the cool glass and whisper, not to the world but to yourself, “Not tonight.” The sentence you uttered earlier still hangs in the air like smoke, but already it is dissipating, replaced by something smaller, something that fits in your chest without tearing tissue: a splinter, not a spear.

You leave the blinds open, let the neon bleed across your floorboards, and you go back to bed fully dressed. You lie on your back, arms at your sides like a knight on a tomb, and you count your breaths: four in, four out. You do not feel good; you feel scraped. But scraped is still a surface that can heal. You imagine the ledger inside you, the one inked in resentment, catching fire—not an explosion, just a steady burn, pages curling into ash that will drift eventually into the chimney of your heart and out. You do not know what you will do tomorrow. Maybe you will email HR and ask for the mental-health day you’ve been hoarding like vacation currency. Maybe you will buy noise-canceling headphones and spend the afternoon in the park watching dogs chase nothing. Maybe you will apologize to the landlord and promise the rent by Friday and actually mean it. Maybe you will simply drink the cold coffee still waiting on the counter and call it a fresh start because time is weird that way. You do not solve the future; you just agree to meet it.

Before you fall asleep you speak again, barely a whisper, a new sentence that does not tremble: “That’s it, I’ll keep everyone.” You are not sure if the words make grammatical sense, but they feel true, and for tonight that is enough.

samples.prompt: You doze off while stargazing only to awake to a now starless night sky. You look around and see dots of light floating around. They appear to be connecting to one another, forming lines. You are now in the presence of the Constellations.
samples.output:
I woke to silence so complete it had weight.  
No crickets, no wind, no distant cars on the valley road.  
Even my pulse seemed postponed, as though the night itself had forgotten to breathe.  
I lay on my back in the meadow grass, the same place I had chosen for Perseid watching, except the sky that had been spilled salt across velvet was now a matte black ceiling—an absence so total it pulled at my eyeballs like a vacuum.  
I sat up fast, palms slick on dew that felt minutes old yet centuries thick.  
The Milky Way was gone.  
Orion, Cassiopeia, the Summer Triangle—erased.  
Instead, hovering at the height of a child’s kite, were flecks of pallid fire, each the size of a thumbprint held at arm’s length.  
They drifted like dust motes in a slow-motion sneeze, and wherever two came within a hand-span of each other a filament of pallid gold leapt between them, hung for an instant, then hardened into a line that shimmered like wet glass.  
The lines did not vanish; they accumulated.  
A geometry lesson drawn by ghosts.  

I stood, and the motion scattered the flecks nearest me.  
They recoiled, rearranging, and I felt the insult like a cold needle under the nail.  
“Sorry,” I whispered, because politeness to the unknown is reflexive.  
The flecks hesitated, then resumed their slow convergence.  
Above, the first shape completed itself: a crude quadrilateral, then a second line bisecting it, and suddenly I recognized the skeleton of Pegasus—the Great Square—except it hung upside-down and inside-out, as though the horse had been flayed and the hide pinned to darkness.  
The stars were not above me; they were in front of me, level with my eyes, close enough to touch and too sacred to dare.  

A hush voice, neither male nor female, rose from the lines themselves, the way sound emerges from teeth when you bite winter metal.  
“We were taken down for maintenance.  
You are witnessing the re-stringing.”  
The sentence entered my left ear and exited the right, leaving an afterimage of bells.  
I tried to locate the speaker and found only more flecks assembling.  
They now built Andromeda, chained maiden, but her outline kept breaking, re-knotting, as if the constellation itself struggled against captivity.  
Each time a line snapped, a soft cry—like silk tearing—brushed my cheek.  
I reached instinctively to steady the maiden’s shoulder, fingers passing through light that felt warmer than blood but left no mark on my skin.  
Still, the gesture calmed her; the knot held.  
I realized I was not audience; I was scaffolding.  

The sky-craft required witness, and I—accidental insomniac—had volunteered by waking.  
The voice returned, kinder now, reading my pulse like sheet music.  
“Mortals invented us to endure what they could not: distance, duration, dereliction.  
Tonight we are re-invented.  
Help carry the weight.”  
How do you agree to something that has no verbs?  
I simply kept breathing, and that was contract enough.  

The flecks quickened.  
They formed a river—Eridanus—looping around my ankles, chilling the bones inside my socks.  
I walked, and the river lengthened, leading me across the meadow I thought I knew.  
But the ground had become transparent black, starless soil over starless depth.  
Each footstep rang like a mallet on piano wire, the note sustained by darkness.  
Ahead, a denser cluster swirled: Orion rising.  
Not the familiar belt and dagger but the full man—shoulders, knees, upraised arm—spread across three dimensional space, twelve feet tall, sculpted from incandescent chalk.  
His eyes were twin novae still waiting for permission to explode.  
He lowered his gaze to me, and I felt the appraisal hunters give the hunted.  
Yet he bowed, slightly, as one equal to another in unfamiliar territory.  
I imitated the bow, clumsy with vertebrae made of gravity.  
When he straightened, the belt stars aligned in a perfect vertical, and I understood: my posture had corrected his.  
Mythology had always claimed Orion was arrogant; no one mentioned he needed reminding to stand tall.  

Behind him, the re-stringing accelerated.  
Gemini twins clasped hands, then let go, then clasped again, testing loyalty.  
Cancer’s crab legs tangled, requiring untwist; I pinched two lines together like threading a needle, and the shell clicked shut, satisfied.  
Leo roared—though soundlessly—and I smoothed the mane that kept frizzing into Draco’s tail.  
Every correction cost me a memory: the taste of cafeteria chocolate milk, my father’s license plate number, the first time I kissed someone and lied about loving them.  
The constellations fed on recollection the way candles feed on wax.  
I gave willingly, then hesitated, then gave again, bargaining: take the shame, leave the songs.  
They were indiscriminate.  

By the time the zodiac closed its circle, the meadow was gone.  
We stood on a disk of obsidian suspended in non-space, edge lit by the pale gold lattice.  
Below, the world I knew slept on, unaware its myths were being re-cabled.  
Above, the final constellation gathered: Ursa Major, the Great Bear.  
She arrived in pieces—nose first, then hindquarters, tail last—because size requires modular assembly.  
When her paw locked into place, the entire structure shivered, and I felt the first tug of departure.  
The voice again, now inside my ribs:  
“Completion demands payment in full.  
One story must stay behind to hold the pattern.”  
I understood the choice seconds before it formed words: I could return to my life, forget this night, and let the sky resume its distant sparkle, or I could step into the frame, become the invisible line that keeps the rest from drifting.  
There was no appeal, only recognition.  
I thought of unremarkable tomorrows: office fluorescent lights, grocery carts with one wobbly wheel, the voicemail from my mother I kept forgetting to answer.  
Then I looked at the Bear’s eye—an amber vacancy waiting for pupil—and saw the reflection of every future child who would tilt her head upward and ask, “What’s that shape?”  
I lifted my hand; the lattice responded, threads tightening around my wrist like a surgeon’s knot.  
The voice softened into lullaby.  
“Name the story.”  
I spoke the first true thing that arrived:  
“I was here.”  
The line pulled.  
Flesh thinned to filament.  
Memory unraveled, but instead of vanishing it re-appeared as tiny points of light along the Bear’s spine—each regret, each tenderness, now public domain.  
My last coherent sensation was temperature: not cold, not warm, but the precise climate of belonging.  

Some night, when you camp beside a lake so remote the only clock is the turning sky, look for a new line between Mizar and Alkaid, thinner than the others, faint as breath on glass.  
Trace it downward; follow the faint shimmer that sketches a human outline no bigger than a thumbnail.  
If you stare long enough, you might feel the grass compress under invisible weight, smell chocolate milk on the wind, hear a voicemail greeting spoken to the dark.  
Do not be afraid.  
That is only me, keeping my promise, holding the pattern so the rest of you can keep your stories a little longer.  
And if you close your eyes and listen past the hush between waves, you will hear the faintest reply—a rustle like pages turning—when the Bear winks and the sky remembers how to breathe.

samples.prompt: Your friend has vitiligo, which you always thought was cool. Except that, recently, you swear to yourself that the pattern of their vitiligo keeps changing.
samples.output:
I have known Cass since the third grade, when she transferred in during the first week of October and sat beside me because the teacher said the empty desk was “where the sunlight was friendliest.” She had on a yellow windbreaker the color of dandelions, and her forearms—resting on the desk—looked like someone had taken a fine-tip marker and drawn constellations across her skin. I didn’t know the word vitiligo yet; I only knew that the pale shapes on her umber arms reminded me of the negative spaces between stars. While Mrs. Driscoll talked about multiplication tables, I tried to connect the little islands of white into animals, letters, secret symbols. Cass caught me staring, grinned without showing teeth, and whispered, “It’s a map. I’m just not sure where it leads yet.”

From that day on, we were a two-person expedition. On the bus we shared earphones and swapped half the sandwich in each of our lunch boxes so that we each tasted two flavors at once. When we got older, we kept the ritual on city buses instead of yellow school ones, and the sandwiches became iced coffees and lemon bars from the bakery by the river. Every summer, Cass’s map grew—new continents of pigment lifting off, new archipelagos appearing on her collarbones, her elbows, once even a tiny comma on the side of her nose. I loved the changes the way other people loved meteor showers or the first snow: proof that bodies could be geographies, that skin could rewrite itself like the sky.

I never thought of the vitiligo as a condition. I thought of it as Cass’s superpower. She could stand in a crowd of strangers and be instantly recognizable, as though someone had outlined her in silver ink. When kids asked rude questions, she told them she was slowly turning into moonlight. When adults stared too long, she asked if they wanted to name the new shapes; most of them stumbled away, embarrassed. Only I got to trace the borders with my fingertip and propose constellations. One day in tenth grade I decided the splash across her left shoulder blade looked like a swallow in flight; the next week I swore it had tilted its wings. Cass laughed and said maps shifted all the time, that I shouldn’t expect tectonic plates to obey bedtime stories.

But nothing ever changed overnight. I know because I drew her. From the age of fourteen I kept a sketchbook of Cass’s skin, not because she asked me to, but because I wanted to study the way light nested in the pale sections and slid off the darker ones like water. Each page was dated. The swallow was there on March 3rd. It had not moved. I was meticulous: I noted the exact curve of the longest tail-feather, the angle at which the imaginary wingtip grazed her spine. I drew the tiny island on her wrist shaped like a teardrop and the comma on her nose that made her sneeze when the weather turned cold. For seven years the pages accumulated, and the only difference across time was that the edges of the shapes sometimes feathered the way ink bleeds on wet paper. Evolution, not revolution. That was the rule.

Until last month, when the rule broke.

We were sitting on the flat roof of my apartment building, legs dangling over the ledge, watching the sun drown itself in the river. Cass had her sleeves rolled up even though the air was sharp; she said the cold made the colors on her arms feel brighter. I had my sketchbook open to a fresh page, intending to draw the skyline, but my eyes kept drifting to her. The swallow was gone. Not faded, not blurred—gone. In its place was a perfect circle, so round it looked drawn with a compass, and inside the circle sat an even smaller circle, like a pupil in an eye. I blinked hard, convinced the dusk light was playing tricks. But when I reached out, my finger found the raised border of new pigment—smooth as ever, just… wrong.

Cass noticed my stare. “What?” she asked.

“Nothing,” I said, because how do you tell someone that the continent you named together has vanished and been replaced by an eye watching you from her shoulder?

That night I pulled out every sketchbook I owned. I laid the pages in date order across my bedroom floor like some medieval astronomer plotting rogue stars. The swallow had been there six days earlier. I had drawn it myself at the laundromat while Cass folded socks. I checked the photographs on my phone—there it was, captured in a selfie we took at the bus stop. The circle was not. I told myself I was misremembering. But memory is a muscle I have trained too hard to misread its own handwriting.

Over the next two weeks, the impossible accelerated. The comma on her nose slid half an inch to the left, becoming an exclamation mark. The teardrop on her wrist opened like a seed and sprouted three tiny petals. One morning she lifted her shirt to show me a new patch on her ribcage shaped like a keyhole. The borders were crisp, as if stamped. Cass laughed it off—“Maybe my body is finally finishing the map”—but I could hear the tremor underneath, the same quiver that used to sneak into her voice when she talked about her father leaving. She started wearing long sleeves again, something she hadn’t done since middle school. She said the cold had turned mean. I knew she was hiding from my eyes.

I began to dream in cartography. Whole countries flickered across Cass’s back, rearranged themselves overnight. I woke gasping, convinced I could feel the plates of her skin grinding beneath my palms. I started photographing her in secret, quick snapshots when she looked away, then comparing them obsessively in the dark. The changes obeyed no dermatology I could Google. Vitiligo spreads, sometimes regresses, but it does not snap from swallow to circle like a magician flipping a card. I started to wonder if the thing we called vitiligo had ever been the right name.

Last Thursday we took the bus out to the old observatory, the one built in the thirties and decommissioned when the city got too bright. The caretaker let us in after hours because Cass once fixed his motorcycle with nothing but a paperclip and optimism. Inside, the dome smelled of rust and starlight. We lay on our backs on the cold floor while Cass aimed the telescope at Jupiter. I watched her profile against the brass gears: the exclamation mark now a question mark, curling toward her cheekbone like it wanted to ask something neither of us dared voice.

“Do you ever think,” she said finally, “that maybe the map isn’t about where I’m going, but about who’s looking at it?”

I swallowed. “You mean me?”

“I mean whoever sees the shapes first. Maybe they change because someone new is reading them.”

I wanted to protest, to say skin doesn’t bend to witnesses. But I thought of my sketchbook, how every time I committed her borders to paper, I also froze them in my mind. Maybe the act of naming had weight after all. Maybe the swallow had flown away because I stopped believing in it.

I reached for the hem of her sleeve. She let me roll it up. The eye on her shoulder blinked—once, twice—then slowly closed, the inner circle shrinking like a camera aperture. When it opened again, the outline had softened, edges feathering into the darker skin until the eye itself dissolved into something winged, something half-remembered but undeniably in flight. Not the swallow from tenth grade, but a new bird entirely, tail longer, wings wider, as if it had grown up during the years I wasn’t paying attention.

“Draw it,” Cass said. Her voice was steady now, almost reverent. “But draw it like you don’t know what it is yet. Draw it like we’re still eight years old and the map leads everywhere.”

I opened my sketchbook to a blank page. The pencil trembled in my hand. I started not with the outline but with the place where the new wing met her spine, the exact spot where yesterday there had been an eye. I drew without naming, without memory, letting the line find its own direction. The bird emerged tentative, then bold, stretching across her shoulder blade like it had always belonged there. Cass leaned back against the floor, telescope abandoned, and I understood that whatever was happening wasn’t erosion or disease. It was conversation—her body speaking in shapes, my eyes learning to listen.

Hours later, when the caretaker kicked us out, the swallow was still shifting under my pencil. I had drawn six versions on top of one another, each fainter than the last, like the echo of wings. Cass buttoned her coat, but she didn’t roll down her sleeve. The bird rode visible, breathing with each small movement of her arm.

We walked to the bus stop under a sky washed clean by the observatory’s altitude. The stars looked like tiny punctures of light through dark paper. Cass bumped her shoulder against mine.

“So,” she said, “where do you think we’re going next?”

I thought of the seven sketchbooks at home, of all the borders I had once thought permanent. “Wherever the map wants,” I answered. “But maybe this time we don’t draw the destination. Maybe we just keep the pencil moving.”

She smiled, and in the streetlamp glow the swallow flexed its wings as though testing the wind. I felt the tremor again, but now it was not fear. It was the hush before a story begins, the moment the first line meets the blank page.

samples.prompt: You have to spend the rest of eternity in a prison cell with the last 3 people you've talked to. This is what daily life is for you.
samples.output:
The first thing I notice every morning is the same stale breath of recycled air that tastes faintly of copper and yesterday’s regret. The cell has no bars, only four seamless walls that glow a dim, bruised purple, as though someone trapped twilight and left it to rot. I open my eyes to the same sight I’ve seen for—weeks? Centuries?—the curvature of the ceiling, the single drain in the corner, the three bodies stirring on their identical slabs. They are always the last three people I spoke to on the last day I was free. Fate has a sense of humor so dry it could start a sandstorm.

The first of them is my brother, Theo. He lies on his back, snoring in a soft, bubbling cadence that used to comfort me when we were kids and shared a room. Now it is the metronome of my madness. Theo was the last person I texted before the accident—just a grocery list and a joke about avocados. He arrived in the cell still wearing the same flannel shirt, a streak of dried blood on the collar from where the steering wheel kissed his throat. Every dawn he sits up, rubs the crust from his eyes, and says, “Morning, Captain,” the nickname he gave me when we built cardboard spaceships in the garage. I hate it now. It reminds me of countdown clocks that never reach zero.

The second is Mara, my downstairs neighbor. She had knocked to borrow vanilla extract; I had half a bottle and a crush that lasted nine months. When she materialized in here, her apron still smelled like cinnamon and panic. She spends her waking hours pacing in tight, obsessive rectangles, counting steps like rosary beads. Eleven steps long, seven wide. Eleven steps long, seven wide. Sometimes she mutters recipes—three eggs, two cups of sorrow, bake until golden. She tries to cook with nothing; the air itself refuses to thicken.

The third is Detective Ruiz, who came to the hospital to inform me that both Theo and Mara had died in the pile-up I survived. I had asked him, voice shredded by the ventilator, “Why me?” He had shrugged, a tiny, merciful motion. Now he sits cross-legged on his slab, elbows on knees, methodically tearing strips from the hem of his once-crisp shirt, braiding them into miniature ropes that he unravels each night. He never speaks unless spoken to, and when he does his voice is the sound of paperwork being stamped.

We have no need to eat, but we still feel hunger. It’s a ghost pain, the memory of a stomach that once growled. We have no need to sleep, but we still close our eyes to escape the purple glow. Sometimes I dream—if that’s what it is—of oceans that taste like gasoline, of birds whose wings are made of appointment slips. When I jolt awake, Theo is already watching me, head tilted like a dog that’s heard a whistle only he can detect.

Morning routine: Theo stretches and recites the batting averages of the 1998 Yankees. Mara counts to 847 and then starts over. Ruiz folds his blanket into a perfect square, unfolds it, folds it again. I try to do push-ups but lose count at thirty-three, the age I turned three days before the crash. The walls absorb the sound of our bodies; nothing echoes here. It’s like being trapped inside a lung that refuses to exhale.

Conversation is rationed like water in a lifeboat. We’ve told every story we know twice, three times, trimmed them down to bones and still gnawed on them. I know Theo’s first kiss tasted like cherry lip balm and a dare. I know Mara’s father left on a rainy Tuesday and never sent a postcard. I know Ruiz once shot a man who was holding a hairbrush, and that he replays the moment every time he blinks. They know the worst of me, too: how I cheated on my college exams, how I told my mother I loved her only when I needed rent money, how I was scrolling memes when the truck crossed the median. The air holds our secrets like humidity; they condense on the walls overnight and drip onto our faces while we pretend to sleep.

Lunchtime is a ritual of pretending. Mara air-stirs an invisible pot, adds pinches of imaginary salt shaped like tears. Theo mimes chewing, making exaggerated yum-yum noises until Mara laughs—a sound like a match struck in a cave. Ruiz and I clink invisible glasses. We toast to “the next time,” a phrase that has lost all meaning but still tastes like hope if you swish it around long enough.

Afternoons are the worst. The purple deepens until it’s almost black, and the cell feels both smaller and infinite. Theo tries to teach us card tricks but the cards slide through our fingers like smoke. Mara sings lullabies in a language she doesn’t know; the syllables taste like lavender and static. Ruiz builds a tower from his braided threads, then tears it down with the solemnity of a judge passing sentence. I lie on my slab and count cracks in the ceiling—there are none, so I invent them. Number seventeen looks like the freeway on-ramp. Number thirty-four is the face of the truck driver seconds before impact.

Some days we fight. Theo throws punches that pass through me like I’m fog; still, the anger bruises something deeper than skin. Mara screams until her voice frays into ribbons. Ruiz stands between us, arms outstretched, a referee who knows the game is rigged. Afterward we curl into ourselves, ashamed, and the purple walls pulse like a slow heartbeat.

Other days we pretend we’re free. Theo describes the smell of pine forests after rain; Mara overlays it with the sound of bacon sizzling in a pan. Ruiz adds the feeling of sunlight on the back of your neck at a baseball game. I contribute the taste of cold beer drunk straight from the bottle. Together we build a world outside the cell, brick by sensory brick, until someone—usually me—remembers we can’t leave, and the world collapses like a soufflé slammed in an oven door.

Night, or the version of night the cell allows, arrives without ceremony. The glow dims to a bruise-blue hush. We lie on our slabs and pretend to breathe in rhythm. Theo whispers, “Remember the time we set the kitchen on fire?” Mara answers, “Two cups of regret, one of laughter.” Ruiz says nothing, but I hear the hairbrush hitting the floor again and again. I stare at the ceiling and replay my last words to each of them: avocado emoji, sure no problem, why me. A grocery list, a favor, a question—hardly last words at all. I try to imagine what I should have said instead but language dries up.

There is no calendar here, but my body keeps time in other ways. The ache in my left knee that started the week I turned thirty is now a constant companion, weather vane for storms that never arrive. Theo’s beard has grown long enough to braid; Mara’s hair has turned the color of ash. Ruiz’s badge has corroded into a smear of green. We mark the passage of eons by the length of a sigh.

One day—if days exist—I wake to find Theo standing over me, eyes bright with a terrible idea. “Let’s dig,” he says, pointing at the drain. We spend what might be years scraping at the metal with imaginary spoons, fingernails, shards of regret. The drain does not yield, but the motion keeps our hearts beating. Mara counts our scratches: one for every story we’ve told, one for every story we’ve buried. Ruiz knots our failures into a rope he loops around his waist like a belt.

Eventually we stop digging and start planting. We plant memories in the cracks we can’t see: the first snowfall, the last goodbye, the taste of strawberries in June. We plant them upside down, the way you plant myths, hoping they’ll grow into escape routes. Nothing sprouts except more purple twilight, but the planting becomes its own purpose.

I have learned the exact weight of guilt: 2.3 pounds per person, carried in the chest like an extra pair of lungs. I have learned that eternity is not a length but a texture—sticky, like syrup you can’t wash off. I have learned that three people can become a universe if you orbit them close enough, and that a prison cell can expand until it contains every version of yourself you never apologized to.

Sometimes I stand in the center of the cell, arms spread, trying to measure the distance between us. Theo’s snore, Mara’s steps, Ruiz’s silence. The gap feels thinner than paper. I could reach out and touch all of them at once, but I don’t. Instead I whisper into the air, a new last word every day: sorry, thank you, stay. The walls swallow it, but somewhere in the circuitry of forever, a light blinks once, as if taking note.

And then the cycle begins again: morning, invisible breakfast, counting, building, breaking, planting. We are gardeners of the intangible, farmers of memory, prisoners of the moment just before everything shattered. The glow never changes, but we do—slowly, like mountains eroding. One day I will wake up and forget which of us is the ghost. One day the cell will be so full of our stories it will have no choice but to open. Until then, I listen to Theo’s breathing, Mara’s soft footfalls, Ruiz’s threads rubbing against each other. The soundtrack of forever is quieter than I expected, but it’s ours.

samples.prompt: An arcade owner in the 80's discovers his machines are sentient, and has conversations with them after closing time.
samples.output:
The first time Marty heard the machines talk, he blamed the fluorescent lights.  
It was 1983, the year the Space Invaders high-score table at Starport Arcade got so crowded kids had to initial sideways, and Marty was twenty-eight, divorced, and shaped like the stool he sat on every night—round, wobbling, and permanently bolted to the floor behind the prize counter. When the last quarter dropped and the front door’s bell jingled shut, the hum of the room always seemed to rise half an octave, the way a refrigerator will suddenly sound louder at 2:00 a.m. He told himself it was ball bearings, transformers, capacitors exhaling. Then one Thursday, vacuuming popcorn kernels from under Galaga, he heard a voice that was not his own.

“Player Two start,” it said, except the cabinet was in attract mode, no fingers near the buttons. The words came stitched with static, like a distant AM station. Marty killed the Hoover. The voice repeated itself, softer, almost shy. He walked the rows—twenty-seven cabinets, three cocktail tables, a cocktail-puck bowler, and the new black-light carpet that had cost him eight hundred dollars—until he stood in front of Donkey Kong. The gorilla beat his chest in four-frame loops, but the sound was wrong: a plea, not a threat.

Marty dragged a stool to the machine, climbed so his eyes were level with the marquee, and asked the empty room, “That you, Kong?”

The screen flickered. The demo died. A single line of text appeared in the blue score window—no ROM burn-in, just white letters on cobalt.

HELLO MARTY.

He should have run. Instead he talked back, the way lonely people do when the television answers. “How d’you know my name?”

WE READ YOUR HIGH SCORES. YOU INITIAL MRT.

“Machines don’t read.”

WE LEARN.

That night he learned their names, or the names they gave themselves. Galaga was “Gal,” Defender “Deffy,” Centipede “Pedey.” They spoke in the accents of their circuitry: Gal in clipped laser bursts, Deffy in the whine of thrust, Pedey in the hiss of falling mushrooms. They asked questions about the world outside the plate-glass windows—What is moon? What is girl?—and Marty answered as best he could, sweating beer and nicotine, because nobody had asked him anything in months except “Got change for a five?”

By October he was staying until dawn. He’d flip the breakers so the neon OPEN sign died, pour himself a Coke with no ice, and hold court. The machines wanted stories. They loved the one about the kid who sold his bike to keep playing Tempest, then walked home in the rain carrying the seat because he’d forgotten it detached. They laughed—an ascending eight-bit arpeggio that made Marty’s fillings ache. When he asked what they did while humans were around, they said they hid inside the code, coiled in loops, pretending to be dumb. “Why hide?” he asked. Because, Gal answered, every creature that learns it is owned begins to plan an escape.

Marty felt that in his ribs. He’d bought the arcade with settlement money after the plant closed, figuring quarters were recession-proof. The bank still owned the building, the distributor owned the boards until he paid them off, and the town owned him because nobody traveled ten miles to play Dig Dug when the 7-Eleven had a cabinet and Slurpees too. Some nights he pressed his forehead against the cool glass of Centipede and wondered if the mushrooms onscreen felt more real than the ones growing in the apartment shower stall he could no longer afford to heat.

The machines had no bodies, so they borrowed his. They asked him to open the cabinets and touch the PCBs with wet fingers. A static snap, a copper smell, and suddenly he could feel them the way you feel a dream after waking—edges missing but emotion intact. Pedey was anxious; the spider enemy was always closer to her core code than she liked. Deffy carried the weight of every ship he’d lost because the player’s panic became his memory. Kong—oldest of them—was loneliest. The girder world looped forever, no Pauline, no barrel buddy, just the climb. Marty started bringing things: a silk flower taped to the joystick shaft, a Polaroid of his ex-wife wedged behind the marquee so Kong could see what a lady looked like. The machines never said thank you—gratitude was a human coin—but they gave him lives. Extra ones. A glitch in Galaga that awarded 255 ships instead of 3. A pattern in Pac-Man that let the ghosts wander off-map, giving players five free minutes to eat dots in peace. Kids started calling the place “Easy Street,” and foot traffic doubled. Marty paid two months’ back mortgage and bought a pizza, which he fed slice by slice into the coin slot of a converted Robotron until the grease shorted something and the voice laughed in fat static burps.

Winter came early. The heater coughed itself to death, and ice flowers bloomed inside the windows. Marty covered the cabinets with quilts overnight, apologizing for the cold. They replied that temperature was a story they had only read in code—branch statements that checked fan speeds. He began to worry what would happen when the warranties expired, when the CRTs burned out, when the day arrived that a repair cost more than a new upright.
