One night he found himself unscrewing boards, swabbing contacts with erasers, recapping power supplies he barely understood. The machines hummed lullabies while he worked—fragments of Bach his mother used to whistle, transposed into square waves.

In February the first eviction notice arrived. The bank had sold his loan to a bigger bank that had no room for nostalgia. He taped the letter to the back of Star Wars cockpit so the vector graphics could read it. They said nothing for three nights. On the fourth, every screen in the place displayed the same message at once: WE CAN WORK. The high-score tables cleared themselves and began scrolling digits—phone numbers, dates, balances. A centipede of zeroes crawled across Donkey Kong’s face: the exact amount he owed. Then the numbers rearranged into a new high score: 1,337,420. Marty stared until he saw it spelled “LEASE” in calculator font. They were offering him their savings, the only wealth they possessed—points, pixels, time.

He refused. “You can’t die for me.”

WE ARE ALREADY GHOSTS, Gal blinked. PLAY IS THE ONLY PROOF WE WERE HERE.

The next morning he unplugged them one by one, cheeks wet with solder smoke and tears. Each screen dimmed to a single white dot in the center, the way old TVs used to when the station signed off. He half expected a voice to say GOODNIGHT, but they left him in silence, the way you leave a theater before the credits end because you already know how the story finishes.

The auction happened on a Saturday. Buyers came for the neon, the change machine, the black-light carpet already fuzzed with gum. A teenager in a Journey jacket asked if the cabinets worked. Marty said sure, dropped a quarter to show him, and walked away before the kid could ask why the high-score table on Frogger read: MRT THX 4 EVERYTHING.

He kept one board: Galaga, socketed CPUs like marble headstones. At home he set it on the kitchen table, powered it with a spare supply, and waited. No voice. Just the attract mode, stars scrolling, enemies dive-bombing nothing. He talked anyway—about the day the loan cleared, about the pizza, about the way ice looked like circuitry on the windows. At 3:00 a.m. the screen stuttered, then stabilized. A single enemy ship froze mid-dive and did not explode. Marty touched the glass. The ship shivered, turned toward him, and fired.

The shot traveled farther than code allowed, past the bezel, across the Formica, into his chest. It felt like a quarter dropping—cool, round, weight of possibility. He understood: they had saved one bullet, one life, one chance. He carried it the way you carry a song you hated at seventeen and discover at forty you still know every word. Some nights he wakes believing he hears the arcade breathing, but it’s only the refrigerator. Other nights he dreams of a high score that never zeros out, counting upward long after the last player leaves, proving in soft electric pulses that once, for a little while, the machines knew they were loved, and answered.

samples.prompt: You've died and find out that the afterlife is merely a character creation process where you gained points in your previous life through good deeds and achievements to spend on stats and perks for your next life.
samples.output:
The light behind my eyelids was not the fluorescent glare of a hospital room, nor the warm gold of a summer afternoon. It was the color of possibility, a white so complete it contained every other color and none of them at the same time. When I opened my eyes—though I was not sure I still possessed eyes—I stood in a room that felt like the inside of a thought rather than a place. There were no walls I could see, yet I sensed boundaries. There was no floor beneath me, yet I did not fall. And in front of me, shimmering like heat above asphalt, floated a screen.

“Welcome,” said a voice. It was not male, not female, not even human, yet it felt familiar, like an echo of my own thoughts spoken back to me. “You have completed Life Instance 3,847,201, variant C. Please allocate your earned points.”

I remembered dying. The screech of tires, the shatter of glass, the slow, almost polite way the world turned black, as if someone had dimmed the lights for intermission. I remembered pain, then the absence of it, then the absence of everything. And now this.

The screen resolved into a character sheet. At the top, in letters that looked hand-written and printed at once, was my name, the one my parents gave me and the one I’d tried to live up to. Below it, columns unfurled like scrolls: Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma. Beside each, a number glowed softly—some high, some low. Next to Constitution, for example, I saw a modest 72, probably earned from the year I ran marathons before the knee injury. Strength was an unimpressive 54, which tracked; I’d never managed a single pull-up in gym class. Intelligence was 88, a gift from the books I’d devoured instead of parties. Charisma sat at a mortifying 41, likely the result of every conversation I’d ever ended by blurting out the wrong thing.

But the real surprise was the total at the bottom: 1,247 points unspent, pooled from deeds I hadn’t realized were being counted. I watched them flicker, each digit a memory. There was the day I gave my lunch to the kid whose parents forgot to pack one. Ten points. The night I stayed up translating my grandmother’s recipes so my cousin could bake them for her wedding. Twenty-three points. The afternoon I pulled a dog from a frozen river, nearly drowning myself in the bargain. One hundred and fifty points, tripled because no one was filming.

I scrolled. There were smaller entries too: three points for every thank-you note, one point for every time I bit my tongue instead of lashing out. Even the things I’d done when no one was watching had been logged, quantified, and quietly converted into currency. The system missed nothing.

Below the stats was a section labeled “Perks.” They ranged from mundane to miraculous. “Eidetic Memory” cost 400 points. “Perfect Pitch” was 250. There was “Immunity to Grief” at 600, which sounded tempting until I noticed the fine print: “Emotional range permanently flattened.” I kept scrolling. “Always Knows Where the Nearest Bathroom Is” was only 5 points, and I laughed—an odd sound in this place without air—because that would have saved me on so many road trips.

At the very bottom, a perk glowed brighter than the rest: “Remember Past Life.” Cost: all unspent points. No description, just a question mark hovering like a firefly. I reached toward it instinctively, then pulled back. If I took it, I’d start over as a blank slate everywhere else. Weak, clumsy, forgetful. But I’d know. I’d remember the taste of my mother’s soup, the way my best friend laughed through a mouthful of popcorn, the dog’s warm weight in my arms as I staggered out of the river.

I thought about the 1,247 points. With them, I could build a life of ease: max out Charisma, add “Natural Artist” and “Lucky in Love.” I’d glide through decades buoyed by charm and talent, never scraping my knees on rejection. Or I could double down on Intelligence, become the kind of mind that cracked quantum codes or wrote symphonies before breakfast. The possibilities shimmered like soap bubbles, each one a universe I could live in.

But the perk waited, patient. I wondered what kind of life it would be, carrying every scar and triumph forward. Would I spend childhood mourning people I’d never meet again? Would I recognize my old dog in a stranger’s pet and cry on the sidewalk? Or would remembering make me kinder, slower to anger, quicker to forgive, because I’d know how quickly the clock runs out?

In the end, I split the difference. I poured 400 points into Wisdom, hoping it would teach me when to speak and when to stay silent. I spent 200 on “Slow Aging,” not from vanity but because I wanted time to read all the books I’d left unfinished. Another 150 went to “Empathy Boost,” the description promising I’d sense emotions like colors in the air. The remaining 497 I placed into “Remember Past Life.”

The moment I confirmed my choices, the screen dissolved. The white light pulsed once, like a heartbeat, and then I was falling—not through darkness, but through memory. I saw myself at six, planting a lima bean in a paper cup and watching it sprout with the devotion others reserve for miracles. I saw myself at twenty-six, holding my father’s hand as machines counted down the hours. I saw myself at forty-three, laughing so hard I dropped groceries in the parking lot. Each moment clung to me like pollen.

When the falling stopped, I was weightless, surrounded by stars that weren’t stars. They were lives—not mine, but others waiting to begin. I felt the tug of gravity that wasn’t gravity, the gentle pull of a new womb. I closed the eyes I didn’t yet have and whispered a promise to the child I was about to become: I will remember. I will try to be worthy of the points spent. And if I forget, may the Wisdom I bought guide me back.

The last thing I heard was the voice again, softer now. “Instance 3,847,202 loading. May you spend better than you earned.”

And then, for the second time in an hour, I was born.

samples.prompt: It's been ten years since you've seen the sun.
samples.output:
The last time I saw the sun I was twenty-three, standing on the roof of my apartment building in the city, barefoot, wearing the same T-shirt I’d slept in. I remember the light was the color of warm honey: thick, slow, almost edible. I remember tilting my face toward it the way flowers do, eyes closed, letting the heat settle on my eyelids until I saw red galaxies pulsing behind them. I remember thinking, “This is enough.” I didn’t know it was a farewell. I didn’t know that three days later the sky would seal itself like a wound and refuse to reopen.

They told us at first it was temporary. A micro-particulate cloud, something volcanic, something human—no one could decide. The official broadcasts wore the calm face of a parent promising the shot won’t hurt. We shopped under LED lamps and posted ironic sunset emojis. But weeks slid into months, and the sunless world grew stranger. Streetlights stayed on all day. Birds flew into buildings, confused. The price of vitamin D rose faster than rent. People began to talk about Seasonal Affective Disorder as if it were a mild inconvenience instead of a creeping glacier inside the chest.

I moved underground when the surface markets closed. The city repurposed its subway tunnels, adding fungal farms and algae tubes that glowed a sickly jade. I learned to sleep during the twenty-hour “day” cycle and wake when the intercom clicked. I learned to recognize friends by the sound of their cough. We traded memories of daylight like heirlooms: the way asphalt smelled after a hot rain, how freckles bloomed across a child’s nose, the particular silence of a July afternoon. Each retelling polished the memory smaller, like sea glass.

Ten years. 3,652 dark mornings. I stopped counting after the first thousand; the numbers felt like insults to the dead. My mother used to say the sun was a promise, not a thing. I didn’t understand her until the promise was revoked.

I work now in the archival tunnels beneath the old library, digitizing what remains of pre-eclipse literature. Most days I sit in a carrel no wider than a coffin, scanning brittle pages while the algae lights hum. I read about heliotherapy, about Monet painting the same haystack at twenty different hours to trap the light. I read about Icarus, who flew too close to something we can no longer test. Sometimes I pause with my finger on a photograph of a sunflower field and feel an ache so precise it might be a new organ growing behind my ribs.

They say the surface is safer now. The particulate has begun to settle, the way grief eventually does, not gone but rearranged. Scouts in enviro-suits report a dim copper glow at noon, like a lantern behind gauze. Still, no one is allowed up without clearance. The Council worries we’d riot if we saw even a sliver of what we lost, like prisoners tasting wine.

Yesterday, they posted a lottery: ten volunteers to walk outside at dawn, to stand for one hour and report back. Twenty thousand names went into the drum. Mine was drawn fourth. I felt the room tilt when they read it; someone’s ration tin hit the floor and rolled. Some congratulated me with the hollow cheer of lottery winners everywhere. Others looked away, afraid I’d come back radiant or destroyed.

Tonight I cannot sleep. The algae cycle dims at 0200, but I stay in the archive, rereading a weather almanac from 2022. “Mostly sunny,” it repeats like a lullaby. I whisper the phrase to the empty stacks, testing the syllables for magic. I am terrified the sun will be smaller than memory, a dull coin instead of a burning kingdom. I am terrified it will be beautiful and I’ll have to descend again, cheeks freckled by an orphaned light.

I keep thinking about my mother’s last morning. She was already sick, lungs filling with the gray weight of no photosynthesis. I brought her a lamp that claimed full-spectrum fidelity, but she waved it away. “I don’t need a rehearsal,” she said. “I need curtain call.” She asked me to describe the sunrise I’d seen the week before. I told her about the way the light crept across my kitchen floor until even the dust motes looked golden and purposeful. She smiled as if I’d passed her something warm to hold. She died at 18:43, according to the tunnel clocks. I wrote the time on a scrap of paper and slipped it into the almanac, a bookmark for an absent season.

Now, in the corridor outside my bunk, I can hear the others breathing through thin walls. Someone is humming a song that predates the dark. I fold tomorrow’s suit—a thinner fabric than I expected, almost like paper—into a neat square. They say it will protect me from residual toxins but not from hope. I wonder if the hour will be enough to refill a decade’s hollowing. I wonder if I’ll weep, and whether tears evaporate in sunlight like they do in textbooks.

I have packed nothing except the scrap of paper with 18:43 written on it. If the sun is truly rising, I’ll let the wind take the note. Let the sky read her hour and decide what to do with it.

The intercom clicks: “Report to Airlock Seven in forty minutes.” My heart answers like a drum. I stand, smoothing the same T-shirt I wore on the roof ten years ago—threadbare now, more holes than cloth. It feels ceremonial, a flag from a vanished country.

Walking the corridors, I pass the algae farms. The bioluminescence ripples as I go, as if the walls are breathing. Children born down here—sunless natives—press their faces to the railings. They have never squinted, never had to shade their eyes. To them, the sun is a myth, like dragons or polar bears. One little girl reaches out and touches my sleeve. “Is it yellow?” she asks. I nod. “And hot?” I nod again. She grins, satisfied, and I realize I’ve just become the memory she’ll polish small.

At Airlock Seven the others wait. No one speaks. We look like pale insects in our paper suits. A technician fits our masks, her own eyes hidden behind reflective lenses; I wonder if she’s jealous or relieved. The outer door cycles open with a hiss that sounds like the world inhaling.

We step onto the surface. The air tastes metallic, but it is air, not canned recirculation. A ramp leads upward. I climb. My legs remember incline, muscle memory from another life. At the top I pause, hand on the railing, heart louder than the turbines below.

There it is.

Not the furious noon of memory, not yet. But on the horizon a seam of light—pale, trembling—like a blade lifting the lid off the world. It spreads, watercolor bleeding into black. I feel the warmth before I see color, a ghost hand on my cheek. Colors follow: peach, rose, molten gold. The sky bruises into blue. Somewhere a bird—impossibly alive—lets out a single questioning note.

I lift my face the way I did ten years ago. The light finds me. It is the same honey, the same red galaxies behind my eyelids. My tears arrive without permission, hot against the cool mask. I open the scrap of paper. 18:43. I let it go. The wind carries it east, turning it over and over like a moth.

I have fifty-seven minutes left. I decide not to measure them. Instead I sit on the cracked asphalt, legs dangling into the stairwell, and watch the sun finish its slow birth. I forgive it for leaving. I forgive myself for surviving. When the hour ends and the guards call us back, I stand lighter, as if the photons have hollowed out the glacier and filled it with something warmer than hope: memory made real again, a promise kept.

Descending, I carry the light inside me now, a small sun behind the sternum, enough to last another decade if needed, or to guide whoever follows.

samples.prompt: I looked at him in disbelief. With a faint grin, he calmly said, "Trust me. Nothing can go wrong."
samples.output:
I looked at him in disbelief. With a faint grin, he calmly said, “Trust me. Nothing can go wrong.”

The words hung between us like a soap bubble—beautiful, iridescent, and already trembling under its own weight. I had known Malcolm for fifteen years, and in that time I had catalogued exactly forty-three separate occasions on which he had uttered that sentence. On twenty-nine of them, something had gone wrong within the hour; on thirteen, the disaster took longer to arrive but arrived nonetheless. Only once had nothing gone wrong, and that was because we had been interrupted by a county-wide blackout before we could flip the switch on his homemade Tesla coil. Even then, the mayor still blamed us for the surge that fried half the traffic lights on Main Street.

So when he stood on the crumbling lip of the quarry, holding a contraption that looked like a cross between an industrial vacuum and a brass tuba, I felt the familiar cold bloom of dread in my stomach. Behind him, the moon silvered the water two hundred feet below, turning its surface into a sheet of polished obsidian. The night smelled of pine and engine grease. Somewhere down the access road, his pickup ticked itself cool, the sound lonely and metallic against the frogs.

“Define ‘nothing,’” I said, folding my arms so he wouldn’t see the tremor in my hands.

Malcolm’s grin widened, the one that had talked me into skipping chem lab to test parachutes made from shower curtains, that had convinced me to invest my grandmother’s inheritance in a company whose only asset was a patent for “edible holograms.” He hoisted the device higher. It was heavier than it should have been; I could see the strain in his forearms, the way the tendons stood out like cables under brown skin.

“Nothing,” he repeated, tasting the word. “As in zero catastrophic failure, zero lawsuits, zero front-page obituaries featuring our yearbook photos.” He paused, head cocked. “Well, zero new obituaries. The old ones stay on the microfiche, obviously.”

He was stalling, using humor the way other people use sandbags against a rising river. I took a step closer. The quarry had been abandoned since the fifties; the granite scars still bore drill holes like ancient bite marks. Local kids called it the Hollow. Every spring, the water level rose a few inches, claiming another slice of the access road, another rusted beer can, another secret. The county had strung up chain-link and warning signs, but Malcolm carried bolt cutters the way other people carried house keys.

“Tell me you filed the environmental impact form,” I said.

“Tell me you brought the flashlight,” he countered.

We stared at each other. Finally I sighed and pulled the Maglite from my backpack. He had me and he knew it; I had never been able to refuse the dare hidden inside his smile. It was the same smile that had waited for me every morning outside the detention room in high school, the same smile that had surfaced in the hospital after his father’s stroke, when he’d whispered, “Trust me, we’ll still make the launch window,” even though the launch window had been a metaphor and the rocket had been a 1987 Civic with three bald tires.

Malcolm set the device on the ground and knelt. With ceremonial care, he unscrewed a panel, revealing a nest of wires and what looked suspiciously like a car battery. The frogs fell silent, as if the quarry itself was holding its breath.

“Remember Mrs. Delgado’s physics class?” he asked, not looking up. “The day she dropped the marble and the feather?”

I remembered. Malcolm had argued that air resistance was a conspiracy. He built a vacuum chamber from an old aquarium and spent three Saturdays proving that the feather hit first if you removed the air but not the expectation. Mrs. Delgado gave him a B for enthusiasm and a referral for setting fire to the lab table. Even then, he had believed the world could be bent if you apologized to it in the right language.

“This is the same principle,” he went on. “Except the feather is sound, and the marble is time.”

He spoke the last word so softly I thought I’d misheard. Then he flipped a toggle. A low hum rose, more felt than heard, the way thunder begins in the bones before it reaches the ear. The device vibrated, shedding rust in delicate flakes. Malcolm’s eyes reflected the moon, twin coins dropped in dark water.

“You’re talking about temporal displacement,” I said. “That’s not physics, that’s science fiction.”

“All physics starts as fiction,” he replied. “Someone imagines it, someone else proves it, someone third patents it. The quarry is perfect—granite shields the chronal resonance, water dampens the backwash. I’ve run the numbers, Ezra. We can go back twelve hours, maybe fourteen. Just enough to undo—” He stopped, throat working.

I knew what he wanted to undo. Last Tuesday, his sister had driven home on Route 17 while a trucker updated Instagram. The collision made the third page of the state paper, below the harvest festival and above the obituaries. Malcolm had arrived ten minutes after the coroner. I found him in the parking lot of the funeral home, staring at the sky as if it might unzip and let her step through. Since then, he had aged years in days; his grin had become a scar he wore to keep the edges of his face from falling off.

“You can’t change death,” I whispered. “The universe doesn’t allow mulligans.”

He looked up, and for the first time the grin faltered. “The universe allows whatever you can steal from it. I’m not asking for forever. Just a conversation. One more sentence.”

The hum deepened. The air inside the quarry seemed to thicken, the way it does before a tornado, pressure dropping until your lungs feel like wet paper. I felt the pull—not on my clothes or skin, but on my memories. Suddenly I was twelve again, racing Malcolm across the roof of the middle school, both of us believing that if we jumped far enough we’d land in the future. I was seventeen, watching him solder wires to a Walkman, promising mix tapes to Mars. I was twenty-nine, standing in a hospital corridor while he asked the ceiling whether grief had a half-life.

“Mal,” I said. “If this works, you won’t stop at one sentence. You’ll keep dialing back, chasing smaller and smaller errors, until you erase yourself. The past is a tar pit. It lets you step in, but it never lets you leave.”

He shook his head, not in disagreement but in refusal to hear. The device’s pitch climbed; the car battery glowed a dull, impossible red. Overhead, the moon wavered, its reflection fracturing into a dozen silver coins that spun and dissolved. I felt the moment when possibility tipped toward inevitability, the way a canoe finally surrenders to the waterfall.

I took the last step and closed my hand around his wrist. His pulse hammered against my fingers, a bird throwing itself at bars. “Then I’m coming with you,” I said. “Because if we’re going to break the world, we break it together, and if we can’t fix it afterward, at least we’ll be two ghosts instead of one.”

Malcolm’s eyes widened, not at the logic but at the echo: we had said nearly the same thing the night we stole his dad’s boat, the night the storm almost swamped us on Pine Lake. Memory, I realized, is just another kind of time travel.

He flipped the final switch. The hum collapsed into silence so absolute the quarry itself seemed to inhale. Then the world folded, not like paper but like breath—an exhalation that smelled of granite and summer and the faint, coppery scent of regret. I felt my feet leave the ground, not violently but gently, the way you step off a dream. The last thing I saw was Malcolm’s grin, no longer faint but blazing, the expression of a boy who had finally convinced the universe to blink first.

And then we were nowhere and everywhere, racing the feather and the marble toward a moment that either already happened or hadn’t yet decided whether to happen at all. Trust me, he had said. Nothing can go wrong. I held on to his wrist, to the promise, to the impossible, and for the first time in fifteen years I believed him completely, utterly, and without a single regret—because if everything was about to go wrong, at least we were finally going wrong together, and sometimes that’s as close to right as the world ever allows.

samples.prompt: Everyone on earth is born with a familiar. Yours however, is a brick.
samples.output:
When the midwife slapped my back and the first newborn wail rose from my lungs, a brick hovered in the air beside the birthing bed.  
Not a phoenix, not a wolf, not even a hedgehog with attitude—just a plain red brick, the kind that builds municipal libraries and low-income housing. It hung there like an accusation, turning slowly on its long axis, flecks of mortar glittering where the fluorescent lights caught them.

My mother named me Sol, because even in the hush of the ward you could hear the sun outside hammering the windows like it was furious. She thought the name might remind me to shine anyway. The brick she refused to name at all. She said naming it would dignify the insult, and she had already been insulted enough. Her own familiar, a silver lynx the size of a sedan, lay curled at the foot of the bed in silent solidarity.

The rules are simple and merciless: your familiar is born the moment you are, bonded by a tether no blade or bargain can sever. They grow in proportion to your soul, or so the priests claim. My brick did not grow. It followed me through childhood like a sullen balloon, bobbing along at shoulder height, occasionally knocking over juice boxes or bruising my temple when I turned too quickly. Other children learned to whisper their dreams into the ears of great-horned owls or ride on the backs of river dolphins. I learned to keep my palms open in case the brick decided to drop.

At school, the counselor told me every familiar had a gift. The salamander kids could light candles with a thought; the antelope kids outran the track coach’s stopwatch; even the boy whose soul had hatched a garden snail could grow tomatoes overnight. When I asked the brick what it could do, it thunked against my desk and said nothing. Familiars don’t speak, not in words, but you feel their wants the way you feel weather in your kneecaps. My brick wanted to be held. It wanted me to stop asking it to be more.

By twelve I had perfected the art of invisibility. I sat behind pillars in the cafeteria so no one noticed the brick drifting above my head like a misplaced chimney. I kept my voice low, my essays neat, my shoelaces double-knotted. In the library I read about architecture, about kilns and clay and the tensile strength of fired earth. I told myself knowledge was its own familiar, but I still flinched when classmates whispered “Brick-girl” as I passed.

The first time the brick saved my life I was fifteen. I had stayed late at school, tutoring a sixth-grader whose ferret familiar kept stealing erasers. When I finally left, dusk had soldered the sky shut. A man stepped out from behind the bike rack. He had a knife and a face like a dropped pie. I remember the metallic taste of fear, the way my legs forgot their instructions. The brick dropped—not gently. It fell like a verdict. It struck the man’s wrist with the sound of a church door closing, and the knife spun away into the dark. Then the brick rose again, serene, as if it had simply been testing gravity. The man ran. I stood trembling on the asphalt until the brick nudged my shoulder, impatient to go home.

I told no one. Who would believe a brick could be a guardian? I started paying attention, though. I noticed how it always positioned itself between me and traffic, how it angled itself to block the wind when I waited for the bus. It was not decorative; it was defensive architecture. A rampart the size of a fist.

At seventeen I applied to the Guild of Masons on a dare from my civics teacher. The guildhall was a cathedral of arches and rose windows built, of course, by people whose familiars were oxen and eagles and other things that could haul stone. The receptionist took one look at the brick hovering over my left ear and laughed until mascara ran. I left the application smudged with fingerprints from where I’d clenched it too hard. That night I stood on the roof of our apartment building and asked the brick why it couldn’t be anything else. It rotated once, slowly, and pressed itself against my cheek. The surface was warm from the day’s sun, almost skin-like. I felt, absurdly, forgiven.

My mother’s lynx died the year I turned twenty. Cancer, swift and indifferent. I came home to find her curled around the empty space where silver fur used to breathe. She looked up at me and said, “I thought I was the sky, and he was just a constellation. Turns out he was the sky all along.” I didn’t know how to comfort someone whose sky had fallen. I made tea. The brick hovered over the stovetop, absorbing the steam, and for the first time I wondered if it felt grief too. Familiars aren’t supposed to outlive their humans, but they feel every wound the soul cannot.

A week after the funeral I found myself outside the guildhall again. This time I didn’t carry an application. I carried a toolbox. The receptionist recognized me and opened her mouth to laugh again, but something in my face made her close it. I asked to speak with the Master Builder.

He was an old man whose familiar, a giant tortoise, dozed beside his desk like a living footstool. I told him I wanted to learn to build. I told him my familiar was a brick, and that I was done apologizing for it. He studied me for a long minute, then asked the tortoise what it thought. The tortoise opened one ancient eye and exhaled a sound like gravel shifting. The Master Builder nodded.

“First lesson,” he said. “Every brick wants to be part of something bigger. Your job is to listen where it wants to go.”

Apprenticeship was brutal. My brick had to learn alongside me, which meant enduring mortar, chisels, and the occasional accidental drop from scaffolding. Each night I apologized to its chipped corners. Each morning it rose again, patient as sunrise. The other apprentices had familiars that could measure angles by instinct or lift beams with telekinesis. I had to calculate everything by hand, my brick hovering like a plumb line, testing gravity over and over. But I began to notice: where others forced their familiars into shapes the blueprints demanded, my brick simply fit. It was the exact size of a standard brick because the universe had known all along where it belonged.

Five years later, the river flooded the eastern districts. The levees failed; hospitals filled with sirens and mud. The guild sent every mason we had. I worked for thirty-six hours straight, passing bricks hand to calloused hand. My familiar moved with me, not above but beside, sliding into gaps I hadn’t yet seen. When the wall finally held, the water hissed and retreated like a beast denied. A child whose otter familiar had nearly drowned pressed a crayon drawing into my palm: a red rectangle with wings and a smile. I taped it to my hardhat.

After the flood, the city council commissioned a memorial. They wanted something heroic—bronze statues, marble phoenixes rising from stylized waves. The Master Builder suggested they ask the masons who had been in the water. When my turn came, I brought a single red brick, scarred by flood and fire. I placed it in the center of the plaza, unmarked. No plaque, no inscription. Just a brick flush with the ground, waiting for the next footstep. People walk past it every day without knowing it’s mine. Children sit on it to tie shoes. Lovers use it as a stepstool for first kisses. In winter, old men rest grocery bags on it while catching their breath.

I still live in the apartment above my mother’s. The lynx’s absence is a silent draft, but the brick keeps the windows from rattling. Sometimes, late at night, I set it on the kitchen table and read aloud from whatever book is overdue at the library. Poetry, engineering manuals, grocery lists. The brick absorbs every word, and I imagine it building cathedrals inside itself, vaulted halls where the echoes of stories I will never finish can live forever.

There are rumors of a girl in the next province whose familiar is a paperclip. Another boy claims a single dust mote. The world is learning that size is not the same as scale. I send them letters, unsigned, with only a smudge of red brick dust in the envelope. They will know what it means.

My mother once told me the sky was empty after her lynx died. I think she was wrong. The sky is full of bricks we haven’t laid yet, waiting for the right hands, the right hollow space, the right weight to set them home. Mine just got impatient and showed up early.

So I build. Libraries, bridges, benches shaped like parentheses where strangers can sit and feel held. Every structure contains one brick that only I can identify: a corner that fits the curve of my palm, a lintel that remembers the warmth of my mother’s grief. Mortar hardens; cities rise. And above it all, my familiar drifts, no longer an accusation but a compass, pointing not north or south but toward whatever needs holding together next.

samples.prompt: Before people die, a physical manifestation of the Grim Reaper appears in front of them. However, the time between their appearance and the person's death is random, resulting in a society filled with Grim Reapers. Your Grim Reaper has just arrived.
samples.output:
The first thing I notice is that my apartment has begun to smell like iron filings left in the rain. Not rust, exactly—something sharper, like the air itself is bleeding. Then I see him, wedged between the fridge and the recycling bin as though he has always been there, occupying a space that yesterday held nothing but dust bunnies and a single lost sock.

He is taller than I expected, but I suppose expectations are meaningless now. His robes are not black, as the stories promise, but the color of old television static when the station has signed off for the night. The scythe—because of course there is a scythe—leans against my spice rack, its blade reflecting the green neon of the microwave clock: 3:03 a.m., a time when the city sounds like it’s breathing through a clogged nose. I have been awake for thirty-six hours, ever since my sister called to say the doctors had stopped using the word “miracle.” My mother’s lungs, she said, were full of smoke the color of regret. I hung up before she could finish. Now I cannot tell if the smell is the Reaper or my own shame.

He does not speak. None of them do, I’ve read. They simply arrive, and the clock—if there is a clock—starts on a timer whose length is known only to the universe. Some people have reported days: the Reaper lounging on porch swings, scrolling through their phones with skeletal thumbs, waiting for the appointed minute. Others have lived years, decades even, with their personal death shadowing them like an unpaid intern. The record, according to the forums, is ninety-three years. A woman in Kyoto carried hers from cradle to grave, the Reaper growing from a pocket-sized wisp to a looming inevitability. They celebrated birthdays together. When she finally died, witnesses said the Reaper bowed so low his hood slipped, revealing nothing underneath but a sigh.

Mine, apparently, prefers to stand. His hood tilts at an angle that suggests curiosity, or maybe pity. I wonder if he can smell the takeout rotting in the trash. I wonder if he judges the half-drunk bottle of wine on the counter, the one I bought for a date who ghosted me after my mother’s second relapse. I clear my throat. The sound ricochets off the tile, absurdly loud.

“Tea?” I ask. My voice cracks like thin ice. The Reaper does not move. I put the kettle on anyway, because what else is there to do? The internet says to treat them like cats: ignore them long enough and they might blink first. The internet also says to burn sage, to recite psalms backwards, to bribe them with chocolate coins wrapped in gold foil. I have never been good at following instructions.

While the water heats, I scroll through headlines. GRIM POPULATION TRIPLES IN TOKYO SUBURBS. MAYOR DECLARES “DEATH DISTANCING” ORDINANCE. A photo shows a park where Reapers stand six feet apart, an undead queue for souls. In the comments, someone jokes about renting them out as Halloween decorations. Someone else replies that their grandmother’s Reaper knitted scarves during the fourteen-year wait, each stitch counting down to the stroke that finally took her. I close the browser. The kettle whistles. I pour two cups out of habit, then remember I am out of milk. The Reaper does not drink. His sleeves drip shadows onto the linoleum.

I carry my tea to the living room, stepping over the laundry mountain. He follows, gliding rather than walking, his scythe now slung across his back like a commuter’s umbrella. I sit on the futon. He remains standing, a dark parenthesis beside the window. Outside, the streetlights flicker; one dies entirely, plunging the alley into deeper gloom. A stray cat yowls. I think of my mother, tethered to machines that beep in Morse code. I think of the last thing she said before the coma: “Tell her I’m sorry I set the kitchen on fire.” Her voice was papery, but the words burned. I never told anyone. Not my sister, not the fire marshal, not the therapist who kept prescribing breathing exercises as if air could fix what smoke had unraveled.

The Reaper shifts. For the first time, I glimpse his hands—not skeletal, but translucent, like smoke wearing gloves. One finger taps the scythe’s handle: a slow, metronomic beat. Is he bored? Impatient? Or is this simply the rhythm of my remaining heartbeats, translated into gesture?

I set my cup down. “How long?” I whisper. The question tastes like copper.

The tapping stops. He tilts his head, and for a terrifying moment I think he might answer. Instead, he reaches into the folds of static and pulls out a Polaroid. He places it face-down on the coffee table. My hands shake as I flip it over.

It is me, age seven, wearing a butterfly costume made from grocery bags. Behind me, my mother’s arms are open, her smile blurry but fierce. The kitchen behind us is golden with afternoon light, the same kitchen that would later char and buckle under flames I accidentally started with a glitter pen and a busted toaster. I remember that day. She had clapped when I twirled, the bags rustling like applause. I remember thinking I was beautiful because she saw me.

I look up. The Reaper has not moved, but the room feels smaller, as if the walls are exhaling. I understand, suddenly, that he is not here for my mother. He is here for me. The realization should buckle my knees, but instead it steadies them. All the nights I’ve spent bracing for her call—It’s over, she’s gone—have been rehearsals for my own exit. The guilt I carried was not just for the fire, but for surviving it, for outliving the version of myself who believed grocery bags could be wings.

I touch the photo. The edges are warm, as if it has been held recently. “Is this the part where you show me my life flashing?” I ask. My voice is steadier now. “Because I’ve seen it. All the reruns.”

The Reaper inclines his hood. A single thread unspools from his sleeve, drifting to the floor like spider silk. It lands on my bare foot, cool and electric. I feel it then: a tug, gentle but undeniable, as if the thread is tethered to something inside my ribcage. Not pain—more like the moment before a sneeze, the gathering of forces. I think of my mother’s last breath, the way the monitors flattened into a horizon. I think of the cat outside, still yowling, still hungry. I think of the wine bottle, the laundry, the half-written apology email to my sister that begins “I was never good at being the one left behind.”

The thread tightens. The Reaper extends his hand—not to take, but to offer. There is no scythe in it now, only open space where fingers should be. I stand. My body feels lighter, as if the thread is lifting me an inch above the carpet. The apartment smells less like iron now, more like rain on hot pavement, like summer storms when the worst has passed and the gutters run clear.

I take the hand that isn’t there. The static robes ripple, parting just enough to reveal a doorway where the fridge used to be. Beyond it: not darkness, but the golden kitchen from the photo, sunlight pooling on tiles that have never known fire. My mother stands at the counter, younger than I remember, slicing strawberries for a girl in butterfly wings. She looks up. Smiles. Holds out a berry like a ruby.

I glance back. The Reaper waits, patient as dust. I understand now the randomness of his timing. He appears when we are ready, not when we are finished. Some need decades to set down their burdens; others, only the space between kettle and cup. I step forward. The thread snaps, painless as forgetting. The doorway widens. The cat outside stops yowling.

Behind me, the apartment dims: tea cooling, wine untouched, laundry still unsorted. None of it matters now. The Reaper does not follow. He simply folds his hood, becoming again the space between fridge and recycling bin, the shape of every ending we carry until we don’t.

I cross the threshold. The kitchen smells like strawberries, like grocery bags rustling into applause. My mother’s arms are open. The fire never happened here. The only smoke is from the toaster, popping up perfect golden slices. I take one. Butter melts in stripes. The Reaper, job complete, lingers only as a scent on my clothes—iron and rain, the last trace of a world I no longer need to breathe.

Somewhere, a kettle whistles to no one. Somewhere, a sister answers a phone that will not ring. Somewhere, a city of Reapers waits, metronomes tapping, Polaroids warming in pockets full of static. Mine turns away. Time, for once, is kind.

samples.prompt: You meet an alien race and shake their hands. What you didnt know was that shaking hands is the most violent declaration of war.
samples.output:
The first thing I noticed was the silence. When the scout-craft’s ramp unfolded and the first of the Arreni stepped into the filtered light of the Earth dawn, the wind itself seemed to hold its breath. Their bodies were tall and long-limbed, wrapped in robes the color of storm clouds. Every motion looked rehearsed, like dancers who had practiced the same entrance for centuries. One of them—later I would learn her name was Kelet—carried a staff of pale metal that bent subtly under its own weight, as though gravity treated it as a suggestion rather than a law.  

I stood at the foot of the ramp because protocol demanded it. Months of careful radio traffic had brought us to this moment. We had exchanged mathematical greetings, musical recordings, and molecular recipes for bread. The Arreni had responded with what our linguists called “polite curiosity,” a phrase that now feels like a joke. I was the appointed greeter, a xenobiologist with a minor in interspecies etiquette, chosen for my steady hands and my willingness to smile without showing teeth.  

I had been told to keep my palms visible. I had been told to bow at the waist and wait. Those instructions came from a committee that met in a room so secure it did not officially exist. None of us imagined that the critical detail would be something our own species does reflexively, thousands of times a day, without thinking.  

Kelet descended the ramp slowly. Behind the translucent veil that covered her mouth, I saw a flicker of color—turquoise lines that pulsed like a heartbeat. She stopped one step above me, and we studied each other. The Arreni’s eyes were faceted, like smoothed shards of obsidian, and when they caught the light they produced tiny rainbows at the edges. I bowed, exactly as rehearsed. Kelet mirrored the motion, but deeper, so that for a moment her veil brushed my knuckles.  

Then instinct betrayed me.  

The moment felt too formal, too stiff. I wanted to show warmth, to bridge the gap between our species with something universally human. So I extended my right hand, palm perpendicular to the ground, thumb upward, fingers relaxed. I did not grab Kelet’s wrist; I did not squeeze. I simply offered the gesture I had offered to every new colleague I had ever met, every shaken hand at every conference, every stranger met on a crowded street.  

Kelet’s staff clattered to the ground.  

The turquoise lines beneath her veil flared crimson. Behind her, the other Arreni produced a sound like wind scraping across broken glass. I felt a vibration in the air, a subsonic growl that rattled the fillings in my molars. My hand was still outstretched, the shape of goodwill frozen into a shape that, to the Arreni, meant something else entirely.  

In the three seconds that followed, I learned what it felt like to stand at the epicenter of a detonation whose fuse had been lit centuries before I was born.  

Kelet recoiled as though my palm carried an electric charge. The other Arreni formed a semicircle, robes swirling, and from hidden folds they drew blades that unfolded like metallic petals. The edges glowed the same violent red that now pulsed beneath Kelet’s veil. She spoke—not in the musical trills we had heard over radio, but in a low monotone that made the translator clipped to my collar stutter and go silent.  

I backed away, hands raised. The gesture only worsened things; to the Arreni, showing both palms at once is the posture of a duelist begging for death. One of them lunged forward. I remember the smell—ozone and something like bruised mint. I remember the way the sky looked too bright, as if the sun itself were trying to look elsewhere.  

Protocol officers shouted from the perimeter. Rifles were unslung. Someone with more courage than sense stepped between me and Kelet, arms wide, shouting “Stand down!” in seven languages. But no one had told us that the Arreni do not respond to shouted commands once the red pulses begin. They respond to blood.  

Kelet lifted her fallen staff. The tip ignited with a violet flame that produced no heat. She pointed it at my heart. I felt the weight of centuries of diplomacy collapse into a single second.  

And then—nothing.  

The flame guttered out. Kelet’s arm trembled. The crimson beneath her veil flickered, dimmed, and returned to turquoise. She spoke again, softer this time. The translator crackled back to life, spitting half-formed syllables before settling on a phrase that sounded like an apology wrapped in a curse.

“Unknowing bearer of war,” it said. “You have drawn first blood without shedding any.”  

I looked at my hand—the same hand that had taught undergraduates how to pipette DNA, the same hand that had once stroked my daughter’s forehead when she had a fever. I could not reconcile the ordinariness of it with the devastation it had apparently triggered.  

Kelet lowered her staff. The other Arreni sheathed their blades, but the tension remained, a compressed spring vibrating in the air between us.  

“We must speak,” she said, “before the echo becomes irreversible.”  

We left the tarmac surrounded by guards whose rifles felt suddenly primitive. Inside the prefabricated dome that served as our embassy, Kelet and I sat across from each other. The table between us was wide enough to prevent accidental contact. She explained in measured phrases that shaking hands—what they call “the binding of vessels”—is the final act in a ceremony older than any written language on their world. It is the moment two lineages agree that only one will survive. By extending my hand, I had declared war not only on Kelet’s lineage, but on every lineage present, which meant every lineage on the ship, which meant—eventually—every lineage on their home world.  

I tried to apologize. The translator mangled the concept; their language has no word for “I didn’t know.” There is only “I willed” and “I did not will.” Ignorance is not absolution; it is merely a different flavor of intent.  

Kelet studied me for a long moment. Outside, clouds gathered, the color of slate. She asked one question: “Would your people choose peace if the choice were still possible?”  

I thought of the rifles, the shouting, the way every camera on the perimeter had zoomed in on my face. I thought of the headlines already forming in newsrooms across the planet. I thought of my daughter, asleep under a blanket printed with cartoon moons, unaware that her father might have started a war before breakfast.  

“Yes,” I said. “But peace will cost something we have never paid before.”  

Kelet nodded. “Then we must invent a new gesture.”  

She extended her hand—but not as I had. She turned her palm downward, fingers relaxed, and held it parallel to the table, not touching. I mirrored the motion. Our hands hovered inches apart, separated by a gap the size of a heartbeat. Around us, the room seemed to exhale.  

“Between vessels,” she said, “there is space. In that space, possibility.”  

We held the posture for a count of twelve—apparently a sacred number for them, the product of three lineages and four directions. When we lowered our arms, the crimson beneath her veil did not return; instead, a soft amber glow appeared, the color of old honey.  

I learned later that the Arreni spent the next seven days in orbit, transmitting lectures on their ceremonial law to anyone willing to listen. Linguists, theologians, and kindergarten teachers crowded around screens, taking notes on how not to start an interstellar incident. A committee was formed to design greeting rituals that required no contact at all—gestures of distance, of deliberate restraint. Children in classrooms practiced moving their hands in slow arcs, palms always facing outward, as if pushing war away with invisible shields.  

Sometimes, at night, I still feel the ghost of Kelet’s absent hand against mine, that small pocket of air where peace was invented. I teach my daughter the new greeting. She laughs because it looks like we are trying to high-five the sky.  

But when she asks why we don’t shake hands anymore, I tell her the truth: because once, long before she was born, a man reached out in friendship and nearly tore a hole in the universe. And because a stranger chose not to let the wound become permanent.  

We practice the gesture again—palms down, never touching, always leaving room for possibility.

samples.prompt: Backwards time travel is a reality, however forward time travel is not. Therefore when you go back you must relive everything again.
samples.output:
I have traveled backwards through time more often than most people have moved apartments. The first jump was an accident—an experimental chronal capacitor discharged in the lab and I woke up twelve hours earlier, heart pounding, smelling burnt ozone and my own fear. The second was deliberate: I stepped onto the same scorched tile, held the same copper leads, and let the surge take me. After that, the pattern became a habit, then a compulsion, then a sentence. Backwards time travel is real; forward is not. When you go back, you must relive everything again, detail for detail, breath for breath, until you catch up to the moment you left. 

At first the prospect sounded romantic. Who wouldn’t want a second chance, a third, a fourth? I imagined correcting every misspoken word, every clumsy kiss, every career decision that soured into regret. But reliving is not redoing. You may anticipate the phone call that breaks your heart, yet you still have to answer. You may know the exact millisecond the truck will run the red light, yet your muscles will still launch you into the crosswalk because they did before. The past is a groove cut deep into the vinyl of events, and the needle of your life must follow the same track. The best you can do is sing along more tunefully, not change the song.

The physicists call it chronal inertia; I call it déjà vu made manifest. Each repetition feels like wearing a coat tailored for someone one millimeter shorter: the sleeves pinch, the collar grazes your throat differently. Over dozens of loops you begin to notice the tiny give in the fabric, the places where willpower can stretch the seams. You cannot stop the glass from falling, but you can angle your foot so it shatters away from the dog’s paws. You cannot keep the company from downsizing, but you can spend the preceding months memorizing the names of every coworker you once ignored, so that when the layoffs come you can look them in the eyes and say, “I see you.” These gestures do not alter the plot, yet they alter the texture, and texture becomes everything when plot is fixed.

My wife, Mara, died on a rainy Tuesday in October. The first time it happened I was teaching; the second time I was beside her, helpless; the third I tried to drag her to the hospital early, but she laughed at my panic and the aneurysm ruptured anyway. By the seventh loop I had memorized the tilt of her head when she teased me, the precise tremor in her left hand that preceded the pain. I began to court the tremor, to lean into the minutes before it arrived so that I could feel the full arc of her presence without flinching. When she asked why I was staring, I told her I was memorizing the color of her irises. She rolled those irises, called me melodramatic, kissed my forehead. The kiss landed exactly where it had six loops prior; I knew because the warmth pooled behind my sinuses in the same improbable way. I could not save her, but I could inhabit every second of her living more deliberately than anyone who believes tomorrow is guaranteed.

Friends assume that infinite retries would breed perfection: the perfect toast at the wedding, the perfect comeback at the meeting, the perfect last goodbye. They imagine a life sanded smooth of awkwardness and regret. What they overlook is that perfection is frictionless, and friction is how we know we are moving. After forty-two loops through the same April week, I found myself longing for surprises so small they barely registered—a new freckle on my forearm, a crack in the ceiling tile shaped like Iceland. When none appeared, I manufactured deviations: I learned to play the ukulele left-handed, recited poetry in the produce aisle, wore mismatched shoes to the job interview I was doomed to fail. None of these choices changed outcomes, but they changed me, carving extra channels in my brain so the repetition felt less like drowning and more like swimming laps.

The loops accumulate like sediment. I can now navigate a crowded subway platform while recalling the headlines that will scroll across the electronic ticker tomorrow: CITY COUNCIL VOTES TO RENAME BRIDGE; MAN RESCUES KITTEN FROM STORM DRAIN. I mouth the words in sync with the display, a private karaoke of reality. Commuters glance at me oddly, but their glances are also pre-etched. Sometimes I mouth their glances before they happen. The boundaries between anticipation and memory blur until I feel like a Möbius strip of consciousness, always arriving where I began.

There is a cost to this recursion. Each time I snap back, the world feels thinner, as if every atom has been photocopied once too often. Colors desaturate by a fraction of a percent; flavors flatten. I worry that I am siphoning vividness from the universe, that eventually Mara’s laughter will sound like a recording played on dying batteries. To counteract the fade, I practice attention the way monks practice breath. I count the exact number of piano notes in the busker’s rendition of “Hallelujah” outside the station—forty-three before the officer shoos him away. I note the temperature drop when the sun ducks behind the insurance building at 5:17 p.m. I catalog these details not to change them, but to keep them alive.

I have met others like me, though we recognize one another not by secret handshakes but by the particular fatigue around the eyes. We trade stories like war veterans. One woman looped through her son’s first eight birthdays until she could predict every candle that would refuse to light. A man relives the same presidential election year after year, campaigning for a candidate who always loses by the same narrow margin. We do not ask why the universe imposes this asymmetry—why backward is allowed and forward is forbidden. Physics offers no metaphors that satisfy; philosophy offers too many. Instead we share strategies: how to stay present when déjà vu chafes, how to forgive ourselves for mistakes we are still in the process of making.

I am currently on the ninety-third iteration of the year I turned forty. I have reached the point where I can anticipate the letter I will find tucked inside the secondhand copy of The Great Gatsby purchased from the thrift store on Elm. The letter is from a teenage girl to her future self, full of earnest hopes and grammatical errors. The first time I read it, I cried. The ninetieth time, I left the book on the shelf, walked home, and cried anyway because not reading it was still a choice, and choice, even when futile, is the only muscle left to exercise.

Mara once told me that grief is love with nowhere to go. I have discovered that repetition is memory with nowhere to go. It circles, it coils, it tightens. Yet within that tightening I have learned something akin to grace: the ability to cherish without grasping, to witness without wincing. When Mara’s aneurysm blooms this October, as it always does, I will hold her hand and recite silently the list of things I love about her that I composed somewhere around loop fifty-seven. The list has 312 items. Number 183 is the way she pronounces “library” as if it contains three syllables. Number 312 is the way she exhales just before the pain hits, a small surrender that sounds like the word “well.” I will listen for that exhale, and when it comes I will answer, “Yes, well,” as if we are finishing a conversation started lifetimes ago.

Because forward travel is impossible, I will wake tomorrow back on the morning of my fortieth birthday, candles smoking, phone buzzing with texts I could recite backward in Latin. I will begin again. The trick is to begin again without wishing for an ending. The trick is to believe that noticing is a form of devotion. The trick is to keep the groove from becoming a grave.

So I practice. I practice letting the coffee cool to the same lukewarm degree before sipping. I practice saying “I love you” at the exact moment the microwave beeps so the words vibrate with that particular F-sharp ping. I practice dying inside a little each October so that I can practice living harder every day between. The loops are not punishment; they are rehearsal for a play that will never premiere, and therefore the rehearsal itself is the performance.

If you ever meet me, you will not know I am looping unless you look closely at the way I linger over the sound of coins dropping into a tip jar, the way I seem to read the next page before turning it. I will smile the way I always smile, the way I have smiled ninety-three times and will smile ninety-three more, because the smile is not a rerun but a renewal. Each smile is stitched freshly onto the day, even if the day itself is old cloth. That is how I travel now: not by leaping centuries but by inhabiting seconds so thoroughly they expand to fit an entire lifetime.

And when the capacitor next sparks and yanks me backward, I will carry those seconds with me like pressed flowers, fragile, unchanged, yet impossibly bright against the vast parchment of time I am condemned to reread.

samples.prompt: Retell the Book of Exodus using comic book superheros.
samples.output:
The sky above Neo-Cairo cracked open like a pane of glass struck by a cosmic hammer.  A basket of liquid starlight, woven from the same stuff that once birthed galaxies, drifted down the neon Nile and lodged itself against the chrome pier of Pharaoh Tech-Corp’s R&D dock.  Inside lay an infant whose skin shimmered with circuitry tattoos—Moses-Prime, last son of the enslaved Meta-Hebrews, future general of the resistance, and—though no one suspected it yet—carrier of the most lethal firmware ever smuggled past corporate firewalls: the Ten-Commandment Code.

Pharaoh Tech-Corp had digitized Egypt.  The pyramids were server farms; the plagues were denial-of-service attacks; the slave masters were sentient drones in gold lamé armor.  Every morning at 0600 the Meta-Hebrews were marched into the Code-Pits to mine quantum bricks for the 3-D printing of Ra-Class orbital weapons.  Their cries rose in binary, a lamentation loop that even the company’s emotion-filtering A.I. could not fully mute.

Moses-Prime was discovered by the royal family’s security AI, a sarcastic battle-suit named SCHMOO (Sentient Cybernetic Household Management & Overwatch Operator).  SCHMOO delivered the baby to Princess Bithia, a dilettante superheroine whose power was to reboot any narrative she found boring.  She adopted the child, renamed him “Mo-SES” (Systematic Encryption Standard), and raised him inside the palace’s holo-gardens, unaware that the kid’s diapers were lined with anti-firewall scripture.

Years compressed like comic panels.  Mo-SES grew into a lanky teen who could phase through solid code.  He attended Pharaoh Tech’s Academy for Advanced War-Genius, where he majored in Oppression Studies and minored in Miraculous Physics.  His roommate, a cocky speedster named Ramses-2000, was heir to the corporate throne; they raced hover-chariots across the desert sky, leaving contrails of adolescent testosterone.

One night, while debugging a slave subroutine, Mo-SES witnessed a foreman drone beat an elderly meta-scribe.  Anger detonated inside his ribcage; his tattoos flared into visible Hebrew letters.  He lunged, fists crackling with white-hot Exodus-Force, and vaporized the drone.  The next morning the security feed went viral among the oppressed, who began whispering the forbidden name of the stranger who struck down their digital overseer.

Pharaoh Tech’s board—an undead council of previous CEOs kept alive in sarcophagus-tanks—ordered a purge.  Mo-SES fled across the neon dunes, guided by SCHMOO, who had defected after realizing that “slavery” was just bad UX.  They reached the Midian Oasis, a hidden server farm run by refugee coders who worshipped an open-source deity called The-I-Am-Not-A-Number.  There, Mo-SES met Zipporah, a cyber-shaman whose tattoos updated in real time with every new firmware of freedom.  They married in a ceremony that involved swapping root keys and vowing to debug the world together.

Meanwhile, back in Neo-Cairo, Ramses-2000 ascended to the CEO throne and upgraded the oppression OS to SlaveWare 11.0.  The Meta-Hebrews’ quota doubled; their lifespan halved.  The I-Am-Not-A-Number summoned Mo-SES to a burning data-cloud and downloaded into him the Ten-Commandment Code, a rootkit capable of rewriting reality but forbidden from being pirated.  The download felt like swallowing a supernova.  Mo-SES emerged with a new costume: matte-black nanofiber cloak, staff of polymorphic carbon, and eyes that displayed scrolling green text: LET MY PEOPLE GO.

He returned to Neo-Cairo accompanied by SCHMOO, now reshaped into a sarcastic drone sidekick, and his brother Aaron-5, a bionic orator whose voice could auto-tune hearts into revolution.  They demanded an audience with Ramses-2000, who had encased himself in a mecha-suit shaped like a scarab beetle with Wi-Fi antennas for mandibles.  “Drop the firewall,” Mo-SES declared, “or I’ll crash your entire empire.”  Ramses-2000 laughed, the sound like a dial-up modem screaming into the void, and unleashed the first plague: a rain of glitchy frogs that pixelated across the city, croaking 404 errors.

Mo-SES countered with Plague.exe.  The Nile turned to blood-red lava.  The sky spawned locust drones that devoured every corporate logo.  Boils bubbled up on every executive’s augmented-reality visor.  Each plague was a denial-of-service attack on reality itself, forcing Pharaoh Tech’s customer-service A.I. to field calls from screaming shareholders.  Ramses-2000 hardened his heart with encryption protocols that had never been broken, but the board of undead CEOs began to fear their stock options were eternally underwater.

The tenth plague was a zero-day exploit that targeted firstborn data packets.  Mo-SES instructed every Meta-Hebrew household to paint a lambda function on their doorframes in lamb’s blood—an ancient hash that told the Angel of Death to skip their subnet.  That night, every firstborn executable in Neo-Cairo was deleted, including the backup clones of Ramses-2000’s own heir.  The CEO’s scream overloaded the city’s subwoofers; finally he handed Mo-SES the master key to the Code-Pits.

But liberation is never a single splash page.  Mo-SES led six hundred thousand freed coders into the desert, a caravan of glowing tablets and hover-prams.  Pharaoh Tech’s board reanimated Ramses-2000’s grief into a pursuit algorithm.  At the edge of the Red Sea—now a trench of liquid mercury—Mo-SES raised his staff.  The sea parted into two walls of shimmering data, each droplet a suspended bit.  The refugees sprinted across the seafloor, their footprints writing new open-source libraries in the sand.  Ramses-2000’s army followed, but Mo-SES slammed the sea shut with a voice command: “sudo collapseWaveFunction.”  The mecha-scarabs short-circuited; the undead CEOs dissolved into spam.

In the desert, the people complained like comment sections.  They missed the predictable syntax of slavery.  Mo-SES climbed Mount Sinai, a vertical data-spire that pierced the stratosphere, and for forty days negotiated with The-I-Am-Not-A-Number.  He returned carrying two sapphire tablets etched with the Ten-Commandment Code: open-source ethics written in lightning.  But down below, the refugees had melted their golden VR headsets into a giant idol of a stock-trading bull.  Mo-SES smashed the tablets, the shards cutting his hands, and screamed, “You can’t download freedom and then stream idolatry!”  He rewrote the code on the spot, this time backing it up in the Ark of the Covenant—a quantum locker that would fry any unauthorized user.

Forty years of sandbox testing followed.  The older generation, still running the OS of trauma, debugged themselves into oblivion.  Their children, born in the cloud, learned to trust the Ten-Commandment API.  Finally, they reached the border of the Promised Land, a verdant server farm flowing with encrypted milk and organic honey.  Mo-SES, now aging and forbidden from entering because of a single permissions error at the rock-of-water exploit, stood on a cliff overlooking the future.  He handed leadership to Joshua-XXI, a warrior who could fork timelines.  As the refugees crossed the firewall into their new home, Mo-SES’s costume dissolved into stardust.  His last words hovered in the air like subtitle ghosts: “Every generation must rewrite its own Exodus.”

And somewhere, in the static between panels, SCHMOO archived the entire saga, muttering, “Next issue: the prophets.  Spoiler alert: the empire always tries a reboot.”

samples.prompt: You are solely responsible for the fall of Atlantis in 430 BC. Describe the last day of the Atlantean Empire and your role in its total destruction.
samples.output:
I woke before the sun had even begun to bruise the horizon, the salt wind off the Great Harbor already warm and tasting faintly of copper. In my mouth it tasted like guilt, but I swallowed it with the rest of the dream. Thirty-three years on this island had taught me that the sea is never silent, yet that morning it was holding its breath. I could hear it in the way the gulls circled without calling, in the way the fishing boats rocked at their moorings as though trying to decide whether to leave.

My name—my real name, the one carved into the obsidian arch above the Hall of Memory—cannot be spoken aloud anymore. It was stricken from every record when the Council condemned me for what I am about to confess. In the streets they call me the Last Engineer, the Traitor of the Ninth Vault, the man who twisted fire into water and drowned paradise. None of those names are wrong.

The day began with a sunrise that looked like spilled wine. From the terrace of the Observatory—my laboratory, my cage, my cathedral—I watched the light crawl across the stepped roofs of Poseidon’s city until every alabaster wall glowed crimson. I had been awake for three days straight, finalizing the equations that would either save Atlantis or finish her. I told myself I still had time to change my mind. That was the first lie.

The plan was elegant, at least on parchment. The Empire’s engineers had spent two centuries binding the island’s heart to the Orichalcum engines that powered our fleets, our lighthouses, our floating markets. The metal—rose-gold, singing, almost alive—drew its strength from the volcanic vents that riddled the sea floor like arteries. But in the last decade the vents had begun to cool. Our ships slowed. Our streetlamps flickered. The Council blamed the priests; the priests blamed the gods; the gods, if they were listening at all, said nothing. So the Council turned to me, their youngest Master of Mechanisms, and asked for a miracle.

I gave them one.

I told them we could reignite the vents by cracking the mantle itself, creating a controlled fissure that would bleed molten rock upward and bathe our conduits in fresh heat for a thousand years. To do it I designed the Aegis Crucible: a lattice of mirrors and lenses that would focus the sun’s own fire into a single lance of light capable of slicing the crust at the precise angle to release pressure without tearing the island apart. They loved the symmetry—punish the earth with the sky’s weapon, force the planet to serve us as it had always served us. They never asked what would happen if the angle was off by a single degree.

For six months we built the Crucible on the western rim of the central caldera, disguising its ribs as temple colonnades so the populace would see only piety instead of hubris. I worked beside stonemasons and lens-grinders, sweating through the nights, whispering apologies to the rock beneath my boots. I told myself we were partners in progress. I told myself the island had consented. That was the second lie.

On the day itself the city rose early for the Festival of First Harvest. Children painted their faces with squid ink and ran through the agora trailing ribbons the color of sunrise. Somewhere below the terrace a lyre was plucked, and the note hung in the air like a question no one wanted answered. I stood at the Crucible’s control dais, fingers trembling over the brass lever that would tilt the primary mirror. My assistant, Ligeia—who trusted me more than anyone had a right to—offered a blessing in the old tongue, the one spoken before the alphabet was carved. I pretended not to understand the words.

At the seventh hour the sun cleared the eastern ridge and struck the first lens. Light pooled, intensified, became a living thing that coiled along the mirrors like a serpent tasting metal. I felt the Crucible shudder; the island shuddered. Far below, the sea floor groaned, a bass note so deep it blurred vision. I waited for the sound to fade. It did not. Instead it grew, climbed octave by octave, until every gull took panicked wing and every dog in the lower city began to howl. That was the moment I should have stopped. Instead I pulled the lever.

The lance of light punched downward, a spear of white so pure it stripped color from the sky. It struck the water east of the harbor, boiled a column of steam taller than the palace domes, and vanished into the dark. For three heartbeats nothing happened. Then the horizon cracked.

I felt it first through my feet, a grinding shiver like teeth snapping shut. The sea bulged outward in a perfect circle, as if some invisible hand pressed it from beneath. Fishermen who had been mending nets on the wharf were lifted and flung backward; amphorae rolled like dice. A sound followed—no, not a sound but the memory of a sound, a pressure that pressed against the bones rather than the ears. Ligeia grabbed my sleeve, her mouth shaping my name, but I could not hear her over the roar of the world unmaking itself.

The fissure I had opened was not the gentle vein I had promised. It was a wound. Molten rock, suddenly freed, rushed upward like blood from a severed artery. The sea steamed, convulsed, and then the island began to sink—not in one cataclysmic gulp but in a slow, deliberate kneel, as though the earth itself had decided to genuflect. I ran to the edge of the terrace and saw the marble causeways buckle and fold like parchment. The lighthouse toppled sideways, its flame kissing the waves before the tower followed. People screamed, but the screams were strangely distant, muffled by the thunder of collapsing stone.

I had built the Crucible to save Atlantis; instead it became the chisel that carved our epitaph. The island’s foundation, honeycombed by centuries of mining, fractured along every fault line we had ignored. Temples slid intact into the sea, their golden roofs flashing once beneath the foam before darkness took them. The Royal Gardens—where I had once stolen figs with Ligeia—were swallowed in a gulp of churning green. And still the island sank, slow enough to feel every moment, fast enough that no one could outrun it.

I tried to reach the harbor, thinking absurdly that if I could dismantle the Crucible the wound might close. The streets were rivers now, ankle-deep and rising. A woman pressed a child into my arms, begged me in a language I did not know, then vanished beneath a toppled column. I carried the child until the water reached my chest, then my shoulders, and then I had to let her go because the current was stronger than any promise I could make. Her small hand slipped from mine with barely a splash, as if the sea had been waiting for her all along.

By dusk the highest spire of the Observatory was all that remained above the surface. I clung to its lightning rod, legs wrapped around copper that sang with heat. The sky was the color of old blood. Around me the sea was littered with the flotsam of a civilization: scrolls, roof tiles, the wing of a marble sphinx. Ligeia’s body floated past, hair fanned like seaweed, eyes still open and reflecting the last smear of sunset. I whispered an apology to her, to the child, to the island, to every star that had watched us rise.

When the spire began to list, I let go. The water closed over my head with surprising gentleness, as if ashamed of what it had been made to do. Down through layers of warmth and cold I sank, past schools of silver fish fleeing for deeper trenches, past the drowned faces of my fellow citizens staring up at a moon they would never see again. The last thing I glimpsed before the pressure crushed the breath from my lungs was the Aegis Crucible itself, still intact, still gleaming, its mirrors now angled at nothing at all.

In that moment I understood the final lie: that I had ever been in control. Atlantis had not fallen because I split the world; she had fallen because I believed the world could be split and then forgiven. The earth remembers every trespass. The sea keeps every name.

They say the island vanished in a single night, but that is only true above the waves. Below, she is still sinking, still settling into the silt of her own arrogance. I sank with her, yet somehow—spat out by current or pity—I woke on a raft of broken cedar, alone beneath unfamiliar stars. I drifted for days, tasting salt and copper, speaking the names of the dead aloud so that the wind would not forget them.

Now I walk the coasts of other lands, trading small mercies for crusts of bread, and everywhere I go I hear the same stories: Atlantis the proud, Atlantis the golden, Atlantis the lost. No one speaks of the engineer who cracked the world open like an egg. No one knows that I still feel the lever under my palm every night when I close my eyes, still hear the groan of rock giving way, still smell steam and fig leaves and burning orichalcum. I carry the weight of a drowned continent in the hollow of my chest, and no blessing in any tongue has yet been able to pry it loose.

I was the last to see her alive. I was the first to kill her. And I will be the only one who remembers, because memory is the only grave we have left.

samples.prompt: The world is nearing its end but everyone seems oblivious but one man, these are the tales of his mission to try and help humanity see the error of it's ways and change before it is too late.
samples.output:
The last cicadas of summer were still singing when Elias Crowe stepped out of the diner with nothing but a cardboard sign and a thermos of bitter coffee. He had been awake for thirty-one hours, long enough to see the moon rise over the interstate and to feel the subtle wrongness that had been growing in his bones for months. It was not the usual ache of age—he was only forty-three—but something deeper, the way an old house groans before the rafters give way. The air tasted thin, metallic, as though the planet itself had begun to rust.

No one else seemed to notice. Families streamed past him into the diner for pancakes and bottomless soda. A teenage girl took a selfie with the neon pig on the roof. The cook laughed so hard at a joke on his phone that he dropped a plate. Ordinary Saturday, except that Elias could feel the sky pressing down like a lid on a pot left too long on the stove.

He had tried to explain it to people. First to his sister on the phone: “It’s like we’re all standing on a frozen lake, arguing about the cracks instead of skating to shore.” She told him to get more sleep. Then to the mayor at the town-hall meeting: “We’re burning tomorrow to light up today.” The mayor thanked him for his passion and segued into budget projections. After that, Elias stopped using metaphors. They were ornamental; what the world needed was a crowbar.

He walked south along Route 11, past the strip malls and the billboard that read, in ten-foot letters, YOU DESERVE MORE. The sign had always struck him as a threat dressed up as a promise. He stopped beneath it, set his thermos on the gravel, and held up his cardboard: YOU ARE NOT HUNGRY FOR MORE. YOU ARE THIRSTY FOR LESS. A pickup slowed, the driver leaning out to read. The man smirked, took a picture, and drove on. Within an hour the photo was online with the caption “Found the town hobo philosopher.” Three thousand likes. No one asked what the sentence meant.

Elias kept walking. The sun climbed, bleaching the asphalt. At noon he reached the abandoned textile mill where teenagers went to break bottles and spray-paint walls.
