He had prepared for this moment: in his backpack were candles, a stack of salvaged mirrors, and a ream of paper he had covered with charcoal rubbings of leaves, coins, handprints—proof that the world had texture worth saving. He set the mirrors in a circle so that each reflected a scrap of sky. Then he lit the candles and waited.

The first visitor was a boy on a dirt bike, mud freckling his calves. He killed the engine and stared at the mirrors. “Some kind of art thing?” he asked. Elias said, “It’s a warning disguised as beauty. Or maybe the other way around.” The boy frowned, unsure whether to be intrigued or embarrassed, and rode off. His tire tracks looked like stitches across the dirt.

By dusk, eight more people had come. An old woman walking her dog, two roofers still wearing their orange vests, a cashier whose name tag said MAY. They formed a loose semicircle, drawn less by the mirrors than by the spectacle of one man talking to the sky. Elias did not preach. Instead he asked questions. “When did you last drink water straight from a stream?” “What’s the oldest sound you remember?” “What would you miss that doesn’t belong to you?” The questions floated up like sparks. Some landed, some didn’t. The roofers left first, joking about UFO cults. The cashier lingered. She touched a mirror, leaving a faint print of flour from the bakery where she worked. “I keep dreaming about the river I played in as a kid,” she said. “In the dream it’s always on fire.” Elias gave her a charcoal rubbing of an oak leaf. “Hold on to the shape,” he told her. “The shape will outlast the smoke.”

Night folded over the mill. The candles guttered. Elias packed the mirrors, though he left one behind, wedged in a window so that tomorrow’s sun would throw light across the graffiti like a second sunrise. He walked on, following the smell of water. The river was low, its stones showing ribs. He slept under a bridge and dreamed of glaciers calving into seas that had not yet risen.

The next day he reached the city. The skyline looked brittle, all glass and hurry. He stood at the intersection where three highways braided together and unfolded a new sign: THE WORLD IS NOT ENDING. IT IS UNRAVELING. THERE IS A DIFFERENCE. Drivers honked, some in solidarity, most in irritation. A woman in a silver sedan rolled down her window. “Unraveling into what?” she shouted. Elias met her eyes. “Into something that can’t hold your children,” he said. She drove off, but her knuckles were white on the steering wheel.

He began to speak in grocery-store parking lots, on subway platforms, wherever the current of bodies slowed enough for words to eddy. He never stayed more than an hour. Long enough to plant a seed, short enough that security didn’t bother him. People started to recognize the man with the cracked boots and the voice that cracked even more. They called him the Unraveler. Some brought him coffee; others brought arguments. A preacher told him he lacked faith in God’s plan. Elias replied that perhaps the plan required human participation. A tech worker offered to build him an app. Elias asked if the app could taste rain.

On the seventeenth day he felt the shift. It was small: a child handing him a dandelion gone to seed, saying, “Make a wish that grows back.” Then larger: the cashier from the mill appearing with three co-workers and a cooler of sandwiches. They had closed the bakery early and come to listen. Someone had brought a battery speaker; another had a guitar. They sang songs older than copyright. Drivers pulled over, hazard lights blinking like cautious stars. Elias realized he was no longer a single man with a sign but a node in a net no one had fully cast yet.

That night he climbed the fire escape of an old hotel and looked out over the city. The lights shimmered, beautiful and doomed. He thought of the mirrors, the charcoal leaves, the dandelion seeds spiraling upward. None of it would stop the seas from rising or the forests from burning. Yet the net was tightening, stitch by stitch, question by question. Somewhere a baker was reducing the lights in her shop, a roofer was teaching his daughter to collect rainwater, the mayor—yes, even the mayor—was drafting a resolution to plant a thousand trees. Small, breakable things, but the world had always ended in increments, and perhaps it could be mended the same way.

Elias descended the fire escape and walked east, toward the first suggestion of dawn. The air still tasted metallic, but now he could detect something else beneath it, green and stubborn as a sprout cracking concrete. He had no illusions that he would see the harvest. The error of humanity’s ways was a glacier—slow to move, slower to forgive—but glaciers could be redirected if enough snow chose a different valley. His mission was not to save the world in one dramatic gesture; it was to keep walking, keep asking, keep holding up mirrors until every person saw the sky pressing down and decided together to lift it back up.

Behind him, the city began to wake. Coffee shops opened, buses exhaled, phones buzzed with headlines about distant wars and stock markets. Somewhere in that chorus was a new sound: the soft scratch of charcoal on paper, the hush of lights being dimmed, the almost inaudible click of a single seed taking root in a crack no one had noticed. Elias smiled, tightened the straps on his backpack, and walked on. The end was still coming, but the middle—this long, luminous middle—was suddenly wider than it had been yesterday, and he intended to spend every remaining breath widening it further, one foot, one question, one small refusal of despair at a time.

samples.prompt: Summoning an Elder God inevitably drives cultists mad. You were expecting tentacles! Parasitic spores! Indescribable shapes and colours! You weren't expecting... this.
samples.output:
We had rehearsed the ritual so many times that I could recite the litany backward while asleep. We had studied the cracked bas-reliefs, memorized the angles of the non-Euclidean geometry, and calibrated the angles of the mirrors so the reflections would fold in on themselves like origami in a hurricane. We had even prepared our minds—at least we thought so—by ingesting small, measured doses of the black lotus resin that grows only in the shadow of the Nameless City. We told ourselves we were ready for the usual catalogue of horrors: the squamous tentacles, the fungal spores that bloom in the lungs, the colours that exist only in nightmares and ultraviolet. We were not ready for what actually answered the summons.

The chalk circle flared, not with eldritch fire, but with the warm, steady glow of a late-autumn sunset. The air smelled of cinnamon and old books. Instead of a thunderclap, we heard a gentle knock—three measured taps, the kind a polite neighbor might give before asking to borrow a cup of sugar. The temperature in the cellar did not plummet; it rose by perhaps two degrees, as if someone had just turned up the thermostat. My ears did not pop, my heart did not seize, and the candles did not gutter. They burned taller, straighter, cleaner, as though someone had trimmed the wicks with loving precision.

Then the door opened. Not the cellar door—we had barred and sigil-marked that—but a door that simply unfolded from the air like a polite cough given shape. It was a plain wooden door, painted a tasteful sage green, with a brass knob polished to a mirror finish. A small wreath of dried lavender hung from it, slightly crooked, as if it had been adjusted by someone who didn’t want to fuss too much. The door swung inward on well-oiled hinges, and through it stepped… an old woman.

She wore a cardigan the color of oatmeal and a pleated skirt that reached mid-calf. Her stockings sagged just a little at the ankles, and her orthopedic shoes made no sound on the stone floor. In her left hand she carried a string bag bulging with knitting needles, half a skein of burgundy yarn, and what looked like a Tupperware container. In her right hand she held a plate of cookies—oatmeal raisin, I think—arranged on a paper doily so delicate it might have been crocheted by spiders with advanced degrees in lace-making. She smiled at us the way my grandmother used to smile when she caught me sneaking an extra slice of pie: fond, mildly disappointed, but mostly just glad to see me.

“Hello, dears,” she said, and her voice sounded like wind chimes made of tea cups. “I’m Mrs. Althaea. You called?”

Brother Voss dropped the obsidian dagger. It clattered against the flagstones with a sound far too mundane for the occasion. Sister Ilyra began to hyperventilate, but not in the ecstatic, prophetic way we had anticipated; she just clutched her chest and wheezed like someone who had run for the bus. I tried to speak, but my tongue had become a useless lump of mortified clay. Mrs. Althaea waited, patient as a Sunday afternoon, then gave a small nod and stepped fully into the cellar. The door folded shut behind her with a soft click and vanished, leaving only the faint scent of lavender water.

She set the cookies on the altar—right between the sacrificial bowl and the vellum scroll inscribed with the seventy-third name of the Unspeakable One. She adjusted the bowl so it sat squarely on the embroidered runner, tutting under her breath at the crooked hem. Then she turned to us, hands folded over her stomach, and beamed.

“I do apologize for arriving unannounced,” she said, “but the post office has shortened its hours, and if I don’t post my niece’s birthday parcel today, it won’t arrive until Thursday. You know how it is.”

Brother Voss found his voice. It emerged as a squeak. “You… you are the Devourer of Reason? The Dweller at the Threshold of the Last Breath?”

Mrs. Althaea pursed her lips. “Well, that’s rather dramatic, isn’t it? I prefer ‘She Who Keeps the Teapot Cosy,’ but I suppose titles do get away from one over the millennia.” She glanced at the sigils chalked on the floor and gave a small, disapproving shake of her head. “You’ve smudged the outer circle, dear. You’ll have ants.”

I looked down. A single line of black ants was indeed filing across the floor, carrying crumbs from last night’s hastily eaten sandwiches. They marched straight through the breach, as if the boundary between our world and the screaming void beyond were nothing more than a crack in the grout.

Mrs. Althaea opened her Tupperware. Inside were tiny sandwiches—crustless, cut on the diagonal, filled with egg salad and watercress. She offered the container to Sister Ilyra, who took one with shaking fingers and bit into it as though it might explode. It did not. It tasted, she whispered later, like childhood summers and forgiveness.

The knitting needles came out next. Mrs. Althaea settled herself on the edge of the altar—careful not to disturb the cookies—and began to work the burgundy yarn into something soft and shapeless. The rhythmic click of the needles filled the cellar like a heartbeat. Every so often she counted stitches under her breath, lips moving in silent arithmetic.

“Now then,” she said at last, “you’ve gone to all this trouble, so I suppose I ought to give you something in return. But I’m afraid I left my tentacles in my other cardigan. And the spores—well, they do get in the carpets, don’t they? So messy. I thought perhaps we could have a nice chat instead.”

Brother Voss began to weep. Not the hysterical, sanity-rending tears we had expected, but slow, bewildered tears, the kind that come when you realize you have been preparing for the wrong apocalypse your entire life. Mrs. Althaea produced a clean handkerchief from her sleeve and dabbed his cheeks with the same care she might have shown a grandson who had scraped his knee.

“There, there,” she murmured. “It’s all right to feel silly. Everyone does, the first time.”

She asked us about our families. She wanted to know whether Sister Ilyra’s mother still grew dahlias, and if Brother Voss had finished that book on maritime knots he’d mentioned in passing—though none of us remembered mentioning it. She spoke of the long night between stars, but only to say that the silence there was peaceful if you brought the right music (she recommended Debussy). She warned us, gently, about the dangers of unventilated basements and suggested we open a window now and then, “for the mildew, dear.”

Time passed. I cannot say how long. The candles burned lower but never guttered; they simply dimmed, like guests growing drowsy after a heavy meal. Eventually Mrs. Althaea tucked the half-finished knitting into her bag, stood, and brushed a few crumbs from her skirt.

“I must be going,” she said. “The kettle will be on the boil, and I do hate to let it whistle. It upsets the cat.”

She patted my cheek with a hand that smelled of lanolin and lavender. “You’re a good boy,” she told me. “Try to remember to call your mother on Sundays. She worries.”

The door reappeared. She stepped through, gave us one last smile, and closed it softly behind her. The cellar was dimmer now, the candles guttering at last, but the smell of cinnamon lingered. The cookies were gone—only a few crumbs on the doily remained—but the Tupperware sat on the altar, washed and dried and neatly lidded. Inside was a single knitted square, burgundy yarn soft as forgiveness, and a note in tidy cursive: “For pot holders. They match the curtains. —A.”

We never spoke of it again. Not directly. But the next week Brother Voss went home to visit his sister’s children. He brought them each a sweater. Sister Ilyra planted dahlias on the roof of the tenement and taught the neighbor kids how to press flowers in old phone books. I called my mother. She cried, then asked if I’d been eating enough vegetables.

Sometimes, late at night, I think I hear knitting needles in the hush between heartbeats. I do not fear them. They sound like lullabies.

samples.prompt: Every answer that was needed was wrapped up in that kiss.
samples.output:
The last bell of the school year had rung twenty-three minutes earlier, but I was still standing in the hallway outside the art room, clutching the strap of my backpack so tightly it left crescents in my palms. Through the cracked door I could see Mr. Alvarez wiping cobalt stains from the countertops with a rag that had once been white. He hummed something off-key; the tune drifted toward me like a question mark. I was waiting for Lila, though I hadn’t told her that. I’d only said, “See you later,” which was both true and the biggest understatement I’d ever uttered.

Senior year had been a carousel of deadlines and weather alerts. Somewhere between college applications and tornado drills, Lila and I had built a friendship out of scavenged jokes and shared earbuds. She wore mismatched socks on purpose and kept a tiny glass vial of stars—she insisted they were stars, though they looked like glitter to everyone else—taped inside her locker door. I was the boy who could recite every constellation but couldn’t name his own feelings without tripping over their syllables. Every day she asked me a different impossible question: If silence were a color, what hue would it be? Do you think memories rust? If you could fold the sky like paper, where would the creases fall? I answered as best I could, but the questions piled up between us like unmailed letters.

That afternoon, she stepped out of the art room carrying a shoebox under her arm. When she saw me, her eyebrows lifted—two tiny kites catching an updraft. “Thought you’d be halfway home by now,” she said. Her voice had a slight rasp, the kind you get from laughing too hard or crying too quietly.  

“I was… delaying the inevitable parental interrogation,” I replied. It wasn’t entirely a lie; Mom had already texted three times asking what time to start the celebratory barbecue. But the bigger truth was that I needed to know whether whatever had sparked between us all semester would survive the summer, or if it would evaporate the moment we walked off school grounds.

We ended up on the football field, the grass gone haywire in June heat. A groundskeeper had forgotten to turn off the sprinklers, and mist rose in slow-motion ghosts. Lila set the shoebox on the fifty-yard line and lifted the lid. Inside were hundreds of paper cranes, each no bigger than a postage stamp. “Origami period,” she explained. “I made one every day you loaned me your pen in calculus.” She nudged the flock with a finger; the cranes rustled like dry leaves. “I wanted to give them all back, but I couldn’t decide on the right moment.”

I swallowed. Somewhere in the distance, a lawn mower coughed to life. “Maybe this is it,” I said.

She laughed, but the sound cracked in the middle. “Maybe.”

We sat cross-legged, our knees almost touching. I counted the cranes without meaning to—forty-six, the same number of days since I’d first noticed the constellation of freckles across her nose. Lila picked one crane up and unfolded it. In miniature, perfect handwriting, she had written: You make math feel like mythology. She smoothed the paper against her palm, then folded it back into shape—a reverse dissection. I realized she was giving me permission to read her the way she read me.

For a while we traded cranes like trading cards. She’d read one out loud, then hand it to me, and I would do the same. Some lines were jokes (You snort when Fibonacci spirals show up in pineapples), others were confessions (I practice saying your name in the dark to see if it still glows). Each slip of paper was a breadcrumb on a trail I hadn’t known we were laying. My pulse thudded so loudly I was sure she could hear it.

When we reached the last crane, Lila hesitated. It was slightly larger, the paper thicker. Instead of unfolding it, she held it out to me and said, “You do it.” My fingers shook. Inside, there was only a date—June third, today—and three words: Ask me again.

I looked up. Her eyes were bright, reflecting the sprinkler’s silver arcs. “Ask you what again?” I whispered.

She bit her lip. “The question you almost asked me after the spring concert. The one you swallowed like a cough drop.”

I remembered that night. We’d stood behind the auditorium, the air thick with tuba polish and lilac. I’d opened my mouth, but the words had tangled like cheap kite string. Now, in the middle of the field, the words untangled themselves. “Would it ruin everything if I told you I’ve been falling for you since October?”

She closed her eyes. For three heartbeats, the world was only sprinkler mist and the distant hum of traffic. Then she leaned forward and kissed me.

It wasn’t dramatic—no orchestral swell or fireworks. Her lips tasted faintly of graphite and strawberry lip balm. The kiss was short, almost chaste, but it contained every answer I hadn’t known how to phrase. I felt the shape of her laughter, the quiet weight of her fear that she’d read me wrong, the bright flare of relief when she realized she hadn’t. Somewhere inside that small press of mouths, she told me she was terrified of the future, too, but less terrified if we faced it together. She told me that the cranes weren’t just gratitude—they were practice for building something that could fly. She told me I didn’t have to count freckles anymore because she planned to stick around long enough for me to memorize them.

When we parted, the sprinklers shut off abruptly, as if embarrassed. The grass around us glittered with a thousand tiny mirrors. Lila rested her forehead against mine. “You didn’t ruin anything,” she said. “You translated it.”

We left the shoebox on the field. By morning the cranes would be soggy, ink bleeding into wings, but that seemed right: proof that paper can dissolve while what it carries keeps beating. I walked her home the long way, neither of us talking much. At her porch, she kissed me again—this one slower, deliberate, mapping new territory. I felt the question mark of Mr. Alvarez’s hum resolve into a period.

Years later, when we argue about whose turn it is to assemble IKEA bookshelves, when we misplace our phones and find them in the refrigerator, when we stand in hospital corridors waiting for news about her father’s heart, I’ll remember that first kiss. I’ll remember how every answer that was needed—yes, and yes, and yes again—was wrapped inside it, small enough to unfold over and over without ever wearing thin.

samples.prompt: A schizophrenic person's experiences and/or how they live their life (Possible trigger?)
samples.output:
The first thing I notice is the hum.  
It isn’t a sound so much as a texture—thick, metallic, like the air itself has been replaced by brushed steel. It starts in the soles of my feet at 3:07 a.m., the same minute the kitchen clock stutters, then spreads upward until my teeth feel like tuning forks. I am standing barefoot on the linoleum, gripping a glass of water I do not remember pouring. The glass is sweating; my palm is sweating; the water inside is perfectly still. That is the second thing I notice: how rarely the world matches itself.

I drink, or pretend to. The hum folds itself into words. Not voices yet—more like someone riffling through a deck of cards made of static. If I focus, I can almost catch the suit: grief, grievance, grieve. I have learned not to focus. Focusing is how the glass shattered last month, how the paramedics found me picking shards out of the rug because each piece was a syllable I needed to save. Seventeen stitches and a discharge paper that said, “Patient reports command hallucinations, low insight.” I keep the paper in the back of my notebook. It feels like a diploma from a country no one wants to visit.

By 3:12 the overhead bulb begins its daily argument with the ceiling fan. One flicker for yes, two for no, strobe for we’re not done with you. I count along because numbers are safer than names. The psychiatrist calls this “hypervigilant pattern recognition.” I call it Tuesday. When I tell Dr. Reza that the fan is spelling morse code with its shadows, she adjusts her glasses the way a translator might press headphones closer to her ears. She says, “What is it telling you tonight?” I say, “That the ceiling is porous.” She writes that down. I imagine the sentence sliding off the page and into the vent, where it will echo for months.

At 3:15 I remember I have a job, or used to. The library lets me shelve returns three mornings a week because the head librarian’s brother once tried to hang himself in a garage that smelled like sawdust and WD-40. She never says this outright, but I can feel it in the way she touches the spines of large-print romances, like she’s steadying them. My badge still says VOLUNTEER though I’ve been paid in actual dollars since February. I keep the badge in my pocket because the laminate is warm and because if I flip it just right, the barcode becomes a street map of the town I grew up in. Every shift I whisper the same instruction to myself: file under fiction, file under fiction. Some afternoons I believe it.

3:19. The refrigerator starts its asthma routine. I open the door anyway, needing the light inside, which is the color of hospitals before they switched to LEDs. On the top shelf sits a single orange, shrink-wrapped in plastic. I bought it because the produce clerk was humming a song my mother used to sing while she folded laundry, the one about the cricket who thinks the moon is following him. I never peel the orange; its skin is the only part that feels real anymore. Instead I hold it to my ear like a conch. The hum inside is softer, almost human. I imagine the orange dreaming of groves, of hands that do not tremble. I tell it, “We are both in here together.” The plastic fogs with my breath.

3:24. The first voice detaches from the static. Male, mid-Atlantic accent, calls himself Archivist. He keeps a ledger of every mistake I’ve made since kindergarten. Tonight he is reciting the week I was seven and refused to eat anything yellow. “Day four: gagged on corn, hid kernels in napkin, blamed invisible dog.” I answer out loud—whispered, but still sound waves, still proof. “I was seven,” I say. “Give me a margin.” Archivist chuckles, which sounds like a filing cabinet closing. Margin is where the errors go to reproduce, he says. I close the fridge, but the voice follows, nesting now in the hollow behind my eyes.

I walk the apartment perimeter: twelve steps living room, pivot, twelve steps back. The rug is an oceanic blue that swells if I stare too long. I keep my gaze on the baseboards where the dust dinosaurs congregate. They are not yet alive; I have sworn off giving them names since the night I tried to vacuum and they screamed. Halfway through lap four I notice the front-door deadbolt is undone. I never forget the deadbolt; it is the only ritual I still trust. My heart begins to sync with the fridge. Did I unlock it in a fugue? Did someone else? Archivist suggests I stepped outside at 1:06, handed a stranger the key to my sternum. I touch the chain, feel its industrial chill. The links are unmoved, but that proves nothing; time edits itself like that.

3:31. I retrieve the notebook. On today’s page I have written, in someone else’s handwriting, The difference between a prophet and a patient is paperwork. Underneath, a doodle of a door with no knob. I add: Bolt untouched, memory porous. The pen is running low; ink fades mid-sentence the way my father’s voice did on the hospice phone. I press harder, carving the words into the next two pages. Archivist tuts: Documentation is still confession. I tell him to file it under fiction.

3:34. The orange is back in my hand. I do not remember retrieving it. Its skin is warmer, as if it has been exercising. I place it on the windowsill where the streetlamp can keep watch. The lamppost flickers once—yes—then holds steady. A pact. I peel off my reflection in the glass: hollow cheeks, T-shirt inside out, one eye dilated like a door left ajar. I try to smile the way Dr. Reza recommends, the soft half-smile you give a nervous dog. The reflection does not return it. Instead it mouths something I can’t read. I back away, count to seven, look again. Just me, same as before. The difference feels academic.

3:37. I consider medication. The bottles stand on the counter like miniature city towers, labels shouting DO NOT CRUSH, DO NOT DRINK GRAPEFRUIT, DO NOT OPERATE HEAVY MEMORY. I take the morning dose now because the night is already contaminated. The pills are small moons, chalky and confident. I swallow with tap water that tastes of pennies and apology. Archivist recites the pharmacology: half-life, peak plasma, risk of tardive dyskinesia. I imagine the molecules fanning out, tiny social workers holding clipboards, knocking on each neuron’s door. May we come in? We have pamphlets. Some neurons barricade; others offer tea. I picture the orange supervising, a benevolent sun.

3:42. Silence, almost. The hum retreats to a corner, grooming itself. I feel the drop in pressure that precedes either sleep or seizure. To choose, I perform the reality checklist Dr. Reza taught me: name five things you can see (orange, deadbolt, notebook, dust dinosaur, my shadow), four you can touch (linoleum, T-shirt hem, scab on knee, air), three you can hear (fridge, own pulse, distant siren), two you can smell (pennies, orange), one you can taste (copper). The inventory steadies me enough to walk to the couch. I lie on my left side because the right is where the voices board. The cushion exhales. I tell Archivist, “Shift’s over.” He is already filing his nails, planning tomorrow’s agenda.

3:46. I watch the ceiling fan slow, each rotation a long drawn breath. The blades leave afterimages like smeared chalk. I think about the town I grew up in, the garage my mother never parked in because the lightbulb sounded like bees. I think about the librarian’s brother, whether he also counts syllables on windowpanes. I think about the orange, still lit by the streetlamp, a small planet refusing orbit. Maybe it will stay there until morning, maybe it will roll off and bruise. Either way, I will wake at 7:05, will shelve romance novels, will drink coffee black enough to silence the softer voices. I will not know how I got from this couch to the bus stop, but the day will accept me anyway. That is the bargain: memory edits itself, and I keep walking.

3:50. The hum returns, softer now, almost a lullaby. Archivist is humming too, the cricket song. I close my eyes and picture the moon following a small insect across an empty road. The insect believes he is being hunted; the moon is only trying to say, You are not alone. I do not know which one I am. The fan clicks off. In the sudden dark, the orange glows.

samples.prompt: Once you die, you meet God. He asks you to play chess against him in order to get into heaven. You get a chess piece for each achievement in your life you can name. Once you're done making your board, God sits down and you see he has only one chess piece.
samples.output:
The air after death is the color of silence: a hush so complete it has a hue. I stand on a marble floor that reflects me like polished obsidian, and across that mirror walks Someone who looks both impossibly old and newly born. He wears a plain linen shirt, sleeves rolled to the elbow as if He has just finished tending a garden. The smell of turned earth and cut roses lingers in the folds of His garment. When He smiles, I realize I have never truly been smiled at until now.

“Welcome,” He says, and the word tastes like water from a mountain spring. “We play for passage.”

I nod because, somehow, I already understand the rules. Behind me, a long table appears—dark walnut, edges worn by generations of elbows. Upon it rests an unopened cedar box. I lift the lid. Inside, a velvet hollow waits, shaped to accept chess pieces. It is empty, but beside it lies a fountain pen the length of a candle.

God takes His seat on the far side of an ivory-inlaid board. The squares are squares, and they are also hours, and they are also graves. He folds His hands; His fingernails are flecked with soil. “Name what you have done,” He says. “Each deed becomes a piece. When you finish, we play.”

My heart flutters like paper in an open window. I press the pen to the air and speak.

First piece: the day I taught my little brother to tie his shoes. I see him again, three years old, tongue poking from the corner of his mouth as the loops collapse under his fingers. I knelt, patient, looped the lace around my thumb twice, then once around his. When he succeeded, he threw his arms around my neck, and the victory tasted like strawberry jam. A pawn slides from nothing into the cedar box—simple maple, the crown barely more than a nub, but it glows.

Second: high school, a winter night when I carried my drunk friend Miles home through the snow. His breath fogged the collar of my coat; his feet dragged furrows behind us. I lied to his mother, said he was just tired, and tucked him into bed with his shoes still on. A bishop appears, taller, carved of pale ash with a diagonal slash like a scar. Miles is still alive somewhere, older now, maybe sober, and the wood carries the faint memory of beer and cold stars.

Third: the scholarship essay I spent three weeks revising, the one that paid my first year of college. I remember deleting the word “utilize” and replacing it with “use,” how the sentence relaxed like a shoulder after a massage. A knight leaps into the box, horse head reared, mane curling like my own handwriting.

Fourth: the afternoon I listened—really listened—to my mother cry about the divorce without trying to fix her. I simply held the phone and let the silence stretch until it became a room she could rest in. A rook joins the gathering, solid oak, corners sharp as the edge I felt inside my chest that day.

Fifth: the stray cat I coaxed out from under a parked Buick with sardines and patience. I named him Thoreau; he lived with me sixteen years, sleeping on my thesis drafts. A second pawn—walnut this time—slides home, its tiny face etched with whiskers.

Piece by piece, I unspool my life. The time I returned the extra change to the cashier. The night shift I worked so my coworker could attend her daughter’s recital. The letters I wrote to senators about clean water, the garden I planted behind the laundromat, the apology I gave my father eight years too late. The more I speak, the easier the pen moves, as though the air itself is ink. A queen arises from the moment I stood between a bully and the kid whose glasses he’d broken; her crown is lightning. A king grows out of the year I spent caring for my grandmother as dementia peeled her memories like wallpaper—he is carved from cedar and smells of lavender.

I keep going. There are small ones: giving blood, smiling at strangers, sharing lunch. There are large ones: the novel finished in dawn-lit bursts, the grant that saved a literacy program, the night I forgave myself for surviving the accident that killed my best friend. The box fills: two pawns, two knights, two bishops, two rooks, a queen, a king—then more. An extra knight for teaching refugees English. A third bishop for the money I sent anonymously. Pawns accumulate like coins in a fountain: tutoring, donating, weeping in bathrooms so my roommate wouldn’t see. I lose count. The table is crowded with carved light.

When the memories thin to static, I set the pen down. My army gleams—twenty-three pieces at least, maybe thirty. They stand proud, polished by the love that made them. I exhale a lifetime in one breath and step to the board.

God has already seated Himself. The board is wide as a desert between us. On His side, a single piece waits. Not a king, not a queen. A pawn. It is carved from something darker than ebony, something that absorbs the room’s glow. When I look closer, the wood is every night I ignored a friend’s text, every dollar I kept when I could have spared it, every cruel joke I laughed at to fit in. The pawn is small, but it weighs more than all my pieces combined.

I look up. God’s eyes are galaxies contracting into tenderness. “Your move,” He says.

I reach for my king—the grandmother year, lavender and cedar—and pause. The rules never said I had to win. They only said we play.

A strange certainty settles over me like a quilt. I pick up my king, feel the grain warm against my fingertips, and carry Him across the board. I place the king at the feet of His solitary pawn. A gift, or an admission, or perhaps both.

God studies the board. Then He reaches out and topples His own piece. The black pawn falls soundlessly, and where it lands, a flower springs up—blue as dawn, petals edged with gold. He looks at me, and His smile widens until it is wider than the room.

“Checkmate,” He says, and the word is a door swinging open.

Light floods in—not the harsh white of hospitals but the soft gold of Sunday mornings when I was six and the world was maple syrup and cartoons. My pieces dissolve into motes that drift upward like dandelion seeds. I am empty-handed, and I am weightless, and I am known.

God stands, offers His arm. We walk together across the marble that is no longer a floor but a path through a garden where every plant is a kindness I performed or received. Thoreau rubs against my ankle; my grandmother waves from a porch that smells of lavender. My brother, age three and thirty-three simultaneously, holds up his tied shoes in triumph.

Somewhere behind us, the chessboard remains—an ivory square under an endless sky. All that is left on it is a single fallen pawn, already sprouting vines that spell a single word in every language I ever loved:

Welcome.

samples.prompt: You are not the hero, your job is to do the bad things in the shadows to help them succeed.
samples.output:
I have never stood beneath the triumphal arch while the confetti drifts like pastel snow. I have never heard my name braided into a victory chant, never felt the warm weight of a medal pressed against my sternum. The stories they print in the morning editions never mention the moment when I loosened the bolts on the tyrant’s balcony rail, or the night I swapped the real treaty for one whose ink was still wet with loopholes. They never mention me because I am the paragraph skipped between “suddenly” and “the people rejoiced.” I am the silence that lets the chord resolve. I am the custodian of necessary sins.

My first lesson came in a cellar that smelled of rust and lamp oil. I was sixteen, all elbows and indignation, and the man who would become my mentor—though he would have laughed at the word—pressed a file into my hand as if it were a ticket to a play I hadn’t asked to see. The file contained a single sheet: a census ledger with one name inked out so thoroughly the paper had thinned. “Heroes need clear paths,” he said. “Your job is to drag the brambles out of the way, then plant them somewhere else so no one else can follow.” He lit a cigarette off the lantern glass and studied my face for flinches. I must have passed, because the next night he took me to the river and showed me how to weight a body so it would never surface on the eve of a liberation parade.

That was the first time I understood: history is a stage whose trapdoors are greased by people like me. We are the night-soil workers of revolutions, unseen, gloved, indispensable. We carry the buckets while the orators rehearse their speeches about dawn.

Over the years I have grown fluent in the dialect of shadows. I can forge a signature that will pass the scrutiny of the very hand that once wrote it. I can brew a poison that mimics the slow decline of a wasting disease, perfect for removing a general whose loyalty wavers at the wrong hour. I can empty a vault without tripping a single alarm, then deposit its contents in the evidence locker of my chosen scapegoat. Each technique is a stanza in an anti-epic, recited only to myself because even conspirators prefer not to know the details. They want results, not receipts.

The heroes themselves—those luminous, broad-shouldered protagonists—barely register my existence. I have stood three feet behind the revolutionary firebrand while she addressed the crowd, close enough to see the tremor in her cuff where the iron had burned her that morning. She never knew I had slipped the detonator out of her lieutenant’s pocket, or that the lieutenant would wake tomorrow in a fishing village with a new name and a tongue shortened by half an inch. She felt only the surge of destiny, the certainty that the world was bending her way. That certainty is my product. I manufacture it wholesale.

There are nights when I walk the city’s roofline and catalog the consequences I have set in motion. The orphan who will grow up to be a senator because I forged the adoption papers that spirited her out of the massacre zone. The mine owner whose suicide note I composed after I drained his accounts to fund the strikers’ soup kitchens. Each life is a candle I have either snuffed or shielded from the wind, and the tally is written nowhere except behind my eyes. I recite it to the stars because they do not judge; they only watch, the way I watch.

People assume that cruelty must feel like a hammer coming down. In truth it is closer to embroidery: thousands of tiny punctures, each one strategic, barely noticeable until the pattern emerges. The morning the regime fell, I was in the telecom exchange building, wearing the uniform of a technician who would never be missed. I inserted a line of code that rerouted every call from the presidential bunker to an empty office in the suburbs. While the tyrant screamed into the void, the heroes marched unopposed into the capital. I heard later that he died believing the world had simply stopped listening. In a way, he was right.

Sometimes I am ordered to save a life instead of end it. Those are the assignments that keep me awake. The dissident poet who must survive to become the conscience of the new republic, but whose liver is already riddled with metastases—so I break into the hospital, falsify scans, divert an experimental drug slated for a minister’s son. The poet lives to denounce the very concessions I helped negotiate, never knowing that his eloquence was purchased with another child’s last chance. I tell myself that art outranks flesh, that verses linger longer than veins. Still, when I see his face on postage stamps, I taste the iron of that child’s unused medicine.

We are, all of us, composites of the stories we refuse to tell. The hero believes she is the author of her own legend; I know I am merely a footnote she will never read. Yet footnotes can redirect entire narratives. Remove one, and the chapter collapses into contradiction. I have become an expert at identifying which detail must vanish: the witness who remembers the hero once worked for the secret police, the ledger that shows the liberation army bought its guns with heroin proceeds, the child who can identify the voice that gave the order to burn the village. I make them evaporate, then stand back while the historians cement the myth in place.

There is a monastery carved into the cliff south of the capital, abandoned now, where I used to store my tools between operations. In the chapel, faded frescoes depict the martyrdom of saints: eyes rolled heavenward, flames licking their ankles. I would sit on the broken altar and clean blood from my fingernails with a knife, wondering whether the painters understood that someone had to bring the wood, someone had to strike the flint. Holiness, like heroism, is a collaborative art. The fire does not light itself.

Once, I tried to exit the craft. I crossed the border under a passport that named me a grain merchant, rented a room above a bakery, woke to the smell of yeast instead of cordite. I thought I could become the vague civilian who drifts through epilogues unscathed. But the world would not hold still. A new hero rose, promising to cleanse the republic of lingering corruption. His speeches named no names, yet I recognized the silhouette he drew in the air: it was mine. The brambles I had planted had grown into a thicket he intended to burn. Within a month I was back in the monastery cellar, unpacking vials and ledger books, resuming the conversation I had never truly left.

I used to dream of a final accounting: a ledger bound in human skin where every deed I performed would be matched with its unintended echo. I imagined standing before a tribunal of those I had saved and those I had sacrificed, watching the scales oscillate. But the longer I serve, the more I suspect no such reckoning exists. There is only the next sunrise, the next directive, the next bolt that must be loosened so the balcony can collapse on schedule. Heroes speak of endings; I inhabit the endless middle.

Tonight the city prepares for another coronation. Fireworks wait on barges like captive suns. The hero—this one still young enough to believe her own metaphors—will stand on the palace steps and promise never to repeat the sins of the past. I will be beneath those steps, in the crawl space where the masonry is weakest, setting charges that will fracture the foundation just enough to ensure the structure lasts her lifetime. Not a second longer. The crowd will cheer, the bells will ring, and no one will notice the faint smell of cordite drifting through the cracks. They will think the earth itself is applauding.

When the last spark falls and the city sleeps, I will walk the riverbank and scatter the residue of my tools into the current. The water will carry it downstream, where tomorrow’s hero will drink, never tasting the metallic tang of preparations already underway. I will return to the shadows, rehearsing the next silence, sharpening the next needle. My name will never be carved into the monument, but if you run your fingers along the base you may feel a slight irregularity, a nick in the stone where I paused to steady the scaffolding. Touch it, and you will know I was there, doing the bad things so the bright things could survive.

samples.prompt: Every human has a number above their head that shows their worth as a human being. You just finished posting a shitty writing prompt and noticed your number has just dropped to a 0.
samples.output:
I hit “submit” on the thread and the page refreshed. The instant the new prompt went live, the number above my head flickered—like a dying streetlamp—and reset to 0. Not 0.1, not even a patronizing 0.01. Just a flat, matte zero, the color of pencil lead, hanging an inch above my hairline where everyone could see. I felt it before I saw it: a sudden absence, as if the air had been siphoned from my lungs.  

I was alone in the apartment, but the building wasn’t quiet. Through the wall Mrs. Kaminsky’s television droned, and somewhere downstairs a baby practiced its first operatic screams. I went to the bathroom mirror anyway, the way you do when you need to confirm a nightmare with your own eyes. Zero. The edges of the digit were fuzzy, like they’d been rendered at the lowest resolution the universe could get away with. I waved a hand over my head; the zero stayed put, casting no shadow, immune to gesture or pleading.  

For twenty-eight years the number had been a comfortable 6.8. Nothing to brag about at dinner parties, but high enough that strangers didn’t flinch when I stepped into elevators. High enough that my parents could mention me at synagogue without their voices catching. A 6.8 let me rent a one-bedroom on the fringe of gentrification, date women who read the *New Yorker*, and get away with posting the occasional hot take. I’d even begun to believe the number measured something real—some alchemy of kindness, utility, and charm—rather than a cosmic accountant’s inside joke.  

Now the scale had rolled over like a car odometer, and I was a null value. I opened Twitter to delete the prompt, but the post had already been cross-screen-shotted to three outrage subreddits. The replies were stacking up like cars in fog:  
— *This is what happens when mediocrity discovers metaphysics.*  
— *Imagine thinking “what if people had numbers” is still a thought.*  
— *OP’s digit just matched his IQ LMAO.*  

Each notification pinged another micrometeor into my hull. I turned the phone facedown, but the damage kept propagating in my head. I pictured coworkers who’d smirk tomorrow when the elevator doors opened and they glanced up. I pictured my mother practicing how she’d explain it to her book club. *He’s always been sensitive,* she’d say, *maybe too sensitive for a system that doesn’t reward self-pity.*  

I tried to remember the exact sequence of keystrokes that had felt so harmless ten minutes ago: *Every human has a number…* The premise had arrived like a sneeze, familiar and satisfying. I’d even chuckled while typing, imagining the upvotes. But somewhere between *shows their worth* and *you noticed your number dropped*, the idea curdled. It recycled a trope that had been circulating since numbers first appeared in 2019. Worse, it recycled it lazily, without the garnish of irony or the courtesy of a fresh angle. The universe, it seemed, had an algorithm for detecting intellectual sloth, and it punished proportionally.  

I sat on the toilet lid and stared at the tile. The grout was the color of old bones. My heart was racing, but underneath the panic a second sensation surfaced: relief. A clean zero meant the game was over. No more mental arithmetic when I passed reflective windows, no more comparing my 6.8 to the barista’s 8.2, no more nightly bargaining with the gods of productivity. I was the baseline, the null hypothesis. There was nothing left to lose, which felt almost like freedom.  

The building’s intercom buzzed. I let it ring until it gave up. A moment later my phone lit up with a text from downstairs: *You okay? Your number…* The message trailed off, but the concern felt genuine. That was the paradox: people loved a tragedy more than a triumph, and a zero might buy me the kindness I couldn’t earn at 6.8. I considered going outside to test the theory, but I couldn’t stand the idea of being watched like a car wreck.  

Instead I opened my laptop and created a new document titled *Apology / Manifesto / Suicide Note*—I wasn’t sure which yet. I wrote: *The number above my head is now a zero. You can stop reading if that disgusts you, but I hope you’ll stay long enough to understand that the number was always nonsense.* I wrote about the night my father taught me to multiply fractions, how we celebrated with ice cream, and how no digit hovered over his balding scalp to validate the lesson. I wrote about the woman I loved who left last winter because her own number had climbed to 9.4 and she felt I was anchoring her orbit. I wrote about the homeless veteran on the subway who carried a 4.3 yet shared his sandwich with a stranger.  

With every paragraph the zero pulsed, neither growing nor shrinking, just insisting on its perfect emptiness. I realized I was writing for an audience of one: the algorithm, or God, or whoever had installed the counters. I wanted to tell them the metric was broken, that worth was the wrong word for whatever they thought they were measuring. But halfway through page three I stopped. Even my apology had become performance, another bid for points.  

I deleted the file, emptied the trash, and slammed the laptop shut. The room was dark now; night had arrived while I typed. I went to the window. Across the street, apartments glowed like a hundred tiny stages. Numbers floated above silhouettes—7.1, 5.3, 8.9—each person moving through their kitchen or living room, occasionally glancing up to check their own score and their neighbor’s. I wondered if any of them felt the vertigo I did. Probably not; most people inherited a number and learned to wear it like a coat. Only the sudden drop exposes the absurdity.  

I stepped onto the fire escape. The metal was cold against my bare feet. Somewhere a siren braided itself into the city’s background hum. I looked up—no moon, just the orange haze of light pollution. I raised my hand, but of course I couldn’t see my own number without a mirror. Maybe that was the final joke: we spend our lives reacting to a value we can’t even witness without manufactured reflection.  

A voice drifted from the balcony above. “Hey, mind if I join you?” It was the neighbor from 5C, the one who painted murals on reclaimed plywood. I’d never learned her name; her number was usually a 7.5, the kind that made small talk feel like an audition. Tonight she didn’t wait for permission; she climbed down the ladder with a cigarette tucked behind her ear. Up close I braced for the flicker of recognition, the flinch when she saw my zero. Instead she leaned against the railing and offered me the cigarette.  

“I saw your post,” she said, lighting it for me. “It was pretty bad.”  

I laughed, a real laugh that surprised us both. “Yeah, the universe agreed.”  

She exhaled smoke into the night. “You know what I hate? The way people pretend the numbers are a prophecy instead of a weather report. One cloudy day and they act like the sun’s never coming back.”  

I wanted to tell her that my sky had gone dark for good, but the words felt melodramatic. Instead I asked, “Does it ever freak you out? Living under a scoreboard?”  

“Every day,” she said. “Then I remember that the only people who never see a dip are the ones who never do anything. You took a swing. You missed. Tomorrow you’ll take another.”  

We smoked in silence. When the cigarette burned down, she flicked the butt into the alley and climbed back to her balcony. Before disappearing she called down, “For what it’s worth, I give you a 3 for courage. That’s a third of the way to interesting.”  

I stayed outside until the chill numbed my toes. When I finally returned to the bathroom, I didn’t look in the mirror. I brushed my teeth staring at the faucet. In bed I kept the lights off so the zero wouldn’t glow like a night-light. I pictured tomorrow: the commute, the office, the whispers. I pictured the day after. Eventually I pictured a week, a month, a year—enough time for the prompt to become an anecdote instead of a verdict.  

Somewhere before sleep I realized the number might climb again, but even if it didn’t, the world had kept spinning when I became a zero. Mrs. Kaminsky’s television was still droning; the baby was still rehearsing arias; the siren was still winding through the grid. The system was rigged, but it was also indifferent, and indifference can be a kind of mercy.  

I closed my eyes. For the first time all night, I forgot to check the mirror.

samples.prompt: [WP`] One day, while drunk, for no real reason, your buddy decides to jokingly summon a crossroads demon, and surprisingly, one shows up. Now the demon has to deal with two drunks argue over what they should do with the demon who just wants to get back to watching Netflix.
samples.output:
“Okay, okay, picture this,” slurs Marcus, waving his half-empty beer like a conductor’s baton. “We get, like, unlimited nachos for life. That’s the deal. Eternal nachos. Boom. Done. Where do we sign?”

The demon—who introduced itself as “Vex, middle-management, Crossroads Division, Department of Infernal Acquisitions”—pinches the bridge of its aquiline nose. The gesture looks so human that I wonder if it took lessons on the way up. Its tailored charcoal suit doesn’t have a single wrinkle, which is more than I can say for Marcus’s hoodie, currently decorated with a constellation of pizza-grease stains.

“I’m not a nacho genie,” Vex mutters. “I traffic in souls, tragedies, Faustian bargains. Netflix calls this ‘ambient office noise.’ I left on pause for this.”

Marcus squints. “You got Netflix in Hell?”

“Satellite internet. Don’t ask.” Vex exhales sulfur-scented annoyance, then glares at the hasty chalk pentagram we sketched on the cracked linoleum of my kitchen floor. One of the candles has already melted into a puddle that looks suspiciously like Florida. “Look, you yanked me out of a perfectly good binge of Great British Bake Off. I’m missing the technical challenge. Someone’s going to over-proof their focaccia and I won’t be there to see it. Do you understand the emotional toll?”

I raise a hand like I’m in class. “Question. If we don’t actually want anything, can he go home? Because I feel bad. That’s like calling an Uber and then telling the driver never mind, except the driver is from the underworld and maybe gets paid in screams.”

Marcus wags a finger at me. “See, that’s where you’re wrong, Mikey. We do want something. We want… unlimited nachos.”

“Dude, you said that already.”

“And I stand by it!”

Vex folds its arms. The motion causes tiny sparks to dance along the edges of its cufflinks—miniature pitchforks, cute in a corporate-logo way. “Crossroads demons require three things: consent, specificity, and collateral. You two haven’t even agreed on an appetizer.”

Marcus nods solemnly. “Exactly. That’s why we need to workshop this. Mikey, you’re the English major—words matter, right? So let’s language this demon.”

I blink. “Language isn’t a verb.”

“It is tonight.”

Vex sighs and pulls a phone out of an inside jacket pocket. The lock screen is a selfie of a three-headed dog wearing reading glasses. “I’m starting a timer. Ten minutes. After that, the summoning circle destabilizes and either drags you both to perdition or explodes in a flash of cheap rum and Axe body spray. I honestly don’t know which is worse.”

Marcus’s eyes widen. “Exploding counts as dramatic irony. English major, back me up.”

I open my mouth, then close it. “I think we should stick to nachos.”

Vex pinches harder; tiny embers drift from its nostrils. “Let me explain how this works. You offer a soul—yours, your neighbor’s, whatever—and I grant a boon. But the boon has to be precise. ‘Unlimited nachos’ is vague. Unlimited in quantity? Time? Dimension? Because I once gave a guy ‘endless beer’ and he drowned in an ever-refilling kiddie pool of IPA. His ghost still emails complaints.”

Marcus strokes an imaginary beard. “Okay, okay. How about: ‘Nachos that appear whenever we want, perfectly made, no soggy chips, and the cheese never congeals into that weird plastic sheet.’”

I raise a finger. “And ethically sourced ingredients. Don’t want Hell-cheese.”

Vex looks at me like I’ve grown a second head, except the second head is also drunk. “Ethics surcharge is extra. Souls are easier. They don’t require supply-chain certification.”

Marcus leans in conspiratorially. “Mikey, we could pool our souls. Fifty-fifty. Joint custody. Weekends in Purgatory.”

“Joint custody of a soul sounds like the worst divorce settlement ever,” I say.

Vex claps once. The sound is gunshot-loud; the fridge rattles. “Focus, mortals. Clock’s ticking. I’m missing Paul Hollywood shake his head at an under-baked sourdough.”

Marcus straightens, the sudden motion making him wobble. “Fine. Let’s think bigger. World peace?”

“Cliché,” Vex and I say at the same time.

Marcus paces, arms windmilling. “What about… every time someone lies, a nacho appears in our pockets?”

“That’s a lot of nachos,” I say. “Also, politicians would bankrupt the corn industry.”

Vex scrolls its phone. “I’m adding ‘nacho-based lie detection’ to the ‘Reject’ pile. Right under ‘make my ex’s hair fall out in the shape of my initials.’”

I rub my temples. The room tilts slightly, like it’s trying to shrug. “Listen, Vex. Honest question. What happens if we just… let you go? No deal, no strings. We erase the circle, you go back to Paul Hollywood. Everyone wins.”

Vex hesitates. The pause feels ancient, like tectonic plates gossiping. “Technically, yes. But the summoning pulls energy from the Abyss. If I leave empty-handed, the balance snaps back. Could level a city block. Or, you know, just this apartment. Hard to predict.”

Marcus gasps. “Dude, the TV’s in this apartment.”

“Exactly,” Vex says, deadpan.

I look at Marcus. Marcus looks at me. The candle that looks like Florida finally collapses into the Gulf of Mexico.

Marcus whispers, “We could ask for something selfless. Cure cancer?”

Vex raises an eyebrow. “Ambitious. Also, the karmic invoice would liquefy your marrow.”

I swallow. My mouth tastes like hops and bad decisions. “What if we ask for the demon to get a raise? Like, promotion, corner office, bigger pitchfork. Then it’s a win-win. Vex is happy, balance restored, we go back to being drunk idiots.”

Marcus snaps. “Yes! HR loophole. Demon labor rights!”

Vex’s expression softens, which is unsettling because its eyes are solid gold and shouldn’t be able to soften. “You’d waste a summoning on… me?”

I shrug. “Seems fair. You were yanked away mid-bake.”

Marcus nods so hard his neck pops. “Dude, focaccia trauma is real.”

Vex stares at us for a long beat. Then it laughs—low, crackling, like a fireplace deciding whether to be cozy or catastrophic. “Mortals, you are catastrophically stupid. I love it.” It extends a hand. Heat radiates, but it’s oddly pleasant, like standing near a pizza oven. “Deal: I get a lateral promotion, you get lifetime nachos, but with a twist.”

Marcus and I exchange wary glances. “Twist?” we ask in unison.

“Every time you eat nachos,” Vex says, “you have to toast the chef. Out loud. Doesn’t matter where. Gas station, funeral, space. You say, ‘To the chef!’ If you forget, the nachos turn into kale.”

Marcus winces. “That’s… oddly wholesome?”

I nod. “We accept.”

Vex claps again. This time the sound is soft, like a book closing. The chalk lines glow crimson, then fade. The melted candle reforms into a perfect cylinder; Florida rises from the dead. Somewhere distant, a timer dings—probably the Bake Off technical challenge.

Vex steps back, already translucent. “Pleasure doing stupid business with you.” It pauses, half-smiling. “Also, new season of Stranger Things drops next week. If you idiots summon me again, I’m bringing spoilers.”

With a pop like bubble wrap, the demon vanishes. The air smells faintly of corn chips and brimstone.

Marcus and I stand in the sudden quiet. The fridge hums. A bag of tortilla chips materializes on the counter, cheese melting in slow-motion rivulets, jalapeños arranged like a tiny green crown.

Marcus raises his beer. “To the chef.”

I clink my bottle against his. “To the chef.”

We dig in. The chips are perfect: crispy, warm, ethically sourced. Somewhere, I swear I hear faint applause from a tent in England.

Marcus licks cheese from his thumb. “So… we just made a demon middle-management?”

“Apparently.”

He grins. “Best drunk idea ever.”

I nod, mouth full, already dreading the kale clause. Outside, sirens wail, but they sound oddly celebratory. Maybe it’s the beer. Or maybe somewhere, a demon just got a corner office with Netflix in 4K and a mini-fridge full of focaccia.

Either way, I’m not complaining.

samples.prompt: She held onto the night, for she feared what the day would bring.
samples.output:
The last streetlamp on Calle de los Suspiros flickered twice and died, but Elena did not quicken her step. She lingered beneath the iron halo of extinguished light, palms against the cool stucco wall, feeling the city’s pulse slow from a frantic daytime gallop to the drowsy arrhythmia of 3:07 a.m. In the darkness, Barcelona belonged to cats, to the far-off clatter of a late tram, to the echo of her own heart—nothing more. Daylight, she knew, would deliver invoices, eviction notices, the sour stare of the bodega owner who no longer extended credit. Daylight would unwrap the bandage she had wound around her life and show the wound had gone gangrenous. So she stayed inside the night’s velvet pocket, fingers curled around its seams as if she could keep it from tearing.

She had discovered the trick of it by accident three weeks earlier, the night the lab called with the second set of results. She had been walking home from the hospital when the sky split open—not with rain, but with a silent detonation of memory: her mother’s voice reading Snow White, the smell of eucalyptus in the pediatric ward, the way the word inoperable sounds like a slammed gate. She had stopped dead on the sidewalk, certain her knees would dissolve. Then the streetlamps blinked, one by row one, and the avenue dimmed as though someone were turning down a dial labeled FUTURE. Time softened; the air grew thick and swimmable. She took a breath, then another, and the panic leveled off. By the time she reached her apartment, she understood: night could be a container, a jar with the lid screwed tight. All she had to do was refuse to open it before she was ready.

Since then, she had become a connoisseur of shadows. She learned which alleys kept the longest shade, which all-night cafés would let her nurse a single cortado until the chairs were stacked on tables. She found a twenty-four-hour laundry on Carrer de la Princesa where the fluorescent lights hummed like captive stars and the owner, an old man from Andalucía, pretended not to notice when she dozed against the warm drum of a dryer. She rotated through these places the way a dying planet might cling to its last moons, always moving, always circling the drain of dawn.

Tonight, however, the night felt thinner, worn cotton rather than velvet. The city had begun to dream of morning; she could taste it in the air, metallic as blood. She walked the narrow lane that hugged the back of the cathedral, trailing her fingers along the stone. Gargoyles leaned out above her, their mouths frozen in perpetual warning. She whispered to them the way other women whisper rosaries: I am not ready, I am not ready. They answered only with the slow drip of rainwater from their limestone tongues.

At the plaza, she sat on the lip of the fountain and watched the horizon for the first telltale bruise. During the white days of her childhood in Cádiz, her mother had taught her to read the sky like sheet music: a clear dawn meant picnickics, a mackerel sky meant raincoats, a red horizon meant the sea was remembering shipwrecks. Elena had trusted that code until she was twenty-seven, until the sky began to lie. The morning her mother died, the sunrise had been a flawless rose, not a cloud to spell out warning. The morning she herself had coughed rust into the bathroom sink, the sky had been bland as hospital linen. Horizons, she now understood, were just the lids of boxes we convince ourselves we can open safely.

A police car cruised past, tires hissing on wet cobblestone. The officer in the passenger seat glanced at her—white woman, mid-thirties, no handbag, eyes like cracked glass— but kept going. People alone at this hour were either predators or prey, and she looked too exhausted to be either. The sound of the engine faded, leaving only the fountain’s chatter and the soft internal ticking that had started in her chest since the diagnosis. She pictured it as a miniature metronome, counting down to some final cadence. When the ticking stopped, would the music simply end, or would there be a chord unresolved, hanging in the air like a question too rude to ask?

She took from her pocket the object she had carried for three weeks: a child’s plastic kaleidoscope, striped like a candy cane. It had belonged to her niece, Sofia, who believed every problem could be solved by looking at it differently. Elena lifted it to her good eye. The plaza, already fragmented by night, splintered further into jeweled wedges: a tessellation of shadow, stone, and the first pale suggestion of blue. She turned the barrel slowly, watching the pattern rearrange itself. Each twist produced a new constellation: gargoyle-wing, fountain-spray, cathedral-spire, all broken and reassembled into meaningless beauty. If she could keep turning, she thought, maybe the next click would reveal a version of the world in which her body was not a traitor, in which mornings were innocent.

A garbage truck growled somewhere beyond the cathedral, the sound of civilization shaking itself awake. The night was definitely fraying now; she could see the weave separating, threads of black pulling loose to expose gray underlayer. Soon the plaza would fill with jogger, nuns, baristas lifting metal shutters like eyelids after a long cry. They would move through their routines with the brisk entitlement of people who still believed in continuity. She envied them the simplicity of their fears: tardiness, overdrafts, the barista who remembered their order wrong. She envied them the luxury of not knowing which star in their personal sky was about to go supernova.

Elena lowered the kaleidoscope. Her reflection stared back from the fountain’s surface: hair cropped short for the biopsy, cheekbones sharpened by sleeplessness, a face that looked like it had been borrowed from someone braver. The water quivered, and for a moment she saw her mother superimposed— the same wide-set eyes, the same stubborn mouth that could not pronounce surrender in any language. Her mother who had danced flamenco in the living room while chemo dripped into her port, who had laughed when the wig slipped off because laughter was the only music that didn’t require hair. Her mother who, on the last morning, had asked for the curtains to be opened so she could see the sky lie one final time.

The horizon blushed, a faint shameful pink. Elena felt the night slipping from her fingers like silk someone was yanking from the other end. She closed her fist around it anyway, the way a child holds onto the string of a balloon already rising. She knew she could not stay; daylight would drag her into its harsh arithmetic of hours and obligations. But she also knew something else, something the doctors with their scans and percentages could not calendar: the night she carried inside her was not governed by clocks. It was portable, a dark country whose citizenship could not be revoked. She could walk into dawn and still remain its citizen, could sit in fluorescent waiting rooms and feel its cool breath on her neck. It was a private eclipse, a black sunflower opening behind her ribs.

She stood, knees creaking like old wood, and tucked the kaleidoscope away. Then she did something she had not done in three weeks: she squared her shoulders toward the east. The first spear of sunlight struck the top of the cathedral, gilding the gargoyles’ tongues. It hurt to look, but she did not blink. She imagined the light as a blade, and herself stepping deliberately into the cut. Pain was just another color in the kaleidoscope, after all, another shard in the pattern that would keep shifting as long as she kept turning the barrel.

Somewhere in the city, a bakery timer dinged, an alarm clock coughed up pop music, a subway train exhaled its metallic sigh. The day was opening like a vast mouth about to speak her name. Elena took a breath, tasted copper and orange blossom and the last trace of night on her tongue, and walked forward. She did not feel brave—bravery was for people who still believed in happy endings—but she felt something gentler, a wordless truce between the woman she had been and the woman she would become by sunset. Behind her, the fountain kept whispering its same liquid sentence, the gargoyles kept their stone vigil. Inside her chest, the metronome ticked on, neither fast nor slow, simply insisting on the next note.

She held onto the night, yes, but she also let it change shape: no longer a jar to hide inside, but a cloak she wore beneath her skin, invisible to the morning crowds yet warm as blood. Daybreak spilled across the plaza, sweeping shadows into corners, and Elena walked through the middle of it, carrying her darkness gently, like a bird with folded wings. Somewhere up there, her mother was watching the same sky. Somewhere down the street, the hospital waited with its clipboard of hours. And somewhere inside, the black sunflower kept blooming, petal by petal, a quiet revolution against the tyranny of light.

samples.prompt: Politics in a fantasy world is tough to say the least.
samples.output:
Politics in a fantasy world is tough to say the least, and no one understood that better than Lady Veyra of the Hollow Spire. She had begun the week with a husband, three warlocks, and the certainty that the moon would never again turn crimson. By sunset on the third day she had lost the first, buried the second, and discovered that the third had been orchestrating both losses in order to sell the lunar omen to a foreign temple whose priests believed prophecy was a commodity like tin or saffron. The moon, naturally, had turned crimson anyway, and the priests were demanding a refund.

Veyra stood on the balcony of what had once been her husband’s observatory, watching the copper disc slide behind the jagged ridge that the cartographers politely called the World’s Teeth. The ridge was actually the fossilized vertebrae of a sky-giant who had tried to invade the planet in the days before gravity was fully codified. When the gods nailed him to the firmament, his spine froze into mountain range and his ribs became the passes through which every army, missionary, and tax collector now had to march. Geography itself was a political actor; the giant’s ghost still groaned whenever tariffs rose, and the passes would slam shut like jaws if too many contradictory edicts were issued at once. The Council of Nine kept a cleric on duty just to read legislation aloud and monitor the tectonic grumbling.

She had come to power precisely because everyone assumed a woman who spoke to lichens could not scheme. Lichens, however, are the most meticulous chroniclers of atmospheric betrayal: they absorb whatever drifts past—promises, poisons, wedding vows—and metabolize it into color. Veyra had only to press her ear to a wall to learn which courtiers had breathed treachery in the night. The problem was that lichens also gossip. By the time she identified the warlock who had traded her husband’s life for a crate of starlight, the story had already been rewritten into a ballad in which she murdered the king herself to avenge a slight no one could name. The ballad had twelve verses and a dance. She had seen it performed in the market square while she was trying to arrange the funeral.

Fantasy politics is governed less by precedent than by mythology. Every statute must be ratified by at least three metaphors and a seasonal storm. When Veyra proposed a regency council, the law insisted she convene a thunderstorm and persuade it to sign in lightning. The storm, offended by her presumption, instead endorsed her fourteen-year-old cousin who could not yet grow a beard but had once been bitten by a dragon and therefore counted as a blood relative of the weather. The cousin immediately declared war on the concept of debt, which meant the treasury was dissolved into a flock of ravens that would only roost on the heads of creditors. The economy contracted to a single anxious pigeon that kept trying to pay for things with feathers.

Alliances, too, are literal. The Dwarf-Lords of the Rift had signed a non-aggression pact etched on the husk of a colossal beetle; when the beetle molted, the pact was void. Unfortunately, the beetle had molted in the middle of the coronation banquet, shedding not only carapace but the entire clause about mutual defense. The dwarves interpreted this as divine permission to invade, and they arrived with siege-worms that could taste weakness in stone. Veyra’s castle had been grown rather than built—an enormous pumpkin coaxed by centuries of enchantment into battlements and ballrooms—and the worms adored it. They began with the east tower, which still contained the nursery. The wet-nurse escaped with the heir strapped to her back and a cookbook under her arm; she would later publish a bestselling volume on how to puree siege-worm into teething biscuits.

To negotiate, Veyra had to descend into the Rift itself, a canyon so deep that the river at the bottom had forgotten the sky and now flowed upward in protest. The dwarves did not want gold; they wanted narrative satisfaction. Their founding myth claimed that every thousand years a surface queen must descend and lose a game of riddles, thereby justifying their monopoly on iron. Refusal would unravel their entire society, turning every axe into rust and every beard into ash. Veyra considered letting them lose—she had a minor in riddles from the University inside the Hollow Spire—but the university had been annexed by the same temple that was suing her over the moon. Its faculty had been turned into owls and could only answer in questions that ended with a shriek. She could not afford to gamble.

Instead, she rewrote the myth mid-game. While the dwarf-king recited the ancient riddle—“What is the weight of yesterday?”—she plucked a strand of her own hair, sang it into a harpstring, and played the memory of her husband laughing at a joke no one else understood. The sound condensed into a silver scale that balanced perfectly on the dwarf’s palm. Yesterday, she declared, weighs exactly one moment of unwitnessed joy. The myth, embarrassed by its own sentimentality, conceded defeat. The dwarves surrendered their iron, but insisted she take it in the form of a crown that would slowly rust into a map of every future betrayal. She wore it out of the canyon; by the time she reached the surface, the rust had outlined the face of the surviving warlock.

Back home, the temple had occupied the palace courtyard and was holding the moon hostage inside a portable reliquary shaped like a birdcage. The high priest argued that since the crimson phase had occurred three heartbeats ahead of schedule, Veyra owed them compound interest in miracles. She offered them the pigeon that had survived the economy; they demanded instead the tongue of the court bard who had first rhymed “treasury” with “pleasury.” The bard, ever the professional, had already rhymed his own name with “abscond” and fled eastward with the heir and the wet-nurse. Veyra was left with a courtyard full of pilgrims, a moon in a cage, and a crown that itched with prophecy.

She solved all three problems by declaring politics itself a temporary measure. Addressing the crowd from the pumpkin ramparts, she announced that the kingdom would be governed for one year by pure symbolism. Every decree would be enacted only in dream; every tax would be paid in insomnia; every war would be fought by shadows on the nursery wall. The temple protested that dreams could not be audited, but she pointed out that their own scriptures claimed the world was the dream of a sleeping god who rolled over every epoch. If the cosmos itself was insolvent, then solvency was a fiction more absurd than mercy. The pilgrims, delighted to be declared fictional, volunteered to become the kingdom’s first bureaucratic lucid dreamers. They fell asleep on the spot; the moon, startled by the snoring, slipped its cage and returned to the sky, blushing so hard it stayed crimson for three extra nights out of embarrassment.

When the year ended, the kingdom had neither expanded nor collapsed. It had simply become difficult to locate on maps that refused to nap. Travelers would stumble across it while lost, enjoy a week of visionary legislation, and wake up at home with improved posture. Veyra ruled from the Hollow Spire, which had grown a second balcony shaped like an ear so that the lichens could eavesdrop more efficiently. The cousin who commanded storms had learned to shave and to forgive debt in moderation; the dwarves sent yearly tribute of iron lullabies; the siege-worms had pupated into librarians that catalogued every unspoken wish. The bard returned, tongue intact, with a new ballad in which Veyra did none of the things she had done and all of the things she wished. The heir learned to read by tracing rust across the crown, and the wet-nurse opened a restaurant where every dish tasted like the moment before you realize you are loved.

Politics in a fantasy world is tough, but it is also permeable. Treaties can be sung, betrayals can be composted, and even the dead sometimes vote—especially if the moon owes them a favor. Lady Veyra never again tried to control prophecy; instead she kept a calendar made of salt. On nights when the rust whispered too loudly, she would walk the balcony, crumbling a grain for every lie she had told the day. The lichens recorded each crystal’s fall and adjusted their colors accordingly. Over time the walls of the Hollow Spire became a living portrait of governance: not the story of who won, but the slower, quieter account of what was forgiven.

samples.prompt: You're watching a horror movie with only one other man in the theater. To your annoyance he begins to yell things at the characters on screen. Surprisingly, they listen.
samples.output:
I picked the last showing of *The Orchard* because I wanted to be alone. Not the noble, Thoreau-kind of alone, just the please-don’t-sit-next-to-me kind. When I stepped into auditorium 6 at 11:05 p.m., the carpet smelled like burnt popcorn and the air was set to meat-locker. Perfect. I took the exact middle of the center row, put my coat on the seat to my left, and glared at the empty aisle as if to warn the rest of humanity away. Then the other man arrived.

He looked like someone had shaved a bear and put it in a windbreaker. Six-five, easy, with a beard so thick it had its own weather system. He carried a tray of nachos that dripped like a broken faucet and a 54-ounce soda that required two hands. I pretended to be fascinated by the pre-show trivia. He lumbered past, paused, and—of course—chose the seat directly in front of me. The stadium seating was steep enough that his head became a lunar eclipse of the screen.
