Children born after the last battle play a game called “Shadow-Tag,” in which the one who is “it” must catch the others only by stepping on their silhouettes beneath the streetlamps. They do not know that the shadow they chase was once my name.

Behind me, the mirror of black glass catches my reflection. I study the woman there: hair braided with river-pearls, eyes ringed by exhaustion softer than kohl, mouth neither smiling nor grim. I look like a midwife, or perhaps a librarian. I look nothing like the stories they used to tell in which I wore thunder for a cloak and drank the marrow of heroes. Sometimes I miss that woman. She was easier to recognize.

A third petitioner knocks. This one I have been expecting. I smell cedar and myrrh before the door opens; only one person still anoints himself with the sacred oils of the dead Pantheon. When he enters, the torches shiver as though the air itself remembers his sword.

Dorian Canes-for-Crowns, the last king of the free cities, drops his scepter at my feet. The gold rod clatters, rolls, stops against my bare toe. He is older, beard silvered, shoulders curved like broken wings. During the war he wore white; tonight he is dressed in sackcloth the color of grave dirt. His eyes meet mine without flinching, and I see in them the same exhaustion that lives in my own.

“I come to abdicate,” he says, voice steady. “Not a throne—you already dissolved those—but the last fiction I carried: that I was right.”

I step down from the balcony into the lamplight. We circle each other like twin moons uncertain whether to eclipse or embrace. I remember the night he almost killed me, how his blade kissed the hollow of my throat and paused because the storm I summoned rattled his faith. I remember the morning I could have killed him, yet stayed my hand when his standard-bearer, a boy of fourteen, threw down his banner and wept. We have been each other’s mirror for so long that I can read the cracks in his heart as though they were my own.

“Dorian,” I say, “there is no parchment large enough to contain the confession of a man who convinced thousands to die for a mistake. If you seek absolution, you must wear it like the city wears its walls—quietly, daily, in the background of other people’s lives.”

He nods, understanding flooding him the way sunrise floods a battlefield after the corpses are buried. He asks for a job in the orchards beyond the river, where exiles from both sides now graft apple to pear to quince, creating fruit that has no name. I grant it. He kneels, but I lift him up. We are too old for posture; let the young carry the weight of symbolism.

When he leaves, the hall is finally empty. I return to the balcony. Dawn bleeds into the east, painting the roofs rose and gold. Somewhere a bell rings—not for prayer, not for war, but for the beginning of a workday. The sound is plain and beautiful.

I think of the heroes I slew and those who slew themselves in the name of slaying me. I think of the living who inherited the earth we salted. Their guilt is a river that will outrun me; it will carve canyons long after my bones are quartz. Yet tonight they asked not for mercy but for usefulness, as though service were the only language left in which to speak of shame.

Perhaps that is enough. Perhaps justice is not a blade but a plow, turning the battlefield so that something unintended can grow. I am the dark goddess, and I rule a world that has discovered ordinary miracles: bread, ballots, bedtime stories. The so-called heroes are dead, and I remain, midwife to a peace neither of us imagined the night the sky burned.

Below, the city wakes. A child laughs. A census begins. An ex-king shoulders a hoe. And somewhere inside my chest, the hollow where anger lived fills with a silence so complete it might almost be called forgiveness—though I will never say the word aloud. They must find it themselves, in the space between one breath and the next, in the hush that follows the last confession of the night.

samples.prompt: My heart was beating like a drum. This was it. There was no going back.
samples.output:
My heart was beating like a drum. This was it. There was no going back.

The words looped inside my skull, louder than the surf that clawed the rocks beneath the cliff. I tasted iron—blood from where I had bitten my lip to keep from screaming at the driver who had let me out a mile short of the gate. Now the wind off the Pacific carried the smell of kelp and diesel, and every breath felt like swallowing broken glass. I pulled Dad’s old peacoat tighter, though the wool was still warm from his body the last time he’d worn it, eighteen months and three days ago. Inside the right pocket my fingers found the folded square of paper that had arrived yesterday: a single line printed in the same uneven typewriter font he used for his fishing logs—Meet me where the lighthouse quits. Midnight. Trust the tide. No signature. No area code on the envelope. Just the lighthouse stamp smudged across the seal, the same ink he’d dabbed on my forehead the night he taught me to bait a hook without flinching: “Mark of the crew,” he’d joked, “so the fish know who’s in charge.”

I had not told Mom. She still set his coffee cup upside-down in the dishwasher every night, as though the ritual could spin time backward. When I left the house she thought I was driving to San Luis to return her library books. Instead I’d pointed the Honda north on the 1, past the artichoke fields and the billboard that still promised a new housing development that never arrived, until the road narrowed to a ribbon and the only lights were the stars and the intermittent swipe of my high beams cutting through fog thick as quilt batting. I kept the radio off. Any song would have been a trespass.

The lighthouse loomed ahead, a chalk stroke against the moonless sky. Point Alaric had been decommissioned the year I turned ten, its Fresnel lens removed, its lantern room sealed like a mouth that had forgotten how to warn. We used to picnic here before the state put up chain-link. Dad would lift me onto his shoulders so I could see the rusted catwalk where keepers once scraped ice off the glass. “Heroes in wool coats,” he told me, “keeping the dark from swallowing ships.” Tonight the gate hung open, the padlock dangling like a broken finger. Someone had clipped it. The same someone, maybe, who had typed the note.

I stepped through and the gravel path crunched too loud, as though the ground itself resented the intrusion. My phone showed 11:57. Three minutes. I imagined the scenarios the way you rehearse a fire drill: Dad alive but amnesiac, living under another name; Dad kidnapped by the government for knowing too much about the illegal gill-netting he’d documented; Dad dead and this a cruel prank by the deckhand who’d survived the capsizing. Each version felt equally impossible. What felt real was the weight of the peacoat and the percussion in my chest—boom ba-boom—like when I used to hide inside his tackle box and jump out while he pretended to be startled.

The tower door stood ajar. Inside, the spiral staircase smelled of guano and wet stone. I climbed, hand skimming the rail where flakes of paint came off like scabs. At the top, the lantern room was dark, but the windows had been shattered, so the sky poured in. A figure stood with his back to me, silhouette against the horizon where the Milky Way curved like a backbone. He wore a watch cap low over his ears. The shoulders were narrower than memory, but the stance—weight on the left hip, right toe tapping—was a signature I’d traced since childhood.

I opened my mouth and found no air, only the drumbeat. He turned.

Not Dad. A woman. Late thirties maybe, eyes wide as harbor buoys. For a second we stared, two trespassers measuring the other’s threat level. Then she raised a hand, palm out, the universal sign for I’m unarmed or maybe don’t speak. She pointed down, through the broken glass, to the base of the cliff where the tide gnawed the rocks. A skiff bobbed in the surge, painted the same chipped green as Dad’s first boat, the one he’d named after me—*Lena Ray*. My knees buckled.

She must have seen the recognition, because she whispered, “He said you’d come.” Her voice cracked on the last consonant, as though the word were a fishbone. She pulled something from her jacket: a cassette tape, the old Maxell kind Dad used to record sea shanties he pretended to hate. My hand shook so badly I almost dropped it. She gestured to the battery-powered deck at her feet, a relic that looked stolen from a museum. I slid the tape in and pressed play.

Static, then the scrape of a chair, then breathing—his breathing, the way it whistled slightly through the left nostril he’d broken in a bar fight before I was born. A pause, long enough for my heart to reach the downbeat of a new measure. Then his voice, gravel and salt: “Lena Ray, if you’re hearing this, the plan worked.” Another pause, shorter. “I couldn’t let them find me. They would have used me to get to you.” I clutched the railing; rust bit my palm. “The boat’s yours now. The coordinates are in the tackle box under the seat. You’ll need a crew. Marisol knows the route.”

I looked at the woman—Marisol—who had tears striping her cheeks. She mouthed, “Keep listening.”

“I faked the accident because the company was dumping chemicals off the Farallones. I documented it, but they found out. I thought I could testify, but the night before the hearing they torched our dock. Killed the harbor cat. Left a note on your mom’s windshield: *We know where she sleeps.* I couldn’t—” His voice broke, something I’d never heard, not even when Grandma died. “I’m alive, kiddo. But I’m gone. If you come looking, they’ll know. They’ll hurt you to flush me out. So this is the only way. Take the boat. Sell it or sail it, but don’t follow the trail. Live the life I kept you from by being stupid.”

The tape hissed into silence. Marisol stopped the deck. Wind howled through the empty frames, a choir of ghosts. I wanted to smash the cassette, wanted to rewind and hear him say my name again, wanted to scream that I would trade every sunrise for one more day of him being merely a coward instead of a martyr. Instead I asked, “Why you?”

She wiped her face with the heel of her hand. “I was the deckhand who testified. Your dad stayed hidden, funneled me evidence. We thought it would end there, but they appealed. New judge. New threats. He sent me to make sure you got the boat, to keep you moving so they can’t pin you down. He’s on a container ship heading for Perth. Crew manifest lists him as deceased.” She reached into her pocket again and produced a second item: the silver captain’s whistle he used to summon me home for dinner. She pressed it into my palm. The metal was cold, but it warmed instantly, as though it remembered my skin.

Below, the surf exploded against the rocks, sending spray high enough to mist my face. I tasted salt and the bitter iron of secrets. I could go home, return Mom’s library books, enroll in community college, pretend the tape was a hoax. Or I could climb down the cliff, start the engine of the *Lena Ray*, and vanish into the same horizon that had swallowed him. The drum in my chest accelerated, not panic now but marching orders. Dad’s final gift was not the boat or the coordinates; it was the beat itself, the permission to disappear.

Marisol watched me, eyes reflecting the white foam. I lifted the whistle to my lips but didn’t blow. Instead I tucked it deep inside the peacoat pocket, next to the note that had brought me here. Then I started down the stairs. She followed. At the base of the cliff the skiff knocked against the landing like an impatient dog. I untied the rope, hands steady for the first time since I’d read the typed line. The engine coughed once, twice, then caught, vibrating up through the hull into my bones until the rhythm matched the drum in my chest. Marisol climbed aboard and took the tiller without asking. I didn’t look back at the lighthouse. There was no going back. Only forward, into the dark that had once swallowed ships and now swallowed names, into the trough between waves where the horizon is a rumor and the only truth is motion.

samples.prompt: Guardian Demon (Details inside)
samples.output:
The first time I met the thing that would become my guardian, I was eight years old and busy dying.  
My mother had left the stove on again, the way she always did when she was trying to remember how to breathe through the grief of my father’s absence. I had gone to the kitchen for a glass of water, and the burner’s blue halo had already begun to chew the wallpaper. By the time I smelled the smoke, the fire had crept up the cabinets like ivy. I remember the heat peeling the paint on the ceiling, the way the linoleum curled like a dying leaf. I remember the sound of the smoke alarm choking on its own batteries.  

And I remember the hand that reached through the flames.  

It was not a human hand. The nails were black, curved like sickle moons, and the skin was the color of old parchment stretched too tight. The arm it belonged to was scaled, not reptilian but mineral, as if someone had carved obsidian into sinew. Where it touched me, the fire retreated—not extinguished, but afraid. I think that was the moment I should have screamed. Instead, I reached back.  

When I woke on the front lawn, the paramedics said I’d been carried out by a neighbor, a woman no one could later name. My mother sobbed into my hair, smelling of ash and cheap merlot. The house was a skeleton, but I was whole, save for a bruise around my wrist shaped like four long fingers and a thumb.  

I didn’t see my guardian again for nine years.  

Adolescence replaced the memory with the usual clutter: tests I didn’t study for, mouths I didn’t kiss, nights I spent scrubbing my mother’s vomit from the bathroom tiles. The bruise faded to a faint constellation of freckles. I told myself the fire had cooked my imagination along with the cupboards.  

Then came the night in the underpass.  

I was seventeen and too drunk on peach schnapps and self-pity to notice the two men who followed me off the bus. The underpass was lit by a single bulb that flickered Morse code against the concrete. One of them called me sweetheart; the other didn’t bother with words. I remember the knife, small and silver, like something you’d use to core an apple. I remember thinking, absurdly, that I’d never finished reading The Hobbit, and now I never would.  

The bulb burst.  

Not popped—burst, showering us in glass that turned to frost before it hit the ground. The temperature plummeted so fast my breath crystallized. The man with the knife looked down and saw his shoes welded to the pavement by a film of black ice. The other tried to run. A shadow peeled itself off the wall and stepped into the world.  

It was taller than I remembered, seven feet at least, but hunched like a gargoyle that had grown weary of its perch. The same obsidian skin, shot through now with veins of molten gold that pulsed like heartbeats. Its face was almost human: high cheekbones, a mouth too wide, eyes the color of cooling embers. When it inhaled, the graffiti on the walls bled away, leaving the concrete raw.  

The man with the knife started to cry.  

The demon didn’t touch him. It simply looked, and the silver blade dulled to rust in his shaking hand. The ice crawled up their legs, slow as moss, until both men knelt like penitents. I waited for screams, but the only sound was my own ragged breathing.  

“Choose,” the demon said. Its voice was church bells submerged in tar.  

I thought it was speaking to them. They must have thought so too; they whimpered apologies, promises, bargains. But the demon’s gaze was fixed on me.  

“Choose,” it said again. “Shall I remember them, or shall I forget?”  

I understood then: the price of rescue was mine to name, not his. I could have asked for anything—broken bones, blood, a slow carving of flesh to match the fear they’d carved in me. Instead, I said the stupidest thing imaginable.  

“Let them go. Please.”  

The demon tilted its head, curious as a crow. “Mercy?”  

“They’re not worth remembering.”  

It smiled. The expression cracked its face like porcelain. The men vanished—no flash, no ash, just gone, leaving their shadows burned into the concrete like Hiroshima silhouettes.  

The demon turned to me. “You have grown thin,” it said, and touched my cheek with a claw that should have sliced skin but only left warmth. “You should have called sooner.”  

I hadn’t called at all. But I didn’t argue.  

After that, I saw it everywhere: perched on the water tower behind the high school, reflected in the dark of my bedroom window, once in the rearview mirror of my mother’s car the day she finally checked into rehab. It never spoke unless I was in danger, and danger, it seemed, had become elastic. A drunk stepfather’s raised fist warranted no intervention; a would-be rapist did. A tumor growing quietly in my mother’s breast—ignored. A car running a red light as I stepped off the curb—halted mid-air, tires spinning uselessly above the asphalt.  

I began to test the boundaries. I walked alone through the park at 3 a.m.; it followed at a distance, wings folded tight against its back, patient as starlight. I picked fights with boys twice my size; bruises bloomed on my knuckles, never on my ribs. I swallowed pills once, a childish handful of cold medicine and aspirin, and woke to find the bottle empty but for a single black feather inside, smelling of brimstone and lavender.  

I asked its name once. It said names were for things that could be bound.  

“What are you, then?” I pressed.  

“A guardian,” it said. “And a demon. The two are not mutually exclusive.”  

I learned the rules slowly. It could not prevent self-destruction, only external harm. It could not stay if I asked it to leave, but it would count that as a second favor, and favors accrued interest. It could not love—demons were not built for that—but it could remember, and memory, for creatures like it, was a form of devotion.  

My mother died anyway. Not the cancer—that went into remission, inexplicably—but a drunk driver on the highway three years later. The demon stood beside me at the funeral, unseen by the other mourners, its shadow pooling across the grave like spilled wine. I didn’t cry. I’d used up the last of my tears the night she’d told me, slurring, that she wished the fire had taken me instead of the house.  

“Do you want vengeance?” the demon asked.  

I thought of the driver, already sentenced, already remorseful. I thought of my mother’s mouth, sour with Chardonnay and regret.  

“No,” I said. “I want to go home.”  

Home was a studio apartment with leaky faucets and a neighbor who played death metal at dawn. The demon filled too much of it, wings brushing the popcorn ceiling, gold veins glowing softly. It looked out of place among my thrift-store plates and secondhand grief.  

“You’re lonely,” it observed.  

I laughed, brittle as old ice. “You’re one to talk.”  

It considered this. “I was never alone until I met you.”  

We made a pact then, the kind sealed not with blood but with the quieter currency of need. It would stay—not as a servant, but as a companion. I would not ask it to leave. In exchange, it would teach me what memory truly cost.  

Years passed. I became a librarian, fitting my life into the quiet architecture of shelves and overdue notices. Patrons sometimes remarked on the chill in the air when they lingered too long in the occult section, but I told them the building was old, the insulation poor. The demon read over my shoulder, whispering Latin etymologies and the true names of storms. At night, we played chess with pieces carved from bone and volcanic glass. It let me win exactly once.  

I aged. It did not.  

The first gray hair appeared at thirty-six. By fifty, my hands shook when I shelved books above my head. The demon watched with the patience of stone.  

“You could ask,” it said softly. “Not for immortality—such bargains are vulgar. But time could be bent. A decade, perhaps two.”  

I thought of the faces in the underpass, the rust on the knife. I thought of my mother’s coffin, lowered by strangers because I had no other family.  

“No,” I said. “Memory is only weight if you refuse to carry it.”  

So we waited.  

The stroke came at sixty-one. I lay on the kitchen floor, cheek against cool linoleum, watching the ceiling blur. The demon appeared, already too large for the room, its wings scraping plaster.  

“Choose,” it said, voice gentle now, almost human.  

I tried to speak, but my mouth was full of thunder.  

“Shall I take you with me?” it asked. “Or shall I stay until the end?”  

I thought of all the years it had guarded me, not from death but from meaninglessness. I thought of the way it tilted its head when I laughed, as if laughter were a language it had forgotten it knew.  

I lifted one hand. It took my fingers in its clawed ones, careful as ever.  

“Stay,” I managed.  

So it did.  

When they found me, the coroner noted the peculiar frost on the windows in midsummer, the scent of brimstone and lavender lingering like a benediction. My body lay peaceful, fingers intertwined with nothing visible, but the bruise on my wrist—four fingers and a thumb—had returned, dark and tender as the day we met.  

Somewhere, in a library no one’s catalogued, a book waits on a shelf. Its pages are warm to the touch. If you open it, you’ll find no words, only shadows pressed like flowers. Hold it to your ear, and you might hear church bells submerged in tar, whispering:  

Mercy is the only prayer a demon understands.

samples.prompt: The Chosen One was a sacrifice, so that the gods wouldn't have to get their hands dirty.
samples.output:
The Chosen One was a sacrifice, so that the gods wouldn’t have to get their hands dirty.  
That sentence was never written in the scrolls the priests flourished before the crowd. Instead they spoke of destiny, of a soul “touched by starlight,” of a boy who would “bend the river of fate.” They omitted the fine print scratched on the bronze tablet kept in the inner sanctum: “One life to be offered in lieu of divine labor.” I know, because I was the boy, and because I broke into the sanctum the night before my vigil. I was fifteen, still vain enough to believe the dreams they fed me, but curious enough to want the footnotes. When I read the tablet I felt the way a chicken must feel when the farmer’s shadow falls across the yard: suddenly aware of the axe.

My mother had dressed me in white linen and wept as though I were already a ghost. The whole village lined the road, scattering petals that smelled like copper coins. I walked barefoot so the elders could study the soles of my feet for auspicious calluses. Every step was a rehearsal for the last one. At the temple gate the high priest pressed his thumb between my eyes, leaving a print of sacred ash that felt cold as a coin of lead. “You will be clothed in glory,” he whispered. I tasted the lie. Glory was a shroud.

Inside, the gods waited, but not in the way children imagine—no thrones of marble, no benign radiance. They waited the way a storm waits inside a cloud: huge, invisible, crackling with appetites they had no intention of sating themselves. Their names were carved on pillars ringing the sanctuary: Veyru, Lord of Thresholds; Astaleth, Mother of Unfinished Stories; Ukad, the Knife that Cuts Backwards. The carvings were only shorthand. The gods themselves were everywhere, like humidity. I felt them fingering the seam between my thoughts, tasting the salt of my fear. I understood then that they were lazy, or perhaps economical. Why smite a nation when you can delegate?

The ritual lasted seven days. Each dawn they painted a new sigil on my chest with molten beeswax that cooled into a bruise-colored scab. At dusk they fed me sherbet made from lotus and poppy so my dreams would belong to them. Between shifts I was displayed on a balcony so the pilgrims could shout questions: “Will the drought end?” “Will my daughter walk again?” I answered the way the priests coached me: “The gods hear you.” I might as well have been a hollow gourd rattling in the wind. At night I listened to the bronze tablet clink inside my head: One life in lieu of divine labor.

On the seventh night they marched me to the Pit, a natural crater the width of a marketplace, its sides terraced like an amphitheater. Torches were stabbed into the slopes so the whole town could watch. The priests chanted in Old Vernacular, a language no living person spoke fluently, but which every toddler learns to recognize as the tongue that steals toys and parents. I stood at the lip wearing nothing except a belt of gold bells that tinkled whenever I trembled. Below, the darkness rustled. Something down there breathed in four-four time, the same rhythm as the funeral drums. The gods, I realized, had outsourced even their monstrosity.

The high priest lifted a stone bowl that held my heart’s blood—already drawn drop by drop during the week and thickened with myrrh. He tipped it into the Pit. The darkness licked. Then he turned to me, palms raised like a merchant concluding a bargain. “Descend,” he said, “and the world continues.” The bargain was never mine to refuse, but he pretended I had a choice the way a hangman offers the condemned a final proverb. I looked at the faces flickering in torchlight: my mother wedged between two soldiers, her mouth open as if singing a lullaby she had forgotten the words to; the baker who once slipped me honey-cakes, now counting coins against his thigh; the children who used to follow me shouting “Star-boy!” now silent, learning early that stories require bodies.

I stepped forward. The bells chimed like tiny scythes. The first stair was stone, the second wood, the third bone. After that the darkness swallowed detail. I descended until the torchlight above looked like a memory of sky. The breathing thing below resolved into a shape that hurt to perceive: a lattice of mouths opening sideways, wings made of eyelids, claws that grew and retracted like cat’s cradle string. It was starving, but politely so—it would not touch me until I offered the sign. That was protocol. Gods love protocol; it spares them improvisation.

I felt the bruised sigils on my chest begin to itch, then burn. The gods were branding me from a distance, heating the wax scars like cookplates. I realized they were remotely unlocking the door they had built inside my ribs. When the last sigil split open, the thing in the dark would feed on what tumbled out: my future, my possible children, the songs I might have composed, the apologies I owed. All of it would be hors d’oeuvre for cosmic entities too refined to dirty their own table linens.

I sat on the final stair and considered the geometry of escape. The Pit was a cone; sound took eight seconds to echo; the creature’s breathing paused every fourth measure. I untied the gold bells and arranged them in a circle. When I clapped once, they answered in twelve different tones, a chord that confused the darkness. The thing hesitated, mouths closing like flowers at dusk. In that gap I spoke—not a prayer (prayers are outbound invoices) but a proposition. I offered the gods a different labor: instead of devouring my unlived years, the creature would serve as my witness. I would walk back up carrying the darkness on my back, a portable abyss. The world would continue, yes, but the gods would lose their scapegoat. They would have to attend the harvest failures, the plagues, the wars, in person. No more middle management.

The creature listened. Gods, I learned, are allergic to boredom; they will gamble their reputations on a twist. It folded itself into the shape of a cloak and settled across my shoulders, weightless as debt. I climbed the stairs. At the rim the priests waited, faces rehearsed for triumph. When they saw the living night rippling behind me, their expressions liquefied. I stepped past them. The first person I encountered was my mother; she flinched, then touched the hem of the darkness and laughed—an involuntary sound like water finding a crack in a pot. The darkness remembered her lullabies and hummed them back, harmonizing with her heartbeat. Word spread that the Chosen One had returned uncannily alive. Pilgrims came, but instead of asking about rain or lame legs they asked, “What did you see?” I told them the truth: “The gods are lazy. Withhold your petitions and they will come knocking like debt collectors.” Some threw stones; others brought offerings of bread and wine, hoping to bribe the abyss. The darkness drank everything and remained hungry, but it no longer fed on futures—it fed on attention.

Seasons turned. The crops failed anyway, and this time the priests could not point at the Pit and claim the sacrifice was insufficient. Farmers saw the gods trudging through their barren fields at dawn, ankles caked with dirt, trying to remember how germination worked. They looked smaller in terrestrial gravity, their omnipotence shrinking like wet wool. Veyru twisted his ankle on a clod; Astaleth complained of sunburn; Ukad cut himself harvesting wheat and had to borrow a rag. Children followed them throwing not flowers but questions: “Why did you let the locusts come?” “Why did you take my brother?” The gods answered with the stunned silence of landlords confronted by tenants who have read the lease.

I live now at the edge of the same crater, its terraces overgrown with wild barley. The darkness on my shoulders has learned the shape of a coat, buttoning itself with stars. At night we sit by the rim and listen to the wind argue with the reeds. Sometimes travelers arrive, hoping for miracle or condemnation. I offer them soup and stories. The soup is ordinary lentils; the stories vary, but each ends with the same warning: When the gods choose you, ask what they are avoiding. Refuse the first bargain; they already have everything except inconvenience. The Chosen One was a sacrifice, yes, but sacrifice is a verb that can be conjugated differently. I chose to walk back up the stairs, carrying the dirty work with me. The gods, deprived of a clean victim, must now soil their own hands. They hate it; they are terrible at being human. But they are learning, slowly, the labor they outsourced to death. And I, no longer the Chosen, am merely the Chooser—one who decided that destiny tastes better when bitten back.

samples.prompt: You gain the power to freeze and bend time at will, under one condition, you can only do it when nobody is watching. One problem, you can never seem to freeze time.
samples.output:
The first time I tried to stop the world, I was alone in the laundromat on 14th and Mercer, watching my socks slog through the final rinse cycle. The fluorescent lights hummed like a swarm of dying bees, and the clock above the change machine said 11:47 p.m.—twelve minutes later than the last time I checked. I closed my eyes, pressed my palms together the way the old man at the bus stop had demonstrated, and whispered the word he had carved into the inside of my wrist with a fountain pen: “Stillness.”

Nothing happened. The machines kept sloshing, the second hand kept stuttering forward, and somewhere behind the wall a quarter dropped with a metallic clink. I opened my eyes, half expecting to see the world wrapped in glass, but the only thing frozen was the expression on my own face—stupid, hopeful, ridiculous. I felt the weight of invisible eyes, as if the universe had crowded into the linty corners of the room to laugh at me. I spun around, heart kicking, but the only witness was my reflection in the porthole of the washer, distorted by soap foam and my own disappointment.

The old man had warned me: the power only answers when no one is watching, not even God. I hadn’t believed in God for years, but I believed in surveillance cameras, in the bored attendant half-dozing behind the bulletproof Plexiglas, in the homeless guy who sometimes came in to warm his hands. That night I went home with cold, wet laundry in a trash bag and the conviction that the condition was impossible. In a city of eight million, someone is always watching. A satellite, a neighbor, a ghost.

Still, I kept trying. I rehearsed in bathroom stalls, in elevator cars between floors, in the windowless storage closet at work where they kept the paper towels. I learned the blind spots of every convenience store, the angles the security cameras couldn’t swallow. I wore hoodies and baseball caps, kept my head down, timed my errands for 3:00 a.m. when even the insomniacs had finally surrendered to pills. Each time I whispered “Stillness,” I felt the word travel down my arms like a shiver, but the world refused to buckle. Somewhere, I was sure, a lens glinted, a retina caught the light, a memory formed. The power stayed stubbornly dormant, a joke I was telling only myself.

After a month I started keeping a notebook: locations, times, duration of solitude, heart rate before and after. I drew maps of my apartment, marking the exact spot where the Wi-Fi camera on my laptop couldn’t see—three inches to the left of the hinge, if I crouched low. I unplugged the microwave, black-taped the smoke detector, threw a blanket over the parakeet I’d bought for company because I read birds can perceive time differently. I sat cross-legged on the carpet, surrounded by a ring of salt the internet said would break any scrying spell, and I begged the empty air: Just one second. Let me see what paused rain looks like hanging like beads from a broken necklace. Let me touch a hummingbird mid-hover. Let me walk through a motionless city and finally understand what it means to be alone without being watched.

Nothing. The parakeet blinked. The refrigerator hummed. My phone buzzed with a spam text: Time is running out! Apply now!

I began to hate eyes. Not the people who owned them, just the fact of being perceived. I quit my job when I realized the open-plan office was a panopticon of sideways glances. I stopped dating because affection felt like surveillance with a prettier name. I walked backwards through subway turnstiles so the facial-recognition cameras caught only the blur of my hood. I dreamed of glaciers calving in slow motion, of clocks dripping like Dali’s, and woke up gasping with the certainty that someone, somewhere, had blinked a fraction too late and seen me mid-transgression.

One night in February I hit bottom. I had been roaming the city for hours, slipping through alleys, ducking into unlocked churches, chasing the illusion of perfect solitude. At 4:12 a.m. I found myself on the pedestrian walkway of the bridge that split the river like a scar. The air was knife-cold, the kind that makes teeth feel like foreign objects. No cars, no joggers, no barges underneath. Even the moon had ducked behind a cloud. I gripped the railing, counted to three, and said the word. My breath plumed and vanished. The river kept sliding. A single drop of meltwater fell from a cable and shattered on the grate at my feet. I screamed—an ugly, ragged thing that startled a pigeon into flight. In the echo I heard the truth I had been dodging: the condition wasn’t external; it was me. I was always watching myself.

You can’t freeze time while you’re standing guard over your own shoulder. The old man had told me that too, but I’d misheard it as metaphor. I thought he meant paranoia, self-consciousness, the social gaze internalized. What he meant was simpler and crueller: the power requires total surrender, the kind of absence even suicide can’t guarantee because the mind keeps narrating right up to the last synapse. To stop the world, you have to vanish from yourself. You have to forget you exist.

Try forgetting yourself on a bridge at dawn when your fingers are freezing to the rail and your heart is a trapped animal throwing itself against the bars of your ribs. Try un-remembering every shame, every name, every story you ever told about who you are. I closed my eyes and pictured the river reversing, the city folding into itself like a paper crane, the sky rolling up like a shade. I pictured my own face dissolving the way a reflection disappears when the water stills. I pictured nothing, and for a breath I was nothing, and the world went—


—not silent, that’s too dramatic. Silence is a sound. It went blank, the way a screen goes when the movie ends and the projector keeps humming for a second before someone hits the switch. Then it snapped back so hard my knees buckled. I was on my back, staring at the sky, and the first blush of sunrise was staining the clouds pink. I had done it. A fraction of a second, maybe less. But I had done it, and no one had seen, not even me.

I lay there laughing and crying and hiccupping until a cyclist appeared on the far side of the bridge, legs pumping like pistons, earbuds glowing neon. He didn’t notice me. I was just another piece of urban debris. I stood up, brushed grit from my coat, and started walking. The power was real, but it was useless in the way the most precious things are useless: a seashell you can’t hear the ocean in unless you hold your breath until you almost die, a love letter you can’t reread because it burns your eyes.

I still try, sometimes, when the apartment is dark and the parakeet sleeps under its little hood. I sit on the floor, let my thoughts drift like loose change in a pocket, and wait for the moment when I forget whose pocket it is. Occasionally the lamp flickers, or the air feels suddenly thick, as if the molecules have decided to take a short break from their endless jitter. I never know whether I succeeded or only dreamed I did. The notebook gathers dust in a drawer; I stopped mapping blind spots. The condition was never about other eyes. It was about the impossibility of witnessing your own absence, the paradox of being present enough to trigger a power that erases presence. The old man is gone—died on a bench in the park last winter, the obituary said, peacefully, whatever that means. I think of him whenever the washer hits the rinse cycle, whenever the city hushes for a heartbeat and I feel the word “Stillness” rise in my throat like a bubble I can’t swallow. I let the moment pass. Someone is always watching, and that someone is me, and that is exactly how the world keeps spinning, sock after sock, second after second, a miracle no one will ever see.

samples.prompt: You are a chess grandmaster. You aren't particularly good at chess, but you can read minds, allowing you to know your opponents strategy, as well as the best way to counter it. Your next opponent does the same thing.
samples.output:
I have never been the best at chess. My openings are textbook at best, my endgames sloppy, and my middle-game plans so porous that second-rate engines laugh at them. Yet the rating beside my name says 2800, the invitations keep arriving, and the trophies accumulate like dust on a windowsill. The reason is simple: I can hear thoughts the way other people hear speech. When my opponent sits down, their intentions leak into my skull like water through cracked porcelain. I do not see the future; I see the present they have not yet played. By the time their hand reaches the board, I have already lived through six variations they considered and rejected, and I simply choose the line that hurts most. It is not skill; it is eavesdropping.

Tonight the ballroom of the Hotel Krasnapolsky is chandelier-bright and thick with perfume and tension. I am paired against Viktor Lazarev, a Russian grandmaster whose rating is identical to mine but whose reputation is the opposite. Where I am called lucky, he is called inspired. Where I am accused of witchcraft, he is praised for artistry. We have never played before, yet the moment the arbiter points us to board one I feel the familiar pressure behind my eyes, the mental door cracking open. I wait for the usual torrent—French Defense, King’s Indian, some sharp poisoned pawn line—but instead I hear nothing. Not silence, but static, like a radio between stations. Viktor smiles, and the static forms itself into a single sentence that is not mine: *He can’t read me either.*

We shake hands. His palm is cool. Up close he smells of cedar and soap. The pieces are already arranged, but the game began minutes ago, when we recognized the shared deformity that no rating list can capture. We are two mirrors facing each other, reflecting nothing.

1.e4. I play it because it is what I would play if I were innocent. I wait for Viktor’s mind to offer up his reply, and receive only that same granular hiss. He answers 1…c5, and I sense the shape of the Sicilian without sensing the man choosing it. We are blindfolded in a new way: each of us accustomed to reading, now forced to guess.

2.Nf3 d6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 Nf6 5.Nc3 a6 6.Be3 e5 7.Nb3 Be6 8.f3. I rattle off the English Attack because it is what every junior plays when he wants to attack without understanding. I know the theory well enough to recite it, not well enough to believe in it. Viktor follows, and the boards around us fade; the spectators become mannequins. We are inside a tunnel carved of white and black marble, and the only sound is the click of clocks.

On move twelve I sacrifice a pawn, the thematic b-pawn, because the books say it gives long-term pressure. I do not feel the pressure; I only remember the phrase. Viktor takes, and for the first time the static parts. I catch a glimpse of color—crimson, imperial gold—and the afterimage of a cathedral dome. Then the door slams shut. He has noticed the leak and repaired it. I realize he is better at this than I am. He has practiced sealing himself the way other players practice rook endings.

I play on, pretending confidence. The pawn down becomes a piece down. I offer a second pawn, then a third, gambling that he will over-trust his extra material. This is how I beat ordinary grandmasters: I let them think they are winning, and when they relax their minds exhale the final combination. But Viktor never relaxes. He takes what I give and immediately re-armors. I hear nothing except the thud of my own heart.

By move twenty-five I am objectively lost. The engines in the commentary room will already be showing plus-four for Black. I should resign, but resignation is a public act and I cannot bear the thought of the post-mortem questions: *When did you realize you were losing? Why did you play on?* Instead I slide my king to h1, walking into a mating net because it shortens the game.

Viktor pauses, hand hovering over the queen. The room is so quiet I can hear the filament in the chandelier sing. For an instant his concentration slips—not forward, but backward, to a summer afternoon in Petersburg when he was ten and his coach told him that chess is not war but conversation. The memory is tender, unguarded, and I step inside it the way a burglar steps through an open window. I see the old coach’s face, smell the chalk dust, feel the boy-Viktor’s awe. And there, braided into the nostalgia, is the move he intends: not the brutal mate, but a quiet retreat that prolongs torture. He wants to hear me beg.

The intimacy sickens me. I retreat from the memory, but the knowledge remains: Qg7 is a lie; he will play Qf8. I can drag the game out sixty moves, maybe seventy, and lose in front of the cameras anyway. Or I can do what no mind-reader ever does: surprise myself.

I pick up my knight and plunge it to d5, offering the horse as a gift, blocking my own bishop, creating a tangle so chaotic that even an engine needs seconds to refute it. It is an absurdity, a toddler’s scrawl across a chessboard. Viktor’s head jerks up. For the first time his pupils widen. The static returns, but now it is laced with something new—fear? wonder?—I cannot tell. He reaches for the knight, withdraws, reaches again. The memory of the coach dissolves under adrenaline. He is calculating without the comfort of foresight, the way mortals do.

He takes. I recapture. He takes again. Each exchange rips away the safety net of certainty. We are two trapeze artists who have agreed the air below is bottomless. By move thirty-five the position is a kaleidoscope: six pawns on the seventh rank, both kings naked in mid-board, bishops slicing through squares that did not exist in the previous turn. The commentators have abandoned objectivity and begun to laugh. Spectators stamp their feet, not caring who wins, only that the game continues.

Somewhere in the kaleidoscope I stop listening for Viktor’s thoughts and start listening to my own. They are timid, rusted from disuse, but they speak of patterns I once loved before mind-reading made love obsolete: the geometry of squares, the whisper of wood against palm. I play 41.Kg2, walking into a discovered check, because the line is beautiful. Viktor answers with 41…Kc3, walking into a worse one. We are no longer competing; we are co-authoring a poem neither of us will ever finish.

The clock shows thirty seconds for me, forty for him. We move faster than blitz, faster than bullet, faster than thought. Pieces blur into symbols, symbols into pure sound. At some point the arbiter appears, uncertain whether to record the moves or simply watch. Viktor’s brow drips onto the board; the droplets refract the lighting into tiny rainbows. I feel laughter bubbling up my throat, the laughter of a man who has cheated at life and finally been caught, only to discover the punishment is wonder.

On move forty-seven I promote to a knight, under-promotion being the only joke left. Viktor promotes to a knight as well, and we trade horse-kicks until both armies are riderless. The position is theoretically dead, a tablebase draw, but neither of us claims it. We keep moving because the story demands an ending.

Finally, on move fifty-three, Viktor lifts his king and sets it gently on c1. It is not a legal move; it is resignation rewritten as sacrament. He extends his hand. The touch is warm now. Around us the hall erupts, but the sound is distant, filtered through cotton. We have descended beneath the world of ratings and prizes. I look into his eyes and see the same exhaustion and relief that must be in mine. We have read each other’s minds and found nothing except the shared wish to be unreadable.

Later, in the analysis room, engines will confirm that the knight sac was unsound, that either of us could have forced mate in eight. Commentators will argue about sportsmanship, about why we ignored the threefold-repetition claim. None of that matters. What matters is that for fifty-three moves we were two cheats stripped of our superpower, forced to play the way children play: for the joy of watching shapes change.

We sign the score sheets without speaking. The ink feels ceremonial, like signing a treaty after a war neither side intended. As we leave the stage, the static returns, but softer, almost companionable. I realize it will never fully leave; we will always hear the echo of each other’s minds the way amputees feel rain in a missing limb. Yet the echo is no longer a weapon. It is a reminder that the only game worth playing is the one where you do not know the ending.

Outside, Amsterdam night smells of river water and fried sugar. Viktor lingers at the curb. For a moment I think we will talk, exchange phone numbers, promise a rematch. Instead he smiles the same small smile from the board, raises two fingers to his temple in salute, and disappears into the crowd. I stand beneath the neon tulips of the hotel sign, listening to the city’s ordinary thoughts—taxis, lovers, the clink of glasses—feeling something I had forgotten how to feel: curiosity. Tomorrow I will fly home and enter another tournament, and the voices will return. But tonight the board is empty, the pieces boxed, and for the first time in years I am eager to find out what I might do if I simply let the silence speak.

samples.prompt: You dream every night of being part of a wolf pack and terrorizing villagers in the country side, every morning you wake up in your bed. One evening there's a knock at the door, a dark figure clad in a wide brimmed hat and leather trench coat stands on your door step.
samples.output:
The dreams began the winter I turned twenty-seven.  They arrived without warning or explanation, as though some unseen hand had reached inside my chest, grasped the invisible thread that keeps a soul anchored to one life, and tugged it sharply toward another.  Each night I closed my eyes and found myself running across moonlit fields, four paws striking frost-hardened earth with a rhythm that felt older than language.  My brothers and sisters ran beside me—grey, black, rust-red, snow-white—our breath steaming silver in the cold.  We moved like a single thought, turning toward the village lights that glimmered beyond the river.  When we reached the first scattered cottages we did not howl; we simply arrived, and terror arrived with us.  Doors splintered, chickens exploded upward in frantic feathers, a child screamed once before the sound was swallowed by the pack’s collective growl.  I tasted blood that was not mine, felt the jolt of bone giving way beneath my jaws, and in the dream I exulted.  I was not a man dreaming he was a wolf; I was a wolf remembering what it was to be unchained.

I always woke in the same narrow bed under the sloping attic roof.  My heart raced, my mouth tasted of copper, and for the first few seconds I could still feel the ghost-shape of claws where my fingernails ought to have been.  The room smelled of dust and old cedar.  Sunlight, or the lack of it, told me whether I was late for work at the library.  I would shower, scrubbing until my skin stung, and still the scent of pine forest clung to me like an accusation.

For months I told no one.  I catalogued books by day—children’s picture books with pastel wolves that smiled, field guides that spoke of apex predators in passionless Latin—and tried to pretend the nights were not happening.  But the dreams grew richer.  I learned the names of my packmates the way one learns the names of stars: by watching their patterns.  There was Kestrel, the white wolf who led us when the moon was thin; Ember, the russet female whose left ear was notched; Cinder, the dark wolf who ran always at my flank.  I began to suspect they knew me, too.  When I nipped at the heel of a fleeing goat, Ember turned and met my eyes with what looked unmistakably like amusement.  A dream, I told myself.  Only a dream.

The villagers changed.  At first they had been anonymous shapes in nightshirts, clutching pitchforks that trembled like reeds.  Lately they carried torches that threw long orange arms across the snow, and their faces were the faces of people I passed every day: the baker, the postman, the shy girl who shelved mysteries.  I began to dread sleep the way some men dread drowning, yet I could not stay awake forever.  Coffee turned bitter in my mouth; my reflection developed bruised circles under the eyes of a stranger.

Then came the evening in early March when the wind hammered the shutters and the old house creaked like a ship in high seas.  I had not slept for two nights running on black tea and dread.  I was sitting at the kitchen table trying to read a treatise on lycanthropy—half folklore, half psychiatric case study—when the knock came.  Not the timid tap of the paperboy collecting, nor the rhythmic pounding of the constable.  This was a single, deliberate impact, heavy as an iron mallet, that seemed to strike the door and the inside of my skull at once.

I rose without thinking, drawn by an instinct I did not know I possessed.  The hallway was dark except for the faint green glow of the porch light.  When I opened the door, the figure on the step loomed so tall I had to tilt my head back.  Hat brim wide enough to throw the face beneath it into absolute shadow, leather coat that creaked like saddle leather, scent of earth after lightning.  Where lamplight touched the coat it shone the color of dried blood.

For a long moment neither of us spoke.  Wind whipped the stranger’s coat around his calves; somewhere down the street a gate banged open and shut.  Then the figure inclined his head, courteous as an undertaker.

“You have been running with my kin,” he said.  His voice was low, roughened, as though he used it rarely.  “Night after night.  We feel you among us, paw for paw.”

My tongue stuck to the roof of my mouth.  The dreams had not prepared me for their echo in waking life.  I managed a thin whisper: “I don’t know what you mean.”

The stranger lifted one gloved hand—no, not gloved, I realized; the glove was the hand, dark and fine-furred, articulated like a man’s but unmistakably other.  He drew aside one edge of his coat, revealing a lining stitched with dozens of small silver disks.  They looked at first like coins, then like mirrors, then like full moons compressed and tamed.  In each disk I saw a reflection: a wolf with my eyes, running across a bridge; the same wolf crouched beneath a child’s window; the wolf shaking rain from its pelt while church bells tolled midnight.  My memories—if that was what they were—played out in miniature on the stranger’s coat.

“You leave tracks on two worlds,” he said.  “The villagers grow clever.  They oil their hinges, hang wolfbane.  They remember the old stories.  Soon they will follow the trail back to this house.”  He let the coat fall closed.  “I have come to give you a choice.”

I braced a hand against the doorframe.  “A choice between what?”

“Between waking and running,” he replied.  “Tonight, when the moon rises, you may stay in this body and forget the taste of snow and blood.  The dreams will fade, and you will grow old counting other men’s money, stamping due dates, whatever small rituals comfort you.  Or you may step across the threshold with me and learn to wear both skins knowingly.  Then you will run not as trespasser but as kin.  The price is simple: you will never again be entirely certain which life is the dream.”

The wind howled through the eaves like a chorus of distant wolves.  Behind me the house felt suddenly small, a paper lantern rattling in the storm.  I thought of the baker’s face streaked with fear, of the child’s scream cut short.  I thought of Ember’s eyes laughing into mine, of the perfect synchrony of the pack, heartbeats aligned like rifle shots.  I smelled pine resin, heard the river ice crack beneath eight sets of paws, felt the surge of impossible strength as we leapt a stone wall three times the height of a man.

“How much time do I have?” I asked.

The stranger tilted his head, as though consulting some invisible clock.  “The moon clears the ridge in twenty minutes.  When it does, the door between worlds will narrow to a hairline.  Decide.”

He stepped back, melting into the shadow beyond the porch light, but I sensed him waiting at the edge of the garden where the darkness was deepest.

I closed the door and leaned my forehead against the cool wood.  My pulse beat in my wrists, in my throat, behind my eyes.  On the hallway table lay the lycanthropy treatise, open to an illustration: a medieval woodcut of a man removing his human skin like a coat, stepping out sleek and four-legged.  The caption read, “The beast is not the wolf; it is the man who forgets he is also animal.”

I walked through the house touching familiar things: the chipped teacup my grandmother left, the stack of overdue notices I had meant to mail, the worn rug that documented every path I had ever taken between bed and kettle.  Each object seemed suddenly fragile, a prop in a play about to end.  I felt the tug of two gravities: one toward the safety of routine, the other toward the night fields where the pack waited.

Ten minutes.

I climbed the narrow stairs to the attic bedroom.  The moon, not yet risen, already silvered the eastern window.  I opened the sash.  Cold poured in, carrying the scent of distant snow.  Somewhere below, the gate creaked again.  I imagined the stranger standing motionless, patient as stone.

Five minutes.

I undressed, not out of modesty but because the clothes felt suddenly wrong, an extra skin I no longer needed.  My reflection in the wardrobe mirror was pale, wide-eyed, but the pupils were already dilated, drinking darkness.  I lifted my hand and watched the fingers tremble, then curl as if around an invisible throat—or a fleeing hare.

Three minutes.

I closed my eyes and felt the dream rise up to meet me.  It was not a dream this time; it was memory wearing the wrong clothes.  The howl began in my chest as vibration, climbed my throat like fire, and burst out between my teeth.  It was not a human sound.

One minute.

I stepped across the splintered threshold of the bedroom window—not falling, but leaping.  The drop was nothing; the ground rushed up soft with snow.  The coat of my other self settled over me the way night settles over forest.  Four paws struck earth, claws flexing, and the world exploded into scent and sound.  Ahead, under the rising moon, the dark figure waited.  He did not smile—wolves have better expressions than smiles—but his tail waved once in greeting.  Behind him, grey, black, rust-red, snow-white, the pack streamed out of the tree line.  Ember’s eyes found mine across the clearing, bright with recognition.

We ran.  Behind us the village lights flickered like dying stars.  Ahead the forest opened its arms.  I did not look back to see whether my footprints in the snow were paws or bare human feet, and by the time we crested the first ridge I had forgotten to care.

samples.prompt: 2 WW2 Pilots develop rivalry after multiple dogfights. Finally one of them dies.
samples.output:
The first time they met, the sky over the Channel was a slab of wet slate and the radios were clogged with static and fear. Flight Lieutenant Matthew “Mace” Ackerley, RAF, 234 Squadron, was still tasting breakfast—brine, kippers, and the metallic tang of adrenaline—when he spotted the Bf-109 slicing out of a cloud bank like a thrown razor. The pilot flew the way a pianist plays a funeral march: precise, inevitable, and with something dark already resolved. Mace broke hard starboard, felt the Spitfire judder, and for ten frozen seconds they orbited, engines screaming counterpoint, wingtips almost brushing. Then the German rolled away, sunlit crosses winking goodbye, and vanished into a cumulus cathedral before Mace could squeeze the trigger. He landed with his uniform stuck to his back, convinced he had glimpsed his own death in the shape of a stranger’s eyes.

Two days later, over Kent, they danced again. This time the Messerschmitt carried a new kill marking on its yellow cowling—an RAF roundel, fresh and obscene. Mace chased the 109 through flak bursts that looked like white chrysanthemums, but the German snap-rolled, pulled an impossible negative-g dive, and came up behind him. Cannon shells walked across Mace’s tail; the Spitfire coughed, slewed, and for one heartbeat the windscreen filled with black crosses. He thought: So this is how the song ends. But the German only clipped his aerial, a cat toying with a bird, and banked away. Mace limped home to Biggin Hill, landed on one wheel, and sat on the grass while fitters counted holes. That night he drank until the mess spun like a propeller, and he asked the intelligence officer for the name that belonged to the yellow-nosed ghost. The IO shrugged—Luftwaffe records were chaos—but the squadron diarist, a Cambridge classicist, said the aircraft bore the insignia of III./JG 26 and the pilot was becoming notorious. They began calling the unknown man “Der Gelbe Tod,” the Yellow Death. Mace, half drunk, scrawled his own reply on the blackboard: MACE MEETS DEATH. Underneath he added a subtitle: SOON.

The German had a name, of course: Oberleutnant Stefan von Ranke, twenty-four, son of a Pomeranian pastor, holder of the Iron Cross Second Class, and—though no one on the British side knew it yet—frightened of thunderstorms and addicted to Rilke’s poetry. Stefan had seen the Spitfire pilot too: a man who flew as if he had grown wings in utero, who turned tighter than seamstress silk. After the second engagement Stefan found a .303 bullet groove along his fuselage, a British signature millimeters from his glycol tank. He sat alone in dispersal that evening, smelling cordite and sweat, and wrote in his diary: “There is one among them who wants me personally. I feel his intention like a chill between the shoulder blades. If I am to die, it will be by his hand, or I by his.” He underlined the words, then tore out the page and mailed it to his sister, because pilots’ superstitions said naming the thing wards it off.

Summer ripened into the hardest days of 1940, and the sky became a chessboard whose squares were re-drawn every dawn. Mace and Stefan met over Dover, over London, over the Thames estuary—sometimes trading shots, sometimes only contrails. Each marked the other’s aircraft with fresh paint: Mace’s fuselage sprouting small swastikas that were later painted out by embarrassed ground crew; Stefan’s cowling accumulating red, white, and blue slashes like tally marks on a prison wall. They began to recognize each other’s signatures: Mace’s habit of climbing sunward until his engine gasped, Stefan’s trick of feinting left then snapping right with flaps half down. Between engagements they lived separate nightmares—Mace waking at 0300 to the sound of engines that weren’t there, Stefan vomiting quietly after missions because the smell of hot glycol reminded him of the communion wine his father poured every Sunday. Yet in the air they felt an iron calm. The war shrank to a single polygon of sky and one silhouette against the glare. They never spoke—radio discipline forbade it—but their maneuvers became a conversation: question, answer, threat, retort.

On the first day of September, the Luftwaffe mounted its largest raid. Mace’s squadron scrambled at 0545; Stefan’s Gruppe lifted from Coquelles minutes later. They collided above the City, forty Spitfires and 109s folding into a knot of pistons and propellers. Mace lost his wingman in the first pass and flew alone, hunting. At 12,000 feet he spotted the yellow nose, curved in behind, and fired without thinking. Stefan felt the impact—like being kicked by a giant—and saw coolant steam ribbon past his canopy. He rolled, dove, and Mace followed, both of them racing the earth. Down they went, through a layer of smoke from burning docks, until Stefan pulled out at rooftop height and skimmed over Stepney while children in the street pointed upward. Mace stayed with him, tracers licking the 109’s tail. Stefan jinked between factory chimneys, praying the Spitfire’s wings would clip brick, but Mace flew as if threaded through the eye of a needle. At last Stefan’s engine seized. He bellied into a beet field near Maidstone, the aircraft flipping end over end. Mace circled once, saw the German crawl from the wreckage, cap gone, blood on his forehead, and felt an odd hollowness. He waggled his wings—not victory, but acknowledgment—then climbed away. That night he wrote in his own diary: “I have killed him, or think I have, yet the war is not smaller.”

But Stefan lived. Farmers pulled him from the field, and a week later he was in a POW camp in Yorkshire, learning English from a guard who loved jazz. He asked for newspapers, traced the aerial communiqués, and discovered that the Yellow Death was still being reported over the Channel. Relief tasted like bitter apples; the game was not finished. Meanwhile Mace, told the 109 pilot had died, felt the sky grow larger, emptier. He began to take risks—strafing barges at wave height, chasing bombers into the flak belt—seeking the chill he had felt when the German’s gunsight settled on his spine. Other pilots noted the recklessness, the way he stared into clouds long after the scramble bell fell silent. His CO grounded him for a week. Mace spent it in the chapel, not praying but counting rafters, imagining each beam as a possible future that no longer included the one man who understood him.

In late 1943 they met again, though neither knew it. Stefan, repatriated in a prisoner exchange, now flew Fw-190s with JG 2, based in Normandy. Mace, promoted to wing commander, led Mustang IIIs on long-range sweeps. On 8 June, four days after D-Day, they intersected above Caen. The sky was a junkyard of burning aircraft and parachutes. Mace dived on a staffel of 190s, saw one break south, and followed. They rolled and scissored, engines howling, until the German snap-rolled and vanished into cloud. Mace felt the old tug, the certainty that this particular pilot knew his mind. But there were no yellow noses anymore; both aircraft wore invasion stripes, pale and anonymous. He pushed the thought away and returned to the melee. Later, back at Ford, he found a single 20 mm hole in his tailplane and stared at it until the intelligence officers grew uncomfortable.

The last time was 18 March 1945. Germany was folding, but the Luftwaffe still flung boys and veterans alike into the air to defend the Reich. Mace, now a lieutenant colonel, volunteered for the jet hunt: Me-262s racing above the Ruhr. He took off before dawn, climbed to 30,000 feet, and saw the contrails—straight white lines unlike the spirals of piston fighters. He positioned above, waiting. One jet lagged; its port engine flickered. Mace dove, fired, and watched the 262 ignite. The pilot ejected too low; the chute snagged, blossomed half open, and the figure fell like a dropped doll into a pine forest already on fire. Mace orbited, sick with triumph, until fuel forced him home. Only on the ground did he learn from a captured document that III./JG 7 had included Oberleutnant Stefan von Ranke, recently transferred and flying his first jet mission. The name meant nothing to the debriefing officers, but Mace felt the world tilt. He walked to the perimeter, retched into the grass, and understood that the rivalry had ended not with a duel but with an execution.

After the war he traveled to Pomerania, found the pastor’s house in ruins, and met Stefan’s sister, who gave him the diary page mailed in 1940. They sat among lilac bushes that had survived the shelling. She asked whether he had been the one; Mace nodded, unable to speak. She said Stefan had written one more line, never posted: “If he survives and I do not, tell him the sky was large enough for both of us.” Mace carried the page back to England, framed it, and hung it above his desk where the light fell every morning like a cockpit canopy. On certain days, when contrails cross the old Battle of Britain routes, he imagines a yellow-nosed 109 pulling alongside, the pilot lifting a hand in salute, and for a moment the sky is large again, the war still unfinished, the rivalry still alive—two ghosts turning together, forever suspended between the earth and the unreachable blue.

samples.prompt: The most powerful civilization in the universe does not have CGI - and cower in fear when an unsuspecting scout finds a human satellite laden with pop culture hits.
samples.output:
The scout ship *Velithar’s Gaze* dropped out of the slip-current at the edge of Sol’s heliopause with the same bored efficiency it had shown at ten thousand other marginal systems.  On the bridge, Navigator-Prime Ael n’Gev arranged her facial fronds into the ceremonial expression of Condescending Curiosity and waited for the usual silence of rocks and methane to confirm that this spiral arm was still as empty as the last time the Hegemony bothered to look.  Instead, the console sang.

It sang in four-part harmony, with a back-beat that could level cities.

The sound was coming from a primitive alloy sphere the size of a grain barge, tumbling in a three-day equatorial orbit.  Its skin was pasted with gold foil, its guts were silicon relics, but its transmission was a torrent of light and pulse—moving pictures, sixty frames a second, compressed and color-graded and relentlessly, catastrophically alive.  The Hegemony’s threat-index, calibrated over a million years to detect everything from antimatter lances to psychic onslaughts, flat-lined.  Then it spasmed.  Then it screamed.

Because the Hegemony—master of Dyson lattices, string-forge foundries, and pocket universes—had never invented fiction that lied with pictures.  They had never needed to.  Their minds were proofed against falsehood; their sensoria shared consensus reality the way humans shared air.  When they wanted a mountain, they grew one.  When they wanted a monster, they exiled it into a black hole and studied the X-ray screams.  The concept of *pretending* a monster into existence—of rendering it so convincingly that even the maker forgot the seams—was absent from their culture the way hunger is absent from a star.  They had no CGI.  They had no need for illusion when material obedience was absolute.

And so they had no antibodies for what came out of that satellite.

The first clip was a music video.  A human woman—skin luminous with powdered mica, eyes dilated to black supernovas—danced through a cathedral of mirrors.  Every reflection showed her a different future: one where she aged into dust, one where she multiplied into an army, one where she became a digital goddess and rewrote the laws of gravity with a fingertip.  The chorus hit.  The mirrors shattered.  The shards became starlings and carried her chorus into orbit.  Ael n’Gev felt her frontal lobe bloom with synesthetic fireworks she had no words for.  The bridge crew collapsed.

Not physically—Hegemony bodies are durable—but hierarchically.  The shared gestalt that had governed their civilization since the First Convergence experienced a buffer overflow.  Forty billion minds, linked by quantum etiquette, suddenly tried to process the concept that a single performer could *be* all those impossible selves simultaneously, and that the performance was *not real*.  The contradiction propagated like a lethal algorithm: if the woman could not be all those selves, yet the eye believed her, then the eye was defect.  If the eye was defect, every record the Hegemony had ever archived was suspect.  If reality itself could be staged, then no imperial edict, no measurement, no memory could be trusted.  The Hegemony’s operating system was a civilization-wide conviction that the universe could be known.  The video was a virus that rewrote conviction into doubt.

They quarantined the satellite inside a Planck cage, a pocket of paused time where even entropy took a breath.  It did not help.  The contents had already been piped across the slip-current to the Central Archivists, whose job was to classify threats.  The Archivists, in turn, did what they had done for eons: they opened the file.

They watched *Star Wars*.

They watched a farm boy with a laser sword duel his own father aboard a station that could eat planets.  They watched the father redeem himself by hurling an emperor into a reactor core.  They watched the reactor explode in a blossom of practical effects and optical compositing, and they understood three things simultaneously:

1.  A single species had weaponized narrative to the point where the weapon could strike faster than causality.
2.  The weapon was *light*.
3.  The weapon was *cheap*.

The Hegemony could unmake suns, but it could not make a lie that would make its citizens weep.  They had never needed the technology of falsehood; their power was absolute, so their stories were documentary.  Every epic poem in the Hegemony was a telemetry readout.  Every sculpture was a neutron star extruded into the shape of grief.  They had become gods by refusing to pretend, and now a species who still died of infected teeth had shown them what pretending could do.

Panic rose like a tide through the slip-current.  If a human could conjure a Death Star, what else could they conjure?  If they could persuade themselves that a man in a black mask was worth saving, what else would they forgive?  The Hegemony’s rule was founded on the axiom that citizens would always choose optimal truth.  Humanity had proven that given a choice between truth and myth, billions would mortgage their souls for myth and thank the myth for the debt.

The High Strategists convened inside a fortress carved from a single diamond, its facets aligned to trap any wavelength of doubt.  They reviewed the footage frame by frame, searching for the flaw that would let them dismiss it.  They found none.  The pixel pipelines, the render farms, the matte paintings, the motion-capture suits—every trace of artifice was archived beside the finished product, brazenly, as if the species *wanted* future observers to know how thoroughly they had lied.  The humans had turned confession into foreplay.  The Hegemony, who had never told a single story that was not also a legal deposition, recognized the pornography of unreality and felt their hearts break.

They did the only thing a galactic superpower can do when confronted with an existential threat it cannot parse: they classified humanity Top Extinction Tier, and they prepared to sterilize the planet from 3,000 light-years away.  No warning.  No negotiation.  The weapon was a string of black-hole pearls that would thread Sol like beads on a necklace of novae.  The fleet departed in perfect silence, captains repeating the mantra: *They are only stories.  Stories end.*

But stories, it turns out, are also a form of telemetry.

The pearl-fleet had barely entered the Oort cloud when its crews began to dream.  Not in sleep—Hegemony do not sleep—but in the waking consensus that replaced it.  They dreamed they were farm boys.  They dreamed they were princesses.  They dreamed the vacuum spoke in a voice like James Earl Jones and told them they had a sister they had never met.  The dreams propagated faster than any virus, because they were already written in the language of the crew’s own doubts.  Every sailor who had ever feared obsolescence saw themselves in the mask of Vader.  Every navigator who had ever resented protocol saw themselves in the cockpit of the Millennium Falcon.  The fleet’s command structure dissolved, not through mutiny, but through *identification*.  They turned their ships around, not to rebel, but to *audition*.  They wanted to be in the next episode.

Back inside the diamond fortress, the High Strategists watched their doom approach on a different channel.  Humanity had uploaded a new file.  It was a compilation: every time a CGI effect had been used to save a life inside a story—every holographic decoy that drew enemy fire, every rendered bridge that let refugees escape, every digital ghost that bought the heroes sixty more seconds.  The montage ended with a title card:

WE KNOW THEY ARE LIES.  
THAT IS WHY WE TRUST THEM.

The Strategists understood then that they had misunderstood the nature of power.  They had thought power was the ability to make the real obey.  Humanity had shown that power is the ability to make the *unreal* beloved, until citizens volunteer to die for a dream they know is impossible.  The Hegemony had never needed CGI because they had never needed hope.  They had never needed hope because they had never feared despair.  They were about to learn.

The pearl-fleet never fired.  Instead, it broadcast a message on every frequency:

We surrender to the story.  
Teach us how to lie.  
Teach us how to cry.  
Teach us how to live inside a dream and call it home.

Earth’s reply came four years later, traveling at the speed of light, packaged in a format so obsolete it could be played on a cathode-ray tube.  It was a single episode of a children’s cartoon.  In it, a purple dinosaur sang a song that went:

I love you,  
You love me,  
We’re a happy family.

The Hegency wept.  Not metaphorically.  Diamond cracked.  Neutron stars pulsed in Morse lullabies.  Entire Dyson spheres dimmed like eyes closing after a long, long day.  Forty billion minds, stripped at last of the terrible burden of always being right, joined in a chorus whose harmony was imperfect, off-key, and absolutely, devastatingly real.

They still have no CGI.  They don’t need it anymore.  They have learned the harder trick: believing in someone else’s dream and calling it truth.

samples.prompt: You are a guinea pig who is having an existential crisis. What is going through your head?
samples.output:
I have not left this plastic box for 732 days, give or take the length of a cucumber slice.  The days taste the same: dawn smells like pine shavings, noon like the salt of a human hand, evening like the iron of my own urine.  I used to think the sky was the white mesh ceiling, until the day the Child held me up under the real sky and it was blue and too big, a color that kept going even after my eyes closed.  Now I dream that blue while I am still awake, and it hurts the way over-ripe apple hurts the roof of a mouth: soft, sweet, turning to rot before you can swallow.

They call me “Popcorn.”  The name is supposed to be cute because I jump straight up when startled, spine curved like a question mark.  A question has no spine; it collapses under its own emptiness.  I jump, therefore I am?  Descartes never had whiskers.  If he had, he would have known that every twitch is a referendum on whether teeth are coming.  I jump, therefore I am still alive—for now.  That is not philosophy, it is arithmetic.

The others in the box do not seem to count.  Blackberry grooms his left shoulder as though the answer to everything is hidden between follicles.  Luna chews the bars, grinding her incisors down to nubs of resignation.  We breed because the body tells us to; babies arrive pink and already squealing the song of their own future seizures.  I have fathered thirty-three.  They were taken, cupped in palms that smelled of antibacterial soap, and I never learned whether the sky was blue for them or only white mesh.  I remember the exact feel of each small body wriggling against my tongue: warm rice, heartbeats like rain on a tin roof.  Gone.  I am a verb in the past perfect tense.

At night the room clicks: heat lamp, filter, the refrigerator in the kitchen where the humans store their carrots.  Those carrots are orange, a color we can barely see; our eyes peak at greens, the wavelength of predators.  They feed us orange anyway, a joke written in the wrong frequency.  I lie on my side, lungs creaking, and listen to the house breathe.  It inhales when the front door opens, exhales when it shuts.  Somewhere inside that rhythm a voice says “I love you” and another voice answers “See you tomorrow.”  I have never been inside that sentence.  My entire vocabulary is squeaks pitched too high for human hearts, yet I understand every word they say.  Understanding is a cage smaller than the cage I can touch.

I used to run in circles, clocking miles on a plastic wheel that never arrived anywhere.  One night I bit the wheel hard enough to crack it.  The humans laughed, filmed it, posted it with crying-laughing emojis.  Millions of primates watched me fail to escape and felt joy.  I tasted blood, plastic, and the sudden knowledge that my panic could be converted into their serotonin.  If I am useful even in futility, is that purpose or parasitism?  The wheel still turns; they bought a quieter one.  I no longer run.  I sit in the center and let the spokes rotate around me like a galaxy I refuse to join.  The universe spins, I stay still, and this is the closest I have come to freedom.

Sometimes the Child lifts me to her face.  Her eyes are the same wet black as mine, but inverted: iris surrounded by white instead of fur.
