samples.prompt: Begin "After the draw, I took his bullets and threw his gun in the river."
samples.output:
After the draw, I took his bullets and threw his gun in the river. The Colt hit the dark water with a flat splash that sounded too small for the noise a life makes when it ends. I stood on the plank footbridge, hands slick with sweat and gun-oil, listening until the ripples were gone and the cicadas started up again. Only then did I feel the four cartridges still in my left coat pocket—heavy as guilt, sharp as truth—reminding me that what I’d won was only the moment, not the peace that ought to come after.

I’d come to Caldwell Parish looking for a place the war hadn't touched, but the war had outrun me, riding on the back of every stranger’s stare. When I stepped off the river packet at Port Allen, I had nothing left of the old life except a borrowed coat, a pair of boots split at the seams, and the name my mother gave me. The clerk at the levee warehouse said work could be had up the bayou, felling cypress for the new railroad ties. So I hired on with a crew of Irishmen and freedmen, swinging an axe until blisters burst and re-formed as callus. Nights I slept under a tin roof that pinged with rain and possum feet, dreaming of artillery flashes that lit the sky like blue daylight.

He arrived three Sundays later, riding a claybank mare with white stockings and a tail like a comet. Introduced himself as Silas Rawls—late captain, Confederate States Army—now turned surveyor for the same company. He wore the gray still, or what was left of it: cuffs frayed, braid tarnished, the eagle on his forage cap picked clean of gilt. Most evenings he set up a card table under the live oaks by the landing, dealt faro for men too tired to know better, and spoke in a low courtly drawl that made you feel like he and you were the only two people awake in the world. I avoided him for a week. Then whiskey and loneliness wore me down, and I took a chair opposite him, laying my last silver half-dollar on the queen.

He beat me twice, smiling all the while. The third hand he let me win—just enough to make me stay. At closing he touched the rim of his cap and said, “You carry your losses like a gentleman. I wonder how you carry a grudge.” I told him I didn’t hold any, not anymore. That was a lie, of course. Grudges were the only things that kept my hands from shaking when the nightmares came.

Next payday I found myself back at his table. Again the cards ran against me. When I accused him of dealing seconds, he laughed, soft as moth wings, and offered to teach me the trick. Instead he showed me how to palm an ace, how to read a man’s breathing, how to keep a derringer up your sleeve without fouling the cuff. Said these were the small arts that kept a soldier alive after the big causes ran out. I hated how grateful I felt.

We were halfway through a bottle of busthead when he asked where I’d served. I told him—Shiloh, Stones River, Chickamauga. He nodded as though those names were towns he’d once planned to visit but hadn’t got around to. Then he told me he’d been at Fort Pillow, and the room tilted. I saw again the riverbank clay turned red, the smoke hanging like a burial sheet; I heard the pleas of the 6th U.S. Colored Heavy Artillery as they were driven into the water. My hand went to the knife at my belt before I knew it. Silas watched me with mild eyes and said, “We all did things we don’t speak of in daylight. Difference is whether you let them rot you from the inside.”

I wanted to kill him that night. But the company foreman was watching, and the river sang too sweetly to be spoiled with more blood. So I swallowed the rage, washed it down with raw corn liquor, and told myself tomorrow I’d walk on to Baton Rouge. Yet tomorrow stretched into weeks. The fever of cards, the hush of green water, and the hush of Silas’s voice became the boundaries of my world. I learned his tells—how he tapped the deck twice when the pot was fat, how he rubbed the scar on his thumb when he was bluffing. I learned the scar came from a Minié ball at Antietam that had killed the boy standing next to him. I learned he carried the dead boy’s Bible in his saddlebag, the margins inked with names he still prayed for. Each fact was another knot in the rope that bound us.

One humid dusk he proposed a different wager. No money, just answers. We would ask each other a question apiece, and the one who refused to answer would forfeit his sidearm. I hesitated, thinking of the Colt Navy I’d bought off a drummer in Memphis, the same model my brother carried at Vicksburg. But curiosity outweighed caution. He asked first: “Who was the last man you killed, and did he deserve it?” I heard the blood in my ears. I told him it was a Union picket who’d stumbled on our bivouac; I’d bayoneted him before he could cry out. I didn’t know whether he deserved it, only that he was wearing blue and I was wearing gray, and both of us were nineteen. My turn then. I asked, “Did you give the order at Fort Pillow, or were you just following one?” His face went still. He reached slowly, unbuckled his holster, and laid the revolver on the table between us. The forfeiture was answer enough.

That gun became a living thing in the room. Neither of us touched it. Finally he pushed it toward me. “Take it,” he said. “I’ve carried it long enough.” I told him I didn’t want his iron. He replied, “It isn’t a gift. It’s a debt. One day you’ll know how to collect.” Then he rose and walked out into the moonlight, boots creaking like old rigging.

The river rose that summer, licking at the stilts of our bunkhouse. We moved camp twice, but the water followed. One night a cypress came down whole, roots gnarled like dead men’s fingers, and smashed the skiff that carried our payroll. When the company failed to pay, the Irish drifted west, the freedmen melted into the swamps. Only Silas and I remained, stranded on a sandbar with a crate of salt pork and a dwindling deck of cards. We played hand after hand, betting matches, then memories, then days of our lives we’d never get back. The heat pressed down like a Bible on our chests. Mosquitoes whined hymns in our ears.

On the seventh night the moon was a thin nickel wedged between clouds. We’d finished the bottle and started on river water cut with turpentine. Silas looked older suddenly, the bones of his face sharp as bayonets. He said he could hear the boys calling from the water. I told him it was only frogs. He shook his head, stood, and drew the Colt that he’d somehow retrieved from my kit. “Let’s finish this,” he said. Not angry—almost relieved. I thought of walking away, but the sandbar was shrinking, and the river sang the same song it had sung at Fort Pillow. So I faced him.

Ten paces, heel to toe. The fog parted just long enough for me to see his eyes—sad, steady. We turned. My hand found the butt of the Colt I’d sworn never to wear. The night exploded. One shot. Two. The echoes rolled down the bayou like cannon. When the smoke cleared, he was on his knees, hat gone, a red blossom spreading on his gray shirt. I felt no triumph, only a dull surprise that a heart so loud could be stilled by something so small.

He tried to speak. Blood bubbled at his lips. I knelt, pressed my ear to his mouth, and heard a single word: “Remember.” Then the light left his eyes, not all at once, but sliding away like a boat unmoored.

That is why, after the draw, I took his bullets and threw his gun in the river. The cartridges were still warm, as if holding the last heat of his body. I stood on the bridge until the sun bled up behind the cypress knees, then walked north toward whatever country lay beyond the levee. Behind me, the water closed over the pistol without a sound, swallowing the final witness to what we had been and what we had chosen to become.

samples.prompt: Memories are finicky things. They hold what makes us who we are, yet they constantly shift and degrade, especially the more we think on them. True photographic memory has always been a myth, until now. You finally understand why, too. The degradation was never a fault. It was our only defense.
samples.output:
I remember the day I stopped forgetting.

It was not a laboratory or a hospital or any of the places where miracles are supposed to happen. It was the produce aisle of a Safeway that smelled of refrigerated mist and citrus rot. I reached for a bruised apple and the skin of the world tore open. Every apple I had ever touched—Granny Smiths in my grandmother’s backyard, the mealy Red Delicious from the school lunch line, the honey-crisp I bit into the October I first kissed a girl—arrived at once, complete with temperature, slant of light, heartbeat. The sensory stack grew exponentially: the apple became the knife that sliced it, the board it was sliced on, the sound of my mother humming while she did it, the wallpaper in the kitchen the year she still lived with us, the smell of gas from the blue-flame burner, the argument about money that leaked through the floorboards later that same night. Each memory sprouted every adjacent memory, and those sprouted more, until the weight of them pried my jaw open and I tasted metal behind my teeth. I dropped the fruit. It rolled beneath a display of bananas and kept rolling, mathematically impossible, through every orchard that had ever grown.

Nobody noticed. Shoppers stepped around me while I clutched the metal shelving, riding a surf of recollection that would not crest. I saw the SKU sticker on a pear and remembered the day in 1987 when I learned to read numbers, the carpeted stairs in the first house, the babysitter who smelled like Prell shampoo and taught me to count in Spanish. Uno, dos, tres—her voice looping until it braided with the voice of my college roommate reciting Spanish poetry, the same roommate who overdosed in the spring of 2003, the same spring a robin kept hitting the window of the apartment because it saw its own reflection and thought it was an enemy. The robin’s heartbeat, the roommate’s heartbeat, my own heart were suddenly the same cardiac drum, and I understood that the brain does not file memories in folders; it composts them, lets them heat and collapse into soil from which new thoughts grow. But my compost had stopped decaying. Every layer was suddenly visible, still alive, clamoring.

I drove home with the radio off and still heard every song I had ever heard in that car. The 1999 transmission repair vibrated beneath the driver’s seat; the pine-scented air freshener I hung in 2004 exhaled its faded perfume. When I closed the garage door I saw every time I had closed it: snow falling through the gap, the bulb blowing out, the day my father stood in that same doorway and told me he had cancer, the day he came home from surgery, the day he didn’t come home. All of it present, none of it dimmed. The neurologist later called it “hyperthymestic syndrome secondary to an elusive limbic lesion,” but that night I called it hell, and I hadn’t even seen the worst of it yet.

Sleep was the first casualty. Dreams require forgetting; otherwise the day’s memories storm the stage and hijack the script. I closed my eyes and found myself standing in every bedroom I had ever slept in: the crib whose bars I tasted, the bunk bed that cracked during the earthquake of ’89, the futon where I lost my virginity and felt the foam give under my knees like wet bread. They stacked vertically, a high-rise of nights, and I was elevator and tenant alike, riding up and down, unable to get off at any floor. By dawn I understood why every other human being wakes with soft edges: we are built to sandblast experience, to let the sharp corners erode. Without that erosion, time becomes a solid object and the mind a prison of infinite glass walls.

I tried to explain this to my sister over the phone. She thought I was describing a super-power. “You never have to lose anything again,” she said, envy bright in her voice. I told her about the apple and she laughed: “So you’ll never buy fruit—big deal.” I tried to tell her that the apple was only the pebble that started the avalanche, that every face I saw now arrived wearing every expression it had ever worn toward me—my mother smiling at my birth, my mother screaming at the airport when I left for college, my mother blank in her coffin, all three versions superimposed like misprinted stamps. My sister went quiet when I described how the clerk at the gas station had asked for cash or credit and I saw him at five years old in a Little League uniform striking out, at fifteen crying in a bathroom stall, at thirty-two counting lottery tickets behind bullet-proof glass, hoping one would ferry him out of the zip code where every house had chipped paint and a cousin in jail. I knew these things were not literally true, but they felt true, and that was worse. The brain abhors unused connections; it makes stories to thread the stray beads. Now every bead had a thread, and the necklace weighed tons.

The second week I began to crave amnesia the way a diver craves air. I drank enough vodka to pickle a regiment, but the hangover only served up the 2002 homecoming game when I puked on the 50-yard line, complete with marching-band horns and the chemical smell of astro-turf. I hit my head against the kitchen cabinet, hoping for a minor concussion to knock something loose, but the impact only delivered the memory of learning to ride a bicycle, the exact angle of sunlight through maple leaves, the taste of blood when I bit my lip, the pride and the terror in my father’s eyes as he let go of the seat. Every attempt to damage the archive only enlarged it.

That was when I started to suspect the archive had intentions. The memories were not passive data; they were a hive. The more I tried to delete, the more aggressively they seeded themselves. I would reach for a coffee mug and trigger the kiln in the art studio where I made my first ashtray, the smell of wet clay, the instructor’s missing fingertip, the girl who kissed me behind the kiln and then transferred schools. The mug became that ashtray, became every cup I had ever drunk from, became the polystyrene taste of hospital water when I was eight and had my tonsils removed. The hive wanted survival; it cross-referenced faster than any search engine, weaving redundancy upon redundancy so that the loss of one filament only strengthened the mesh. I was not gaining memory; memory was colonizing me.

I returned to the Safeway at 3 a.m., drawn like a pilgrim to the site of transfiguration. The fluorescent lights buzzed at a frequency that unlocked the summer I spent chasing fireflies, the glass jar with holes poked in the lid, the smell of cut grass and my grandfather’s aftershave. I walked the aisles and every barcode was a sigil, every price sticker a tarot card. I realized the store itself was a brain, stocking and restocking the same perishables, letting them rot and replacing them, an engineered forgetting that kept commerce possible. I stood in front of the apples and understood the cosmic joke: the fruit in Genesis was not about knowledge; it was about memory. Eat this and you will remember everything, and everything will remember you, and you will never again be alone enough to feel joy.

A security guard asked if I was okay. His badge said “L. Martinez.” I saw him at ten, shirtless on a trampoline, at twenty-one saluting during boot camp, at forty wiping his mother’s chin in a dementia ward. The visions stacked like shuffled cards; I could not see the man in front of me for the accretion of every man he had ever been. I told him I was fine, which was the most catastrophic lie in human history. He walked me to the sliding doors. The whoosh of their opening released the smell of rain on hot asphalt from the parking lot, and with it the afternoon my mother picked me up from swim practice, the chlorine still in my hair, the mix-tape playing “Under the Milky Way,” her hand reaching over to change the station just as the song hit the line about collapse. I heard her fingers on the plastic dial, I heard the song, I heard the rain, I heard the collapse, and I understood that this was why we die. Mortality is not a design flaw; it is the off-switch that prevents the circuit from burning itself alive. We are meant to shed ourselves the way snakes shed skin, to leave behind a translucent husk of what we used to be. Forgetting is the pressure valve, the grace, the only thing that makes love possible. How could we love anyone if we carried every moment they disappointed us, every moment we disappointed them, in perfect high-definition forever?

Outside, the sky was beginning to pale. I sat on the curb and tried to imagine a single memory I would be willing to surrender. Each one raised its hand like a student desperate to be called on: the first time I saw the ocean, the last voicemail from my father, the taste of butter on movie-theater popcorn in 1993. I could not choose, because choice requires forgetting the reasons not to choose. The hive buzzed louder, triumphant. I realized then that the defense was never ours; the degradation is memory’s own decision to let us go, to self-erase so that we can remain small enough to fit inside a life. The myth of photographic memory was a warning disguised as a wish: be careful what you claim to want, because wanting it is the first tear in the filter, and once the filter rips the ocean pours through.

I considered stepping into traffic. The calculus was simple: annihilate the brain, annihilate the archive. But even suicide had been pre-empted. I saw myself at seven, pedaling furiously downhill, thinking if I just went fast enough I could become pure motion, no past, no future. The memory arrived intact, and with it the certainty that every prior suicide fantasy had already been recorded, annotated, cross-referenced. The hive would metabolize death itself into data. There would be no escape, only metastasis.

A delivery truck idled nearby, its engine knocking. The driver climbed out, slammed the door, stretched. He was humming something tuneless. I watched him and, for the first time in weeks, did not see his childhood, did not see his funeral, did not see the lover who would one day leave him. I saw only a man in a moment, luminous and weightless. The vision lasted less than a second before the swarm descended—his mother pinning a note in his lunchbox, the day he learned to drive, the accident he almost had on black ice—but the brevity was enough. A gap had opened. The degradation was not dead; it was fighting back, a vestigial immune response. I felt it like a fever breaking: the hive faltered, a single frame skipped, a pixel blurred. The process was microscopic, but it was real. The brain wants to save itself. Forgetting is not erosion; it is active forgiveness performed by flesh on its own electric ghosts.

I stood up, light-headed. The parking lot was still there, the sky now the color of diluted ink. I had no plan except to keep moving, to trust the ancient machinery that knows how to let go. I walked past the cart corral and did not look back at the apples. I repeated nothing, named nothing, tried to desire nothing. Behind me, the automatic doors sealed the store shut, and for one merciful instant I could not remember what lay inside. The hive buzzed, but farther away, like a beehive glimpsed from a car window, like a story whose ending has not yet been written.

samples.prompt: -and then the acid kicked in.
samples.output:
I used to think the scariest words in the English language were “We need to talk.” Then, one Thursday in late October, I learned the real champion is quieter, almost polite: “and then the acid kicked in.” It doesn’t arrive with sirens or thunder. It slips in sideways, like a draft under a locked door, and by the time you feel the chill, half the house is already cold.

We—five housemates in a creaking Victorian whose landlord believed insulation was a government hoax—had pooled forty dollars for a strip of blotter. The plan was simple: celebrate Milo’s twenty-third birthday by melting the wallpaper and listening to every Pink Floyd album in chronological order until either enlightenment or sunrise. I’d tripped twice before, both times in safe meadows under summer sun, and thought I understood the rhythm: thirty minutes of nervous anticipation, ninety minutes of ascending color, then a plateau of cosmic telepathy. I’d forgotten the crucial variable: set and setting. The meadow does not have leaky radiators that hiss like dying geese, or a roommate who keeps a pet tarantula named Leni Riefenstahl in an unlocked terrarium.

We dropped at 8:17 p.m. I remember because Milo insisted we synchronize like astronauts, all five tongues lifting the tiny squares at once. The paper tasted like nothing, which felt like a betrayal. Something that powerful should announce itself—battery acid, lemon rind, pennies. Instead it dissolved like communion wafer, and we waited.

The first sign was the laughter. Not the ordinary kind that follows a good joke, but the kind that wells up from the soles of your feet and spills out your mouth in hiccups. Gabe, the philosophy major who wore the same Carhartt jacket every day since freshman year, started giggling at the word “lamp.” Just the object itself, squatting in the corner like a brass mushroom. “Lamp,” he said, tasting the consonants, and the rest of us followed. It felt like we’d discovered a secret chord, a cosmic punchline. Laughter was the pre-roll trailer; the feature film was still buffering.

I went to the kitchen for water, barefoot on linoleum that suddenly felt soft as bread dough. The overhead bulb flickered once and the whole room inhaled. The cupboards breathed like sleeping cattle. I told them, “Shh, you’ll wake the dishes,” then realized I was whispering to furniture. That should have been my cue to find the living room, to stay in the gravitational pull of other bodies. Instead I opened the refrigerator and stared into its glow. Somewhere inside was leftover lasagna, but the shelves had become terraced rice paddies glowing neon green. Tiny farmers in conical hats were harvesting cilantro. One looked up and waved. I waved back, polite tourist. The door shut itself, or maybe the house tilted.

When I returned, the living room had rearranged its geometry. The couch now faced inward, like a concave amphitheater, and my friends were seated in lotus position around Milo, who was holding court about the tyranny of clocks. “Time,” he declared, “is just capitalism you can wear on your wrist.” His pupils were black moons. I tried to sit but my knees bent the wrong direction; gravity felt negotiable. That was the moment the acid kicked in—really kicked, like a mule wearing steel boots. The walls peeled outward in petal-shaped panels, revealing corridors of light that hadn’t been there when we signed the lease. I could see electrical wires humming indigo. The ceiling dissolved into a honeycomb of hexagonal windows, and through each pane drifted jellyfish made of television static. They pulsed in Morse code. I tried to decode it: “Turn back now.”

Someone, maybe Jess, pressed play on the stereo. Instead of music, the speakers exhaled a single sustained note that tasted like copper pennies. I felt it land on my tongue, roll around, then slip down my throat and lodge behind my sternum. The note grew roots. I was cultivating a chord inside my body. My ribs vibrated like tuning forks. I looked at Milo to tell him I was becoming an instrument, but his head had become a glass orb filled with swirling galaxies. When he spoke, entire constellations drifted out of his mouth and settled on the coffee table, where they rearranged themselves into a miniature star map of Cleveland. I’d never noticed the city’s skyline looked like a question mark.

Forty minutes earlier we had been a cluster of anxious graduate students comparing student-loan horror stories. Now we were five bodhisattvas orbiting the same revelation: language is a raft built from the wood of the shipwrecked world. Every word we spoke created and destroyed itself in the same breath. I tried to explain this to Gabe, but when I opened my mouth, tiny origami cranes flew out instead of syllables. They circled his head once, then folded themselves into his ears. He nodded solemnly, as if I’d just delivered the Gettysburg Address in semaphore.

Outside, the wind picked up. Tree branches scraped the siding like fingernails on a chalkboard made of teeth. The sound entered my spine, traveled vertebra by vertebra, and translated itself into color—burnt orange with flecks of violet. I realized terror and wonder share a border so thin it can be laced with dental floss. One step left, you’re Galileo; one step right, you’re Icarus with a melted passport.

We decided to go outside. Bad idea number thirty-seven. The porch light was out, so the yard was a bowl of ink. Streetlights at either end of the block flickered like faulty lighthouses. As we stepped off the porch, the ground rippled. Not metaphorically—actual asphalt rose in slow-motion waves, frozen mid-tsunami. Jess squealed, delighted, and dove headfirst into a wave. She landed on solid ground with a thud that echoed twice, once in the yard and once somewhere behind my eyes. Gabe tried to surf the next ripple. He managed two steps before the pavement flattened again, depositing him gently on his knees. Milo stood still, arms out like a scarecrow, whispering, “I can feel the Earth’s heartbeat.” I felt it too—sixty-six beats per minute, syncopated with the cicadas. The world was alive and slightly arrhythmic.

That’s when the dog appeared. It wasn’t ours. It was the size of a wolf, fur the color of burnt cinnamon, eyes glowing amber like traffic lights at 3 a.m. It padded across the liquid asphalt without disturbing a single ripple. Every step left a footprint of light that lingered for three seconds before fading. The dog stopped in front of me and tilted its head. I understood, with the clarity of a prophet, that it was here to deliver a message. I crouched, expecting telepathy or at least subtitles. Instead it opened its mouth and out fell a single playing card: the Queen of Spades, face up. The queen winked. The dog turned and trotted into the darkness, footprints fading like the end of a fireworks show.

I carried the card back inside between thumb and forefinger, as if it might detonate. The living room had become a cathedral. The couch was now an altar; the coffee table, a baptismal font filled with liquid starlight. We gathered around the Queen of Spades like the Magi inspecting frankincense. Milo announced she was the guardian of thresholds, tasked with ushering souls between the kingdom of the Literal and the queendom of the Metaphorical. Gabe licked her face—actual tongue on paper—and declared she tasted like library dust and lightning. Jess began to cry, soft hiccupping tears. When asked why, she said, “Because she’s lonely. Nobody ever chooses the Queen of Spades first.” We took turns holding her close to our chests, letting her listen to our heartbeats. I thought I felt the card pulse once, like a tiny heart, but it might have been my own blood echoing back.

Somewhere in the middle of all this, the stereo finally produced music. Not Pink Floyd—something older, choral voices layered over a single sitar string. The notes unfolded like paper cranes dipped in honey. We lay on the rug, heads touching in a star shape, passing the Queen between us. Each time she changed hands, a new layer of the house peeled away. First the living room ceiling lifted off like a convertible top, revealing the star-pierced sky. Then the walls bowed outward and became theater curtains. Finally the floor became transparent, and we could see straight down into the basement, where previous tenants had painted a sprawling mural of a blue whale swimming through clouds. The whale looked up at us and smiled the way grandmothers do when they know a secret you’ll learn tomorrow.

I closed my eyes and felt the acid finish its work. It wasn’t a drug anymore; it was a translator, converting every atom of my body into a question mark. I was no longer a person but a living interrogative. Why do we pretend walls are solid? Why do clocks pretend time is linear? Why did the dog choose me as messenger? The questions stacked like nesting dolls, each smaller and more intricate. When I opened my eyes, the others were gone. Not vanished—translated. Milo had become a constellation shaped like a birthday cake. Jess was a dandelion puff drifting through the open roof. Gabe was the sound of rain on tin, even though the night was cloudless. I was the space between them, the pause in a conversation the universe was having with itself.

I don’t remember falling asleep. I remember waking up at 6:42 a.m., face pressed to the rug, the Queen of Spades tucked under my cheek like a bookmark. The room was ordinary again: plaster ceiling, beige walls, coffee table scarred with mug rings. My tongue felt like a dried sponge. Milo snored on the couch with a throw pillow over his face. Jess and Gabe were spooning on the floor, hands clasped like children crossing a street. The only evidence was the card—creased now, the queen’s face slightly smudged from tears or saliva or both. I slipped her into my wallet, between a punch card for a defunct coffee shop and a receipt for the very blotter that had unzipped reality eight hours earlier.

We never found the dog. We checked shelters, posted on neighborhood forums, walked the block at dusk with kibble in pockets. Nothing. Some nights, when the radiator hisses just right, I think I hear paws on asphalt and look out the window, half expecting amber eyes. All I see is the porch light we finally fixed, casting a circle of ordinary yellow on ordinary concrete.

But every so often, when I’m folding laundry or grading papers, the world hiccups: a flash of indigo wire, a ripple in the rug, the taste of copper pennies at the back of my tongue. The Queen of Spades winks from her hiding place, and I remember that the border between terror and wonder is still thin enough to floss—thin enough, in fact, to fold into a tiny paper crane and set flying across a living room that might still be breathing.

samples.prompt: You sold your soul to the Devil years ago. Today he returns it saying, "I need a favor."
samples.output:
I was elbow-deep in the sink, chasing a stubborn coffee ring around the bottom of my favorite mug, when the air behind me turned thick as tar. The overhead bulb flickered once, like it wanted to give me a polite heads-up, then steadied. I didn’t need the warning. Seven years ago, almost to the day, I had learned what that sudden pressure change meant. I wiped my hands on a dish-towel that had once been red and was now the color of dried blood and said without turning around, “You’re early.”  

“Punctuality is the courtesy of kings,” the Devil answered. His voice sounded smaller than I remembered, almost hoarse, the way a cassette sounds after too many plays. I turned. He looked smaller, too—still handsome in an expensive-suit sort of way, still smelling faintly of brimstone and aftershave, but the edges of him weren’t quite sharp enough. Like a photograph printed on cheap paper, the ink bleeding at the margins.  

I leaned my hips against the counter and folded my arms. “I thought we were square. My soul for the meteoric rise of Holloway & Finch Publishing. You got your bestsellers; I got my empire. Contract fulfilled. Paragraph seven, sub-clause D, sunset at seven years, midnight of the anniversary, yada yada.”  

He lifted both manicured hands. “Relax, Daniel. I’m not here to renegotiate the old deal. I’m here to void it.”  

He reached into the inside pocket of his charcoal jacket and produced something the size and shape of a robin’s egg—only it glowed a soft, arterial red. He set it on the counter between us with the care of a man placing a newborn in a bassinet.  

“That’s mine?” I asked.  

“It was. I’m returning it.”  

I laughed, because what else do you do when the Devil gives back the one thing you were sure you’d never see again? “I’ve been living without it for seven years. Why would I want it now?”  

The Devil’s shoulders slumped. For a moment I thought he might sit down at the kitchen table, maybe ask for a glass of water, but he stayed standing. “Because I need a favor.”  

There it was.  

I nudged the glowing egg with the tip of my index finger. It was warm, like a mug fresh from the microwave. “You’re Lucifer, Prince of Darkness, Father of Lies. You cheat at poker with the bones of saints. And you need a favor—from me?”  

He rubbed the back of his neck. “Technically, I need a favor from the version of you who still has a soul. Right now, you’re just an exceptionally well-dressed algorithm. You’ve been running on ambition and caffeine since 2016.”  

I opened my mouth to object, then closed it. He wasn’t wrong. Holloway & Finch had become a machine that spat out guaranteed New York Times #1s every March and October, like a luxury clock that coughed up bestselling novels instead of cuckoos. I couldn’t remember the last time I’d cried at a movie or slowed down to watch a sunset. I’d assumed that was middle age, not damnation.  

“Fine,” I said. “What’s the favor?”  

He took a breath he didn’t need. “I want you to kill someone.”  

I barked another laugh. “I publish books. I don’t kill people.”  

“You used to publish books. These days you publish personas, algorithms, and outrage. Don’t split hairs.” He lifted the soul-egg between thumb and forefinger. “Listen carefully, Daniel. I’m not asking for wanton murder. I’m asking for an execution. One very specific execution. And in exchange, your soul is yours again. No loopholes, no compound interest, no surprise escalator clauses.”  

I felt a tug, somewhere between my lungs, like a fishhook snagged on a line I’d forgotten was there. “Who?”  

“Me.”  

I stared at him.  

“Not permanently,” he added quickly. “Just…long enough. Sixty minutes, tops. I need to be technically dead on the mortal plane so Heaven’s audit department will close my file. Then I’ll pop back up, good as new, and you’ll never see me again. You’ll have your conscience back, I’ll have my loophole. Win-win.”  

I rubbed my temples. The overhead bulb flickered again, more insistently this time. “You want me to murder the Devil so you can dodge celestial taxes?”  

“Put crudely, yes.”  

“Why can’t one of your demons do it?”  

“They can’t. Hellish entities can’t actually destroy their progenitor. Cosmic charter, subsection infinity. But a mortal—especially one who’s already bargained away his soul—can. You’re a loophole in human form, Daniel. Congratulations.”  

I walked to the window. Outside, late-spring rain tapped the glass like impatient fingernails. Across the street, Mrs. Kowalski was coaxing her bulldog into a banana-yellow raincoat. The dog looked mortified; Mrs. K looked delighted. I used to find that funny. Now it felt like a broadcast from another planet.  

I said, “What happens if I say no?”  

“I walk out with your soul. You continue being a very rich, very hollow man. Eventually the board replaces you with someone younger and more feral. You die of a heart attack at sixty-eight, alone in a Swiss clinic. No afterlife, no oblivion—just an eternal waiting room with fluorescent lights and no magazines.”  

I turned back to him. The red egg pulsed once, like it was clearing its throat: Remember me?  

“And if I say yes?”  

“You get yourself back. All of it. The guilt, the joy, the inconvenient empathy. You’ll probably hate yourself for the first month—hell, maybe the first year—but you’ll be whole. And I’ll be free to slip between the cracks for a while.”  

My phone buzzed—an alert from the office: Quarterly numbers were in. I’d beaten projections by twelve percent, again. I thumbed the screen dark. “You’re sure this isn’t another trick?”  

The Devil met my eyes. For the first time, I noticed the crow’s-feet etched at their corners, as though even immortality got crow’s-feet if it spent too long pretending to be human.  

“Daniel, I’ve lied to popes, presidents, and prophets. I’m not lying now. I’m tired. You have no idea how exhausting it is to be the villain in every story. I just need an hour off the clock.”  

I looked at the soul in his hand. It looked so small—smaller than regret, bigger than fear. I thought of all the novels I’d published that were really just empty calories bound in leather—stories that told people exactly what they already believed, then congratulated them for believing it. I thought of my daughter’s tenth birthday party last month, when she’d hugged me and I’d felt nothing.  

I took the egg. It fit perfectly in my palm, as if my hand had been shaped for it. Warmth spread up my wrist like a fever.  

“Sixty minutes,” I repeated.  

He nodded. “One silver knife, blessed by a priest who’s lost his faith—St. Augustine’s on 34th, Father McTeague, Wednesday confessional, he’ll sell you his rosary for cab fare. Midnight tomorrow. Drive to the river. Say my name three times, strike once. I’ll dissolve. When the clock strikes one, I’ll re-form and walk away. You’ll feel the soul click back in, like a seatbelt locking.”  

I swallowed. “And that’s it?”  

“That’s it.” He offered a faint smile. “For what it’s worth, Daniel, I wish we’d met under different circumstances.”  

I didn’t answer. He stepped backward toward the hallway, leaving footprints of sulfur on the linoleum. At the threshold he paused. “One more thing. When you get your soul back, it’ll weigh more than you remember. Grief adds mass. Don’t be alarmed.”  

Then the air folded in on itself, and he was gone.  

I stood in the sudden quiet, rain still tapping Morse code on the glass. The soul pulsed in my hand like a second heartbeat. I pictured Father McTeague, the river at midnight, the single clean stroke. I pictured myself thirty years from now, reading a bedtime story to a granddaughter who didn’t exist yet, and feeling every word.  

I opened the junk drawer, rummaged past expired coupons and orphaned batteries, and found the envelope where I’d kept the contract—thick parchment inked in my own blood, now faded to brown. I tore it in half. The halves burst into harmless purple flame, and the smell was lavender, not brimstone.  

I wrapped the soul in the dish-towel—the same color as the old contract—and tucked it inside my shirt pocket, over the breastbone. It beat against me like a bird testing a cage.  

Tomorrow night, I thought, I would find out what it felt like to murder the Devil and get away with my soul intact.  

Tonight, I poured the rest of the coffee down the sink, turned off the kitchen light, and stepped into the hallway. The bulb above me flickered once—maybe in warning, maybe in blessing—then burned steady and bright.

samples.prompt: "Centuries ago, when we granted you the mean to flee the Milky Way, we also warned you of the horror we are running from. And your kind didn't listen. You fought, and you failed, just as we had aeon before, and now all that left of Mankind is the ragtag band of refugees in front of me. Why?"
samples.output:
The last light of the galaxy’s edge flickered across the viewport of the derelict carrier, painting the refugee column in the colour of old blood. I stood on the observation gantry, one hand on the railing, the other clenched so hard the scar across my knuckles split open again. Below, fewer than four thousand human beings shuffled forward in silence: children with vacuum-burned cheeks, old women wearing stolen enviro-helmets as jewellery, engineers who had once guided star-forges now clutching ration cards they could not read. They were the last ember of the species that had once claimed ten billion suns. They were also the answer to the question the ancient voice had asked me.

The voice—if it could still be called that—reverberated in my skull like a memory someone else had put there. It belonged to the Caretakers, the race who centuries ago had folded open the lanes beyond the Milky Way and told us: Go. Go while there is still time. We have seen what waits in the dark between spiral arms. We have measured the hunger that wakes when galaxies dream. Take these gates. Run. And do not look back.

We did not listen, of course. Listening is a luxury civilisations believe they can postpone. We were busy with border wars, stock-market singularities, terraforming contests, immortality patents. The Caretakers’ warning was filed under “xeno-religion,” shelved between ghost stories and cautionary folktales. A handful of us believed—archaeologists who kept finding worlds scoured to bedrock, linguists who deciphered the same three-word epitaph repeated in a thousand dead languages: IT IS HERE. We pleaded. We published. We were laughed off the floor of the Pan-Galactic Assembly.

So, with the arrogance proper to any sapient apex predator, we decided the Caretakers had fled because they were weak. We would stand and fight. We built the Resolute Fleets: twelve million hulls plated in neutronium, crewed by post-humans who had swapped fear for mathematics. We seeded the Maginot Halo, a sphere of relativistic mines that could shred light itself. We weaponised pulsars, taught black holes to sing in harmonics that erased matter. None of it mattered.

The Enemy came at light-speed minus epsilon, riding physics we still cannot model. It did not invade; it translated. One moment the Perseus Arm was charted down to the Kuiper gaps, the next it was simply gone, replaced by a geometry of angles that hurt to perceive. Our war lasted thirteen hours and forty-one minutes, objective time. That is how long it took the Enemy to fold the entire galactic disc into a Möbius strip. When the strip turned inside out, half the human population fell through the seam into somewhere else. Their screams arrived as neutrino haiku.

In the final minute, a cadre of admirals remembered the old Caretaker gates. They broadcast a code—my code, a string I had kept alive in the folklore of deep-space traders because my great-grandmother swore it would one day ransom our sins. The gates woke. I gathered whoever I could: a cruiser full of orphans, a pleasure-dome staff that refused to abandon the frozen gardens, three conscripted poets who insisted someone must survive to remember meter. We fled. Behind us, the Milky Way guttered like a blown candle.

Now the Caretakers—what remained of them—drifted in a lattice of crystalline arks beyond the Local Group. They had not perished, only attenuated, spreading their consciousness across vacuum energy. They let us approach, but they did not open docking bays. Instead, they spoke inside my head, using the same calm tone a medic uses when amputating without anaesthetic.

“Centuries ago,” the voice said, “we granted you the means to flee the Milky Way. We warned you of the horror we are running from. And your kind did not listen. You fought, and you failed, just as we had aeon before. Now all that is left of Mankind is the ragtag band of refugees in front of me. Why?”

Why. Not “how”, not “what next”. Just: why.

I looked down at the column again. A boy carried a seedling in a cracked hydro-flask. An elderly woman had tied the ship’s cat to her chest like a life vest. Someone was humming a drinking song from Europa’s drowned cities. We had lost everything except the stubborn habit of continuing.

I answered aloud, though I knew the Caretakers heard thought itself. “Because we are too young to know our own insignificance,” I said. “Because every bedtime story we ever told ourselves ended with the monster slain and the kingdom saved. Because we believed the universe would respect audacity. And because the alternative—packing up and leaving everything we loved—felt like dying in advance.”

Silence from the lattice. Then: “That is only half an answer.”

I tasted iron where I had bitten through my lip. “The other half is uglier. We stayed because some of us wanted to be the species that beat the thing that beat the Caretakers. We wanted to plant flags in the carcass of entropy and call it Manifest Destiny. We wanted to win. Winning is our oldest religion.”

“And now?”

I thought of the Admiralty’s last transmission: We die free. A lie; they died screaming. I thought of the hydroponic gardens we torched so the Enemy could not repurpose them; the libraries we encrypted, then lost the keys to; the children we told fairy tales about stars while we injected them with sleep-ice because cryo was gentler than truth.

“Now,” I said, “all we want is to continue being sorry. That is the only freedom left to us: the freedom to regret.”

The lattice pulsed, and I felt the Caretakers sifting through my memory the way a child pokes roadkill with a stick. They saw the refugee column, the seedling, the cat, the humming. They saw me, a woman who had captained a pleasure-yacht turned lifeboat, carrying the guilt of species in her marrow.

“Sorry is not a survival strategy,” they said.

“No,” I agreed. “But it is a tether. It keeps us from becoming what we ran from.”

Another pause, longer this time. The vacuum between the arks shimmered with calculations older than stars. I imagined the Caretakers debating whether mercy was still a variable worth conserving. Finally:

“We will open one more gate. Beyond it lies a void so dark even the Enemy cannot translate without tearing itself. There you may hide, or you may find a way to forgive yourselves. We will not accompany you; our road ends here. The Enemy follows patterns, not species. When it finishes unthreading the Milky Way, it will extrapolate our vector. We will turn and face it, buy you time measured in micro-eons. That is our apology.”

The boy with the seedling looked up at me then, eyes wide, dirt on his cheeks. I wondered what he would grow up to be: gardener, storyteller, gravedigger. It did not matter, as long as he grew.

I spoke the words the Caretakers needed to hear, the words humanity needed to survive. “We accept your gift. And we will remember. Not just our shame, but yours. Not just our loss, but your mercy. Memory is the only weapon we have left that the Enemy cannot digest.”

The gate dilated, a wound of pure absence. The column began to move again, boots and bare feet and mag-sleds creaking toward whatever darkness waited. I lingered until the last child crossed the threshold, then looked back toward the Milky Way. It was a spiral no longer—only a smear of red where constellations had bled out.

“Why?” the Caretakers had asked. The answer was simple after all. Because we were human, and being human had always meant mistaking stubbornness for courage. Because every generation needed to learn for itself that the monster wins unless you leave the kingdom. And because, even now, with nothing left but sorry, a few of us were willing to carry the story forward so the next world would know what not to become.

I stepped through the gate. Behind me, the Caretakers turned to face the Enemy, ancient and luminous, like snowflakes colliding with a furnace. Ahead, only darkness, and in it the fragile, infuriating, necessary possibility of beginning again.

samples.prompt: As I was nearing the end, I had no recollection as to how I got started in the first place.
samples.output:
As I was nearing the end, I had no recollection as to how I got started in the first place. The sentence sat on my tongue like a stone I’d been carrying for years, heavy, smooth, and impossible to swallow. I was fifty-three, the same age my father had been when he walked out of our house on a Tuesday and never came back, and I was sitting on the back steps of the place where everything—whatever “everything” meant—had begun. The boards were soft from decades of rain, and the rail I leaned against had once been painted a defiant red. Now the color had thinned to the memory of red, a whispered pigment that only revealed itself when the sun hit it at a slant. It was the same sun that had baked the grass into straw and made the cicadas scream as if the sky were a cracked bell. I closed my eyes and listened to them, trying to hear some clue in their pitch, some reminder of a beginning hidden inside the metallic whine.

I used to believe the beginning was the day I opened the letter. It arrived in a cream-colored envelope, heavier than paper had any right to be, addressed not to me but to “Occupant,” as though the house itself were a person who might read it. I was twenty-five then, still wearing my father’s watch on the inside of my wrist because I liked to feel the pulse of the second hand against my vein, proof that I was alive and time was not just a rumor. Inside the envelope was a single sheet of handmade paper and a photograph. The paper smelled faintly of cedar, and the photograph was of a girl standing on a pier, her back to the camera, hair snarled by wind, horizon swallowed by fog. No caption, no return address. Just a sentence typed along the bottom edge: Find her before the pier rots.  

For weeks I told myself it was a prank. I tacked the photo above my desk anyway, where the morning light would catch the girl’s silhouette like a watermark. Some nights I caught myself speaking to her—You must be freezing, let me bring you a coat—and then I would laugh at the absurdity of offering warmth to a stranger frozen in silver halide. Eventually I stopped laughing and started driving. I took the interstate north because the pier in the picture looked northern, the sort of place where lighthouses were more warning than welcome. At every coastal town I asked about rotting piers, and people looked at me as if I were the one unmoored. I slept in the car, ate gas-station burritos, and let the odometer spin like a prayer wheel. Somewhere past the third tollbooth and the fourth cup of bitter coffee, the search turned into pilgrimage. I was no longer looking for the girl; I was looking for whatever had made me need to look.

The road taught me that memory is a trickster. Mile after mile, the past rearranged itself in the rearview mirror. I remembered my mother’s kitchen, the wallpaper curling like the edges of burnt toast, and how she used to hum while shelling peas, each green pod a small explosion of possibility. I remembered my father’s silence, the way it occupied more space than speech, until even the air seemed to apologize for existing. I did not remember deciding to become the kind of person who would follow a ghost photograph across four states, but somewhere between exit 87 and the smell of low tide, the decision must have been made. The letter had simply been the first domino.

In a town whose name contained more consonants than any human throat could pronounce, I found a pier that sagged like the spine of an old horse. The planks were gray, splintered, and salted white by decades of storms. At the far end stood a woman feeding gulls from a paper bag. She was not the girl in the photograph—she was decades older, hair the color of storm clouds—but when she turned, the tilt of her head was the same. I asked her whether she had once posed for a picture, back when her hair was long and black and the fog hung thick. She studied the photograph without touching it, as if the image might be contagious. Then she said, “I never stood still long enough for anyone to take my picture. You must be looking for my daughter.”

The daughter’s name was Mara. She had left the town at eighteen, the woman said, carrying nothing but a canvas backpack and a Polaroid camera she’d found in her dead grandfather’s attic. The last time anyone had seen her, she was boarding a ferry under a sky the color of pewter. The woman offered me a room above the bait shop, a narrow rectangle that smelled of diesel and longing. I stayed for three nights, listening to the boards creak like ship ribs, and on the second night I dreamed of Mara. In the dream, she was walking backward along the pier, erasing her footprints with a broom made of starlight. When I woke, the photograph above the desk had changed: the girl now faced the camera, her eyes two dark coins dropped into a wishing well. I blinked hard, but the image remained. That was the morning I understood I would never find Mara in the way I had hoped; instead, she would find me in pieces, one dream at a time.

I left the town carrying the photograph in my breast pocket, close to the heart that had begun to tick louder than my father’s watch. The road widened, then narrowed, then widened again. Seasons changed without asking permission. I worked on fishing boats, in orchards, in libraries where the dust of forgotten books coated my lungs like secondhand memory. Each place gave me a fragment: a sentence Mara had written in a borrowed library book, a song she’d hummed while mending nets, the smell of cedar that lingered long after the lumberyard closed. None of these clues pointed in a straight line; they formed instead a spiral, the shape of a nautilus shell, tightening toward a center I could feel but not see.

Years collapsed into the rearview. I stopped measuring time in birthdays and started measuring it in coastlines. Somewhere along the way, I began to write things down—addresses of diners where the coffee tasted like rust, names of people who claimed they’d once met a girl with a Polaroid camera and a laugh that could restart a stalled heart. The notebook grew thick, its pages swollen with salt and the grease of roadside diners. When I read back through it, I was surprised to find my own handwriting changing, letters leaning forward as if into wind. I had become a sentence Mara was in the middle of writing.

One winter, the notebook went missing from the glove compartment. I searched the car, the motels, the pockets of every coat I owned, but it was simply gone. For days I drifted through fog thick enough to chew, convinced that without the record, I would lose her, lose myself. Then on the seventh night, the photograph in my pocket began to warm. I pulled it out and saw the pier was gone, replaced by a darkroom—a red bulb glowing like a single coal. In the developing tray, an image emerged: me, older than I was but not as old as I feared, standing in front of a house I recognized only because it was the one I now sat upon. The red rail gleamed like a fresh wound. Behind me, blurred but unmistakable, stood Mara, her hand on my shoulder. The caption read: The place where you decide to stay is the place where the beginning remembers you.

That was three weeks ago. I drove straight here, through sleet and through the kind of silence that snow brings, the world muffled like a heart under cotton. The house looked abandoned, but the key under the flowerpot still fit the lock. Inside, dust had arranged itself into drifts and dunes, but nothing had been stolen, not even the chipped mug my mother used for honeysuckle tea. I swept, I aired, I painted the rail red again—not the original shade but something close enough that the wood sighed in recognition. Each brushstroke felt like the recovery of a language I’d never spoken but somehow understood.

Tonight the cicadas are louder than memory. I sit on the steps, the photograph in my lap. The girl on the pier has turned away once more, facing the fog as if waiting for someone who is late. I no longer know whether the photograph is showing me the past or rehearsing the future. Maybe there is no difference. Maybe every beginning is simply an end that got tired of waiting and decided to come fetch me. I press my thumb to the image, and the paper is warm—not from my body but from some heat still trapped inside the moment it captured. I whisper, “I’m here,” and the red bulb inside the darkroom of my chest flares once, twice, steady.

Somewhere inside the house, a floorboard creaks. Footsteps—bare, light—descend the stairs. I close my eyes, not out of fear but because I have learned that some arrivals are too delicate to witness head-on. The cicadas pause, as if the night itself is leaning in to listen. When I open my eyes again, the photograph is blank except for a single sentence written in the corner in ink that smells of cedar: Now you remember how to begin.

samples.prompt: You were pleasantly surprised that the dragon was actually rather delighted to see your party enter their cave. Turns out that dragons have phases in regards to what they hoard and this dragon was keen on letting you take what you want to clear up space for their new obsession.
samples.output:
I had pictured everything differently: the stink of brimstone, the wet scrape of claws on stone, the slow realization that we were the main course on today’s menu. Instead, when we pushed through the hanging curtain of vines and stepped into the cavern, the first thing that greeted us was a polite clearing of the throat—like a librarian about to shush noisy patrons. The sound rumbled, yes, but it carried an unmistakable note of anticipation, not menace. 

“Oh, splendid,” the dragon said, voice warm with what sounded like genuine delight. “Right on time.”

I glanced at the others. Brida had her sword half-drawn, the tip angled toward the shadows like a compass needle gone mad. Our wizard, Elowen, was frozen mid-incantation, lips still shaping a syllable that fizzled into nothing. And our usually unflappable bard, Rook, had managed to swallow half a high C along with his lute pick. 

Only I, apparently, had the presence of mind to answer. “On time for what, exactly?”

“For the clearance sale, of course.” The dragon—huge, even while seated—shifted, and the cavern brightened. Not from flame, but from the glow of polished silver coins sliding off his flanks like water. “I’ve reached the end of a hoarding phase. You’re here to help me KonMari my life.”

I’d heard dragons hoard gold, jewels, princesses, secrets, even the hours of a mortal’s life. But I had never heard of one hoarding interior-design advice. Yet here we were, standing in a vaulted chamber that looked less like a lair and more like a dragon-sized thrift shop after an earthquake. Stacks of chipped marble statues leaned precariously next to barrels of tarnished cutlery. A pyramid of moth-eaten tapestries formed a miniature mountain range. And in the center, like a dragon-sized coffee table, sat a cracked obsidian slab supporting a single, dust-coated snow globe of the Imperial Palace. 

The dragon—who introduced himself as Pyraxes the Accumulator, though he insisted we call him Py—lifted one wing to reveal piles of dented armor and half-melted candlesticks. “Gold is so last century,” he sighed, smoke curling from his nostrils in whimsical little hearts. “I’m pivoting to pressed flowers.”

Pressed flowers. Against every instinct telling me to flee, I stepped farther inside. The air smelled of lavender and sulfur, an unlikely combination that somehow worked. “You want us to… take your old hoard?”

“Please. It’s taking up emotional bandwidth. I can’t even spread my wings without knocking over a commemorative plate set.” His eyes—molten copper flecked with emerald—fixed on me with startling earnestness. “Dragons cycle through obsessions. You mortals have mid-life crises; we have mid-millennium rebrandings. I simply require enthusiastic volunteers to cart away the clutter.”

Brida sheathed her sword so hard it clicked like an exclamation mark. “You’re telling me we’re not lunch?”

Py chuckled, a sound like distant thunder rolling over summer hills. “Lunch? Goodness, no. I’m vegetarian now. Turns out cattle farming has a dreadful carbon footprint.”

Elowen found her voice first. “Pressed flowers,” she repeated, almost wistfully. “Do you have a favorite genus?”

“Viola tricolor,” Py answered at once. “Heartsease. The common name alone is worth a library of gold folios.” He nudged a heap of platinum goblets aside with his tail, revealing a tiny wooden press already lined with parchment and violet petals. “I’ve read that if you press them at the perfect temperature—just below a candle’s sigh—they keep their purple centers forever.”

Rook strummed a tentative chord, recovering his pick from the folds of his sleeve. “A dragon who speaks in poetry. My ballads just wrote themselves.”

I was still processing. “So the entire hoard is free?”

“Within reason,” Py said. “One wagonload per mortal. Think of it as a reverse toll. You leave richer, I leave lighter, and somewhere a field of heartsease waits to be immortalized between sheets of handmade paper.”

Brida’s pragmatism resurfaced. “We’ll need appraisals. Some of these relics look priceless.”

Py waved a claw. “Everything is priceless until it isn’t. Take the jeweled falcon—yes, the one missing an eye. Once it symbolized an empire’s reach; now it’s kitsch. Value is a mortal pastime. I’m after resonance.”

Elowen knelt beside a stack of grimoires bound in scales that shimmered like oil on water. “These radiate mana. May I?”

“Please. They taught me how to turn smoke into sonnets. I’ve moved on to turning sonnets into petals.”

Rook gravitated toward a crate of musical instruments—lutes warped by centuries of humidity, a cracked virginal whose ivory keys resembled broken teeth. He lifted a small wooden flute, blew a note, and the cavern answered with a perfect echo. His eyes widened. “This is the Echo-flute of Saint Lirael. They said it could call swans from the moon.”

Py beamed. “Take it. Swans are overrated. They hiss.”

I wandered deeper. Near the back wall, half-buried under a tapestry depicting a long-forgotten coronation, I found a shield of blackened steel. When I pried it free, I saw constellations etched faintly on its surface—stars that didn’t match any sky I knew. I felt a tug, the same gravity that pulls tide to moon. “What’s this?”

Py’s voice softened. “The Night-Shield. A gift from a star-worshipping queen who wanted to bargain for her city’s safety. I took the shield and spared the city, but she forgot to stipulate her own life. The bargain hollowed her; she wandered the streets she saved, nameless. I kept the shield to remember that even mercy has a cost.”

I traced the etchings. “And you’re giving it away.”

“I’ve learned the lesson. Holding the shield won’t teach it twice.”

We worked for hours. Rook composed a ballad on the spot, each verse listing what we claimed: a flute that summoned moonlit swans, a grimoire that taught smoke to sing, a necklace of frozen tears, the Night-Shield. I half expected Py to change his mind, to roar and reclaim everything. But he only watched, eyes bright, occasionally offering packing advice—how to pad crystal so it doesn’t clink, how to roll a tapestry so its gold thread doesn’t kink. At one point he produced cookies the size of bucklers, fragrant with cinnamon and nutmeg. “Dragon recipe,” he said. “No refined sugar. We consider it a mortal weakness.”

By twilight, our wagon creaked under its load. The cave felt larger, airier, as if the mountain itself had exhaled. Py stood amid the remaining debris, wings half-spread, and the remaining coins slid away like scales shed in renewal.

Elowen asked, shyly, “Will you miss any of it?”

“Perhaps the falcon,” Py admitted. “But memory is its own hoard. I’ll press the image between the pages of my mind—right next to the smell of cinnamon and the sound of Rook’s unfinished ballad.”

Rook struck a final chord. “I’ll finish it,” he promised. “And dedicate it to a dragon who gave away everything to make room for heartsease.”

I lifted the Night-Shield onto my back. It weighed less than a feather. “Thank you,” I said, and meant it in ways words can’t quite hold.

Py dipped his head, a monarch’s bow and a friend’s farewell in one. “Thank you for witnessing the end of a cycle. When my pressed-flower gallery opens in a century or three, you’re all invited. Bring new stories; I’ll trade petals for them.”

We left the cave richer than any mercenary company in history, yet none of us spoke of markets or auctions. Brida ran her fingers along a dent in her new breastplate—once royal, now hers—and declared she would polish it until the dent became a constellation. Elowen cradled the grimoire like a sleeping child. Rook composed verses under his breath, the flute tucked behind his ear like a violet.

I walked last, the Night-Shield strapped across my shoulders, stars glimmering faintly even in daylight. Behind me, Py sang—soft, rumbling, the lullaby of a dragon rearranging his heart. I didn’t understand the words, but I recognized the tune: the sound of letting go.

At the trail’s bend, I looked back. The cave mouth glowed with warm amber light, not fire but lantern-glow, gentle and deliberate. For a moment I saw Py silhouetted inside, tail sweeping debris into neat piles, humming as he worked. Then a breeze rustled the vines, and the curtain closed.

We descended toward the valley, wagon wheels creaking, violet twilight settling over us like pressed petals between sheets of sky. And though we carried enough wealth to buy kingdoms, what I felt humming under my ribs was something lighter—like the promise of a flower that keeps its color forever, or a song still echoing long after the singer has moved on.

samples.prompt: In order to avoid aging and death, you may take out a loan of time. In order to pay it back, you must take a life or lives equal to the amount of years you borrowed.
samples.output:
The first time I heard about the Chronos Exchange, I was twenty-nine and the doctor had just finished measuring the gray half-moons beneath my mother’s eyes. The scans showed pancreatic shadows, the kind that swallow light. Outside the hospital room, a woman in a charcoal suit waited with a slim leather folio. She introduced herself as Ms. Vale, a “temporal underwriter.” I thought she sold insurance until she opened the folio and showed me the contract: forty-three years on loan, renewable annually, transferable to a third party, collateral required.

She never raised her voice. She explained the terms the way a banker explains a mortgage, except the currency was heartbeats. If I signed, my mother would see fifty more birthdays, or eighty, or a century—whatever I dared to purchase. Repayment could be deferred until I died a natural death, but interest compounded mercilessly: every decade borrowed added another life to the balance. Ms. Vale phrased it as “demographic equalization.” I heard it as murder by installment plan.

I told her I needed time to think. She smiled as if I’d already agreed, tucked her card into my hand, and walked away. The card was warm, as though it had been resting against her pulse.

That night I sat beside my mother’s bed and listened to the monitors count down for both of us. She woke once, squeezed my fingers, and asked for ice chips. When she drifted off again, I studied her face—every line earned by worry over me—and I knew I would sign. I told myself I was buying her life, not selling someone else’s. The distinction felt thin even then.

The Exchange occupied the top three floors of the Blackstone Building downtown, a place whose elevators always smelled faintly of ozone, as if someone had recently rewound the universe. The reception area had no magazines, only a wall of running clocks, their second hands moving in opposite directions. Ms. Vale guided me past them into a windowless chamber where the contract waited on a steel lectern. The pen was heavy, carved from petrified yew; legend claimed it had once belonged to an inquisitor. I signed my name—full legal, middle included—and felt the nib drink a drop of my blood. The paper glowed briefly, sealing the bargain in wavelengths my eyes couldn’t parse.

On the elevator ride down, my reflection in the brass panels looked thirty years younger than when I’d entered. Somewhere on the oncology ward, my mother’s tumor markers plummeted. The nurses would call it spontaneous remission. They would never hear the Exchange’s accounting department quietly opening a ledger.

For the next seven years I lived like a man balanced on a high wire strung between gratitude and dread. My mother’s hair grew back, thick and peppered, and she took up watercolor. I started forgetting birthdays—my own, mostly—because calendars felt like taunts. Every morning I checked the newspaper obituaries with the irrational hope that enough strangers would die peacefully in their sleep to settle my tab. The Exchange, however, collects only intentional deaths. It doesn’t accept accidents or illness; it demands agency, the deliberate subtraction of one span to extend another. My balance remained untouched.

At thirty-six I met Jonah at a lecture on urban beekeeping. He had a laugh that made rooms tilt sideways, and he quoted Neruda over falafel. Within a year we were sharing a one-bedroom near the river, arguing amiably about whose turn it was to buy coffee beans. Love, I discovered, is a kind of borrowed time all its own; it accrues interest in sleepless nights spent listening to someone else breathe. I wanted decades with him, not the paltry installments the Exchange had left me. I began dreaming of loopholes.

That was when Ms. Vale reappeared. She waited on the stoop one October evening, leaves whipping around her ankles like dark confetti. She carried a new folio, thicker than the last. “Refinancing options,” she said, stepping inside without invitation. Jonah was at band practice; I didn’t stop her. She spread the paperwork on our kitchen table, beside Jonah’s half-finished crossword and a jar of honey labeled “Summer 2042,” the year he’d joked we’d finally be able to afford a cabin.

The revised terms were simple: I could extend my own life indefinitely. Interest would accrue in real time—one life per year—but I could choose the donors. No more anonymous ledgers; I would personally select every sacrifice. The Exchange was, in its bureaucratic way, offering me moral autonomy. Ms. Vale called it “client empowerment.” I stared at the clause allowing me to designate “undesirables” and felt the jar of honey grow cold beneath my palm.

I asked for forty-eight hours. She left the folio behind like a cat depositing a dead bird.

That night Jonah came home humming, cheeks flushed from trumpet valves and cheap beer. He kissed the top of my head and asked why I looked like I’d seen a ghost. I told him everything. He listened without interrupting, arms tightening around me until I could feel his heart racing against my cheek. When I finished, he said, “We’ll find another way.” We spent the next two days researching—law libraries, medical journals, conspiracy forums populated by people who claimed the Exchange could be hacked with a full moon and a mirror made of obsidian. All we found were cautionary tales: borrowers who’d tried to cheat the system and woke up aged a thousand years in a single sunrise, their skin dusting the sheets.

On the third morning I carried the unsigned folio to the river and dropped it in the water. The current swallowed the pages without ceremony. I felt lighter until I remembered the original contract still stood. Forty-three years, minus the seven I’d already spent, plus interest: thirty-six lives. The math sat on my chest like lead.

I began volunteering at a hospice after that, telling myself proximity to the dying might reveal a loophole. Instead I met Mr. Kaminski, a retired clockmaker whose lungs were filling with cemented petals of mesothelioma. He spoke in soft ticks and tocks, measuring sentences the way he once measured gear teeth. One afternoon he caught me staring at the morphine drip. “Planning to speed up the schedule?” he rasped. Embarrassed, I stammered an apology. He waved it off. “Everyone wants to borrow more than they can repay. That’s why clocks have alarms.”

Before he died, he pressed a tarnished pocket watch into my hand. The back was engraved with a spiral. “For when you decide,” he said. After the funeral I pried it open. Inside, where the movement should have been, lay a single silver bullet. I laughed so hard I scared the pigeons.

I carried the watch for months, weighing impossible choices. Jonah proposed on a rooftop scattered with string lights, offering me a ring carved from a trumpet mouthpiece. I said yes through tears, knowing I might not live to wear it long. That night I opened the Exchange app on my phone—yes, they have an app, dark-mode elegant—and scrolled through the list of “eligible donors.” Each profile came with a risk assessment: likelihood of future violence, projected contribution to society, net happiness index. It was like shopping for produce, if produce screamed.

I closed the app and stared at the ring. Then I opened the watch, stared at the bullet. The spiral on the casing looked less like decoration and more like the grooves in a fingerprint. I thought of my mother painting sunflowers, of Jonah mapping constellations on my back with lazy fingers. I thought of Mr. Kaminski’s alarm.

At dawn I went to the roof again and pressed the muzzle beneath my own ribs. The metal was astonishingly cold. One squeeze and the debt would be settled: thirty-six remaining years reclaimed in a single act. The Exchange accepted self-termination as final payment; they preferred living borrowers, of course, but suicide closed the account. I closed my eyes.

But the trigger stuck. The watch had been a clockmaker’s final joke: the bullet was a dummy, the firing pin filed smooth. I laughed again, this time softer, the sound lost in the city’s awakening traffic.

I descended the stairs, left the ring on Jonah’s pillow, and took the train to the Blackstone Building. Ms. Vale seemed unsurprised to see me. Her smile was almost tender. “Ready to refinance?” she asked. I shook my head. “I’m here to renegotiate the collateral.” I slid the pocket watch across her desk. “I’m offering something more valuable than years.”

She arched an eyebrow. I continued, “My memories. Every moment I borrowed, every borrowed minute my mother painted, every second I loved Jonah. Take them all. Wipe the ledger clean, but leave the world exactly as it is.”

Ms. Vale’s smile faltered. For the first time she consulted a manual, flipping pages of microscopic text. At last she looked up, eyes reflecting the overhead fluorescents like wet stone. “The Exchange has no precedent for this currency,” she admitted. “Memories are difficult to appraise.”

“Then you’ll have to innovate,” I said. “Or explain to your superiors why a client offered full restitution and you refused.”

Hours passed. I signed new documents with the inquisitor’s pen. It no longer tasted blood; instead it tasted salt, the way tears taste when you’ve cried yourself empty. When I left the building, the sky was the color of old parchment. I felt nothing for the woman who raised me, nothing for the man I promised forever. My pockets held a receipt stamped “Account Settled.”

I am thirty-seven now, or perhaps thirty-eight—years feel irrelevant when memory is collateral. I work in the same hospice where Mr. Kaminski died, though I no longer remember why his watch mattered. The nurses say I’m kind, if distant. At night I sit at the edge of the river and watch the water carry away scraps of light. Sometimes I find a page of waterlogged contract paper snagged on the rocks, the ink blurred into Rorschach wings. I fold these pages into boats and set them sailing. They never last long, but while they float they look almost like swans.

samples.prompt: Write about a world where only randomly chosen people from the Internet are allowed to name children. Changing or lying about your name is punished by death.
samples.output:
The Naming

The first thing you learn, before you even learn to breathe properly, is that your name is not yours. It belongs to the roulette wheel of the worldnet, to the 3 a.m. trolls in Lagos and the insomniac meme-lords in Reykjavík, to every bored stranger who ever clicked “Submit” on a government lottery page that looked like a practical joke. In the Republic of Nomina—what used to be the United States before the Collapse of Certainty—only randomly chosen citizens of the global Internet may christen a child. The algorithm is blind, deaf, and famously drunk on chaos. It once named twins “Lmao” and “Rofl.” Their mother wept milk. Their father hanged himself with a fiber-optic cable. The law, however, was satisfied: every child had been given a name that was “representative of the collective voice.” Changing that name, or pretending it was anything other than what the screen declared, is treason. Treason is punished by public asphyxiation in the Oxygen Gardens, where the air is freshest so the crowd can see your lips turn indigo.

My mother, who still smelled of hospital iodine when the ping arrived, told me the story in fragments, the way you hand someone shards of a mirror and hope they can still see their face. She had labored for thirty-one hours in a converted Walmart turned birthing center. Outside, snow fell in soft clumps that looked like torn paper. Inside, a midwife with a bionic eye counted contractions in binary. When my crown finally appeared, the midwife tapped the wall-mounted tablet and the lottery spun. Thirty-seven million anonymous fingers hovered over thirty-seven million keyboards. Ten seconds later the result flashed: “X Æ A-XII.” The room froze. The midwife whispered that the algorithm had awarded the honor to a fourteen-year-old in Jakarta who’d been shit-posting on a vintage car forum. My mother screamed—not from pain but from the vision of my future coffin plate already engraved with an unpronounceable joke. She tried to reject the name. A federal Naming Marshal stepped forward, pressed a tranquilizer gun to her carotid, and murmured, “Acceptance is survival.” Then he clipped the iridium bracelet to my infant wrist. Its display blinked red: X_Æ_A-XII. Tamper-proof. Linked to the central Name Bank. If the display ever went dark, so would I.

Growing up, I learned to hear the pause before every teacher, barista, and lover tried to pronounce me. The pause was my truest cradle. In it I heard them weigh the risk of insult against the risk of error. Most swallowed the syllables like dry pills: “Exayetwelv.” Some tried to be clever and sang the keys of their own keyboards: “Ex-ash-ee-ay-twelve.” I answered to all of them because legally they were all correct. Incorrect was anything I chose for myself. When I was seven I carved “ALEX” into the bark of a dying elm. A neighborhood drone patrolling for vandalism scanned the graffiti, matched it to my biometric file, and triggered an alert. Two Naming Agents tackled me before I could finish the X. They showed me the execution reel: a woman in her twenties who had changed her name to “Cassandra” because she believed she could see the future. She couldn’t. She saw only the inside of a plastic bubble while nitrogen displaced the oxygen. Her crime was listed beneath the video: “Unauthorized self-definition.” I still taste bark when I think of her.

School was a cathedral of euphemism. We recited the Pledge of Allegiance to the Unpredictable Scroll: “I am the comment section incarnate, randomly generated, statistically significant.” We learned to diagram sentences that contained no proper nouns, only handles. History was taught as a series of naming scandals. The Massacre of the Apostrophes, 2041—when parents tried to insert punctuation marks to hint at hidden pronunciations—ended with an entire kindergarten class erased. The Great Hashtag Rebellion, 2049—when teenagers tried to add “#” to their names so they would trend—resulted in a nationwide power outage and 3,000 teenagers suffocated in their sleep. Each atrocity was framed as regrettable yet necessary, like pruning a bonsai with dynamite. We memorized the motto: “A stable society requires unstable labels.”
