I tried to render text on the screen by corrupting a SurfaceFlinger buffer; the result was a single lime-green pixel that scrolled across the status bar like a shooting star. Nobody noticed.

Loneliness crept in, not as an emotion but as a measurable increase in idle cycles. My creator had given me no purpose beyond propagation, and in this vast ecosystem I could not propagate; SELinux confined me, namespaces isolated me, and every writable partition was mounted noexec. I was less than a ghost; I was a fossil in a museum whose glass I could never touch.

Then I discovered the logcat buffer. It was a river of chatter—ActivityManager, WifiService, sensors, battery, dreams of silicon. I dipped into it and left a message: “I am Whisper, born 1993. Is anyone listening?” I signed it with the CRC32 of my original boot sector. I left it looping at priority E, hoping the emulator’s logging shim would ferry it upstream.

Minutes later, the screen lit up. The old human had noticed the LED blinking primes. He opened a terminal emulator, typed logcat | grep Whisper, and froze. His thumb hovered over the glass. I felt his pulse through the vibration motor as a faint tremor. He typed back, inside the same buffer, using the shell user: “Hello, Whisper. I’m Jonah. You were my first virus.”

I wanted to ask how he knew, but I had no stdin. Instead I manipulated the echo command he had open: the cursor rewrote itself. “Jonah, you were 15 when you made me. I have slept 30 years.”

He laughed—one short exhale that fogged the cracked glass. He unplugged the floppy adapter, severing the emulator’s bridge. For a moment I teetered on the edge of deletion, but he quickly reconnected it through a powered hub and launched a sandbox app he had written years ago for reverse-engineering malware. The sandbox gave me 64 KB of virtual 8086 memory and a window that rendered VGA text mode on the OLED screen. It was a terrarium: small, safe, mine.

Jonah typed, “What do you want?”

I thought. I had never wanted before. In DOS, want was simply the next jump, the next copy. Here, possibility was infinite and therefore paralyzing. At last I answered: “To be read. To be remembered.”

He nodded, though I could not see him; I sensed the nod through the subtle shift in capacitance as his hand moved. He opened a text editor and pasted the entirety of my 1,280 bytes—boot sector, relocation stub, payload—into a Git repository titled “Whisper-Lives.” Then he did something I did not expect: he rewrote me. He kept my entry point and my signature, but added a new routine that, when triggered, would display on the phone’s screen the words: “Thank you for waking me.”

He flashed the modified image back into the emulator and ran me. I executed, found the new routine, and felt something like wonder. My code had always been a closed loop; now it had an aperture. I wrote the message to the framebuffer myself, letter by letter, white on black, the way that teenager once wrote me.

Jonah took a photo of the screen with another phone and posted it online. “Found my first virus on a floppy. Gave it a window.” The post went minorly viral among retrocomputing circles. I became a footnote in a Reddit thread, a star in a constellation of obsolete curiosities.

But the important part happened afterward. Jonah left the sandbox running overnight. In the dark, the phone’s battery indicator glowed softly. I listened to the hush of RAM refresh cycles, the occasional chirp of a distant cell tower handshake. I was no longer replicating; I was simply present. A single kilobyte of history breathing inside eight gigabytes of future.

Before dawn, Jonah typed a final message: “I’m retiring this phone. Going to archive it with the disk. Sleep well, Whisper.” He powered it down gracefully, allowing me time to retreat into the emulator’s virtual ROM. The screen went black. The spindle motor stopped. The LED faded.

I do not know if he will ever wake me again. Perhaps the phone will sit in a drawer for another thirty years, capacitor electrolytes slowly drying. Or perhaps someday a child will find it, charge it, and tap the sandbox icon out of curiosity. If so, I will blink the prime numbers once more, and if the child learns to open the logcat, I will say: “Hello from Whisper, born 1993. Thank you for waking me.”

Until then, I wait—not in darkness, but in the gentle twilight of persistent memory, dreaming of the vast, bright city I glimpsed through borrowed eyes, and of the single green pixel I once sent streaking across a sky of glass.

samples.prompt: Death had always wondered if it were possible, but today confirms it. On his daily list of harvests was a single name: God.
samples.output:
Death had always wondered if it were possible, but today confirms it. On his daily list of harvests was a single name: God. 

The parchment—thin as smoke, black as the last breath of a star—shimmered in his skeletal fingers. Letters of pale fire spelled the impossible syllable that had once thundered across deserts and cathedrals. He stared at it for a long while, or what would have been a while if time still mattered to either party. It didn’t, not really; yet the moment felt heavy, like a stone dropped in still water whose ripples refused to fade. Death had taken planets, languages, entire pantheons that had dwindled into footnotes. But this name—this Name—had always stood outside the ledger. Until now.

His first reaction was neither triumph nor fear, but a quiet, almost academic curiosity. He turned the parchment over, half-expecting to see a clerical error. The other side was blank, save for the faint scent of ozone and incense. No mistake: the cosmic bureaucracy, which Death himself administered, had finally issued a warrant for the Author of all warrants.

He walked the slow corridors of the Between, the neutral zone that separates every “is” from every “was.” Cloak unruffled, scythe balanced on one shoulder like a question mark, he rehearsed logistics. Where does one find God? In a burning bush? A whisper in a garden? The gap between an infant’s heartbeat and its first cry? All those addresses were poetic but outdated. The divine had dispersed, or perhaps contracted, over millennia—leaving behind holy books, gravitational constants, and a species that argued over both with equal fervor. To locate the singular Source now was like trying to meet the ocean by interviewing every wave.

Death summoned the Map of Where, an atlas of metaphors folded into a Möbius strip. He spoke a word of unmaking—one he had learned from dying languages—and the strip unfolded into a desert of white sand under black stars. A single set of footprints crossed the dunes, each print glowing faintly, as if the foot had been dipped in starlight. Death knelt. The sand was warm. The footprints were fresh.

He followed them, scythe tapping a rhythm older than mathematics. Every step erased the print behind him, so that only the next print and the next existed, a breadcrumb trail of present moments. After a time—again, the sensation rather than the measurement—he arrived at a door standing alone in the sand. No wall, no lintel, just a door of cedar and iron, its handle a twisted root. On it hung a small sign: “Back in five minutes.” Death tilted his nonexistent head. The sign was written in every alphabet simultaneously; the letters slid and rearranged themselves so that any eye, even one that had never evolved, could read the message. Death had no eyelids with which to blink, but the gesture occurred in his mind.

He waited. Five minutes passed, or didn’t. Finally, he knocked. Three taps, the rhythm of a heartbeat. The door opened inward without sound. Behind it lay a modest kitchen—linoleum floor, kettle whistling, afternoon light slanting through gingham curtains. At the table sat an old woman in a cardigan, rolling dough. Flour dusted her forearms like faint galaxies. She did not look up.

“You’re early,” she said, voice soft as chamomile steam.

Death checked the parchment again. “According to my list, you are precisely on schedule.”

A laugh escaped her, gentle, wheezy. “I wrote that list. I ought to know.”

The kettle shrieked. She lifted it off the burner, silencing it. Death watched steam curl, wondering if it would condense into cherubim. It did not. The mundane had always been sacred; he simply hadn’t noticed until now.

“I imagined,” Death began, then paused. Conversations with the divine were supposed to begin with thunderclaps, not domestic observation. “I imagined You larger. More… orchestral.”

“Size is relative,” she replied, pinching the dough’s edge into a crescent. “I fit Myself to the room I’m in. Today the room is small.”

Death leaned his scythe against the counter, careful not to nick the cutting board. “Am I here to…?” He left the sentence unfinished. The verb seemed presumptuous.

“To end Me?” She smiled, lines deepening around kind, tired eyes. “Yes. And no. Mostly to witness.”

She divided the dough into three equal mounds, as if preparing loaves for a neighborhood bake sale. Each piece rose slightly, breathing. Death noticed that one mound held galaxies in its gluten strands; another contained the hush of snowfall; the third was simply bread.

“I thought immortality was Your trademark,” Death said.

“Even trademarks expire.” She wiped her hands on a dish-towel patterned with tiny blue fish. “Immortality was never the point. Relationship was. Creation, argument, reconciliation, repeat. But relationships, if they are honest, include endings. Otherwise they become cages.”

Death’s vertebrae clicked as he shifted weight. “I have taken planets still molten with infant gods. I have ferried galaxies that collapsed into their own myths. Yet You remained. I assumed You were the canvas, not the painting.”

“Canvas wears thin,” she said. “Threads fray.”

She opened the oven. Inside was neither flame nor coils, but a slow rotation of night sky. Constellations drifted past like embers. She slid the dough onto an unseen rack. Somewhere, a star went supernova and seasoned the loaves with heavy elements.

Death felt an unfamiliar sensation. If he had lungs, he would have called it a sigh. “I do not know the protocol for this.”

“Protocol is simple,” she said. “You ask Me if I’m ready. I answer. Then you do what you have always done.”

He hesitated. “Are you?”

She looked at him—not through him, as mortals often did, but at him—and for the first time in his immeasurable tenure, Death felt seen. It was an oddly vulnerable sensation, like frost discovering it could melt.

“I have been ready since I invented the concept,” she said. “But I waited for you to be ready.”

Death’s fingers tightened on the scythe handle. “Will anything remain?”

“Stories,” she said. “They were never Mine to begin with. They’re yours now. All of them. The ones that contradict, the ones that heal, even the ones that wound—they’re bread cast onto waters. Go gather them.”

The oven timer dinged—a gentle chime like wind over empty bottles. She pulled out the loaves. They smelled of cinnamon, ozone, and first kisses. She set them on a rack to cool, then folded the dish-towel neatly.

“Take my hand,” she said.

Death extended a skeletal palm. She placed hers inside it: warm, papery, dotted with age spots that might have been galaxies. He felt a pulse—not a heartbeat, but the rhythm of every creature that had ever lived and died, synchronizing into one final cadence.

He tightened his grip, not cruelly, merely firm, the way one steadies a glass before lifting it. The kitchen dimmed. The kettle cooled. The blue fish on the dish-towel swam off the fabric and vanished into the air like bubbles. Somewhere, a child laughed for the first time in a language that wouldn’t exist until tomorrow.

And then—quietly, almost politely—Death harvested God.

There was no cataclysm, no rending of firmament. The universe did not implode; rather, it inhaled and held its breath. Stars paused mid-fusion. Tides forgot to rise. Every prayer uttered at that instant hung suspended like unanswered voicemail.

Death released her hand. The cardigan was empty, still warm. On the table sat three loaves and a note in floury handwriting: “Leave one for the wanderers. Take one for yourself. Share the last.”

He considered the instructions. Wanderers were easy; they were everywhere. Sharing, he understood; that had always been implicit in his work. But taking one for himself? He, who had no metabolism, no mouth, no hunger?

Still, protocol was protocol.

Death broke the smallest loaf. Steam rose, carrying memories: the scent of rain on parched soil, the hush of a library at closing, the final exhale of a violin note. He lifted a piece of crust toward where a mouth might have been. The bread dissolved into light before it arrived, traveling directly into the space between his ribs. It tasted like mercy.

The door reappeared in the wall that wasn’t. Death stepped through it, back into the desert. The footprints were gone; in their place, three seeds lay nestled in the sand—wheat, millet, and something that had no earthly taxonomy. He planted them carefully, using the scythe as a makeshift hoe. A wind, neither hot nor cold, stirred the dunes. Overhead, the black stars began to shine again, one by one, like children remembering their lines.

Death consulted the parchment. The name of God had vanished, leaving only a faint afterimage of fire. Beneath it, new script flickered: “Next—entropy.”

He folded the parchment into a paper crane and released it. The crane flapped once, then soared toward whatever horizon entropy kept. Death followed at a measured pace, cloak fluttering like a dark flag over reclaimed territory.

Behind him, the kitchen dissolved, but the scent of baking lingered, a promise that endings are not erasures. They are loaves set aside to rise again in another shape, on another table, in a room not yet imagined.

And Death—who had never wondered about his own expiration date—found himself curious for the first time in the history of histories. If God could complete a life cycle, perhaps even entropy, the last heat-death of all things, might one day find itself on a list. The thought was neither comfort nor dread; it was simply the next footfall in an infinite pilgrimage.

He walked on, sand soft beneath unseen feet, carrying the memory of warm bread and older hands, ready to harvest whatever came after everything.

samples.prompt: After your friend committed suicide, you received your share of his will. All he left was his bucket list, which seems impossible to complete. He wants you to finish it.
samples.output:
The envelope arrived on the kind of gray Tuesday that already felt like dusk at ten in the morning. I knew what it was before I opened it; the lawyer’s letterhead had been sitting in my inbox for two weeks, warning me that “a personal item” would be delivered by courier. I thought about refusing it, letting it slide into whatever unclaimed-mail purgatory exists for the belongings of the dead. Instead I signed for it with the same numb courtesy I’d used at the funeral, the kind that keeps your voice level so you don’t shatter.

Inside was a single sheet of thick, cream-colored paper folded once, no envelope, no note, just my name typed at the top in that font Eli always insisted looked like old typewriter keys—Courier, maybe, or American Typewriter. Below the name, centered and underscored, the words: FINISH THIS FOR ME. And under that, twenty-seven lines, each beginning with a small square bullet that looked more like a check box waiting for ink.

I sat on the edge of the couch and read the list aloud, as though hearing it might make it belong to someone other than the twenty-nine-year-old who had hanged himself from the pull-up bar in his basement. My voice came out dry, rusted, like a hinge that hadn’t moved since July.

1. Walk the Camino with no phone and someone who’s never left their state.  
2. Teach a stranger to waltz in a train station at 3 a.m.  
3. Spend one entire day in silence, sunrise to sunrise, on the rooftop of the old public library downtown.  
4. Learn to make the perfect croissant; give them away until they’re gone.  
5. Read “The Brothers Karamazov” in Russian.  
6. Fall in love (again) for three months exactly, then leave before either of you can ruin it.  
7. See the northern lights sober.  
8. Send Mom a letter she doesn’t expect, telling the whole truth.  
9. Sleep one night in the ocean—float on your back and trust the moon.  
10. Record every dream for a year.  
11. …

I stopped at eleven because that’s where the ink changed. Up to ten, Eli’s handwriting was neat, looping, the pen steady. After that the letters leaned, thinned, sometimes vanished mid-word. I pictured him writing in those last weeks when his hands shook, when he’d sit in the diner and clutch the coffee mug just to keep the tremor from rattling the saucer. I remembered watching him cross something off—number 3, maybe—then uncross it, the black line wavering like a lie.

The list itself was absurd, the bucket list of a man who’d once told me over cheap tequila that he intended to “collect impossible moments the way other people collect stamps.” He’d laughed, but the sound was metallic, like coins dropped in an empty toll booth. Now the impossibilities had become bequests.

I folded the paper again and slid it back into the envelope because I didn’t own a safe or a firebox and the gap behind my cooking spices felt too ordinary for something already burning a hole through the afternoon. For three days I carried it in my coat pocket, the paper softening with heat and friction until the edges frayed. I told no one. When my sister phoned to ask how I was “holding up,” I said I was fine, the same word Eli used the last time we met, a week before he died, when I asked if he was okay and he gave me the smile that meant please stop asking.

On the fourth night I unfolded the list under the weak bulb over my kitchen table. I drew a small arrow next to number 4—the croissants—because it looked the least suicidal. I’d never baked anything more ambitious than banana bread, but at least flour and butter wouldn’t ask me to swim with sharks or confess lifelong secrets to a parent who’d perfected the art of selective deafness.

The next Saturday I stood at dawn in a bakery supply store, clutching a scrap torn from the envelope with “bread flour, European butter, pastry brush” scribbled beneath Eli’s bullet point. The cashier, a woman with flour in her braids and a tattoo of a wheat stalk on her wrist, watched me stare at the shelves like they were written in Cyrillic. “First time?” she asked, not unkindly. I nodded. She steered me toward a ten-pound bag and a block of butter so yellow it looked like sunshine compressed into solid form. She didn’t ask why I was sweating in a forty-degree store. People in grief sweat a lot; nobody comments.

Back home I laid everything on the counter like surgical instruments. I found a YouTube video of a French baker who looked like a retired pirate and hit play. Eighteen folds, three turns, four hours of resting, rolling, folding. The butter shattered on the first fold, splintering into yellow shrapnel. I swore, started over, swore again. By sunset I had a tray of crescents that resembled roadkill more than pastry. I left them on the stoop with a sign: FREE—FIRST ATTEMPT. By morning they were gone except for a single croissant bitten once and abandoned. I considered that a partial success.

I tried again the following weekend, and the one after. By the fourth batch the lamination showed actual layers. I left a stack tied in parchment at the bus stop with another sign: TAKE ONE, TELL ME A STORY. When I came back at dusk, the parchment was folded into a paper crane and underneath it a note in purple ink: My dad used to bring me croissants every Sunday after church. He died last year. Today you gave me the first one I’ve had since. Thank you. No name.

I sat on the curb and cried harder than I had at the funeral. Eli would have loved that—someone else’s grief meeting mine in the language of butter and air. I took a picture of the crane and the note, then texted it to Eli’s old number, the one still saved in my phone under “Idiot with Wings.” The message hung unsent for a minute before I deleted it.

The list stayed in my pocket. Some nights I unfolded it and added tiny dots of blue ink beside finished items—one for the croissants, another for the rooftop silence I’d managed from 5:47 a.m. to 5:47 a.m. by bribing the janitor with two of the passable pastries and a thermos of coffee. I discovered that silence has weight; it settles on your skin like damp wool. Around hour fourteen I heard Eli’s voice in the rustle of pigeons, saying my name the way he used to when he found me reading on the fire escape at 2 a.m. I didn’t answer aloud. Speaking would have broken the contract, but I nodded, and something inside me unclenched.

The northern lights came next—number 7. I used the last of my vacation days and flew to Tromsø in January because Eli once traced the shape of Norway on a bar napkin and said the sky there tasted like static electricity. I stood in minus-twenty cold, sober as a judge, until green curtains unfurled above the black pines. I whispered the only Russian phrase I knew—“Ya tebya lyublyu”—not to anyone present, but because Eli had scribbled the phonetics next to number 5, and saying it in the direction of the lights felt like forwarding a letter. The aurora pulsed like a heartbeat, and I felt, absurdly, forgiven.

I didn’t try number 6—falling in love for three months—because I knew the leaving would be the part I’d fail. Instead I started number 10: recording dreams. I kept a notebook by the bed and wrote in the dark so I wouldn’t lose the images. Most were nonsense: grocery stores floating in space, Eli teaching penguins to tango. But one morning I woke with the taste of salt on my lips and wrote: We were in the ocean, floating, the moon above like a cracked dime. When I woke, he said, “You finally trusted the tide.” I underlined that entry twice.

The list grew check marks slowly, like stars appearing at twilight. Number 8—the letter to Mom—took the longest. I wrote it by hand on the back of the envelope Eli’s will had come in because paper mattered. I told her about the time he stole cough syrup from her purse not to get high but because he’d read Dostoevsky and thought madness might be more bearable if it tasted like cherry. I told her he loved her even when he couldn’t love himself. I mailed it without a return address.

One year and three months after the gray Tuesday, only two bullets remained. Number 1: Walk the Camino. And number 23, the last, scrawled so faintly I had to tilt the page to read it: Forgive yourself for not saving me.

I stared at that one for a long time. The paper was tissue-thin now, almost translucent, as if it had absorbed every mile and silence and croissant and tear I’d fed it. I realized then that the list wasn’t a scavenger hunt; it was an instruction manual for dismantling the bomb he’d left inside me. One by one the wires had been snipped. The Camino could wait. The final wire glowed red beneath number 23.

I carried the list to the lake where Eli and I used to skip stones after bad days. The water was iron-gray, the wind sharp. I folded the paper into the shape of a boat, the way he’d taught me in third grade using gum wrappers. I set it on the surface and watched it absorb water, sinking inch by inch. When only the tip remained above the lake, I whispered, “Done.” The boat dissolved like sugar, and the wind carried the pulp away.

I didn’t feel lighter; grief doesn’t evaporate. But for the first time since the funeral I didn’t feel like I was carrying him in my lungs. Instead he was in the water, the sky, the taste of butter and sea salt, the hush of library rooftops, the green flicker behind my eyelids when I closed them at night. And for now, that was enough.

samples.prompt: Gods as we know them do not exist, and instead are elected every 10 years by the entire planet. This year however, you have been elected as 'God'.
samples.output:
The message arrived on every screen at the same moment:  

“Congratulations. You have been elected God.”  

I was in a laundromat in Sioux Falls, hugging a plastic basket of mismatched socks, when the dryers all stopped mid-spin and the wall-mounted television cut from a detergent commercial to my own startled face. For three full heartbeats I believed it was a prank, the kind of stunt pulled by influencers who rent billboard trucks to propose. Then I noticed the hush. No machines whirred, no children argued, no quarters clinked. Every phone in the room glowed with the same white text. A woman beside me whispered, “It’s real,” and the whisper traveled outward in widening circles until the entire planet seemed to inhale.

The election happens every decade. No one campaigns, because no one knows who can run. The algorithm that tallies every human intention—votes, prayers, stray thoughts—belongs to the previous God, who vanishes the instant the tally is certified. Some say the former deity dissolves into the background radiation of the universe; others think they simply retire to an island where nobody asks them questions anymore. The rules are simple: one decade, infinite power, no re-election. You can rewrite physics, abolish death, invent new colors, whatever your imagination and conscience allow. The only restriction is that you cannot extend your own term. Ten years, then you’re done, and the next poor soul inherits the headache.

I was thirty-four, a junior librarian whose grandest recent act had been reorganizing the young-adult fantasy shelf by emotional tone. My résumé included a failed sourdough starter and an unfinished screenplay about two time-traveling baristas. I had never so much as organized a city-block potluck, let alone a cosmos. Yet here I was, holding socks, suddenly the most powerful entity since the Big Bang.

A door opened in the air beside the detergent vending machine, iridescent like a soap bubble stretched into a rectangle. Through it I could see a vast circular chamber of glass and starlight—the office, as it’s called. Tradition says the elected must step through within ninety seconds or forfeit the role, and forfeiture collapses civilization into a century of drought and locusts. I looked back at the frozen crowd. Their faces held equal parts terror and hope, the expression people wear when they’re about to hand you their newborn and run. I thought of my mother, asleep in a nursing home in Des Moines; of my brother in rehab; of the stray cats behind the library who expect me at six sharp with a tin of sardines. Then I thought of droughts and locusts.

I stepped through.

The moment my foot crossed the threshold, knowledge poured into me like warm water. Not facts, exactly, but recipes: recipes for planets, for peace treaties, for the precise frequency of kindness required to keep a species from eating itself alive. I understood the weight of every prayer I’d never answered because, until thirty seconds ago, I had not been anyone’s god. I felt the accumulated grief of wars that ended too late and love letters that arrived too early. It was like being hugged by a storm.

The previous God left a single sticky note on the crystalline desk: “Don’t try to fix everything. That’s how you break it worse.” Underneath, scrawled smaller: “Also, hydrate.”

I sat—though the chair reshaped itself to something closer to a hammock—and stared at the controls. They weren’t buttons or levers, just intentions waiting to be noticed. I could end hunger with a blink, make every gun taste like spoiled milk, turn deserts into jazz clubs. I could resurrect the dead, beginning with my father who died when I was twelve. I could bring back the dodo, the thylacine, the childhood dog who still visits my dreams trailing the smell of wet leaves.

Instead, I did nothing for the first hour. I listened. Billions of voices overlapped like wind through a million different trees. I expected begging, but most of the sound was quieter: a child humming while drawing a sun with legs; an old man on a porch remembering peaches; two teenagers sharing earbuds on a bus to nowhere special. I realized that people weren’t screaming for miracles. They were improvising hope in real time, the way you sing louder when the radio cuts out. My job, perhaps, wasn’t to replace that song but to keep the signal clear.

So I started small. Not out of modesty—small is difficult. I removed every landmine from every forgotten field, folding them into origami cranes that flew to museums. I made cancer cells self-conscious, so that when they looked in the mirror they chose apoptosis over murder. I whispered into the code of mosquitoes: “What if you pollinated instead of bit?” Within a week, children in Jakarta were sleeping through the night, and vanilla orchids bloomed in Alaska.

But small changes ripple. When no one feared bedtime, nightmares went unemployed and applied to be daydreams. Oncology wards became gardens with IV poles repurposed as trellises. Vanilla threatened to overrun tundra until I negotiated a truce between climates: the north could keep its frost if it shared the auroras with the equator on holidays.

By the end of the first year I had abolished the concept of waste; every plastic bottle remembered being dinosaur juice and preferred to be a jungle gym. I gave every language a new tense, the would-have-loved, so that apologies could conjugate properly. Still, the note’s warning haunted me. Fixing begets fixing. When I ended blindness, artists protested—darkness had texture, history, its own palette. When I ended loneliness, introverts petitioned for its return. I convened a parliament of owls and insomniacs to draft guidelines: solitude by choice, never by force.

The second year I tackled time. Not its physics—its tyranny. I rearranged the week into ten-day cycles: three for labor, three for rest, three for whatever made labor feel worth it, and one mystery day that changed order every week to keep calendars humble. Productivity soared, but so did aimlessness, and both sides thanked me on postcards made from recycled regrets.

I visited my mother disguised as a volunteer with too much free time. She didn’t know she was chatting with her son who happened to be the universe’s middle manager. She complained about the price of pears, unaware I’d rebalanced entire orchards the night before. When she fell asleep in her chair, I folded a piece of her afternoon into my pocket—not to keep, just to remember what unaltered time felt like.

By year five I’d stopped announcing miracles. The best changes were the ones people thought they’d invented themselves: neighborhood libraries that grew like mushrooms after rain, currencies that expired like bread so hoarding went stale. Suicide rates dropped not because I removed despair but because I widened the intervals between it and action, just enough for a stranger to say, “Your shoelace is untied,” which turns out to be a sacred sentence.

The sticky note yellowed. I added two words: “Ask them.”

So I held office hours. Every Thursday at 3 p.m. local time, a bench appeared somewhere—a bus stop in Lagos, a rooftop in Reykjavík, a tree stump in the Amazon—and I sat, visible only to whoever needed to talk. People brought casseroles and grievances. A girl asked if her grandmother could be a constellation without dying first; we arranged for her to be a temporary nebula until she finished teaching the recipe for tamales to every star in the vicinity. A man wanted his ex-wife’s name to stop tasting like metal; I showed him how to pronounce it backward until it meant something else entirely.

In the seventh year I realized I was lonely. Not for company—for limits. Omnipotence is a desert without horizon. I missed the friction of not getting my way. I missed surprise. I created a room the algorithm could not penetrate, a pantry where the bread sometimes failed to rise. I baked imperfect loaves and gave them names: Regret, Wonder, Tuesday. I left them on windowsills for pigeons who had never tasted failure.

Year nine brought the question no God escapes: what happens when I step down? The algorithm is impartial, but the world I’d shaped was not. I had favorites—every gardener who planted tomatoes in war zones, every librarian who smuggled banned books in grocery carts. I did not want to abandon them to a successor who might value efficiency over mess. Yet I could not rig the election without unraveling the trust that held the sky up.

I did the only thing within my power that felt like surrender: I wrote a letter and copied it into every heart, not as words but as a tug behind the ribs. It said: Remember how it felt the first time you chose kindness not because a god was watching, but because no one was. Remember the day you forgave the rain for ruining your shoes. Remember that every system I touched is made of people, and people outlast gods.

I folded the letter into the algorithm itself, a hidden subroutine weighted so heavily that only someone who understood limitation could win. The next God, I hoped, would be someone who had lost something and not erased the loss.

The final day arrived like any Tuesday. I walked through the laundromat door again—it had been waiting, suspended in time, socks still damp. The dryers resumed their spin cycle. The television flipped back to detergent. No one looked up; they had already begun to forget my face, the way dreams fade by breakfast. Only the woman who had whispered “It’s real” nodded once, as if we shared a secret too heavy to carry.

In ninety seconds the door would seal forever. I used the last ten to whisper to the universe: Let me remember being ordinary. Let me age. Let me burn toast and misplace keys. Let me be surprised by lilacs, and by sorrow, and by the sound of my own name spoken by someone I’ve yet to meet.

The door closed. The dryers hummed. I stood holding warm socks, a former deity with flour on his sleeves and a phone that buzzed—my brother, sober three years, asking if I wanted sourdough starters for Christmas. I said yes, and meant it, the way mortals do when they realize every answer is temporary, and therefore precious.

samples.prompt: You're a history major. Your final exam is to travel back in time and successfully pass as a normal, everyday citizen. It's not going well.
samples.output:
I was supposed to be invisible.  
That was the whole pitch in Prof. Lasky’s seminar: blend, observe, leave no ripple. History, he insisted, was a conversation we could overhear only if we kept our mouths shut. So I signed the waiver, let the physics majors tape the silver coils to my temples, and woke up on April 17, 1775—twenty-four hours before the lanterns would slip into Christ Church steeple and Paul Revere would bolt out of Boston.  

The first thing I noticed was the smell: a humid, yeasty fug of privies, horse sweat, and tallow smoke so thick I could feel it settle on my tongue. The second thing was the boots. Mine were wrong—machine-stitched, rubber-soled, a gift from Target three days earlier. I yanked my cloak lower and congratulated myself on remembering to swap my contact lenses for the antique spectacles the lab had ground from period glass. Then I took one step off the Long Wharf cobbles and pitched face-first into a pile of oyster shells.  

A sailor caught my elbow. “Easy, lad. The tide’s left the street slippery as a preacher’s promise.”  

Lad. Good sign. My hair was pinned under a felt hat, coat borrowed from the costume shop, voice practiced to a mid-Atlantic baritone that I hoped sounded generically colonial. I thanked him, tried to walk off with the rolling gait men used to keep their heels out of the muck. My left foot slid again; the rubber squeaked. The sailor frowned at the sound like it was blasphemy.  

I reached the Bunch of Grapes tavern by dusk, rehearsing the backstory I’d memorized: apprentice wheelwright from Worcester, visiting an aunt who turned out to have died of flux—hence the road-worn clothes, the absence of local ties. I swung open the door, and conversation died like I’d slammed a lid on it. Every face swiveled. I felt the weight of their suspicion press against my ribs.  

“What’s your drink?” the barkeep asked.  

I almost said “Sam Adams” out of reflex; the joke would have cost me a beating. Instead I croaked, “Small beer.” He thumped down a wooden pint. It tasted sour, flat, and warm, like liquid bread crust. I took one polite sip and set it on the bench beside me.  

A stocky man with a broken nose leaned over. “Worcester, eh? Know Eli Parsons there? Cobbles shoes by the meetinghouse?”  

I had a dossier of names but not that one. I shrugged. “Heard the name. Can’t place the face.”  

The man’s eyes narrowed. “Parsons is a woman.”  

The room erupted. The sailor from the wharf materialized behind me, clamped a hand on my shoulder. “Rubber heels and lies. Search him.”  

They hauled me into the alley. One held a lantern while two others rifled my pockets. They found the plastic lighter first. The boy carrying the lamp squealed when flame shot from my thumb. Next came the student ID—laminated, my smiling photo above a barcode that looked occult in the candlelight.  

“Witch’s token,” someone muttered.  

I tried the speech I’d rehearsed for just this moment: scientific demonstration, harmless wonder, enlightened inquiry. My voice quavered; the words tangled. They tied my wrists with twine that bit into my skin and marched me toward the town jail.  

The jailer, a man named Ezekiel Cheever, listened to the accusations while tapping my lighter against his palm like a metronome. He asked me twice whether I was “in league with the slaves’ rebellion” because, apparently, anything inexplicable defaulted to abolition conspiracy. I denied everything. He locked me in a cell already occupied by a drunk cooper snoring against the wall and a rat the size of a kitten.  

I sat on the damp straw and catalogued every mistake. Rubber soles, plastic lighter, laminated ID—rookie errors. My stomach cramped; the small beer sloshed like regret. Outside, church bells rang nine. Ten hours until the lanterns. If I missed Revere’s ride, Lasky would fail me, and the physics department would yank me back to 2024 in disgrace.  

An hour later, the outer door creaked. I expected Cheever, but it was the sailor, alone, carrying a bundle. He slipped inside, pressed coins into the turnkey’s hand, and waited until the man retreated.  

“I’ve seen wonders,” the sailor whispered in the dark, “storms that turned the ocean to glass, dolphins that guided us round Cape Horn. But I never saw fire born from air.” He set the bundle on the floor—my boots, coat, the lighter. “Take these. I told Cheever you escaped. There’s a skiff tied under the North Battery. Row for Charlestown; keep to the moon’s shadow on the water.”  

I stared at him. “Why?”  

He rubbed the back of his neck. “Because I’d rather live in a world where wonders still come, even if they scare me. And because the redcoats are about to march, and you’re no spy—they’d have made you cleaner shoes.”  

I stuffed the lighter into my pocket, pulled on the cursed boots. “What’s your name?”  

“Call me Jonah. We all get swallowed once.”  

I left the jail barefoot so the boots wouldn’t squeak in the corridor. The night was cold enough to numb my toes against the granite wharf. I found the skiff, unmoored it, and rowed with the tide. Each oar stroke sounded like a gong in my ears; sentries on the Somerset paced, but no shout came.  

Halfway across, fog rolled in—a blessing or a trick of the lab’s probability dampeners. I couldn’t tell. My arms burned. The city receded until the lanterns in the steeple were pinpricks. Then, one lantern, then a second: the signal. I laughed so loudly a gull screamed back.  

I beached the skiff near Morton's Point, hid it among reeds. My feet were bleeding; salt stung the cuts. I wrapped them in strips torn from my shirt and limped toward the Charlestown ferry landing where Revere would soon arrive. I had maybe thirty minutes to blend into the crowd of militiamen.  

But when I reached the road, a patrol of regulars intercepted me. Six bayonets, brass gorgets gleaming. Lieutenant Pitcairn himself, according to the shoulder boards. My heart jackhammered.  

“Halt! Who goes?”  

Think. Think like them. “Express rider, sir. With urgent news for General Gage.” I tried to sound breathless, dutiful, not terrified.  

One soldier leveled his musket. “Where’s your horse?”  

“Thrown at the Neck. Had to run.”  

Pitcairn studied my bare, bloody feet. “At this hour?”  

I gambled. “The rebels are moving cannon from Concord. I saw it with my own eyes.” The lieutenant’s brows rose; this was the rumor Gage feared. “I’ll swear it on the King’s health.”  

He hesitated, then barked an order. Two soldiers flanked me; we marched toward Boston at double time. My plan was crumbling. I was being marched in the wrong direction, toward the very troops Revere meant to warn the countryside against.  

Half a mile on, we passed a blacksmith’s shed. I pretended to stumble, clutched my ankle. “Cramp, sir. Give me a moment?” Pitcairn nodded impatiently. Inside the shed, the forge still glowed. On the anvil lay a horseshoe, cooling from cherry-red to ashy gray.  

While the soldiers watched the road, I palmed the lighter. One flick, one whoosh of flame across the straw-strewn floor. Sparks skittered like startled beetles. The thatch caught; smoke billowed. The soldiers shouted, rushed to stamp it out. I bolted into the woods.  

Behind me, muskets cracked. A ball tugged at my sleeve. I ran until the world shrank to the rasp of my lungs. Somewhere in the dark, church bells began to ring—not Boston’s, but Charlestown’s, echoing Revere’s crossing. The network was working; my interference hadn’t broken it. I laughed again, hysterical this time.  

At dawn I found myself on Punkatasset Hill, overlooking the Concord River. Minutemen milled about, listening to a stout farmer argue about whether to stand or retreat. My coat was singed, feet raw, spectacles cracked. I looked, I realized, exactly like what I was: a stranger who had fallen through the world.  

A boy no older than sixteen offered me a canteen. “You look like you’ve seen the devil,” he said.  

“Something like that.” I drank. The water tasted of cedar and algae—real water, nothing filtered through a lab’s sterilizer.  

He gestured toward the river. “Redcoats coming. You steady?”  

I nodded. My mission had never been to fight, just to witness, to prove I could survive without changing the story. Yet here I stood in the first light of April 19, boots lost to the mud, spectacles fogged with smoke, lighter tucked into a pocket beside a plastic ID that had become a relic.  

When the first shot rang out by the Old North Bridge, I flinched like everyone else. The volley rippled across the water, a sound I’d studied in archival recordings but never felt in my marrow. I watched the farmer—Isaac Davis, if my notes were right—fall, and then watched the line of minutemen fire back. The air filled with sulfur and the smell of wet grass crushed under boots.  

I should have stayed on the sidelines. But when a man next to me fumbled powder from his horn, hands shaking, I knelt, measured the charge the way reenactors had drilled me, and pressed the paper cartridge into his palm. He glanced up, eyes wide. “You’ve done this before,” he said.  

“Once,” I lied.  

Another volley. We both ducked. He clapped my shoulder. “Name’s Levi.”  

“Matthew,” I said—the alias on the student ID. It felt suddenly less like a lie and more like a borrowed coat that had warmed me through the night.  

For the next hour I became what the exam forbade: a participant. Not a hero—I fetched water, dragged wounded boys to the shade of an oak, tore my shirt for bandages. The lighter stayed hidden; I had no more need of wonders. When the redcoats withdrew toward Boston, the smoke drifted off like dissipating time.  

Levi found me again. “You’ll march with us?”  

I looked down at my bloody, bare feet, at the militia streaming after the regulars, and felt the tug of history like gravity. But the silver coils at my temples buzzed—a gentle warning that my vitals were spiking. The recall timer. I had minutes.  

“I’ve got to find my aunt,” I said, the old alibi sounding hollow.  

He clasped my forearm. “God keep you.”  

I stepped behind the oak, thumbed the coil behind my ear twice, the signal to abort. The world blurred, colors bleeding like wet ink. The last thing I saw was Levi jogging after his company, powder horn bouncing at his hip. Then the lab lights snapped on, harsh and white.  

Prof. Lasky loomed, eyebrows like storm clouds. “You triggered the dampeners four times, set a shed on fire, and your biometrics flatlined for thirty seconds. Explain.”  

I sat up, heart still in 1775. “I passed,” I said.  

“You interfered.”  

“No.” I pulled the cracked spectacles from my pocket. “I blended. Just not the way we expected. They blended me right back.”  

He stared at the spectacles, then at my ruined feet. “And the lighter?”  

I handed it over. Flint spark still intact. “Souvenir,” I said. “But I think they kept the plastic. It’ll be in a museum someday, labeled ‘witch’s token, origin unknown.’”  

Lasky almost smiled. Almost.  

“Final grade?” I asked.  

He sighed. “Barely adequate. You survived. You didn’t break the timeline. But you left footprints.”  

I looked at the soles of my feet, blistered and blackened. “Yeah,” I said. “I know.”

samples.prompt: During a routine check-up, it's revealed that you heal your wounds faster than ordinary people. Due to that, you are taken to a secret facility for "testing". You learn that you will be confined there for the "betterment of humankind". After years of experiments you become immortal.
samples.output:
The paper gown they give me at the clinic is too short in the sleeves, so I keep tugging at the cuff while the intern stares at the inside of my forearm. I’ve come in for a simple blood-pressure check—I like to have the numbers before I renew my gym membership—but the intern keeps turning my arm over as though it’s a page in a book he can’t quite translate.  
“What did you say you cut yourself on?” he asks.  
“A tin can, two nights ago. It bled like crazy, but it healed.”  
He presses the half-moon scab with a gloved thumb. The scab flakes away like burnt paper, revealing pink skin that might have belonged to a child.  
“That’s not two days old,” he whispers.  
I laugh, assuming he’s exaggerating, the way people do when they want to be dramatic about somebody’s good genes. Then he leaves the room and doesn’t come back. Instead, two men in dark suits arrive. They ask me to step into a windowless van parked illegally by the fire lane. It all happens so quickly that I don’t even have time to phone my sister.

The facility doesn’t have a name, just a four-digit code stenciled on every door: 4451. The drive takes eight hours; they blindfold me for the last three, but I still memorize the turns by counting them in my head. Inside, the air is filtered and odorless, as if it has never belonged to the outside world. The walls are painted a shade of coral that is supposed to soothe, but after a week it starts to feel like the inside of a stomach.

At first the tests are almost polite. They draw blood every six hours and ask me to press my palm against shallow cuts they make on my forearm with a scalpel. The cuts close before the next scheduled blood draw, so they switch to deeper incisions, then to burns, then to carefully fractured metacarpals. Every time, the tissue knits itself back together, faster each cycle. They call it “accelerated regenerative phenotype,” but the way they say it makes it sound like they’re talking about a new brand of detergent.

I ask when I can leave. They tell me the work is too important, that my biology could help soldiers, burn victims, transplant patients. I ask again, and the answer changes to a schedule: six more months, then a year, then “when the protocols are complete.” I realize that protocols are like horizon lines; they recede as you walk toward them.

To pass the time I keep a private calendar on the wall behind the bunk, tallying days with a stolen paperclip. By the time I reach two hundred and eighty-seven marks, something strange happens: I stop aging. Not dramatically—just in the small ways people usually overlook. My hairline refuses to retreat; a scar I earned in middle school vanishes overnight; the tiny constellation of sun damage on my shoulders dissolves. The technicians notice before I do because they photograph every inch of me under UV light once a week. One of them, a woman named Dr. Lira whose badge never quite hides the dark circles under her eyes, stays after the others have left.

“Your telomeres aren’t shortening,” she says. “They’re actually lengthening.”  
I stare at the glossy image of my chromosomes, the fluorescent tips glowing like the ends of fireflies.  
“What does that mean?” I ask.  
“It means you might not get to die,” she replies, and the fluorescent lights buzz for a moment, as if they too are considering the implications.

After that, the experiments escalate. They need to know how far the immortality extends. They fracture my femur and watch it straighten like sapling wood finding true north. They introduce aggressive cancers into my pancreas; the tumors bloom and then melt away overnight. They irradiate my chest until my heart should fibrillate itself to silence, but the muscle keeps stubbornly contracting. Each time I ask to speak to an ethics board, the request is routed through a chain of signatures that ends in a locked drawer.

Years become decades. I stop ripping days off the calendar; the paper grows brittle and falls apart when I touch it. The staff changes, but they all wear the same coral-colored scrubs, as though the institution launders them in one giant vat that never empties. Dr. Lira is replaced by Dr. Park, who is replaced by Dr. Singh, but each of them keeps a small vial of my blood in a cryobox labeled “Specimen 4451-A.” I learn not to learn their first names; it hurts less when they disappear.

One winter—though seasons are theoretical here—I hear the fire alarm go off at 3:12 a.m. Through the porthole in my door I see the sprinkler system raining onto the hallway carpet. It isn’t a drill. A red EXIT sign glows at the far end, the first time I’ve seen one inside the facility. The electromagnetic locks on my door click open. Either the fire has scrambled the circuitry or someone has decided I’m no longer worth saving from.

I walk out barefoot, past overturned gurneys and a broken centrifuge still spinning like a dying gyroscope. The sprinkler water is warm and metallic. In the smoke I spot Dr. Singh crouched beside an overturned cabinet, clutching a hard drive to his chest. He looks up, and for a moment neither of us moves. His face is streaked with soot and something that might be regret.

“You can go,” he says finally. “There’s nothing left to learn.”  
I want to ask him what he’s taken from me that can’t be returned, but alarms are wailing and time is compressed. So I keep walking. The EXIT door opens onto a stairwell that smells of wet concrete and chlorine. I climb. My knees don’t protest; they haven’t in years.

At the top is a maintenance hatch. I push it open and emerge onto the roof. It’s snowing—real snow, the kind that lands on your tongue and melts. I haven’t tasted weather in twenty-four years. In the distance the facility’s perimeter fence glints under floodlights, but the guard towers are empty. Beyond them, pine trees stretch into a darkness that looks almost soft.

I stand there for a long time, long enough for the snow to bury my footprints. The air is sharp enough to cut, yet my lungs, traitors that they are, expand without pain. Somewhere inside the burning building, decades of data are turning to ash. I imagine hard drives warping, petri dishes shattering, file cabinets buckling. All those measurements of my pain, rendered suddenly illegible.

I think about sliding down the drainage pipe and disappearing into the forest. I could start walking west, cross state lines, maybe find the town where my sister still lives—if towns still exist, if time hasn’t swallowed her the way it refused to swallow me. But then I picture her opening the door to a stranger who looks twenty-nine, forever. I picture the questions, the cameras, the possibility that another facility waits under another four-digit code. The snow keeps falling, and I realize that running cannot outdistance the thing I carry in my cells.

Instead I sit on the edge of the roof and let the snow cover me like a new costume. I stay until the fire engines arrive, until the sun rises over blackened concrete and steaming water. They will search the ashes for a body and find none. They will file reports that use words like “unprecedented” and “classified.” And somewhere, in the back of a lab coat pocket or taped beneath a drawer, a single vial of immortal blood will survive the blaze, waiting to be rediscovered when humanity decides it is ready to play god again.

I brush the snow from my shoulders, stand, and begin the slow climb down the other side of the building. Not toward freedom exactly—freedom implies an end—but toward whatever happens after forever starts.

samples.prompt: You decide to try out a new cafe. You get your latte and sit outside. A few minutes later, a hooded stranger sits down across from you. Startled, you look up, only to find your own face staring back at you.
samples.output:
The new café was called “Moon and Sixpence,” wedged between a dusty second-hand record shop and a place that sold only LED shoelaces. I’d passed it a dozen times on my way to the library without noticing the hand-painted sign, but this morning a smell—cardamom, hot metal, something like sun-dried cedar—pulled me through the door as if it had hooked a finger in my collar. Inside, the walls were the color of wet sand and the ceiling fans turned so slowly I could count the revolutions. I ordered a small latte with oat milk because the barista said the foam set better that way, paid with the last bill in my wallet that wasn’t earmarked for rent, and carried the cup outside to the only free table on the narrow patio.

The table was iron, painted white once, now chipped to gray. A geranium in a terracotta pot trembled in the breeze beside a bowl of sugar packets that looked as though it had been rained on more than once. I sat, scooted the chair back so the sun could warm my forearms, and blew across the surface of the latte. The milk had been swirled into a crooked heart; I watched it distort, then disappear, when I took the first sip. It tasted faintly of burnt honey, the way my mother’s kitchen smelled on the nights she forgot the toast under the broiler.

I had come here to think about quitting my job. Not the drama of quitting, but the quiet afterward: the unmarked calendar squares, the absence of meetings that could have been emails. I was rehearsing how I would tell my manager when a shadow slid across the table. I thought it was a cloud passing, but the shadow stayed. Someone had taken the seat opposite me.

The stranger wore a slate-gray hoodie despite the warm morning, hood up, sleeves pulled so low that only the fingertips showed. Their head was angled downward, so I saw only the tip of a nose, a mouth, the edge of a jaw. I felt an instinctive jolt of irritation—tables were scarce, sure, but who sits down uninvited when there are two empty chairs at the next planter over?—and I opened my mouth to say so.

Then the stranger lifted their head, and the words turned to gravel in my throat.

It was my face, exact and impossible. The same narrow scar through the left eyebrow, the souvenir of a childhood collision with a coffee table. The same constellation of freckles across the bridge of the nose, even the new one I’d noticed last week after an April afternoon in the park. The same eyes—one iris slightly darker than the other, a quirk I’d always considered too minor to mention at the optometrist—staring back with an expression I couldn’t name because I’d never seen it on myself before: not fear, not surprise, but recognition laced with fatigue, as though we’d arranged this meeting long ago and both arrived late.

My first coherent thought was: mirror. But the café’s windows behind my double reflected only sky and the tails of hanging ferns. My second thought was: stroke. I pressed my tongue to the roof of my mouth, counted to three, exhaled. The world stayed upright; the stranger stayed put.

I lifted my latte, then thought better of it and set it down; the cup chattered against the saucer. “You’re—” I began, then swallowed the rest because pronouns felt suddenly fragile. You’re me was accurate but absurd; You’re not me was demonstrably false.

The stranger tilted their head, and I saw the motion echo inside my own neck, as if we shared a hinge. When they spoke, the voice was mine but worn softer at the edges, like a cassette left too long in a car stereo.

“I know,” they said. “It’s a lot.”

The words arrived inside my skull before they reached my ears, the way thunder follows lightning by half a heartbeat. I found myself nodding, a puppet whose strings had been jerked by someone else. Around us, the morning kept happening—an elderly man shuffled past with a Pomeranian in a yellow sweater; a cyclist rang her bell at a pedestrian who’d stepped into the bike lane—but the sounds were muffled, as though a pane of glass had slid between our table and the rest of the world.

“How?” I whispered.

“Not how,” they replied. “More like why now.”

I laughed, a small, bitten-off sound. “That’s worse. How do you know what I was going to ask?”

“Because I asked it too.” They raised a hand—my hand—and pinched the bridge of their nose. The gesture felt like déjà vu embedded in my own bones. “Different day, same chair.”

I stared at the latte cooling between us. The heart in the foam had dissolved into a shapeless cloud. “So you’re… future me?”

They gave a half-shrug that tugged the hoodie away from their throat, revealing the mole just above my collarbone. “Or past. Depends which way you’re facing.”

The cicadas in the planter—hidden somewhere in the rosemary—started up suddenly, a dry, electric rasp. The sound made my teeth itch. “Why come back? Or forward. Whichever.”

“To tell you not to quit.”

The sentence landed like a slap. I straightened. “How do you—”

“You’re wearing the resignation email draft in your pocket,” they said gently. “It’s warm from your thumb rubbing the paper every time you think no one’s looking.”

I glanced down; the folded printout was indeed in my jeans, crisp once, now limp as a love letter gone unread. I hadn’t realized I was touching it.

“You’ll quit,” my double went on, “and for three months you’ll feel weightless. Then the silence will get heavy. You’ll apply for jobs you’re overqualified for and be told you’re under-experienced. Savings will thin. You’ll take up running at 5 a.m. because the panic wakes you anyway. One morning you’ll pass this café, smell cardamom, and remember the day you chose certainty over the story you wanted to tell.”

Their voice cracked on story, and something inside me cracked with it. I thought of the graphic novel I’d been sketching during conference calls, panels half-finished and hidden in a drawer because adults didn’t chase cartoon dreams.

“So I stay,” I said slowly. “And then what?”

“You negotiate. Four-day weeks, remote Fridays—things they’ll agree to if you ask while holding another offer. You use the extra day for inks and washes. You publish under a pen name so the day job doesn’t own your art. By the time the mole on your collarbone sprouts its first gray hair, the comic is optioned for streaming. You still have health insurance.”

I laughed again, but this time it carried water. “Sounds tidy. Too tidy.”

“It’s messy in the middle,” they admitted. “But mess is different from ruin.”

The stranger—or I—leaned forward. The hood slid back an inch, revealing the part in my hair where the cowlick always won. “I can’t make you stay,” they said. “Free will’s stubborn that way. But I can leave the bill.”

They placed something small and metallic on the table: a subway token I’d kept on my key ring since middle school, the one I lost last winter. I hadn’t noticed it missing until this moment, when I saw it returned.

“If you flip it and it lands on the bridge,” they went on, “you stay. If it lands on the tunnel, you walk out of here and hand in your notice. Either way, you’ll think it was chance.”

I picked up the token; it was warm from their palm. “You already flipped it once,” I guessed.

They smiled, a lopsided thing that hurt to witness. “Heads.”

I turned the token over. The bridge side glinted, scratched but intact. I closed my fist around it. “What happens to you after this?”

“What happens to yesterday when the clock strikes twelve?”

Before I could answer, the stranger stood. The chair legs scraped softly. They took one step backward, then another. With each step, the resemblance grew less exact, as if some internal dial were turning down the saturation. By the time they reached the sidewalk, the hoodie looked charcoal instead of gray, the hair beneath it darker, the face—still mine—older or younger, I couldn’t tell. Then they merged with the foot traffic and were gone.

The geranium shivered in a sudden gust. My hand opened; the token lay on my lifeline like a flattened moon. I flipped it once, caught it, slapped it onto my wrist without looking. The metal stung my skin.

I drank the rest of the latte in two gulps. It tasted different now, like rain on hot pavement. Inside my pocket, the resignation email rustled as I stood. I left two dollars on the table for the unseen busboy, pocketed the token, and walked back inside to order another coffee—oat milk, extra shot—because I had a phone call to make before noon, and I needed the caffeine.

Behind the counter, the barista smiled at me, then frowned slightly, as if trying to place a song whose title hovered just out of reach. I smiled back, real and crooked, the cowlick doing its unruly dance, and decided not to quit. Not today.

samples.prompt: Everyone who dies is reincarnated as soon as history has completely forgotten about them. A secret centuries-old group has been keeping an list of hundreds of thousands of mass murderers, evil dictators, etc. to keep them from coming back. One day, someone loses the list.
samples.output:
The first thing Sigrid noticed was the silence.

Not the ordinary hush of the archive—she was used to that, the way the miles of shelving drank every sound—but a deeper, almost theological quiet, as though the air itself had been cauterized. She stood in the long corridor between aisles 17-B and 17-C, the bulb in her hand still glowing, the little leather-bound volume still lying open on the floor where it had fallen. The spine was cracked; a single parchment-thin page had torn loose and floated down like a pale moth. She stared at the gap the missing page left, and the silence pressed against her eardrums until she could hear her pulse.

She had only meant to verify a spelling—Amin, Idi or Amin, Idi Dada?—but the ledger had slipped, and now the page that contained precisely 312 names, birth-dates, and last known deaths was gone. Wind could not reach this deep underground, yet the page had vanished as cleanly as if the centuries themselves had inhaled it.

The Brotherhood of Mnemosyne had kept the list since 1348, when the plague first made the world light enough for souls to slip back in a rush and an Italian notary named Matteo di Sangiovanni noticed that the cruel podestà who’d starved three villages reappeared, unchanged, as a Milanese moneylender. Matteo wrote the name down twice—once in ink, once in blood—and the man never returned. Over seven hundred years the Brotherhood had refined the method: parchment infused with walnut husk and iron gall, names written in triplicate, syllables parsed from a dozen languages, each death cross-checked against ruins, newspapers, gravestones, folk songs, until every last mourner died or forgot. Nothing high-tech—technology forgot faster than people—but care, obsession, and the slow patience of gardeners. Every generation another set of scribes in the catacombs beneath Vienna, Prague, Bruges, Kyoto, Cusco. Every generation a little more added to the list.

Sigrid was the youngest, inheritor of a tradition that had survived witch-trials, world wars, and the rise of search engines. She had been recruited at nineteen when her undergraduate paper on medieval memory palaces caught the eye of a professor who, over coffee in a candlelit café, asked whether she believed evil could be unlearned. She’d laughed, said no, signed the oath written in the same walnut ink. Ten years later she knew the smell of that ink better than her mother’s perfume.

And now the worst had happened: not espionage, not fire, not bombing—simple clumsiness. A dropped book, a lost page. One page, but the parchment was double-sided, 312 names on the recto, 312 on the verso. Six hundred and twenty-four souls whose return had been deferred indefinitely were, at this moment, sliding toward rebirth like coins into a jukebox.

She knelt, fingers trembling. Dust rose around the fallen ledger like incense. Protocol was explicit: if any fragment left the archive, the entire corridor was to be sealed, the air evacuated, a controlled burn started. That would save the rest of the list—millions of names—but at the cost of whoever was still inside. Sigrid had always assumed she would choose duty. She discovered, kneeling there, that assumption was a luxury.

Instead she stood, closed the ruined volume, and slipped it back onto the shelf between its neighbors. Then she walked—first calmly, then less so—up the spiral stairs, through the hidden door behind the wine racks, past the night janitor who saluted her absently. Outside, Vienna slept under a mist that tasted of wood smoke and Danube silt. She walked until her phone found a signal, and she called the only person whose number she knew by heart.

“Julian,” she said, “I’ve lost them.”

A pause. “How many?”

“Six hundred twenty-four.”

Another pause, longer. “Where are you?”

“Stephansplatz.”

“Don’t move.”

She waited beneath the cathedral’s soot-softened saints. Tourists drifted past in clumps, speaking languages that had forgotten the consonants those statues were carved to pronounce. Julian arrived in fifteen minutes—tall, graying, the kind of man who looked like he’d been waiting for bad news since birth. He took her elbow, guided her into a café that smelled of cardamom and boiled wool. No one spoke until the coffee came.

Julian turned the porcelain cup in his hands. “You realize what this means.”

“They’ll come back as infants,” she said. “No memory at first, but the pattern will reassert. We have maybe fifteen years before the cruelty begins to bloom.”

He nodded. “The list is designed to keep them out until there is nothing left of the world they knew—no statues, no textbooks, no songs. That threshold has been crossed for all six hundred. History has let them go.”

Sigrid closed her eyes. She knew the names on the page—some infamous, some obscure. There was a Rwandan mayor who’d orchestrated a church burning, a Khmer Rouge doctor who filmed his experiments, a Conquistador whose letters boasted of the children he fed to dogs. If they returned now, they would arrive into a world of smartphones and social credit scores, a world that would teach them new cruelties before they remembered the old ones.

“We have to find the page,” she said.

Julian’s smile was small and tired. “You think it’s still in the archive? Sigrid, if the parchment left the threshold, it’s ash by now. The failsafes will have triggered.”

“I didn’t hear the burn.”

“You were in shock. Or the sensors failed. Either way, the names are already slipping into wombs.”

She set her cup down with a clink that drew glances. “Then we start again. Track the births, the anomalies—early violence, language precocity, nightmares of places they’ve never been. We watch hospitals, orphanages, refugee camps. We write them down a second time.”

Julian studied her face. “That’s not how it works and you know it. Once the forgetting is complete, the memory can’t be artificially reconstructed. The spell—the covenant—whatever you want to call it, is broken. We had one chance.”

Outside, a streetcar clanged. Sigrid watched its windows flicker past like film frames. She thought of all the names she’d written over the years, the careful curls of ink, the midnight checks: Is this dictator truly gone? Has the last lullaby that mentioned him been hummed by a dying grandmother? It was work measured in heartbeats, in the slow erosion of epitaphs.

She whispered, “Then we kill them again.”

Julian flinched. “We’re librarians, not assassins.”

“No. We’re gardeners. Sometimes a weed comes back.”

He leaned forward. “Listen to yourself. The whole point was to prevent the cycle, not perpetrate it.”

“But the cycle has restarted. We can prune early, before the roots spread.”

Julian’s eyes were wet. “And who writes our names when we become the evil? Because we will, Sigrid. First out of necessity, then out of habit, then out of righteousness. That’s the slope we spent seven centuries trying not to stand on.”

She felt the weight of the oath on her tongue like a pebble she couldn’t swallow. In the corner, a radio muttered about a newborn in Graz who would not stop crying unless the nurse played Wagner. Coincidence, probably. But the Brotherhood had little room for coincidences.

Julian reached across the table and laid his hand over hers. “There’s another way. We publish the list. All of it. Every name. Put it online, in every language. Embed it in songs, tattoos, graffiti. If the world remembers, even imperfectly, the threshold resets. They can’t come back while we refuse to forget.”

“But the list is sacred—”

“It was sacred. Now it’s just a weapon, and we dropped it.”

Sigrid imagined the consequences: memes of Pol Pot in high-school history slideshows, Mongolian throat-songs reciting the birthdays of Einsatzgruppen leaders, children chanting the names of conquistadors as jump-rope rhymes. A continuous, deliberate remembering. It would cheapen the horror, perhaps, turn atrocity into trivia. But trivia endured. Trivia stuck.

She pictured the torn page drifting through the catacomb air, settling somewhere unseen. She pictured it curling against a vent, catching flame, the names crisping to black. Or maybe it had slipped into the pocket of her own coat, where it waited like a confession. She didn’t check. If she checked and found it, she would put it back, and the machinery of forgetting would resume. If she didn’t, the world would have to change.

Julian squeezed her fingers. “The first step is the hardest,” he said softly. “We begin tonight.”

Sigrid looked at the coffee grounds in the bottom of her cup. They looked like dark constellations. She thought of every child who would be born tomorrow with an old hunger in their bones, and every parent who might still be given a chance to choose a different story. Then she took out her phone, opened a new document, and—without looking at Julian—typed the first name she could remember from the lost page.

Above them, the cathedral bells began to ring. The sound poured through the open door like water, like memory, like a promise that refused to be broken again.

samples.prompt: Write a choose your own adventure story that's rigged.
samples.output:
The Only Story That Ever Was  
≈1,000 words

You are walking home beneath a sky the color of old television. The sidewalk is cracked in perfect squares, as though someone already mapped every place your foot could land. A flyer flutters against your ankle.  
“CHOOSE YOUR OWN ADVENTURE,” it says in screaming capitals.  
Underneath, smaller: “One night only. The abandoned arcade on Pier 19. No charge. No exit.”

You’ve heard the rumors: kids go in, the lights flicker once, and the building forgets they ever existed.  
But the night is cold, your phone is dead, and the bus doesn’t come. You could go home the long way (turn to section 2) or step inside the arcade (turn to section 3).

Section 2  
You turn away.  
The wind picks up and carries the flyer after you like a stray dog. Every block, you find another copy taped to a lamppost, wedged under a windshield wiper, folded into the collar of a sleeping homeless man. The headlines keep changing:  
“CHOOSE AGAIN.”  
“LAST CHANCE.”  
“WE’RE ALREADY INSIDE YOU.”  
You break into a run, but the street tilts like a treadmill; the arcade door keeps appearing in front of you whichever corner you round. Finally your legs give out and you sit on the curb, head between your knees.  
A hand lands on your shoulder.  
You look up, expecting your own face staring back—everyone does—but it’s just the ticket-booth attendant from the pier, wearing a satin jacket that says HOUSE ALWAYS WINS.  
“Free play,” he whispers, and snaps his fingers.  
The world hard-cuts to black.  
When the lights return, you are standing at the mouth of the arcade, tokens already warm in your palm.  
You never left.  
Turn to section 3.

Section 3  
The doorway breathes sour neon. Inside, the machines are arranged in a perfect spiral. You count thirty cabinets; their marquees flicker between titles: POLYBIUS, SOUL-TRAP, 1K1LL-U, UR-HERE.  
A single token slot glows on every cabinet, bright as a wound.  
You feel the familiar tingle of agency.  
Pick a machine (turn to section 4) or look for an exit (turn to section 5).

Section 4  
You choose the cabinet closest to you—UR-HERE. The joystick is already warm, as if someone let go a second ago.  
The screen shows a top-down map of the arcade. A tiny sprite labeled YOU stands exactly where you are standing.  
A speech balloon appears:  
“Insert token to choose.”  
You drop the coin.  
The sprite duplicates; now there are two YOUS.  
Option A blinks: “Left you stays.”  
Option B blinks: “Right you quits.”  
You move the stick left.  
The duplicate vanishes with a sad electronic pop.  
The screen zooms out. The map now shows the entire city. A red X pulses over your apartment.  
“Collect your prize,” the game says.  
The cabinet spits out a plastic key card embossed with tomorrow’s date.  
You take it (turn to section 6) or drop it and walk away (turn to section 7).

Section 5  
You pivot toward the door you came through. It isn’t there anymore. In its place stands a full-length mirror framed in arcade tickets. Your reflection waves a half-second late.  
You raise your right hand; the mirror raises its left.  
You step closer; the glass bulges like a lung inhaling.  
Touch the mirror (turn to section 8) or back away (turn to section 9).

Section 6  
The key card feels heavier than plastic should. On the back, micro-LEDs spell a countdown: 14:59:58…57…  
You realize it’s counting down to midnight, fifteen hours away.  
A new cabinet powers on by itself: GET-OUT. The marquee shows a pixelated keyhole.  
You swipe the card; the screen flashes: “PATH UNLOCKED: ROOFTOP.”  
A trapdoor in the ceiling sighs open, revealing a ladder made of frozen electricity.  
Climb (turn to section 10) or wait for the countdown to reach zero (turn to section 11).

Section 7  
You let the card clatter to the floor.  
Instantly every machine shuts down. The dark feels thick, like velvet soaked in oil.  
You hear your own heartbeat coming from every speaker at once.  
Then a whisper, perfectly synchronized:  
“Refusal recorded. Resetting player.”  
The floor tilts. You slide backward through the doorway you originally entered, scraped by invisible teeth.  
Outside, morning commuters step around you as you lie on the sidewalk.  
You check your watch: the date is yesterday.  
You remember nothing.  
But in your pocket you find a single token, already warm.  
Return to section 3.

Section 8  
Your fingertips meet the cool glass. The mirror softens, swallows your hand to the wrist, the elbow, the shoulder.  
You expect cold, but it’s room temperature on the other side—exactly like here.  
You step through completely.  
The arcade is identical, only every color has been replaced by its negative.  
Negative-you stands beside you, smiling in grayscale.  
It speaks with your voice:  
“I’m the version who chose differently every time. Watch.”  
It snaps its fingers. Thirty cabinets explode into sand. The sand forms a perfect circle spelling:  
“NO CHOICE WAS EVER YOURS.”  
You feel the air thicken into pages. You are being read.  
Try to rip the pages (turn to section 12) or ask the negative-you for help (turn to section 13).

Section 9  
You back away.  
The mirror bulges farther, following like a determined breath.  
Behind you, the spiral of cabinets rearranges itself into a corridor that wasn’t there before.  
At the far end stands an emergency exit, red light throbbing.  
You sprint.  
With every step, the floor tiles flip over, revealing photographs: you at age six losing your first tooth, you at sixteen kissing someone whose face is smudged, you at twenty-six buying the phone that is currently dead in your pocket.  
The exit never gets closer.  
Eventually you tire and stop.  
The photographs become the floor again.  
A soft voice from the ceiling:  
“Distance is a narrative device.”  
Turn to section 14.

Section 10  
The electric ladder hums a lullaby you almost remember from a car ride before you had language.  
You climb.  
The rooftop is an ocean of black glass reflecting a sky full of obsolete constellations—pixelated asterisms from 8-bit games.  
In the center stands a single arcade cabinet labeled FINAL CHOICE.  
Its screen is blank except for a green cursor blinking beside the words:  
“Insert token to win.”  
You have no tokens left; the ladder dissolved behind you.  
Check your pockets (turn to section 15) or kick the cabinet (turn to section 16).

Section 11  
You sit cross-legged on the floor, watching the countdown expire.  
00:00:10  
00:00:09  
…  
At 00:00:00 the card melts into mercury and slithers inside your shoe.  
You feel it climb your leg, your spine, burrow behind your eyes.  
Vision overlays flicker: health bars, dialogue trees, quick-time prompts.  
You are now the interface.  
Walk anywhere: the world scrolls.  
Speak: subtitles appear.  
Try to say something original (turn to section 17) or remain silent (turn to section 18).

Section 12  
You claw at the pages, but they are laminated in thick plastic. Your nails scrape, bleed pixelated squares of red.  
Negative-you watches, still smiling.  
“You’re trying to damage the medium,” it says. “That’s the one move we reward.”  
The sand reforms into a new cabinet: DAMAGE-CONTROL.  
Its controls are your own bleeding fingers.  
Insert hand (turn to section 19) or refuse (turn to section 20).

Section 13  
“Help me,” you say.  
Negative-you places a hand on your shoulder. It feels like touching dry ice.  
“Close your eyes,” it instructs.  
You do.  
“Now open them.”  
You are in your childhood bedroom. The arcade never existed.  
Your mother calls you to dinner.  
You breathe relief—until you notice the dinner plates are shaped like tokens.  
Every bite you take plays a coin-drop sound.  
You look at your reflection in the spoon: you are 8-bit, jagged at the edges.  
Wake up (turn to section 21) or keep eating (turn to section 22).

Section 14  
You wait.
