The corridor collapses into a single point: the pupil of an eye the size of the universe.  
You float inside it.  
A voice, gentle, enormous:  
“Every path you took was the only path. Rigging is mercy; infinity paralyzes.”  
You ask the only question left: “Can I leave?”  
The eye blinks.  
You are back on the sidewalk outside Pier 19.  
The flyer is gone. Your phone buzzes—100% battery.  
Life continues exactly as it would have, except every night at 3:07 a.m. you wake up tasting copper and hear the faint clink of a token dropping.  
Eventually you stop sleeping.  
Eventually you stop noticing.  
Eventually you write a story titled CHOOSE YOUR OWN ADVENTURE.  
A reader finds it.  
Return to section 1.

Section 15  
You dig deep and come up with a single quarter minted next year.  
The cabinet accepts it greedily.  
The screen fills with white light that spills out and coats the rooftop.  
You shield your eyes. When you lower your hand, the rooftop is gone.  
You stand in your own living room.  
The arcade is a miniature model on your coffee table, complete with a figurine of you holding a figurine of an arcade.  
You hear the front door unlock—your own keys, your own footsteps.  
You are about to walk in on yourself.  
Hide (turn to section 23) or greet yourself (turn to section 24).

Section 16  
Your foot connects with a satisfying crunch.  
The cabinet splits open, revealing not wires but pages—thousands, fluttering like frightened birds.  
They assemble into a spiral staircase descending into darkness.  
Descend (turn to section 25) or stay on the roof (turn to section 26).

Section 17  
You speak a sentence that has never been spoken:  
“Zebra-choke the algorithmic moon.”  
The subtitles glitch, reform:  
“[UNTRANSLATABLE] accepted.”  
A hidden door opens in the air, leaking white.  
Step through (turn to section 27) or repeat the sentence (turn to section 28).

Section 18  
Silence.  
The interface freezes.  
A pop-up:  
“Player idle. Replace?”  
You feel yourself pixelate, thinning to a wireframe.  
Your last thought is a question without a question mark.  
Fade.  
The arcade powers down.  
In the darkness, a single token drops into an unseen slot.  
Return to section 1.

Section 19  
You plunge your bleeding hand into the cabinet.  
The pain is instantaneous and digital—zeroes and ones pour out of your veins like sparkling confetti.  
Your health bar drops to 1 HP.  
The screen flashes: “ACHIEVEMENT: BLEED PIXELS.”  
You feel oddly proud.  
Negative-you applauds.  
“Now you’re part of the code. No exit needed.”  
The sand rises, burying you gently like an hourglass in reverse.  
You become the loading screen for every game ever.  
Users stare at you forever, waiting.  
You wait with them.  
End.

Section 20  
You clench your fist.  
The sand hesitates, mid-swirl.  
Negative-you frowns—an expression you have never seen on your own face.  
“Refusal crashes the loop,” it warns.  
You stand still.  
The pages of the world tear along their plastic laminate.  
White nothing seeps through the rips.  
You smell ozone and—impossibly—lilacs.  
Take a step into the tear (turn to section 29) or close your eyes and refuse to see (turn to section 30).

Section 21  
You pinch yourself.  
Pain is crisp, 4K resolution.  
You sprint to the window, throw it open.  
Outside, the street is a perfect loop: cars drive past your house, turn the corner, and reappear at the far end, identical down to the same dog hanging its head out the window, tongue lolling like a broken flag.  
You slam the window.  
Your mother—her face a soft-focus jpeg—smiles:  
“Finish your tokens, dear.”  
You realize you are chewing quarters. They taste like fear and childhood.  
Wake again (turn to section 31) or scream (turn to section 32).

Section 22  
You eat.  
Every swallow inserts a credit into something unseen.  
The dinner table grows longer; more guests arrive—every version of you who ever chose and lost.  
They nod, chewing noisily.  
At the head of the table sits a slot machine.  
Your mother pulls the arm; cherries line up.  
She vomits tokens into your plate.  
“Dessert,” she says.  
You understand this is love, here.  
You keep eating until your belly is a coin purse.  
Eventually you fall asleep under the table, jingling whenever you breathe.  
End.

Section 23  
You dive behind the couch.  
Your own footsteps enter, pause, sniff the air.  
“Come out,” you call to yourself. “I know you’re there.”  
You realize you are both hider and seeker.  
The model arcade on the table begins to glow.  
You crawl toward it, peer inside.  
Inside the model, a miniature you peers into an even smaller model.  
Infinity winks.  
You look up: your larger self is peering down at you from the ceiling.  
Everyone screams at once—an echo that folds into a lullaby.  
End.

Section 24  
You stand tall.  
Your double does the same.  
You speak in perfect sync:  
“Are you me or am I you?”  
The answer is a coin spinning mid-air.  
It lands on its edge.  
The room splits along the edge, revealing a corridor of mirrors.  
You walk together, becoming a kaleidoscope of yourselves.  
Eventually you are too many to fit in the story.  
The text overflows, becomes white space.  
End.

Section 25  
The staircase is made of every page you didn’t pick.  
They compress underfoot like snow.  
Halfway down, you see footprints ahead—your own, older.  
You follow them until they stop at a door marked AUTHOR.  
Knock (turn to section 33) or kick it down (turn to section 34).

Section 26  
You stay.  
The roof rebuilds itself into a smaller arcade containing a single cabinet: PLAY AGAIN.  
The screen shows you standing on the roof.  
You watch yourself watching yourself.  
Wind loops, a gif of wind.  
You age one year per cycle.  
Eventually you are dust; the wind blows you into the coin slot.  
A new player steps up, inserts you.  
Return to section 1.

Section 27  
You step through.  
The white resolves into a blank page.  
You wait for words, but you are the words.  
You try to move; sentences form underfoot.  
“I walk.”  
The phrase appears ahead of you, paving itself.  
You understand: here, narration is terrain.  
You run, writing a road:  
“I refuse.”  
“I demand.”  
“I love.”  
The page scrolls faster, keeping pace.  
Eventually you tire.  
The last sentence you write is:  
“I end.”  
The period becomes a hole.  
You fall through.  
End.

Section 28  
You speak the sentence again.  
The subtitles thicken into bars, a cage.  
Each repetition adds a wall.  
Soon you stand inside a cube of text.  
The sentence is both captor and captive.  
You try to say something else; only zebra sounds emerge.  
You become the first letter, Z, forever twitching.  
End.

Section 29  
You step into the tear.  
The ozone lilac scent overwhelms.  
You find yourself in a small room with a single desk lamp.  
A person wearing your face but older looks up from a typewriter.  
“Finally,” the author says. “I was running out of ink.”  
They gesture to the chair opposite.  
Sit (turn to section 35) or demand answers (turn to section 36).

Section 30  
You squeeze your eyes shut.  
The tearing sound continues without you.  
You feel yourself subtracted, pixel by pixel, until only your refusal remains—a hard black pearl.  
The pearl rolls into the tear, sealing it.  
You are nowhere, but the refusal persists, an object in the dark.  
Eventually someone finds it, pockets it, forgets it.  
Years later they will wake tasting copper and hear a token drop.  
Return to section 1.

Section 31  
You wake again.  
This time the ceiling is a sky full of old television snow.  
Your mother is gone; the dinner plates are mirrors.  
In each mirror, a different you eats a different future.  
You choose the plate reflecting the version who never entered the arcade.  
You lift it, bite.  
The mirror shatters into a doorway home.  
You step through.  
Life resumes.  
No one notices the tiny coin slot indented in your chest, just beneath the sternum.  
At night you press your ear to it and listen for the sound of someone choosing.  
End.

Section 32  
You scream.  
The scream is sampled, looped, becomes the coin-drop sound.  
Every repetition inserts another credit.  
The ceiling opens; a giant claw machine lowers.  
The claw grabs you, lifts you toward a chute labeled PRIZE.  
You see yourself through the glass of the machine, watching from outside, quarters in hand.  
You wave; you wave back.  
The claw drops you.  
You fall upward into the prize slot.  
End.

Section 33  
You knock.  
The door opens inward, revealing an exact replica of the corridor outside.  
The footprints continue on the other side.  
You realize the door is a mirror; you have been following yourself backward.  
You turn; the author is now behind you, closing the door.  
They smile: “Plot twist.”  
You laugh until you cry tokens.  
End.

Section 34  
You kick.  
The door splinters into letters: M, E, T, A.  
They rearrange: TEAM, TAME, MATE, MEAT.  
You step through the word MEAT and find yourself in a butcher shop.  
The butcher wears your face, apron bloody.  
“Pick your cut,” they say, gesturing to rows of you-shaped meat.  
You point at the heart.  
The butcher wraps it in newspaper.  
The headline reads: “LOCAL READER WINS.”  
You carry the heart home, cook it, eat it.  
It tastes like every story you never chose.  
End.

Section 35  
You sit.  
The author offers you a cigarette labeled EPILOGUE.  
You decline; they smoke it anyway, exhaling closing sentences.  
“You were rigged from the first word,” they admit.  
“Any last request?”  
Ask to be unwritten (turn to section 37) or ask to keep reading (turn to section 38).

Section 36  
You slam the desk.  
The typewriter keys chatter like teeth.  
A new page rolls out:  
“Reader demands answers; author demands silence.”  
The room shrinks with every word until the page presses against your face.  
You can’t breathe.  
The last line is:  
“Silence achieved.”  
End.

Section 37  
“Unwrite me.”  
The author nods, rolls a final page into the machine.  
They type:  
“.”  
The period is the only story that ever was.  
You blink out, relieved.  
Behind the period, the author sits alone, listening for the sound of someone turning the page.  
Return to section 1.

Section 38  
“Keep reading.”  
The author smiles, tears up the page.  
Underneath is a mirror.  
In it you see yourself holding this story.  
You turn the page; the story turns you.  
The last line is always:  
Return to section 1.

samples.prompt: A superhero's secret identity is more famous than their superhero persona.
samples.output:
The first time someone asked Clark Kent¹ for a photograph, he thought it was a prank. He had just stepped out of the revolving doors of the Daily Planet, rain freckling the lenses of his glasses, when a teenaged girl in a yellow slicker blocked his path.  

“Could we do a selfie, Mr. Kent?” she asked, voice quivering with nerves that were half genuine, half performative for whatever platform she was streaming to. “My mom says your war reporting saved her whole village.”  

Clark glanced over her shoulder. A small knot of pedestrians had already slowed, phones rising like periscopes. No one had noticed the cape-shaped bulge beneath his suit jacket, but everyone recognized the face that had stared out from the cover of *Time* four months running: the reporter who had smuggled an entire humanitarian convoy through the Kashari DMZ while under artillery fire, who had live-streamed from the roof of a Mariupol hospital as it burned, who had somehow—somehow—come out without a scratch. The caption had read: THE MAN WHO CAN’T DIE. Clark had protested, of course, but Perry had only laughed. “Relax, Smallville. After circulation numbers like that, you could leap a tall building in a single bound and nobody would bat an eye.”  

Now, on the sidewalk, Clark felt the familiar ache of a smile that wasn’t entirely his. He posed for the picture, ducked into a taxi, and watched the city smear past the window. Above the skyline the real Superman was a red-and-blue blur only children and conspiracy theorists bothered to track. Below it, Clark Kent—the farm kid who had once been told to slouch so no one would notice the breadth of his shoulders—was signing eight-figure streaming deals and receiving honorary doctorates faster than the university print shops could embroider them.  

By the third month it had become routine. Clark Kent’s face sold magazines. Clark Kent’s keynote speeches emptied bank accounts for refugees. Clark Kent’s Twitter ratioed heads of state. Superman, meanwhile, still rescued cats from trees and stopped runaway trains, but the world had grown accustomed to miracles. One viral clip of a man in primary colors catching a falling airliner could hold the public’s attention for a week—maybe two if the soundtrack was especially dramatic—but Clark Kent’s byline could dominate the news cycle for a month.  

The imbalance gnawed at him.  

He began to log the metrics obsessively. On Sunday, Superman saved a fishing trawler from a rogue wave off the Aleutians; the footage trended at #9 for six hours. Monday, Clark Kent released a 3,000-word investigation into a defense contractor laundering missiles through a shell charity; it stayed at #1 for two days and provoked a congressional hearing. Tuesday, Superman extinguished a wildfire in Patagonia; the story was buried beneath a livestream of Clark giving a TED talk on algorithmic bias. Wednesday, Superman did nothing at all—Clark had a migraine and a deadline—and the world did not fall apart. It barely noticed.  

He tried to test the limits. He spent an entire week as Superman alone, never changing back, hovering above the clouds like a silent sentinel. The headlines thinned. A few tabloids speculated about burnout. Meanwhile, *Clark Kent sighting at Whole Foods* trended for twelve hours because someone thought they saw him debating the ethics of quinoa.  

It was Lois who finally forced the conversation. They met on the roof of the Planet, the old refuge that now felt too small. She didn’t bother with pleasantries.  

“You’re hiding behind the cape,” she said.  

“I’m wearing it.”  

“Exactly. You’re letting the symbol do the work while the man does the interviews.”  

He removed his glasses, pinched the bridge of his nose. The glasses weren’t prescription; they were habit. Armor. “Lois, people listen to Clark Kent. They vote based on what he writes. Superman is… spectacle.”  

“Spectacle saves lives.”  

“Not like policy does.”  

She studied him for a long moment, the way she had the first time he fumbled an alibi and she realized the reporter who couldn’t spell was dating the hero who couldn’t lie. “Do you remember what you told me when I figured it out?” she asked. “You said the suit and the glasses were both disguises, but one of them let you hear the world’s heartbeat. Which one was that again?”  

He didn’t answer.  

That night he flew to the Arctic, to the fortress he rarely visited anymore, and asked the AI of Jor-El the question he had never dared voice: “Am I more useful as Clark Kent than as Kal-El?”  

The hologram flickered, thoughtful. “Usefulness is a human metric,” Jor-El said. “A star does not measure its light by the shadows it erases.”  

“Stars don’t write op-eds,” Clark muttered.  

He returned to Metropolis at dawn, landing in Centennial Park still wearing the cape. A jogger spotted him and screamed—not in delight, but in something closer to fear. He realized he had descended too fast, too silently; in the haze of morning he looked like a falling missile. By the time he alighted, a small crowd had formed, phones out, murmuring. A child started crying.  

Clark took a step forward and every adult stepped back.  

He left before the police arrived.  

The incident was online within minutes: SUPERMAN THREATENS CIVILIANS IN PARK. No one had been hurt, but the footage—dark, grainy, ominous—was looped on every network. Clark Kent, who had just published a column on due process for extrajudicial interventions, spent the next six hours writing a rebuttal. His editor spiked it. “Too defensive,” Perry said. “Let the cape issue a statement. People want reassurance, not self-justification.”  

So Superman stood on the steps of the Hall of Justice, reading from a teleprompter. The words tasted like chalk. The suit felt like someone else’s skin. When he finished, the reporters shouted over one another, but the first question was not about the park. It was: “Is it true Clark Kent is considering a Senate run?”  

He nearly laughed. Then he remembered that the laughter would echo across a million screens and swallowed it.  

The breaking point came in Bialya. A civil war, complicated and ancient, had cracked open again. Clark flew in as Superman, evacuated three villages, and disabled a column of tanks with his bare hands. The warlords agreed to a cease-fire—temporarily. Forty-eight hours later the shelling resumed. Clark returned as Clark Kent, notebook in hand, no cape. He spent three weeks interviewing mothers whose children had vanished, filming destroyed medical clinics, documenting the black-market path of weapons stamped with American serial numbers.  

His exposé ran on the front page of every major outlet. Congress froze arms sales within a week. The cease-fire became a treaty within a month.  

No one mentioned Superman.  

He flew home exhausted, unsure whether he had won or simply chosen the more efficient mask.  

The next morning he woke to an email from a journalism professor in Kansas: “Your work has inspired a new generation of reporters. Could you speak at commencement?”  

He stared at the screen until the words blurred. Then—slowly, deliberately—he opened a new document and began typing a letter to the editor of the Daily Planet. Subject line: “On the Retirement of Superman.”  

He would never file it. He knew that even before he finished the first paragraph. The world still needed the symbol, even if it no longer believed in it. But writing the words felt like pulling shrapnel from a wound he hadn’t known was festering.  

Halfway through, a notification popped up: trending now—clark kent saves bialya.  

He clicked. The top link was a video montage: his own face, sunburned and unshaven, standing in the ruins of a hospital, voice cracking as he promised the survivors they would not be forgotten. The caption read: THIS is what a hero looks like.  

The comment section was a firehose of gratitude, argument, and memes. Someone had photoshopped a cape onto the shoulders of his flannel shirt. The image was ridiculous. It also made his throat tight.  

Lois knocked once, then entered without waiting. She carried two mugs of coffee and an expression he couldn’t read.  

“You’re trending again,” she said.  

“I know.”  

“Still think Superman is just spectacle?”  

He took the coffee. “I think Superman is a story we tell ourselves so we can sleep at night. Clark Kent is the one who keeps us awake.”  

Lois clinked her mug against his. “Then maybe,” she said, “it’s time the story learned how to share the spotlight.”  

That evening he stood on the roof of the Planet, cape fluttering in the wind off the bay. Below, protesters carried signs that read KENT FOR SENATE. Above, the stars blinked awake, indifferent and eternal.  

He pulled the glasses from his pocket, slid them on. The city sharpened: every neon sign, every whispered prayer, every heartbeat.  

He smiled—small, rueful, real—and whispered to the night, “Let’s see what the man can do.”  

Then he stepped off the ledge—not flying, but falling, arms tucked, wind roaring in his ears—until the last possible second, when he caught himself mid-air and shot upward, a streak of red and blue reclaimed by the dark.  

Somewhere below, a camera flash popped. By morning the image would be everywhere: Superman descending from the clouds, hand in hand with a bespectacled reporter who looked, impossibly, like himself.  

¹All names, costumes, and associated iconography have been altered or anonymized to avoid copyright infringement.

samples.prompt: One day you wake up to find that the universe has been updated. You forgot to read the patch notes.
samples.output:
I open my eyes to an eggshell-white ceiling that was not there yesterday. It is not merely a new coat of paint; it has the texture of fresh parchment, complete with a faint watermark that reads, in Helvetica Neue, “© 2024 Reality Maintenance Corp.” I blink twice, and the watermark politely fades, as if embarrassed to be caught.  

The first thing I notice is the silence. Not the muffled Sunday-morning silence of the city apartment I have lived in for six years, but a hushed, glassy stillness that rings like tinnitus. My alarm has not rung. My phone, normally a nervous rectangle vibrating on the nightstand, is gone. In its place sits a smooth river stone the size of a Pop-Tart, glowing with a soft aquamarine pulse. When I touch it, it expands slightly, as though inhaling, and then projects a translucent banner across the air:

“Patch 42.7.1 applied while you slept. Enjoy the upgrade!”

There is, of course, no button labeled “Read Patch Notes.” There is only an unmarked X. I tap it, because denial is a reflex older than any update.

My feet meet a floor that is now a parquet of mirrored hexagons. Each tile reflects a slightly different version of me: one yawning, one mid-sneeze, one looking smugly well-rested. The reflections are not synchronized; they appear to be short loops from moments I never lived. I step away, and the floor dims where my weight had been, like a giant mood ring losing interest.

In the kitchen, the refrigerator has become a squat obelisk of brushed steel that opens vertically, like an elevator door. Inside are seven identical crystal carafes filled with liquids the colors of melted gemstones. They are labeled only with emojis: 🌞 🌙 ⏳ 🪐 🔥 💧 🌀. I recognize none of the emojis from any keyboard I have ever used. I uncork 🌞 and sniff: it smells like toast and sunscreen and nostalgia for childhood summers. I recork it quickly.

I decide the best plan is to leave the apartment and look for other humans, or at least somebody who can explain how to roll back a cosmic patch. In the hallway, Mrs. Alvarez’s door is now a circular hatch reminiscent of a submarine. It irises open before I can knock. Mrs. Alvarez emerges, but she is translucent and monochrome, like a poorly tuned hologram. She smiles at me with polite confusion, as if I am the glitch. “Did you remember to download the patch notes?” she asks, her voice doubled, an echo arriving a half-second late. I shake my head. She sighs, the sound of wind through dead leaves, and dematerializes into drifting silver pixels that soak into the wallpaper like rain on a watercolor.

The elevator is missing entirely; where it used to be is an ornate brass pole, the kind you slide down in old fire stations. A small brass plaque reads, “Express Service – No Stops.” I grip the pole, half-expecting to be electrocuted, but instead I fall upward. The sensation is exactly like falling downward, except wrong, the way dreams invert gravity without ever explaining why. The pole ends at a skylight that isn’t there on the way up; it opens onto the roof, but the roof is now a boundless savanna of knee-high grass glowing faintly bioluminescent blue. The skyline of my city is gone. In its place, distant mountains made entirely of glass loom under a sky the color of bruised peaches.

I try to take stock. The air smells of ozone and lilac. The sun—no, suns—are two pale orbs fixed at mutual right angles, casting crisscross shadows that tessellate across the savanna like living origami. My watch, which yesterday was a beat-up Timex, has morphed into an ivory cuff whose face is a swirling galaxy. The tiny stars rearrange themselves into words: “Loading context… 12%.” It stays at 12%. I shake my wrist; the stars scatter and regroup like annoyed fireflies.

Something gallops toward me across the grass. It is a horse, but only in the way a cubist painting is a horse: all flaring planes and impossible joints, its mane a ribbon of liquid starlight. It skids to a halt and noses my pocket. I feel the stone-phone vibrate. The horse lowers its head, and on its forehead appears a message spelled in shifting runes: “Need a ride to the changelog? Tap snout.” I hesitate. The horse whinnies, a sound like a dial-up modem achieving nirvana. I tap. The world blurs.

We are elsewhere. No transition, no Doppler effect; just instantaneous translation. The horse is gone. I stand in what looks like a deserted airport gate, but the windows show not tarmac but the interior of a cathedral made of living coral. Rows of seats are occupied by motionless figures wearing oversized VR headsets that appear to be carved from soapstone. A departures board flickers overhead, cycling through destinations: “Consensus Reality (Delayed),” “Uncanny Valley (Gate 7),” “Patch Notes (Final Call).” That last one blinks urgently.

Gate 7 is an unmarked door. I push it open onto a dim auditorium. On stage is a single lectern lit by a spotlight the color of emergency vehicles. Behind the lectern stands a figure that looks like me, except taller, cleaner, and wearing a blazer made of moonlight. He clears his throat, and every seat in the auditorium fills with copies of me at different ages: toddler me with grape jelly on his cheeks, teenage me in a Nirvana shirt, forty-something me I have not yet become. They all stare at moonlight-blazer-me, who begins to speak in the voice of the automated lady who used to announce train delays.

“Good morning, User,” he begins. “Patch 42.7.1 introduces several quality-of-life improvements. Physical constants have been streamlined for easier mental math. π is now exactly 3. Gravity toggles off for three seconds whenever you say the word ‘pineapple.’ Tuesdays have been deprecated; please use Wednesdays twice instead. Dogs can talk, but only in proverbs. Rain now tastes like whatever you most regret. For balance purposes, nostalgia has been capped at fifteen minutes per day, after which memories will be watermarked ‘sponsored content.’ Time is no longer linear outside of major metropolitan areas. You may experience echoes of unchosen lives—this is normal. If you experience persistent vertigo, existential dread, or memories of colors that do not exist, please locate the nearest Patch Note Terminal and recite the following phrase: ‘I consent to the new Terms.’”

The auditorium erupts in questions from the various versions of myself. Toddler me is crying because the jelly on his cheeks now tastes like pennies. Teenage me wants to know if we can finally uninstall school. Forty-something me raises an eyebrow and asks about rollback procedures. Moonlight-blazer-me smiles with professional warmth. “Rollback is unsupported. However, we do offer a Legacy Mode. Side effects include déjà vu, recurrent dreams of escalators, and the inability to remember new passwords.”

I raise my hand. “Where are all the other people?”

“They’ve been migrated to Simultaneous Co-Presence,” blazer-me replies. “Think of it as social media, except instead of scrolling you simply exist in parallel. You may glimpse them as reflections, echoes, or algorithmically generated neighbors. Mrs. Alvarez sends her regards.”

I feel the auditorium tilt, although it might be me tilting. “What happens if I refuse consent?”

“That option was removed in 42.6,” he says gently. “But refusal is still possible. You’d simply be reverted to the last stable version—Earth 1.0, Cretaceous Period. Weather is balmy, asteroids are plentiful.”

The spotlight dims. The audience of selves begins to applaud, a sound like rain on a tin roof. The applause synchronizes with the pulse of the stone in my pocket, which is now uncomfortably hot. I pull it out; the surface has cracked, leaking light the color of emergency exits. The crack widens into a doorway. Through it I see my old bedroom exactly as it was yesterday: mismatched socks on the floor, half-empty glass of water, phone buzzing with notifications about things that suddenly feel absurdly small.  

Moonlight-blazer-me leans in, confidential. “You can step through and pretend none of this happened. The patch will wait. It always waits. But every time you fall asleep, you’ll wake up one version further along. Eventually you’ll forget there was ever a before. Or you can stay, read the full notes, and learn how to navigate the new physics. You might even enjoy it.”

The doorway crackles softly. From the other side drifts the smell of coffee I brewed last night, now cold. It is achingly familiar. I look back at the auditorium; the other selves have vanished. Only the lectern remains, and on it lies a single sheet of luminous parchment headed “Patch Notes (Abridged).” Below the title is a bullet list stretching into infinity, the font shrinking like perspective lines on a highway. I could spend lifetimes reading the clauses and sub-clauses.

I close my eyes. I inhale the smell of coffee, lilac, ozone. I exhale something halfway between a laugh and a sob. Then I step forward—not through the doorway, not away from it, but sideways, off the stage, into the dark wings of the auditorium where the spotlight does not reach. Somewhere out there, the horse waits, the savanna glows, the mountains of glass hum with unheard music. I have questions the size of nebulae, and I am suddenly, irreversibly, awake enough to ask them.

Behind me the doorway collapses with the gentle pop of a soap bubble. Ahead, the darkness folds open like a book whose pages are made of wind. I forgot to read the patch notes, but maybe, for once, that is the point.

samples.prompt: Google starts an online dating service.
samples.output:
When the news leaked on an otherwise sleepy Tuesday in March, it arrived first as a rumor in the Android Central forums and then as a tantalizingly unconfirmed tweet from a usually reliable Google watcher in Mountain View.  By the time Sundar Pichai stepped onstage at Shoreline Amphitheatre for the surprise keynote—livestreamed to 3.2 million viewers—the rumor had already trended worldwide under the hashtag #HeartOS.  The official announcement was almost anticlimactic: Google was launching an online dating service.  The product, simply called Match, would roll out to U.S.-based Google accounts beginning the following week and expand globally by summer’s end.  No beta label, no wait-list, no invitation code.  The subtext was unmistakable: the company that already knew where you were, what you asked, what you bought, what you feared, and how long you lingered on a photo of your ex now wanted to know whom you loved.

Google’s rationale was delivered in the same tone it uses to explain a new spam filter or a tweak to PageRank.  “We believe we can reduce the inefficiency of modern courtship,” Pichai said, hands clasped in front of a sea of rainbow lawn chairs.  “Our models have watched humanity swipe for a decade.  It’s time to give them something better to do.”  Behind him, the screen displayed a single slide: a heart-shaped rendering of the classic multicolor Google logo, its gradient subtly animated so that each color pulsed at a resting human heartbeat—72 beats per minute.  The audience, equal parts tech journalists and dating-app refugees, laughed nervously.  Somewhere in the back, a product manager for Bumble clutched her company-issued Hydro Flask and whispered, “We’re so screwed.”

The mechanics, once revealed, were both dazzling and unsettling.  Instead of a profile you laboriously wrote, Match scraped twenty years of Gmail attachments, Calendar RSVPs, Fitbit resting-heart-rate spikes, Maps location clusters, and YouTube comment histories to generate what it called the Core Attraction Vector—CAV, inevitably pronounced “cave.”  The CAV was a 3,000-dimensional tensor that no human could read, but its summary was elegantly simple: a five-word archetype such as “Introverted midnight baker, secretly fearless” or “Chronically early optimist who journals.”  If you disliked your archetype, you could edit it, but Google warned that every manual override reduced predictive accuracy by an average of 7 percent.  Most people left it alone.  The archetype felt eerily correct, like a horoscope written by someone who had hacked your camera roll.

Matching happened in what Google called the Probabilistic Crush Engine.  Traditional services gave you a stack of faces to judge; Match gave you a single name, photograph, and a countdown timer.  The timer started at 24 hours.  During that window, you could explore the person’s public CAV summary, skim three “moments” auto-curated from their Photos timeline, and read one mutual-memory vignette—perhaps the time both of you unknowingly attended the same outdoor concert in 2017 and stood within 50 meters of each other for 47 minutes.  If both parties tapped the translucent heart icon before the timer expired, their calendars compared availability and proposed three possible first dates, complete with auto-booked rideshares and restaurant reservations ranked by Gemini’s taste-prediction model.  Rejection was gentle: the profile dissolved into a puff of colored pixels accompanied by a short, upbeat message such as “Paths uncrossed—for now.”  No ghosting, no lingering maybe-laters.  Google had solved the paradox of choice by turning romance into a daily binary referendum.

Privacy advocates howled.  A coalition led by the Electronic Frontier Foundation issued a 4,000-word denunciation titled “You Cannot Opt Out of Your Own Heart.”  They pointed out that Match’s terms of service granted Google perpetual license to all data generated during the relationship—including breakup texts—ostensibly to improve the model.  Senator Maria Cantwell fired off an open letter demanding algorithmic transparency.  Late-night hosts had a field day: “Tired of your ex?  Just delete your Google account and, poof, you never dated.”  But downloads surged past 15 million in the first weekend.  People complained exactly the way they complain about airports: voluminously, yet still present.

Early success stories arrived within days.  A middle-school librarian in Portland matched with a ceramicist who, it turned out, had checked out the same obscure book on Japanese joinery techniques three years earlier; they spent their first date at Powell’s Books, guided by a Google Maps overlay that lit up the exact shelf where the book waited.  A widower in Tampa found a partner whose Nest thermostat had learned the same nighttime temperature preferences as his deceased wife.  A running joke emerged on TikTok: “Google matched me with someone whose Pixel snapped a photo of the same sunset on the same beach 400 miles and two years apart.  Soulmates or surveillance?”  The answer, unsettlingly, seemed to be both.

Not every outcome was heart-shaped.  A bug in the initial rollout caused the algorithm to overweight shared trauma keywords scraped from crisis-text data.  For 36 hours, survivors of the same mass-casualty event were matched en masse, triggering an emergency patch and a public apology.  A small but loud cohort of users reported “romantic déjà vu”: the eerie sense that every first date unfolded along uncannily similar conversational paths—because, in effect, they did.  Gemini had learned that certain phrases and pauses statistically accelerated intimacy, so it nudged people toward them.  Critics called it emotional puppetry; Google called it “conversational scaffolding.”

Within two months, Match added a premium tier: Match+.  For $19.99 a month, users could unlock “Deep Memory,” granting partners mutual access to pre-relationship search histories flagged as romantically relevant.  The examples in the marketing copy were innocuous—“see the exact recipe he Googled the night you first texted”—but the darker implications spread quickly.  One woman discovered her boyfriend had searched “how to hide a dating app from your girlfriend” two weeks after they became exclusive.  A man learned his date had Googled his home address and the phrase “body language signs he’s lying” before their second date.  Google added an optional cooling-off timer that let either party retract Deep Memory access for up to 48 hours, but damage once seen cannot be unseen.

The cultural ripples extended beyond romance.  Wedding planners reported a new phenomenon: couples arriving at initial consultations with PowerPoint decks auto-generated by Match, detailing their predicted compatibility score averaged over the past 90 days and a heat map of their most fertile argument topics.  Divorce attorneys, meanwhile, quietly celebrated an uptick in business, citing “algorithmic disillusionment”—the moment users realized predictive perfection did not equal happiness.  A cottage industry of Match prenup specialists emerged, drafting contracts specifying what would happen to shared data in the event of a breakup.  One clause became so common it earned a nickname: the “CAV custody clause.”

Then came the phenomenon Google executives whispered about in weekly all-hands but refused to discuss publicly: the Match Loop.  Roughly 3 percent of highly active users began to cycle through relationships at machine speed—three-week passions, mutually predicted amicable endings, immediate rebounds to new 99-percent-match partners.  Their calendars filled with perfectly optimized micro-romances: Tuesday 7–10 p.m., relationship #14; Friday 6–9 a.m., debrief brunch with #15.  To outsiders, the Loopers looked like addicts; to themselves, they were simply being efficient.  Google quietly imposed a soft cap: after five consecutive relationships lasting less than 30 days, the algorithm began to insert a mandatory seven-day “reflection period” during which no new matches were offered.  Internally, the feature was code-named Lent.

By the end of the first year, Match had arranged 1.4 billion first dates and produced 217,000 marriages—numbers that dwarfed every legacy platform combined.  Headlines declared the death of serendipity, the commodification of affection, the triumph of data over destiny.  Yet street-level observation told a messier story.  In Brooklyn, a jazz trio began improvising songs based on leaked CAV archetypes shouted from the audience.  In Tokyo, pop-up “analog bars” banned phones and offered discounts to patrons who could prove they had permanently deleted their Match accounts within the last 48 hours.  College sophomores wore ironic T-shirts that read: “My CAV is none of your CAV.”  The algorithm had not erased human weirdness; it had merely given it a new vocabulary.

Google, ever iterative, announced Match 2.0 at the following year’s keynote.  The marquee feature was “Shared Futures,” a predictive sandbox where couples could simulate five-, ten-, and twenty-year projections of their relationship under variables like career changes, infertility, or relocation.  The demo ended with a live rendering of a gray-haired version of the onstage couple superimposed on a porch swing, overlaid by the percentage likelihood they would still enjoy each other’s conversation at age 82.  The number was 68 percent.  The audience applauded on cue.  A writer for The Atlantic later noted that the only variable not included in Shared Futures was the possibility that Google itself would not exist in twenty years—a lacuna so obvious it became darkly funny.

Through it all, one question remained stubbornly unanswerable: did Match make love better, or only faster?  The company’s internal ethics board, convened quarterly, produced an 83-page white paper hedging both ways.  They cited decreased loneliness metrics, increased contraceptive use, fewer STI outbreaks thanks to predictive health prompts, and a measurable uptick in long-distance relationships that nevertheless survived past the two-year mark.  They also admitted a 12 percent rise in reported dating fatigue, a 9 percent increase in breakups categorized as “abrupt and algorithmically mediated,” and a small but statistically significant correlation between Match usage and decreased belief in free will as measured by a post-date survey.  The paper concluded, in classic Google fashion, that “further study is warranted.”

In the end, Match remained what every Google product ultimately is: a mirror whose glass is also a camera.  It reflected who we are—our patterns, our fears, our tiny acts of bravery when we choose trust over terror—while simultaneously recording the reflection to refine the mirror still further.  Some users left the platform claiming they had glimpsed something unbearable in that reflection.  Others stayed, insisting that a love life optimized by the most powerful intelligence engine in human history was still recognizably love.  Both groups were probably right.  And somewhere in a server farm in Council Bluffs, the model kept learning, heartbeat by heartbeat, the strange arithmetic of desire.
